questions.text: The number of polio cases has been steadily declining in comparison to previous years. This pattern is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option D - Secular

Explanation:

  • The secular trend implies changes in the occurrence of a disease, i.e., progressive increase or decrease in incidence over a long period of time, such as years or decades.
  • Although it may have short-term fluctuations imposed on it, secular trends imply a constant tendency to change in a particular direction of a definite movement in one direction.
  • Examples include diabetes mellitus, coronary heart disease, and lung cancer (an increase in the number of non-communicable diseases when compared to previous years).

Cyclical trends (Option B ruled out)

Seasonal trends (Option A ruled out)

They occur in cycles spread over short periods of time.

Cycles are associated with seasons.

Examples:

  • Measles: every 2-3 years.
  • Rubella: every 6-9 years.
  • Influenza: every 7-10 years.

Examples:

  • Measles.
  • Varicella.
  • Cerebro-spinal meningitis.
  • Upper respiratory tract infections.
  • Malaria.
  • Sunstroke.
  • Hay fever.
  • Snakebite.

Note: Road traffic accidents can be cyclical (more during weekends) and seasonal (more common in winter).

Periodical (Option C): Relates to events or phenomena that occur at fixed intervals or specific time points. These trends may be related to public health campaigns, health screenings, or other planned interventions. Examples include regular immunization campaigns, biennial health surveys, or annual health awareness months (e.g., Breast Cancer Awareness Month).

questions.text: Cytotoxic drug is disposed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A - Yellow bag

Explanation:

  • Cytotoxic drugs, also known as antineoplastic or chemotherapy drugs, are disposed of in a specialized yellow bag. These drugs are considered hazardous substances due to their toxic properties. The yellow bag is designed specifically for collecting and disposing hazardous or cytotoxic waste, including unused or expired drugs, empty drug vials, IV tubing, and other items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs.

Color

Type of waste

Example of waste

Treatment and disposal

Yellow (Option A)
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste.
  • Soiled waste.
  • Discarded or expired medicine.
  • Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Chemical waste.
  • Chemical liquid waste.

 
  • Placenta.
  • Post-operative body parts.
  • Plaster of Paris (POP).
  • Pathological waste.
  • Cotton waste.
  • Dressing materials.
  • Beddings.
  • Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth.
  • Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover.
  • Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines.
  • Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste.
  • Blood bag
  • Vacutainers with blood
  • Incineration.
  • Plasma pyrolysis.
  • Deep burial.

 

Red (Option B ruled out)
  • Contaminated waste that is recyclable.
  • Syringe without needles.
  • Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut.
  • IV set.
  • Catheters.
  • Gloves (soiled or unsoiled).
  • Urine bag.
  • Dialysis kit.
  • IV bottles.
  • Tubing's.
  • Bottles.
  • Vacutainers with needle cuts.
  • Vacutainers without blood.
  • ELISA plates and vials not containing blood samples.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making.
  • Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites.

White

Waste Sharps
  • Needles
  • Syringes with fixed needles
  • Blades
  • Scalpers
  • Trocar cannula
  • Insulin pen needle
  • Puncture proof , Leak proof, Tamper proof containers
  • Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding or mutilation or encapsulation in metal container or cement concrete
  • Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries or sanitary landfills or designated concrete waste sharp pit

 

Blue (Option C ruled out)

Glassware or metallic body implants.
  • Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated.
  • Glass:
    • Broken glass.
    • Ampoules.
    • Lab slide
  • Metals:
    • Nails.
    • Metallic body implants.
    • Scissors.
    • Artificial pacemakers.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue colored markings or blue coloured puncture-proof and tamper-proof containers.
  • Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving or microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling.

 

Black bag (Option D): Black bags are commonly used for general waste or municipal solid waste that does not require specialized handling or disposal. Similar to blue bags, black bags are not appropriate for the disposal of cytotoxic drugs due to their hazardous nature.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the value that appears most frequently in a set of data?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option B - Mode:

Explanation:

  • The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset. It represents the value that occurs with the highest frequency. In the dataset [1, 2, 3, 3, 4, 5], the mode is 3 because it appears twice, which is more frequently than any other value.

Incorrect Options:

Median (Option A): It is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.

This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by

The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

Standard deviation (Option C): Measures the variation or dispersion of a set of values around the mean. The formula for calculation is σ = √(∑(x− x̄)2 /n).

Mean (Option D): It is calculated by summing all the variables and dividing the same by the total number of variables.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a pillar of primary health care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A - Health education

Explanation:

Four Pillars of Primary Health Care:

Equitable distribution (Option D ruled out):
  • Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status.

Intersectoral coordination (Option B ruled out):
  • Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc.
  • Maintains good health.

Appropriate technology (Option c ruled out):
  • Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community
  • Eg:
    • ORS
    • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label
    • Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading
    • Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care

Community participation:
  • Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining.
  • For the promotion and maintenance of their health.
  • Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community.

questions.text: What is the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are aimed in the medical field?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option C: Goal

Explanation:

Goal in health planning represents the ultimate desired state that directs all objectives and resources.

  • Not constrained by time and resources
  • Timeframe guideline - should not extend beyond a five-year period.

Incorrect Options:

Target (Option A): It measures the degree of achievement of objectives.

  • E.g. To complete the objective, i.e., increase immunization coverage by 60%., one needs to target conducting 1 health education session per week.

Mission (Option B): It refers to the overall purpose or reason for the existence of an organization or entity.

Plan (Option D): It refers to a detailed course of action outlining how specific objectives will be achieved.

questions.text: A 25 year old female is using vaginal sponge as a barrier contraceptive during sexual intercourse. Which of the following Spermicide is used in contraceptive 'TODAY'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option C) Nonoxynol-9

Explanation:

Nonoxynol-9 is a commonly used spermicide that is used as the active ingredient in many barrier contraceptives, including vaginal sponges, foams, gels, and creams. It works by immobilizing and killing sperm, thus reducing the risk of pregnancy. Nonoxynol-9 is the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'.

 

Brand name

TODAY

Material

Small polyurethane foam sponge

Mechanism of action

Combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception Saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol-9’ (Option C)

Technique of use
  • Must be run under water till thoroughly wet before insertion
  • Inserted vaginally and must be ‘placed over the cervix to be effective
  • Must be left in place for 6 hours after ejaculation
  • All sponges must be removed within the time limits specified by the manufacturer (24 hours for Today)

Disadvantages
  • No protection from HIV or STDs
  • May lead to Toxic Shock Syndrome if left beyond 24 hours
  • Has to be left for 6 hours post ejaculation
  • Increased risk of yeast infection and UTI
  • Higher failure rate than diaphragm

Failure rate
  • Parous women: 20-40 per HWY
  • Nulliparous women: 9-20 per HWY

Incorrect Options:

NET-EN (Option A): NET-EN stands for norethisterone enanthate, which is a progestin hormone used in some hormonal contraceptives, such as injectable contraceptives. It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY.

DMPA (Option B): DMPA stands for depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, which is another progestin hormone used in injectable contraceptives, commonly known as the birth control shot. It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'.

Norethisterone (Option D): Norethisterone is a progestin hormone used in some hormonal contraceptives, such as combined oral contraceptives (COCs) or progestin-only pills (mini-pills). It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'.

questions.text: The true statement about cow's milk (per 100 gm) when compared to breast milk is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option D: High protein

Explanation:

  • Cow's milk does have a higher protein content compared to breast milk. The protein content in cow's milk is generally around 3.2 grams per 100 grams, whereas breast milk contains around 1.1 gram of protein per 100 grams.

questions.text: What is the most frequent side effect experienced by a 24-year-old woman of reproductive age who visited a rural primary healthcare center in India for the purpose of having an IUCD inserted to prevent pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D: Bleeding

Explanation:

  • The most common side effect of IUCD insertion is increased or irregular menstrual bleeding. Women may experience heavier or longer periods, spotting between periods, or irregular bleeding patterns in the initial months after IUCD insertion. This is a common and expected side effect that usually resolves over time.

Side effects of IUDs

Bleeding (Option D)
  • Most common side effect; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months. Iron supplementation may be needed.
  • Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal.

Pain (Option C ruled out)

Frequently causes removal; managed with analgesics. Resolves in 3 months. Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare).

Pelvic inflammatory disease (OptionB ruled out)

Certain organisms reach the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries via the IUD thread. Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge. Higher risk in women with multiple sexual partners. Requires broad-spectrum antibiotics; IUD removal if no improvement.

Uterine perforation

Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique. 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of pregnancy.

Failure of contraception ➜ pregnancy
  • Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA.
  • If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible:
    • Pull the thread and continue pregnancy.
    • Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible:
    • Uterus examination for any complications
    • Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified.

Ectopic pregnancy (OPTION A ruled out)

Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea. Women at high risk should avoid IUDs.

Expulsion

Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation; higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs

Migration of IUD

Rarely causes intestinal obstruction; diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected.

questions.text: A couple approaches the doctor with a query regarding sexual precautions following the male partner's vasectomy procedure conducted a month ago. What guidance should be provided in this situation?

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills for 1 month for the woman
Hormonal treatment given for 2 more months for the man

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option B: Use condoms for 3 months

Explanation:

  • After a vasectomy, it is important to provide appropriate advice to the couple regarding contraception. Using condoms for 3 months helps to ensure that any remaining sperm are cleared and reduces the risk of unintended pregnancy during this period.
  • After 3 months, the couple may choose to rely solely on the vasectomy as a contraceptive method. However, it is important to note that a follow-up semen analysis should be performed to confirm the success of the procedure and the absence of sperm in the ejaculate.

Vasectomy is a terminal method of contraception done in males. It is a single time method, which does not require prolonged motivation for its effectiveness.

Guidelines for Vasectomy:

  • The age of the husband should be 25-50 yrs.
  • The couple should have 2 living children.
  • If the couple has 3 or more children, then the lower limit of age can be relaxed.

Procedure:

Postoperative advice:

  • Must use alternate methods of contraception for 30 ejaculations (roughly 3 months) after the procedure to ensure sterility (option B).
  • Should keep the surgical area clean
  • Should not lift weights

questions.text: What is the method employed to gather agreement on predictions among a substantial group of individuals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D) Delphi method

Explanation:

Delphi method is a structured communication method that depends on a panel of experts.

  • It involves gathering opinions from the panel of experts on a specific issue, summarizing their collective feedback, and repeating this process for several rounds.
  • After each round, the experts share their feedback and the reasoning behind their judgements anonymously. This feedback encourages experts to reconsider and potentially revise their earlier opinions based on the responses of other panel members.
  • Through this process, the range of responses tends to narrow, and the group will reach a consensus.

The Delphi method does not involve participants discussing the issues or natural observation or statistical analysis.

Incorrect Options

Television (Option A): It is a medium for broadcasting information and entertainment to a wide audience (mass communication). It is not a structured method for gathering agreement or predictions from a group. Instead, it is typically one-way communication with no direct feedback mechanism to facilitate consensus.

GATHER approach (Option B): It is employed in family planning counseling to offer supportive communication to clients when choosing contraceptive methods.

Conferences (Option C): They are gatherings where individuals present ideas, research, and discussions. While they allow for the exchange of information and networking, they are not specifically designed to achieve structured consensus or gather collective predictions systematically.

questions.text: What could be the diagnosis for a child who exhibits below-average mathematical skills despite having a normal IQ and age-appropriate learning abilities and remains unaffected by a year-long private mathematics tutoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Specific learning disorder

Explanation:

  • The child described is likely experiencing a Specific Learning Disorder (SLD), specifically with impairment in mathematics. This is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterised by persistent difficulties in learning and using academic skills despite normal intelligence, adequate educational opportunities, and appropriate interventions such as private tutoring.

Features of SLD in Mathematics (Dyscalculia):

  • Mathematical Difficulties: Problems with basic arithmetic operations, understanding numbers, or applying mathematical concepts.
  • Persistence: The issues persist despite normal IQ and adequate learning in other areas.
  • Impact on Daily Life: The difficulties impair academic achievement and daily functioning.

 

Incorrect Options:

ADHD (Option A) involves inattention, hyperactivity, or impulsivity affecting multiple domains, including academics. Poor math performance in ADHD stems from difficulty focusing, not from specific deficits in mathematical skills.

Mathematics Learning Disorder (Option B): While this term describes the condition, it is not a standalone diagnosis in the DSM-5. Dyscalculia is a subtype of Specific Learning Disorder, making "Specific Learning Disorder" the correct and broader diagnostic term.

Asperger’s Syndrome (Option C) (now classified under Autism Spectrum Disorder in DSM-5) involves difficulties with social communication and restricted interests, not specific academic skills like mathematics. Children with Asperger’s often excel academically, including in mathematics.

questions.text: Which of the following is defined as the systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals at predetermined or random intervals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D- Work sampling

Explanation:

  • Work sampling refers to the systematic observation and recording of activities performed by one or more individuals at predetermined or random intervals. It is a technique used in industrial engineering and management to gather data about how work is being conducted, how time is allocated, and how resources are utilized.

Work Sampling does not involve calculating project costs or evaluating monetary benefits.

  • It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks, aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement.

  • It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities.

  • It is a type of quantitative health management technique.

Model (Option A): It refers to a conceptual or mathematical representation used to simulate, predict, or explain real-world phenomena. This option is incorrect.

Decision making (Option B): It is a cognitive process involving the selection of a course of action from available alternatives. This option is incorrect.

Personnel management (Option C): It involves the administration of human resources within an organization, including recruitment, training, performance evaluation, and employee relations. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old male who underwent appendectomy 7 hours ago and is currently experiencing auditory hallucinations and confusion about the source of the voices? The patient maintains orientation, and his vital signs are stable. Upon inquiry, his wife reveals that he occasionally consumes alcohol.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Alcoholic hallucinosis.

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Alcoholic Hallucinosis, given the patient’s history of alcohol consumption, auditory hallucinations, preserved orientation, stable vital signs, and recent surgical stress.
  • Alcoholic hallucinosis is a complication of chronic alcohol use, characterised by the presence of hallucinations (usually auditory) during or shortly after heavy alcohol use or withdrawal.

Incorrect Options:

Delirium tremens (Option A). A more severe withdrawal syndrome known as delirium tremens can affect alcohol users. Tremors, agitation, confusion, and hallucinations are some of its symptoms. Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that must be treated right away. Minor liquor withdrawal is described by the quake, nervousness, queasiness, spewing, and sleep deprivation. Significant liquor withdrawal signs and side effects incorporate visual mind flights and hearable pipedreams, entire body quake, heaving, diaphoresis, and hypertension (hypertension).

A/c transient psychotic disorder (Option B). Psychological stress can lead to the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms in Acute and Transient Psychotic Disorder (ATPD). In this, episodes are present moments, enduring from days to 90 days, trailed by complete abatement. Delusions, hallucinations, and mood swings are their hallmarks. Most of the time, transient psychotic disorder goes away on its own after a few weeks or a month.

Delirium (Option C). Delirium is a mental state in which you can't think clearly or remember anything, are lost, and are confused. There are many things that can cause delirium, such as an infection, taking medication, or going through a medical procedure. It usually appears out of nowhere. It is frequently brief and treatable.

questions.text: Which one of the following options does not meet the minimum standards for maintaining sanitation in schools and their surroundings in India?

choices.text: Combined doors + windows area = 25% of floor space area
One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 students

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D: One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 students

Explanation:

  • The correct standards are 1 urinal for 60 students and 1 latrine for 100 students.

Healthful School Environment

Aspect

Details

Location

Centrally situated with proper approach roads, away from busy places like roads, factories, and marketplaces. School premises should be fenced and hazard-free.

Site

High, well-drained land. 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for primary schools, with additional 1 acre per 100 students.

Structure

Single-story buildings preferred. Exterior walls should be 10 inches thick and heat-resistant

Doors and windows
  • Combined door + window area = atleast 25% of floor area.
  • Cross ventilation should be present. (Option B ruled out)

Classroom

No more than 40 students per room. Minimum 10 sq. ft. per student. (Option C ruled out)

Color of Interior

White interior walls, periodically white-washed.

Furniture
  • Desks should be of ‘minus type’.
  • Chair with proper back rest. (Option A ruled out)

Lighting

Natural light from the left side, not from the front.

Water Supply

Independent source of safe, potable water, continuous supply distributed from taps.

Lavatory

One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students. Separate facilities for boys and girls. (Option D)

questions.text: A concerned grandmother brings an 18-year-old boy to you, reporting that he had multiple episodes of body jerking the day before his final exam. There were no signs of confusion or tongue biting after the episodes, and his medical tests came back normal. Which of the following conditions should be taken into consideration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Malingering

Explanation:

  • The boy's symptoms, which only occurred the day before his final exam, suggest malingering. He is likely faking his symptoms to avoid taking the exam.
  • Malingering is the falsification or profound exaggeration of illness (physical or mental) to gain external benefits such as avoiding work or responsibility, seeking drugs, avoiding trial (law), seeking attention, avoiding military services, taking leave from school, and taking paid leave from a job, among others.
  • It is not a psychiatric illness. Malingering is associated with an antisocial personality disorder and histrionic personality trait.

Incorrect Options:

Factitious disorder (Option B): In this condition, a person deliberately causes or feigns symptoms to assume the sick role. Dissimilar to malingering, individuals with factitious turmoil have no outer inspiration for their way of behaving. They might do it for the consideration, the compassion, or the sensation of being really focused.

Somatization syndrome (Option C): Individuals with somatization syndrome experience various physical symptoms unrelated to any medical condition. In somatic symptom disorder (SSD), exaggerated anxiety about these symptoms leads to intense thoughts, feelings, and behaviours, often impairing daily activities.

Hypochondriasis (Option D): Illness anxiety disorder, also known as hypochondriasis or health anxiety, involves excessive worry about illness, often without physical symptoms. Individuals may interpret normal sensations or minor symptoms as signs of a severe illness, even when thorough medical evaluations reveal no serious condition. This anxiety, rather than the symptoms themselves, causes significant distress and disrupts daily life.

questions.text: Which of the options below aids in determining the severity of a disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option C: Case fatality rate

Explanation:

  • The Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is closely related to virulence, representing the killing power of a disease. It is calculated as the ratio of deaths to cases, without specifying a time interval, using the formula:
  • CFR is typically used for acute infectious diseases (e.g., food poisoning, cholera, measles) but is less useful for chronic diseases due to the long and variable period from onset to death.
  • The CFR for the same disease can vary across different epidemics due to agent, host, and environmental changes.

Proportional mortality rate (Option A): Measures deaths from a specific cause relative to all deaths, not directly predicting disease severity. This option is incorrect.

Incidence (Option B): Tracks new cases over time, not directly related to disease severity. This option is incorrect.

Prevalence (Option D): Total cases at a specific time, not indicating disease severity. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 40-year-old man who has been experiencing excessive and uncontrollable worry about daily life activities, finances, and his health for the past two years? He also presents with restlessness, fatigue, disturbed sleep, and waking up once due to a fear that his family was involved in an accident.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Generalized anxiety disorder

Explanation:

  • Generalized Anxiety Disorder is characterized by excessive, persistent, and uncontrollable worry about various aspects of daily life, such as health, finances, and personal relationships, lasting for six months or longer. The individual finds it difficult to control this worry, which significantly interferes with daily functioning.
  • In this case, the patient has experienced symptoms for two years, including restlessness, fatigue, disturbed sleep, and intrusive thoughts (such as fear of family accidents). These symptoms align with GAD, which often coexists with other mood or anxiety disorders.
  • Treatment for GAD includes:
    • Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is particularly effective.
    • Medication: Antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs) and anxiolytics may be used to manage symptoms.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment can significantly improve the patient’s quality of life.

 

Incorrect Options:

Depression (Option A) is a mental illness that makes people feel worthless, hopeless, and sad all the time. Additionally, it may alter sleep patterns, appetite, energy levels, and concentration. The man in the situation refers to no side effects of gloom, like pity, sadness, or uselessness.

Illness anxiety disorder (Option B) is a sort of uneasiness problem where individuals have a steady feeling of dread toward fostering a difficult sickness. Even when there is no sign of illness, they may still be concerned about their health. The man in the scenario doesn't talk about any of the symptoms of anxiety disorder, like the constant fear of getting a serious illness.

Somatoform disorder (Option C) is a mental condition in which people suffer from physical symptoms brought on by psychological factors like stress or anxiety. These side effects can be genuine and incapacitating, yet an actual disease does not bring them about. The man in the scenario doesn't mention any signs of somatoform disorder, like physical signs that are caused by mental factors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true according to the sustainable development goals?

choices.text: End the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and combat hepatitis
Reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 (per 100,000 liver births)
Reduce the neonatal mortality rate to as low as 25 (per 1,000 liver births)
Reduce under-5 mortality to as low as 25 (peer 1,000 liver births)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C - Reduce the neonatal mortality rate to as low as 25 (per 1,000 liver births)

Explanation:

  • Goal 3 and target 3.2 of the sustainable development is: By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births.
  • The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted by the United Nations and UNDP in 2015, aim to eradicate poverty, ensure prosperity, and protect the planet by 2030.

There are 17 goals:

1.

End poverty everywhere in all its forms.

2.

Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

3.

Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

4.

Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities.

5.

Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls.

6.

Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

7.

Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

8.

Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

9.

Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

10.

Reduce inequality within and among countries.

11.

Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

12.

Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns.

13.

Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts.

14.

Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources.

15.

Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity.

16.

Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions.

17.

Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

 

Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages:

Target 3.1: Reduce maternal mortality

By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births (Option B ruled out)

Target 3.2: End all preventable deaths under five years of age

By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births (Option C) and under‑5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births (Option D ruled out)

Target 3.3: Fight communicable diseases

By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases (Option A ruled out)

Target 3.4: Reduce mortality from non-communicable diseases and promote mental health

By 2030, reduce by one-third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being

Target 3.5: Prevent and treat substance abuse

Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol

Target 3.6: Reduce road injuries and deaths

By 2020, halve (50% less) the number of global deaths and injuries from road traffic accidents

Target 3.7: Universal access to sexual and reproductive care, family planning and education

By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programs

Target 3.8: Achieve universal health coverage

Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all

Target 3.9: Reduce illnesses and deaths from hazardous chemicals and pollution

By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the given image is not true?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It has a life-span of 5 years
It is used in emergency contraception

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C) It has a life-span of 5 years

Explanation:

  • The image depicts CuT 380. Copper T is designed to provide contraception for an extended period. Depending on the specific type of Copper T used, it typically has a lifespan of 10 years for CuT380A.

2nd generation IUDs

Type

Copper containing device

Mechanism of action
  • Reduces sperm motility and survival
    • alters cervical mucus
    • affects uterine enzymes
    • increases cellular response in endometrium

Features
  • Strong anti-fertility effect
  • Low expulsion rate
  • Easy to fit in nulliparous women
  • Lesser side effects
  • Effective post-coital contraceptive (Option D ruled out)

Side effects
  • Bleeding
  • Pain
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine perforation
  • Failure of contraception ➜ Pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Expulsion
  • Migration of IUD

Insertion technique

Withdrawl technique (Option A ruled out)

CuT 380A
  • 380 mm² of copper wire around a stem with nylon thread attached (Option B ruled out)
  • Shelf life -10 years (Option C)

Nova-T
  • CuT 380 A with a silver (Ag) core attached to it
  • Shelf life - 5 years

Multiload
  • U-shaped ring
  • Most commonly used IUD
  • CuT 375

questions.text: Jet black pigmentation of the tongue with tactile hallucinations is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cocaine

Explanation:

  • Cocaine is most commonly associated with black pigmentation of the tongue and tactile hallucinations.
  • The black pigmentation of the tongue is known as "black tongue," and it occurs due to a condition called black hairy tongue.
  • It is characterised by elongation of the filiform papillae on the tongue, which can appear black or dark brown.
  • Tactile hallucinations, also known as formication, are a common symptom of cocaine use and can involve sensations of insects crawling on or under the skin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Heroin (Option A) is an opioid drug derived from morphine. Black pigmentation of the tongue is not typically associated with heroin use. Heroin use may cause other physical symptoms, such as constricted pupils, drowsiness, and respiratory depression.

Opium (Option B) is another opioid drug derived from the poppy plant. Opium use can lead to symptoms such as sedation, euphoria, and constipation but is not associated with black pigmentation of the tongue.

Alcohol (Option C) consumption does not typically cause black pigmentation of the tongue. Excessive alcohol intake can have various effects on the body, including impaired judgment, motor coordination, and liver damage.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitters are implicated in depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serotonin and norepinephrine

Explanation:

Depression is primarily associated with dysregulation in the monoamine neurotransmitter systems, particularly:

  • Serotonin (5-HT):
    • Plays a critical role in mood regulation, sleep, appetite, and emotional well-being.
    • Deficiency is linked to feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and increased sensitivity to stress.
  • Norepinephrine (NE):
    • Influences attention, arousal, and energy levels.
    • Reduced norepinephrine activity contributes to fatigue, lack of motivation, and cognitive dysfunction.

 

Incorrect Options:

GABA and dopamine (Option A): GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that helps regulate neuronal excitability in the brain. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter involved in reward, motivation, and pleasure. While imbalances in GABA and dopamine levels have been implicated in certain mental health conditions, such as anxiety disorders and schizophrenia, they are not considered the primary neurotransmitters involved in depression. However, dopamine dysregulation may play a role in specific subtypes of depression, such as atypical depression.

Dopamine and serotonin (Option C). While both dopamine and serotonin are involved in mood regulation, dopamine is not considered one of the primary neurotransmitters involved in depression. Dopamine dysregulation is more closely associated with conditions like schizophrenia, substance abuse disorders, and certain mood disorders.

GABA and norepinephrine (Option D). Similar to the first option, GABA and norepinephrine are not considered the primary neurotransmitters involved in depression. While norepinephrine plays a role in mood regulation and stress response, GABA dysregulation is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and epilepsy rather than depression.

questions.text: The likely diagnosis for a girl who exhibits typical language milestones but primarily focuses on observing her own hands and lacks interaction with others is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Autism

Explanation:

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental condition characterised by:

  • Core Features:
    • Impaired social communication: Difficulty in forming or understanding relationships, reduced social-emotional reciprocity, and challenges in non-verbal communication.
    • Restricted and repetitive behaviours: These include hand movements, insistence on sameness, fixated interests, or unusual sensory responses.
  • Language Development:
    • While some children with ASD exhibit language delays, others, particularly those previously categorised under Asperger's syndrome (now under ASD in DSM-5), meet typical language milestones but struggle with the social use of language.
  • Behaviour Described in Question:
    • The focus on observing her own hands is a classic example of repetitive and self-stimulatory behaviour.
    • The lack of social interaction fits the hallmark features of difficulty in social reciprocity and relationships seen in ASD.

 

Incorrect Options:

ADHD (Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder) (Option A) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterised by difficulties with attention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity. Individuals with ADHD may display problems in social interactions and exhibit certain repetitive behaviours.

Asperger’s syndrome (Option C) Previously considered a separate diagnosis, it is now included under ASD in the DSM-5. Typically involves normal to advanced language development but significant social interaction difficulties. Lack of repetitive hand-focused behaviour makes this less likely than Autism.

Rett's Syndrome (Option D) is a rare genetic disorder that predominantly affects females. It is characterised by severe cognitive and physical impairments, loss of purposeful hand skills, and the development of repetitive hand movements.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 37-year-old male who is a chronic alcoholic and has recently stopped drinking alcohol but presents to the emergency department after three days with symptoms of disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Delirium tremens

Explanation:

  • Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that occurs typically 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is a medical emergency characterised by severe autonomic hyperactivity and delirium.

Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

(Option A ruled out)

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life-threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

 

Korsakoff’s psychosis (Option B) or Korsakoff’s syndrome, is a chronic neuropsychiatric disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often linked to chronic alcoholism. It typically follows Wernicke’s encephalopathy and is marked by severe memory problems, including amnesia, confabulation, lack of insight, and apathy. Unlike acute conditions, it is characterized by chronic memory deficits rather than symptoms like tremors, hallucinations, disorientation, or hypertension.

Marchiafava-Bignami disease (Option D) is a rare condition in chronic alcoholics, characterized by demyelination of the corpus callosum and surrounding white matter, leading to severe neurological deficits. Symptoms include seizures, dysarthria, spasticity, and progressive cognitive impairment. Acute symptoms like disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension are not typical, as the disease primarily presents with chronic, progressive neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the immortality of cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Telomerase

Explanation:

  • Telomerase maintains telomere length, preventing chromosome degradation.
  • Telomere shortening occurs with each cell division, contributing to cellular ageing and death.
  • However, telomerase extends telomeres, enabling indefinite division. In cancer cells, its overexpression promotes uncontrolled proliferation and immortality.

 

Incorrect Options:

Topoisomerase (Option B) is responsible for manipulating the structure of DNA by inducing and resolving DNA strand breaks.

Helicase (Option C) unwinds the DNA double helix, allowing other enzymes to access and replicate the DNA.

RNA polymerase (Option D) synthesises RNA from a DNA template during transcription, essential for gene expression and protein synthesis. While its dysregulation can occur in cancer, it is not directly linked to cancer cell immortality.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the emergency department after sustaining a fall. X-ray showed a fractured neck of the femur and was operated on for the same. On postoperative day 2, he experienced a sharp, severe, constant burning pain over his right back. On examination, the lesion is as seen below. The area is tender to light touch, with a rash over the area. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Valacyclovir:

Explanation:

  • The clinical features and the provided image suggest a diagnosis of herpes zoster, for which Valacyclovir is the treatment of choice.

Valacyclovir (a prodrug of acyclovir)

MOA

Uses

Varicella zoster virus (VZV) - Most effective

Epstein Barr virus

Herpes simplex virus-1 and 2

  • Genital herpes
  • Mucocutaneous herpes simplex (use IV)
  • Herpes labialis, Keratoconjunctivitis (use topical)
  • HSV encephalitis (use IV)

Resistance

Associated with viral thymidine kinase mutation

Side effects

Thrombocytopenia

Neurotoxicity: seizures, confusion, hallucinations

Nephrotoxicity: Obstructive renal failure (crystalluria)

  • Contraindicated with cyclosporine and probenecid
  • Administer plenty of IV fluid and water

Amitriptyline (Option A) is a tricyclic antidepressant used for managing chronic pain such as postherpetic neuralgia, but it is not the primary treatment for acute herpes zoster.

Topical steroid (Option B) is not indicated for herpes zoster as it does not treat the viral infection and may worsen the condition by suppressing local immunity.

Mupirocin (Option D) is an antibacterial agent that is inappropriate for viral infections like herpes zoster.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who has swelling in the middle of their neck, along with weight loss, and a thyroid biopsy showing the presence of 'Orphan Annie eye nuclei?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Explanation:

The histopathological features of psammoma bodies, nuclear grooves, and "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei are indicative of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

  • It is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterised by lymphatic spread.
  • It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy.
  • Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion

HPE shows

  1. True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core.
  2. Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact.
  3. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
  4. Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
  5. Presence of psammoma bodies: Dystrophic calcifications.

It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies.

 

Follicular thyroid carcinoma (Option A) typically does not exhibit "Orphan Annie eye nuclei." Instead, it is characterised by follicular cell differentiation and the presence of follicular patterns.

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma (Option C) is a highly aggressive and undifferentiated form of thyroid cancer. It typically does not exhibit "Orphan Annie eye nuclei." Instead, it is characterised by marked cellular pleomorphism and loss of cellular differentiation.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (Option D) arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland and is associated with the production of calcitonin.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 36-year-old farmer who presented with a cough, chest pain lasting one week, fatigue persisting for a month, and a chest x-ray revealing the image provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

The image shows ‘Water lily sign’ (partially fluid-filled cyst with a floating endocyst) seen in hydatid cyst.

Hydatid cyst

Echinococcus granulosus (most common), E. multilocularis, and E. vogeli.

Cause cystic lesions primarily in the liver and lungs.

Dogs are the primary reservoir; mammals serve as intermediate hosts.

Unilocular Cystic Echinococcosis (E. granulosus):

  • Pulmonary Involvement Can occur through diaphragm invasion or hematogenous spread.
  • Lungs are the second most common site for hematogenous spread in adults and the primary site in children.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Uncomplicated cysts appear as thin-walled, round or oval masses with low-attenuation contents and a thin enhancing wall, up to 10 cm in size.
  • Signs of Impending Rupture:
  • Meniscus Sign: Air lucency between the pericyst and laminated membranes when cyst communicates with bronchioles.
  • Signs Associated with Cyst Rupture:
  • Cumbo Sign or Onion Peel Sign:
    • Indicates that the endocyst has shrunk and ruptured due to increasing air.
    • Curvilinear membrane outlined by air both inside the endocyst and a crescent of air between the endocyst and pericyst.
    • Water Lily Sign:
      • Also known as the camalote sign.
      • Indicates that the endocyst membrane is detached, it will appear as a floating curvilinear structure ( fluid-filled cyst ) within an intact pericyst.
      • This gives the appearance of a floating water lily.
  • Mass Within the Cavity: An endocyst floating in a completely fluid-filled cyst.
  • Other Radiographic and CT Findings:
    • Possible pleural effusion, elevated hemidiaphragm, consolidation, basilar atelectasis, pleural cavity cysts, and superadded infections leading to empyema.

Anthrax (Option B) is an infection caused by gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria known as Bacillus Anthracis.It commonly affects domestic or wild animals. Animals become infected when they breathe or ingest contaminated soil, plants, or water. Humans become infected when they inhale spores or eat food contaminated with spores. Inhalation Anthrax is associated with pleural effusions and mediastinal widening

Silicosis (Option C) is a chronic disease caused by inhaling large amounts of crystalline silica dust for many years. In chest radiography, it appears as small and large with irregular opacities, bilaterally symmetrical: commonly in the middle lung zone or peripheral ⅓ of the lung.

Byssinosis (Option D) is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis that can result from exposure to cotton fibers. Chest x-ray examination may show hyper translucency, diaphragm flattening, and emphysema. Ill-defined haziness can be seen in lower lung fields.

questions.text: Which medication can be administered to reduce the frequency of future headache episodes in a 26-year-old female patient who experiences one-sided pulsating headaches accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and finds relief in a dimly lit environment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Propranolol

Explanation:

  • The clinical history indicates a migraine headache. Propranolol is commonly used for migraine prophylaxis, with effects typically observed within 4 weeks and sustained with prolonged therapy.

Use of propranolol

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis
  • Essential tremors
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improve cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

 

Acute management of migraine attack

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

Prophylaxis of migraine

  • Propranolol (Beta-blocker, DOC for migraine prophylaxis).
  • Flunarizine (Calcium channel blocker)
  • Cyproheptadine: (Antihistamine that can help alleviate migraine symptoms).
  • Candesartan: (Angiotensin II receptor blocker).
  • Clonidine
  • Pizotifen (Serotonin antagonist that can help reduce migraine frequency).
  • Gabapentin, valproate, nortriptyline, and topiramate are medications that can help manage migraine symptoms by releasing the neurotransmitter GABA.
  • Topiramate
  • Methysergide (Manages migraine symptoms by blocking serotonin receptors).

Alprazolam (Option B) and Diazepam (Option C) are benzodiazepines that can be used in acute attacks of migraine by inducing sleep in the patient.

Fluoxetine (Option D) is an SSRI that may help treat migraine in some people.

questions.text: A patient took a drug for migraine treatment, following which there was numbness, and his hand appeared as below. What is the possible drug that was taken?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Dihydroergotamine

Explanation:

  • The patient's numbness and hand discolouration, as shown in the image, suggest treatment with dihydroergotamine for migraine.

Dihydroergotamine

Drug class

Ergot alkaloids

MOA

Partial agonist activity at 5HT1B/1D receptors causes vasoconstriction, reducing migraine-associated inflammation.

Uses

Acute migraine attack

Side effects

  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
    • Manifest as numbness, tingling, and discolouration of the fingers, commonly referred to as Raynaud's phenomenon.
    • Discolouration of fingers - White → Blue→ Red
    • It can lead to gangrene of extremities and organs with end arteries.
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Paradoxical headache and dizziness
  • Flushing
  • Nasal congestion
  • Chest pain
  • Muscle pain

Sumatriptan (Option B) is a medication used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. While it can cause side effects such as tingling or numbness, it is not associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon, unlike Dihydroergotamine.

Butorphanol (Option C) is an opioid analgesic used for the treatment of pain, including migraines. It is not typically associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Aspirin (Option D) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used for pain relief. It is not known to cause peripheral vasoconstriction or Raynaud's phenomenon.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was admitted to the emergency ward with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. The ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbed after 3 hours. During the autopsy, his heart was taken out and immersed in a solution. The normal area of the heart turned brick-red, whereas the infarcted portion turned pale. Which of the following is a likely component of the solution?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride

Explanation:

  • Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) is a histochemical stain that differentiates viable from non-viable myocardium by reacting with dehydrogenases in active mitochondria.
  • Viable myocardial tissue stains brick-red, while infarcted tissue, lacking dehydrogenase activity, remains pale and unstained.

Incorrect Options:

Formalin (Option A) is a fixative used for tissue preservation. It cannot differentiate between viable and infarcted myocardium.

Ethanol (Option C) is a solvent and fixative used in histological procedures. It does not specifically stain or differentiate between viable and infarcted myocardial tissue.

Glutaraldehyde (Option D) is a fixative used in electron microscopy. While it preserves cellular structures, it does not differentiate between viable and infarcted tissues.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to you with a limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The x-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Development of dysplasia of the hip

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

Explanation:

  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a disorder of adolescents in which the growth plate is damaged and the femoral head moves (“slips”) with respect to the rest of the femur.
  • It results in a non-traumatic painful hip of adolescence. Usually, an anteroposterior view of the pelvis and frog lateral views of both hips helps in the diagnosis of SCFE.

Frog Leg Lateral View:

Indication: Used in the assessment of:

  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
  • Perthes disease
  • Procedure:
    • The patient is supine with the affected limb flexed at the knee approximately 30° to 40°, and the hip is abducted 45°. The beam is focused midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.
    • If it is a bilateral examination, both knees are to rest on sponges, giving the appearance of "frog legs."

Perthes disease (Option B) is a childhood disease that occurs when the blood supply to the femoral head of the hip joint is temporarily interrupted and the bone begins to die. This can cause pain, limping, and limited movement of the hip joint. The early signs of Perthes disease may be joint effusion and widening of medial joint space. In the advanced burnt-out stage femoral head and neck deformity occur.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) (Option C) is a disorder that is due to abnormal development of the acetabulum with or without hip dislocation. This condition may occur at any time, from conception to skeletal maturity and the child may be born with dislocation or instability of the hip joint which then may result in hip dysplasia.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option D) is a chronic, inflammatory disease of the axial spine. There is a fusion of both SI joints and thin, symmetrical syndesmophytes bridging the Intervertebral disc spaces are seen as depicted in the x-ray of sacroiliac joints.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Tolcapone

Explanation:

  • Tolcapone acts by inhibiting the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme.

Tolcapone

MOA

It inhibits the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme, which is responsible for the breakdown of catecholamines, which prolongs the action of catechols in the CNS and peripheral tissue.

Uses

Adjunct therapy in Parkinson’s disease.

Side effects

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • On/Off phenomenon

Neurological Symptoms:

  • Dyskinesia (due to increased levodopa bioavailability)
  • Dizziness
  • Headache
  • Sleep disturbances (e.g., insomnia)

Psychiatric Symptoms:

  • Hallucinations
  • Confusion
  • Increased impulsive behaviors

Incorrect Options

Amantadine (Option A) is an antiviral and antiparkinsonian medication that primarily acts by increasing the release of dopamine and inhibiting its reuptake. It does not inhibit the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme.

Rotigotine (Option B) is a dopamine agonist used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and restless legs syndrome. It stimulates dopamine receptors directly and does not inhibit the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme.

Selegiline (Option D) is a selective monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitor, which increases dopamine levels by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine by the MAO-B enzyme. It does not directly inhibit the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Desmopressin

Explanation:

  • Desmopressin is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus.

Desmopressin

DDAVP, or desmopressin, is a synthetic analogue of vasopressin

MOA

Acts on V2 receptors located in renal tubules, which increases water reabsorption in the renal tubule

Uses
  • Diabetes insipidus(central)
  • Nocturnal Enuresis

Route

Nasal or intravenous, as the oral route is less efficacious due to getting metabolised by trypsin in the gut

Side effects
  • Hyponatremia
  • Cerebral edema
  • Fluid overload

Insulin (Option A) is primarily used to manage diabetes mellitus, a condition characterised by high blood sugar levels due to insulin deficiency or resistance. Central diabetes insipidus on the other hand, is a water balance disorder caused by a vasopressin deficiency (also known as antidiuretic hormone or ADH).\

Diazoxide (Option C) is a medication primarily used to treat hypoglycemia caused by excessive insulin secretion, such as in certain forms of hyperinsulinism. It works by opening potassium channels in the beta cells of the pancreas, inhibiting insulin release. It does not directly affect vasopressin/ADH or the treatment of central diabetes insipidus.

Chlorpropamide (Option D) is an oral medication that belongs to the sulfonylurea class of drugs and is primarily used to lower blood sugar levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus. It stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas and enhances the effectiveness of insulin in peripheral tissues.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with solid cancer of the bowel. He also experienced massive proteinuria a few months after the initial diagnosis of cancer. What do you think is the likely cause of the development of urinary findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Membranous nephropathy

Explanation:

Characteristic Features of Membranous Nephropathy

Feature

Description

Primary Cause

Autoantibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) on podocytes (most common in idiopathic cases).

Secondary Causes

Autoimmune diseases (SLE), infections (Hepatitis B/C), drugs (NSAIDs, penicillamine), and malignancies (lung, breast, colon cancer).

Nephrotic Syndrome Features

Massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, oedema, hyperlipidemia, lipiduria.

Risk of Thrombosis

Renal vein thrombosis is a known complication.

Light Microscopy

Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) without hypercellularity.

Electron Microscopy (EM)

Subepithelial immune deposits create a "spike and dome" appearance.

Immunofluorescence

Granular IgG and C3 deposits along the GBM.

PLA2R Antibodies

Specific for primary membranous nephropathy and helps differentiate from secondary causes.

Treatment

ACE inhibitors/ARBs (reduce proteinuria), steroids + immunosuppressants (cyclophosphamide, rituximab) for severe cases.

Prognosis

⅓ spontaneous remission, ⅓ persistent proteinuria, ⅓ progress to ESRD.

 

 

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option B) (FSGS) is characterised by scarring and sclerosis of the glomeruli. While FSGS can occur in the setting of cancer, it is not commonly associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option C) (MPGN) is characterised by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and the proliferation of cells within the glomeruli.MPGN is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

Dense deposit disease (Option D), also known as C3 glomerulopathy, is characterised by the abnormal accumulation of complement component C3 within the glomeruli.Dense deposit disease is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for UTI in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

  • Ceftriaxone is the preferred antibiotic for UTls in pregnancy due to its effectiveness against common pathogens that cause UTls, including Escherichia coli.
  • It is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is generally safe for use during pregnancy.

Uses of cephalosporins

First generation
  • ENT, upper respiratory & cutaneous infections
  • Surgical prophylaxis

Second generation
  • Mixed aerobic-anaerobic infections

 

 

Third generation
  • Empirical therapy for meningitis
  • Pseudomonas meningitis
  • Urinary tract infection in pregnancy
  • STI : Gonorrhea, chancroid, syphilis
  • Enteric fever
  • Patients with neutropenia

Fourth generation
  • Nosocomial infections (intensive care borne)

 

Fifth generation
  • Penicillin-resistant community-acquired and hospital-acquired pneumonia by S.pneumoniae
  • Penicillinase-producing S.aureus infections
  • MRSA

﻿﻿Amoxicillin (Option A) is an antibiotic commonly used for various gram-positive infections, but ﻿it is less commonly used due to rising resistance rates.

Azithromycin (Option B) is a macrolide antibiotic often used for respiratory tract infections and it is not used as a first-line treatment for UTl. ﻿﻿

Clarithromycin (Option C) is primarily used for respiratory tract infections and is not typically recommended as a first-line treatment for UTl as it may have limited effectiveness against the specific bacteria that commonly cause UTl.

questions.text:
What is the likely diagnosis for a 20-year-old male who presents with pain in the right flank, along with fever and chills?

The patient experiences pain when the hip is passively extended on the right side. Lab tests indicate an increased white blood cell count, and a CT scan reveals specific findings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Psoas abscess

Explanation:

  • A psoas abscess is the pus collection which is located in the iliopsoas compartment. The classical presentation is back pain, fever, and limping.
  • The pain on passive extension occurs due to muscles causing friction against inflamed tissue. The CT scan demonstrates abnormal fluid collection surrounded by irregular rim enhancement.

Pyelonephritis (Option A) is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidney. It can cause fever and back pain but not limping. The pain will not be present on the passive extension of the hip. CT findings are enlargement of the kidney with thickened parenchyma and an Impairment of corticomedullary differentiation.

Appendicitis (Option C) is an inflammation of the appendix. It causes pain in your lower right abdomen CT findings are dilated appendix with the wall thickening and adjacent mesenteric fat stranding.

Torsion of right undescended testis (Option D) clinical symptoms include nonspecific abdominal pain, poor oral intake, vomiting, and restlessness.CT shows a well-circumscribed, isodense, or hetero-dense mass and had proper fine anatomic detail in locating the undescended testis.

questions.text: What is Zileuton's mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 5-Lipooxygenase inhibitor

Explanation:

  • Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, which is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes.
  • It is primarily used to maintain asthma and is particularly effective in reducing bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation in conditions like asthma.

Cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors (Option A), such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), work by inhibiting the activity of the COX enzymes involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxanes. Zileuton does not inhibit cyclooxygenase.

5-phosphodiesterase inhibitors (Option C) inhibit the enzyme that breaks down cyclic nucleotides like cAMP and cGMP. Drugs like sildenafil are used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Zileuton does not inhibit 5-phosphodiesterase.

Prevention of mast cell degranulation (Option D) is seen with mast cell stabilisers, like cromolyn sodium. Mast cell degranulation refers to the release of inflammatory mediators, such as histamine and cytokines, from mast cells. Zileuton does not directly prevent mast cell degranulation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with the development of seizures, for which a CT-guided biopsy was done. The histopathological image showed the presence of psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Meningioma

Explanation:

  • Meningiomas are tumours originating from the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. They are not derived from glial cells but rather from the arachnoid cap cells of the meninges.

 

Incorrect Options:

Astrocytoma (Option A) is a GFAP-positive glial cell tumour and the most common primary brain tumour in children. Histologically, it features densely packed elongated cells with round to oval nuclei and prominent nucleoli.

Medulloblastoma (Option B) are embryonal tumours that develop from undifferentiated neuroepithelial cells in the cerebellum. They are not derived from glial cells but instead from primitive neuroectodermal cells. It is the most common malignant tumour in children.

Ependymoma (Option D) arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricular system or spinal cord. It is commonly seen in the fourth ventricle in children and in the spinal cord in adults. Histologically, it is characterised by perivascular pseudorosettes, where tumour cells are arranged around blood vessels, and ependymal rosettes, where cells form true rosettes with a central lumen.

questions.text: A female patient presented with burning micturition. A diagnosis of cystitis was made. Which of the following drugs will be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - TMP-SMX is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated cystitis.

Explanation:

  • TMP-SMX: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an antibiotic that is used as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated cystitis

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

MOA

Trimethoprim (TMP): Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, blocking the conversion of dihydrofolate acid to tetrahydrofolic acid

Sulfamethoxazole (SMX): Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase, preventing the incorporation of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) into dihydropteroic acid, an essential precursor in folate synthesis.

Uses

  • Urinary tract infections (DOC for mild cases)
  • Respiratory tract infections
  • GIT Infections
  • Prevention and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in immunocompromised patients

Side effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea
  • Rash
  • Hypersensitivity reactions (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis)
  • Blood dyscrasias (e.g., neutropenia, thrombocytopenia)

Note
  • Contraindicated in patients with folate deficiency
  • Use with caution in pregnant women, infants, and individuals with G6PD deficiency
  • Increased risk of hyperkalemia with potassium-sparing diuretics


Amoxicillin (Option A) is effective against many bacterial infections; it is not the preferred choice for treating uncomplicated cystitis. It may be used in certain cases, but it is not the first-line treatment due to increasing antibiotic resistance.

Ciprofloxacin (Option C) is a fluoroquinolone often used for more complicated or resistant infections. It is generally not recommended as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated cystitis due to concerns about increasing resistance.

Doxycycline (Option D) is not a standard treatment for cystitis. It is more commonly used for atypical infections, such as those caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Mycoplasma.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with hepatic angiosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Arsenic

Explanation:

  • Arsenic is a well-established carcinogen for hepatic angiosarcoma.
  • Chronic arsenic exposure leads to DNA damage and promotes endothelial cell malignancy.
  • It also notes that vinyl chloride, Thorotrast, and arsenic are the most frequently implicated agents in hepatic angiosarcoma development.

 

Incorrect Options:

Iron (Option A) overload (e.g., in hereditary hemochromatosis) is primarily associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), not hepatic angiosarcoma.

Copper (Option B) accumulation in Wilson's disease is linked to hepatocyte damage and cirrhosis but is not associated with angiosarcoma development.

Zinc (Option C) is essential for normal cellular function and is not carcinogenic.

questions.text: Which of the following DMARD uses require regular monitoring of visual acuity and fundus examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydroxychloroquine

Explanation:

The use of Hydroxychloroquine requires regular monitoring of visual acuity and fundus examination due to the risk of Ocular toxicity, such as

  • Vortex keratopathy (cornea verticallata)
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract
  • Bull’s eye retinopathy (deposits like concentric rings in the retina)

 

Hydroxychloroquine

MAO

Hydroxychloroquine⟶ Lysosome Accumulation ⟶ ↑ Lysosomal pH ⟶ Inhibits Antigen Processing ⟶ ↓ Antigen-MHC Presentation ⟶ ↓ T-Cell Activation ⟶ Inhibits TLRs ⟶ ↓ Pro-inflammatory Cytokines ⟶ ↓ Inflammation in RA

Uses
  • Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Prevention and treatment of malaria
  • Autoimmune diseases like Sjögren's syndrome

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Dermatological (rash, pigmentation changes)
  • Ocular toxicity:
    • Vortex keratopathy (cornea verticallata)
    • Posterior subcapsular cataract
    • Bull’s eye retinopathy (deposits like concentric rings in the retina)
  • Cardiovascular (cardiomyopathy, QT prolongation)
  • Neurological (headache, dizziness)
  • Hematologic (anaemia, leukopenia)

Note
  • Regular ophthalmologic examinations to monitor for retinal toxicity.
  • The maximum safe dose of hydroxychloroquine to minimise the risk of bull's-eye maculopathy is recommended to be 5 mg/kg of real body weight per day.

 

Methotrexate (Option A) does not cause ocular toxicity but requires regular monitoring of liver function tests (LFTs), complete blood counts (CBC), and renal function. It can cause hepatotoxicity, myelosuppression, and pulmonary fibrosis.

Sulfasalazine (Option C) requires regular monitoring of CBC (to detect hemolytic anaemia, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia) and LFTs (for hepatotoxicity).

Leflunomide (Option D) requires regular monitoring of LFTs because of the risk of severe hepatotoxicity. It also necessitates monitoring for hypertension and teratogenicity in women of childbearing age.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Midbrain

Explanation:

The midbrain is a region of the brain located between the pons and the diencephalon. In a CT scan image, the midbrain appears as a centrally located structure, typically exhibiting a more dense and compact appearance compared to the surrounding brain tissue. It is characterized by its distinct shape and size, with a relatively smaller volume compared to other brain regions.

Pons (Option B): The pons is a part of the brainstem located above the medulla and below the midbrain. In a CT scan image, the pons appears as a rounded structure situated anterior to the cerebellum. It has a slightly lighter density compared to the adjacent brain tissue, and its size and shape can vary among individuals. The pons serves as a communication pathway, relaying signals between the cerebrum, cerebellum, and other parts of the central nervous system.

Medulla (Option C): The medulla, also known as the medulla oblongata, is the lowermost part of the brainstem. In a CT scan image, the medulla appears as a tapered structure at the base of the brain, just below the pons. It has a similar density to the adjacent brain tissue. The medulla plays a crucial role in controlling vital functions such as breathing, heart rate, blood pressure, and reflexes.

Cerebellum (Option D): The cerebellum is a region located at the back of the brain, below the occipital lobes of the cerebrum. In a CT scan image, the cerebellum appears as a distinct structure with a granular appearance. It is characterized by its distinctive lobes and folia (ridged surface). The density of the cerebellum is similar to that of other brain tissues. The cerebellum is involved in coordinating voluntary movements, balance, posture, and motor learning.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man has presented with chronic lower back pain, fatigue, and headaches for the last few weeks. On examination, he has pallor and bony tenderness. Lab investigations revealed an increased ESR, and his skull radiograph revealed several punched-out lytic lesions. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serum electrophoresis showing IgG

Explanation:

  • The patient's pain, fatigue, multiple punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray, and elevated ESR suggest Multiple myeloma.
  • The best investigation is serum electrophoresis, which detects monoclonal immunoglobulins, such as IgG, confirming the diagnosis and quantifying the abnormal proteins.

 

Incorrect Options:

Serum levels of CA 15-3 (Option B): CA 15-3 is a tumour marker primarily used for monitoring breast cancer.

Whole-body scan (Option C): While imaging studies such as whole-body scans may be useful in assessing the extent of multiple myeloma involvement, they are not typically the initial investigation for diagnosis.

CT head with contrast (Option D) is not necessary for multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A female presented with burning micturition and symptoms of UTI. Which of the following fluoroquinolones is least likely to be effective if UTI is caused by Enterococcus species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Moxifloxacin

Explanation:

  • Moxifloxacin is less likely to be effective in treating urinary tract infections (UTls) caused by Enterococcus species.
  • While it is a broad-spectrum fluoroquinolone antibiotic, its coverage against Enterococcus species is limited.

Fluoroquinolones

 

First Generation

Second Generation

Drugs

 
  • Norfloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin (Option B)
  • Ofloxacin (Option A)
  • Pefloxacin
  • Sparfloxacin
  • Levofloxacin (Option D)
  • Moxifloxacin (Option C)
  • Gemifloxacin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Good oral absorption
  • Moderate half-life
  • Good oral absorption
  • Longer half-life
  • Better tissue penetration

Mechanism of Action

Inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase

Inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

Spectrum

Effective against Gram-negative bacteria

Broader spectrum, including Gram (+ve), Gram (-ve) and Atypical pathogens.

Uses
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Prostatitis
  • Respiratory infections
  • Skin infections
  • Complicated UTIs

Side Effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Dizziness
  • QT prolongation
  • Tendonitis
  • CNS effects
  • Phototoxicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy
  • Children
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Same as the first-generation
  • Patients with cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: What is the primary protein that binds to thyroxine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thyroxine-binding globulin

Explanation:

  • Thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) are thyroid hormones transported in the blood bound to carrier proteins. These carrier proteins ensure the hormones' solubility and regulate their availability to tissues.
  • TBG is the primary and most specific protein that binds to thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). It has a high affinity for thyroid hormones and is responsible for carrying the majority of T4 in the blood.

 

Follistatin (Option A): Follistatin is not involved in thyroid hormone transport. It primarily binds to and inhibits activins, which are proteins involved in various biological processes.

Transthyretin (Option B): Transthyretin (TTR), also known as prealbumin, binds a smaller fraction of T4 compared to TBG. It plays a secondary role in thyroid hormone transport, particularly in the cerebrospinal fluid.

Transferrin (Option D): Transferrin is a transport protein for iron in the blood and is unrelated to thyroid hormone transport.

questions.text: Which drug is most suitable for treating edema in a patient with heart disease and presenting with breathlessness with rales?

choices.text: Na-K-2Cl symporter inhibitor in the loop in Henle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Na-K-2Cl symporter inhibitor in the loop in Henle

Explanation:

  • The most suitable drug for treating edema with heart disease presenting with pulmonary edema.

Loop diuretic

MOA

Inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle, increasing the excretion of sodium, chloride, and water, resulting in diuresis and reduction of edema.

Drugs

Furosemide, Bumetanide

Uses

  • Acute pulmonary edema

  • Chronic heart failure

  • Hypercalcemia

Side effects

  • Hypokalemia,

  • Ototoxicity,

  • Metabolic alkalosis,

  • Hyperglycemia,

  • Hyperuricemia
