ACE inhibitors (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors) (Option A) are commonly used in the treatment of heart disease, but they primarily target the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) to reduce blood pressure and improve cardiac function. While they can have some mild diuretic effects, they are not the first-line choice for managing edema and pulmonary edema.

Na-Cl symporter inhibitors in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) (Option C), such as thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide), are effective in reducing blood pressure but have limited efficacy in treating edema. They primarily promote sodium and water excretion in the DCT but are less potent than loop diuretics. They are not preferred for acute management of pulmonary edema

Aldosterone blockers (Option D), such as spironolactone and eplerenone, act on the aldosterone receptors in the distal tubules to inhibit the effects of aldosterone, a hormone that promotes sodium and water retention. While aldosterone blockers can be beneficial in some cases of heart failure, they are typically used as adjunct therapy rather than as the primary treatment for edema.

questions.text: In a clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of a new drug, a normal efficacy potecy graph is used. Which of the following statements regarding the graph is true?

choices.text: The graph shows the relationship between drug potency and its efficacy
The graph demonstrates that higher potency always leads to higher efficacy
The graph represents the dose-response curve for the drug
The graph indicates that drugs with low potency can never be effective

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - The graph represents the dose-response curve for the drug

Explanation:

The graph represents the dose-response curve for the drug, showing the relationship between drug dose and its observed response or effects.

  • Efficacy is the maximal effect a drug can produce, represented by the Vmax /y-axis value. The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy.
  • Potency is the amount of drug required to produce a given effect. The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.
  • Both are independent of each other
    • Efficacious drugs can have high or low potency and vice versa.
  • The graph helps us estimate the efficacy of the drugs (the higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy
    • Thus, order of efficacy: Drug A > B

Incorrect Options

The graph shows the relationship between drug potency and its efficacy (Option A): The graph does not specifically represent the relationship between drug potency and efficacy; its primary focus is on illustrating the dose-response curve.

The graph demonstrates that higher potency always leads to higher efficacy (Option B) The graph does not necessarily indicate that higher potency always leads to higher efficacy; efficacy depends on various factors beyond potency alone.

The graph indicates that drugs with low potency can never be effective (Option D)

The graph does not suggest that drugs with low potency can never be effective; efficacy can still be achieved with lower potency drugs if administered appropriately within the therapeutic range.

questions.text:
Please identify the structure labelled 'X' in the given ultrasound image of the liver.

 ​
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Portal Vein

Explanation:

In an ultrasound of the liver, the portal vein appears as a tubular structure running through the liver tissue. It can be visualized as a hypoechoic (darker) tube with a characteristic branching pattern.

The portal vein plays a crucial role in delivering nutrients and substances absorbed from the digestive system to the liver for processing and detoxification.

Hepatic Artery (Option B):The hepatic artery is a blood vessel that supplies oxygenated blood to the liver. In an ultrasound of the liver, the hepatic artery may be visualized as a smaller, pulsatile vessel alongside the portal vein. It appears as a hyperechoic (brighter) tube with a pulsating motion. The hepatic artery delivers oxygenated blood to the liver cells for their metabolic needs.

Hepatic Vein (Option C): The hepatic veins are blood vessels that drain deoxygenated blood from the liver and carry it back to the heart via the inferior vena cava. In an ultrasound of the liver, the hepatic veins can be seen as hypoechoic (darker) tubular structures that converge and eventually merge into a single vessel known as the main hepatic vein. The hepatic veins drain blood from the liver and play a role in the liver's excretory function.

Inferior Vena Cava (Option B): The inferior vena cava (IVC) is a large vein that receives deoxygenated blood from the lower body and carries it to the right atrium of the heart. In an ultrasound of the liver, the IVC is typically visualized as a larger, hypoechoic (darker) vessel located posterior to the liver. It can be observed entering the liver at the level of the main hepatic vein. The IVC acts as the final drainage pathway for blood leaving the liver through the hepatic veins.

questions.text: A patient on anti-cancer therapy developed an infection. Blood analysis revealed a total leucocyte count of 2000/mm3. Which of the following drugs is likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Filgrastim

Explanation:

  • In patients with chemotherapy-induced neutropenia (low white blood cell count, particularly neutrophils), Filgrastim is most likely to be effective in this patient.

Drugs promoting WBC formation

Drug Name

Mechanism of Action

Clinical Uses

G-CSF

(Glycoprotein with 175 amino acids)
  • Stimulates colony-forming unit (CFU) granulocytes to increase neutrophil production.
  • Enhances phagocytic and cytotoxic activities of neutrophils.
  • Treats severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and high-dose cancer chemotherapy
  • Treats severe congenital neutropenias

Filgrastim

(Recombinant human G-CSF)
  • Same use as G-CSF
  • Treats neutropenia in patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine
  • Used in patients undergoing peripheral blood stem cell collection for stem cell transplantation

PEG-Filgrastim

(Longer acting pegylated form of G-CSF)
  • Prevention of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia

Sargramostim

(Recombinant human GM-CSF)

Stimulates myelopoiesis
  • Autologous marrow transplantation treatment
  • Mobilizes CD34+ progenitor cells for peripheral blood stem cell collection post-myeloablative chemotherapy
  • Treats neutropenia in patients on intensive cancer chemotherapy
  • Supports myelopoiesis in cyclic neutropenia, myelodysplasia, aplastic anemia, and AIDS-associated neutropenia

Molgramostim

Targets GM-CSF receptors on bone marrow precursor cells
  • Increases granulocytes and monocytes
  • Approved for chemotherapy-induced neutropenia

Romiplostim & Oprelvekin (Option A and B) are not indicated for the treatment of infection or low leukocyte count. Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist used to increase platelet production in patients with thrombocytopenia and low platelet count. Oprelvekin is a recombinant interleukin-11 that stimulates platelet production in patients with severe thrombocytopenia.

Erythropoietin (Option D) is a hormone that stimulates the production of red blood cells and is used to treat anemia, not low leukocyte count or infection.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male underwent a bone marrow examination, which revealed the presence of the following findings, as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy characterised by the uncontrolled proliferation of clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow.

Bone Marrow Examination:

  • Presence of ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow.
  • Atypical plasma cells with features such as binucleation, prominent nucleoli, and perinuclear hof (Golgi clearing).

Serum and Urine Electrophoresis:

  • Detection of monoclonal (M) protein in serum or urine (commonly IgG or IgA).
  • Free light chains may be detected in urine (Bence Jones proteins).

CRAB Criteria (End-Organ Damage):

  • Calcium elevation (hypercalcemia).
  • Renal dysfunction (elevated creatinine).
  • Anaemia (normocytic, normochromic).
  • Bone lesions (osteolytic lesions on skeletal imaging).


Incorrect Options:

ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia) (Option B) is characterised by increased bone marrow and peripheral blood lymphoblasts but lacks the plasma cell morphology seen in multiple myeloma.

Tuberculosis (Option C) of the bone marrow usually shows granulomas with caseous necrosis, not plasma cells.

Sickle Cell Disease (Option D): Bone marrow findings in sickle cell disease may show erythroid hyperplasia and abnormal erythrocytes, but plasma cells are not a feature.

questions.text: A person presents with acute chest pain. Nitro-glycerine was given sublingually, and pain relief occurred within a minute. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Release of nitric oxide

Explanation:

  • Relief from chest pain by use of sublingual Nitro-glycerine occurs due to the release of nitric oxide, which causes vasodilation of coronary arteries, thus causing increased blood flow to the ischemic region of the myocardium.

Nitrates

Drugs

  • Glyceryl trinitrate
  • Isosorbide dinitrate
  • Isosorbide mononitrate
  • Pentaerythritol tetranitrate

MOA
  • Venodilation → Reduce preload → Reduce myocardial contractility → Decreased O2 demand.
  • Dilates coronary artery (increase cGMP): effective in vasospastic angina.
  • Redistribution of coronary blood flow to the ischemic area (Robinhood phenomenon).

Uses
  • Angina (stable, vasospastic and chronic)
  • Acute coronary syndrome or myocardial infarction (STEMI/NSTEMI)
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • Abdominal colicky pain


Release of endothelin (Option A) by endothelial cells leads to potent vasoconstrictor. It increases vascular tone and blood pressure. It is not used for the treatment of angina.

Calcium channel blockade (Option C) by Calcium channel blockers (e.g., amlodipine, verapamil) inhibits L-type calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle and cardiac myocytes, leading to vasodilation, decreased heart rate, and reduced contractility. It is not used for the treatment of angina.

Beta blockade (Option D) by Beta-blockers (e.g., atenolol, metoprolol) antagonise beta-adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate, myocardial contractility, and oxygen demand. Nitroglycerine does not interact with beta-adrenergic receptors.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with Down syndrome presents with mediastinal mass (presenting as SVC-like syndrome), and Peripheral blood and bone marrow have increased lymphoblasts. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is based on the presence of increased lymphoblasts in peripheral blood and bone marrow, along with a mediastinal mass causing SVC-like syndrome, a characteristic feature of T-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (ALL).
  • The strong association with Down syndrome further supports the diagnosis.
  • Common in children, with a worse prognosis in adults.
  • T-cell ALL often presents with a mediastinal mass.
  • Immunophenotyping: TdT+ (a marker of pre-T and pre-B cells), CD10+ (a marker of pre-B cells).

Incorrect Options:

Acute Myeloblastic Leukemia (AML) (Option A) typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, recurrent infections, bleeding tendencies, and bone pain. It is less commonly associated with hepatosplenomegaly and sternal tenderness.

Chronic Lymphoblastic Leukemia (CLL) (Option B) usually occurs in older individuals and is characterised by lymphocytosis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. It is less likely to present with hepatomegaly, sternal tenderness, and petechiae in a 10-year-old patient.

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) (Option D) typically presents in adults and is characterised by an elevated white blood cell count, splenomegaly, and a characteristic genetic abnormality called the Philadelphia chromosome. It is less common in children and may not present with the described symptoms.

questions.text: A patient has pain in the facial nerve distribution while chewing and speaking. Which of the following drugs should be given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Carbamazepine

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms are indicative of trigeminal neuralgia, and Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for managing this condition due to its proven efficacy in reducing pain.

Drugs for trigeminal neuralgia

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Uses

Side Effects

Carbamazepine

Inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels.

Trigeminal neuralgia

GTCS, partial seizures, bipolar disorder.

Sedation, dizziness, ataxia, GI disturbances, bone marrow suppression, hypersensitivity reactions, water retention.

Gabapentin

Enhances GABA release modulates voltage-sensitive Ca2+ channels.

Partial seizures, post-herpetic neuralgia, migraine prophylaxis.

Sedation, tiredness, dizziness, tremor, unsteadiness.

Diazepam

Enhances GABAergic neurotransmission.

Status epilepticus,

Febrile seizure.

Thrombophlebitis, hypotension, respiratory depression.

Topiramate

Multiple mechanisms, including sodium channel inactivation, GABA potentiation, glutamate receptor antagonism, and potassium channel modulation.

GTCS, myoclonic epilepsy, and absence of seizures.

Impairment of attention, sedation, ataxia, word-finding difficulties, poor memory, weight loss, paresthesias, renal stones.

Lamotrigine (Option A) is an anticonvulsant medication used in the treatment of epilepsy and bipolar disorder. While it has some efficacy in neuropathic pain, it is not used for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia.

Phenobarbital (Option C) is a barbiturate that is primarily used as an anticonvulsant. It is not commonly used for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia.

Haloperidol (Option D) is an antipsychotic used primarily to treat psychotic disorders like schizophrenia. It has no role in the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: Among the following, which molecule is required for the presentation of the antigens by the APCs to TH2 cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MHC

Explanation:

  • Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells play a crucial role in the adaptive immune response by presenting antigens to T-helper (TH2) cells.
  • This process requires Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) Class II molecules, which are essential for the activation of CD4+ T cells, including TH2 cells.
  • MHC Molecule Role: APCs process antigens and present them on their surface bound to MHC Class II molecules. MHC Class II molecules interact with the T-cell receptor (TCR) on CD4+ T cells. This interaction is critical for the differentiation and activation of TH2 cells, which secrete cytokines to mediate humoral immunity.

Incorrect Options:

NK cells (Option A) are part of the innate immune system and do not present antigens or directly interact with TH2 cells.

G-protein coupled receptors (Option B) are involved in cell signalling but are not involved in antigen presentation to T cells.

Lectin receptors (Option D) are involved in innate immune recognition, particularly of carbohydrate molecules, but they do not mediate antigen presentation to TH2 cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was treated for a high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma with radiotherapy. Since he was not responding, he was shifted to chemotherapy. After initiating chemotherapy, he developed erythematous rashes over the areas where radiotherapy was administered earlier.Which of the following drugs causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Doxorubicin

Explanation:

  • Doxorubicin is anthracycline chemotherapy which can lead to radiation recall dermatitis, which presents as erythematous rash in areas previously exposed to radiation therapy.
  • This phenomenon occurs when Doxorubicin exacerbates or "recalls" the inflammatory reaction caused by prior radiation exposure.

Doxorubicin

MOA

This leads to DNA Intercalation, Topoisomerase II Inhibition, and free radical formation, causing DNA damage.

Uses

  • Soft tissue sarcoma
  • Hodgkins and Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Leukaemia

Side effects

  • Radiation recall dermatitis
  • Alopecia
  • Stomatitis
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Hypersensitivity reaction - Rash and fever
  • Hyperpigmentation of skin and nails

Vincristine (Option A) is a vinca alkaloid chemotherapy drug that acts by disrupting the formation of microtubules in cells. It is not typically associated with radiation recall dermatitis.

Cyclophosphamide (Option C) is an alkylating agent commonly used in chemotherapy. It is not known to cause radiation recall dermatitis.

6-mercaptopurine (Option D) is an antimetabolite chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer. It does not typically cause radiation recall dermatitis.

questions.text: What is the mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from colour blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) XLR

Explanation:

  • The mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from colour blindness is X-linked recessive (XLR).

X-Linked Recessive:

  • The gene for Color blindness is located on the X chromosome.
  • Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation.
  • Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X.
  • Affected males cannot pass the disorder to sons but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers.

X-linked Recessive

(WISE ABCDEFGH)

Wise-Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome

AB- Hemophilia A, B

B- Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia.

C- Chronic Granulomatous Disease, Red Green Color Blindness

D- DMD, BMD

E- Lesch Nyhan Syndrome

F- Fabry Disease, Fragile X Syndrome

G- G6PD Deficiency

H- Hunter Disease

 

Incorrect Options:

Autosomal Dominant (AD) (Option A) disorders affect both sexes equally, and only one mutated allele is required for the disease to manifest.

  • Examples: Marfan syndrome, Achondroplasia, Familial hypercholesterolemia.

Autosomal Recessive (AR) (Option B) disorders require both alleles to be mutated for disease manifestation.

  • Examples: Cystic fibrosis, Sickle cell disease, Phenylketonuria (PKU). Colour blindness is inherited in an X-linked pattern, not AR.

X-linked Dominant (XLD) (Option D) affects both males and females, but females more commonly due to having two X chromosomes.

  • Examples: Rett syndrome, Fragile X syndrome, and Hypophosphatemic rickets. Colour blindness is X-linked recessive, not dominant.

questions.text: Macrophages play an important role in phagocytosis and chronic inflammation. Which of the following cells perform the same function in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kupffer cells

Explanation:

  • Kupffer cells are specialised macrophages located within the liver sinusoids.
  • They play a crucial role in phagocytosis, removing pathogens, damaged cells, and cellular debris from the bloodstream.
  • They are also involved in the regulation of immune responses and the promotion of chronic inflammation when necessary.
  • Therefore, Kupffer cells in the liver perform similar functions to macrophages, including phagocytosis and participation in chronic inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Hepatocytes (Option A) are the main functional cells of the liver responsible for various metabolic functions, such as detoxification, synthesis of proteins, and storage of nutrients. While hepatocytes are involved in many liver functions, they do not primarily perform phagocytosis and chronic inflammation.

Merkel cells (Option B) are specialised cells found in the skin and are involved in the sensation of touch and tactile discrimination. They are not present in the liver or involved in phagocytosis or chronic inflammation.

Sinusoidal cells (Option C) refer to the cells lining the sinusoids in the liver, which are specialised blood vessels.

questions.text: What is the accurate order of muscle utilization during ejaculation?

choices.text: Ischiocavernosus relaxation-external urethral sphincter relaxation-Bulbospongiosus contraction
Ischiocavernosus relaxation-External urethral sphincter contraction-Bulbospongiosus relaxation
Ischiocaveernosus contraction- external urethral sphincter relaxation- Bulbospongiosus relaxation
Ischiocavernosus contraction- External urethral sphincter relaxation- Bulbospongiosus relaxation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ischiocaveernosus contraction- external urethral sphincter relaxation- Bulbospongiosus relaxation

Explanation:

Ejaculation is a complex process that occurs in two stages: emission and expulsion. The correct sequence of muscle activity during the expulsion phase is as follows:

  1. Ischiocavernosus contraction:
    • The ischiocavernosus muscles contract to maintain penile rigidity by compressing the base of the corpora cavernosa and increasing intracavernosal pressure.
  2. External urethral sphincter relaxation:
    • Relaxation of the external urethral sphincter allows semen to flow from the prostatic urethra into the penile urethra.
  3. Bulbospongiosus contraction:
    • The bulbospongiosus muscles contract rhythmically to expel semen forcefully from the penile urethra.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Barrett's oesophagus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intestinal metaplasia

Explanation:

  • The primary cellular change seen in Barrett's oesophagus is metaplasia of squamous epithelium into intestinal/columnar epithelium.

 

Incorrect Options:

Squamous Metaplasia (Option A) is the replacement of normal columnar epithelium with stratified squamous epithelium, typically due to chronic irritation (e.g., bronchial epithelium in smokers or the cervix). In Barrett's oesophagus, the reverse occurs, with squamous epithelium replaced by columnar epithelium.

Severe Dysplasia (Option B) is disordered cellular growth and a precancerous condition. In Barrett's oesophagus, dysplasia (low-grade or high-grade) may arise as a progression from intestinal metaplasia toward adenocarcinoma, but it is not a defining feature-rather, a complication.

Cuboidal Metaplasia (Option D) is not a recognised feature of Barrett's oesophagus or any other oesophagal condition. Barrett's oesophagus is specifically defined by intestinal metaplasia, with goblet cells present within the columnar epithelium.

questions.text: Oxytocin plays a role in-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Milk ejection

Explanation:

  • Oxytocin, a hormone released by the posterior pituitary, is primarily involved in stimulating the milk ejection reflex (let-down reflex) during breastfeeding.
  • Oxytocin acts on the myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli of the mammary glands, causing them to contract. This contraction propels milk from the alveoli into the ducts and towards the nipple, enabling milk ejection.

 

Milk production (Option A): Milk production is regulated by prolactin, another hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary, not oxytocin.

Milk storage (Option C): Milk storage occurs in the alveoli and lactiferous sinuses of the mammary glands. Oxytocin is not involved in this process.

Osmoregulation (Option D): While oxytocin has some roles in osmoregulation by influencing kidney function, its primary physiological role is in milk ejection and uterine contractions during labor.

questions.text: What does the image below represent in terms of murmurs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ejection systolic

Explanation:

  • An end-systolic murmur begins in mid-to-late systole and ends at the second heart sound (S2). These murmurs are typically associated with conditions such as mitral valve prolapse or late systolic mitral regurgitation.

Ejection systolic murmur:

An ejection systolic murmur is a heart murmur that occurs during ventricular systole, often due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed outflow tract or valve. The hallmark of this murmur is its crescendo-decrescendo pattern, indicating that it rises in intensity and then falls.

  • Timing:
    • Begins shortly after the first heart sound (S1) when the semilunar valves (aortic or pulmonary) open.
    • Peaks mid-systole and ends before the second heart sound (S2).
  • Causes:
    • Aortic Stenosis: Narrowing of the aortic valve leading to increased flow velocity.
    • Pulmona
    • Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Outflow obstruction during systole.
  • Sound Characteristics:
    • Best heard at the aortic area (right upper sternal border) or pulmonary area (left upper sternal border).
    • Crescendo-decrescendo pattern on auscultation.

 

End Diastolic (Option A): End-diastolic murmurs occur towards the end of diastole, just before the first heart sound (S1). These murmurs are often linked to conditions like mitral stenosis or tricuspid stenosis, which don't match the given pattern.

Pan Systolic (Holosystolic) (Option C): A pan-systolic murmur begins with S1 and extends through systole to S2. This is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, or ventricular septal defects, but does not fit a murmur ending late in systole.

Mid Diastolic (Option D): Mid-diastolic murmurs occur between S2 and S1, often caused by mitral stenosis, tricuspid stenosis, or increased blood flow through these valves.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with a history of trauma to the left eye 5 days back now presented with complaints of complete loss of vision. Upon examination the following findings were seen. What should be the subsequent course of action to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratoplasty

Explanation:

  • The history of trauma to the eye and complete loss of vision and examination finding revealing congestion and corneal perforation is suggestive of uncontrolled keratitis commonly seen with bacterial keratitis. The choice of treatment for corneal perforation with uncontrolled infection penetrating is keratoplasty.

Penetrating Keratoplasty (PK):

  • It is a type of Allografting (Allo-Keratoplasty) which is the replacement of a patient’s diseased cornea with a healthy donor cornea.
  • Full-thickness grafting.

 

Indications for Penetrating Keratoplasty:

 

Optical
  • Corneal opacity
  • Bullous keratopathy
  • Corneal dystrophies
  • Advanced keratoconus

Therapeutic

To replace an inflamed cornea that does not respond to conventional therapy

Tectonic Graft

To restore the integrity of the eyeball, e.g., after corneal perforation (Option A) or in cases of significant corneal thinning.

Cosmetic

To improve the appearance of the eye

Complications: (ak142)

  • Early Complications:
    • Flat anterior chamber
    • Iris prolapse
    • Infection
    • Secondary glaucoma
    • Epithelial defects
    • Primary graft failure
  • Late Complications:
    • Graft rejection
    • Recurrence of disease
    • Astigmatism

Incorrect Options
 

Keratotomy (Option B) is used for correcting refractive error causing flattening of the cornea and reducing its focusing power.

LASIK (Option C) surgery is commonly used for keratomileusis, which is altering of the curvature of the cornea, done for refractive correction. .

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) (Option D) is a surgical procedure done for dacryocystitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is accurate regarding a 50-year-old male who was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumor, underwent tumor removal, and subsequently experienced damage to the lingual nerve?

choices.text: The taste sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue is lost
The taste sensation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is lost
A general sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue is lost
A general sensation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is lost

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A general sensation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is lost

Explanation:

  • The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), plays a crucial role in providing general sensation (touch, pain, and temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also carries taste fibers from the chorda tympani (a branch of the facial nerve, CN VII) responsible for taste in this region.
  • Damage to the lingual nerve disrupts the sensory fibers responsible for the general sensation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This is the most reliable symptom after lingual nerve damage.

Clinical Insight:

During submandibular gland surgery, the lingual nerve is at risk due to its anatomical proximity. Postoperative complications often include:

  • Loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Occasionally, taste loss in the same area if the chorda tympani is also injured.

 

The taste sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue is lost (Option A): The posterior one-third of the tongue is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for both general and taste sensations. This region is not affected by lingual nerve damage.

The taste sensation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is lost (Option B): While the lingual nerve carries chorda tympani fibers (responsible for taste), taste loss depends on whether the chorda tympani is also damaged. General sensation loss is more consistent with lingual nerve injury.

A general sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue is lost (Option C): The general sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and is unaffected by lingual nerve injury.

questions.text: A patient has a road traffic accident and is now bleeding profusely. He is hypotensive and needs large volume replacement with IV fluids. What cannula gauge will you use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 14 G

Explanation:

  • 14 G cannula has the thickest diameter with flow rate of 250-300ml is orange color coded cannula, which is used when large volume replacement with IV fluids is needed.

 

Incorrect Options:

13G (Option B) cannula is not present.

16G (Option C) cannula is gray color coded which is commonly used in emergency replacement of fluid volume.

18G (Option D) cannula is green color coded and can also be used in emergency replacement of IV fluids.

questions.text: Surfactant is secreted by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type Il pneumocyte

Explanation:

  • Surfactant is a lipid-protein substance secreted by Type II pneumocytes in the alveoli of the lungs. Its primary function is to reduce surface tension within the alveoli, preventing alveolar collapse during exhalation and aiding in efficient gas exchange.
  • Type II pneumocytes are specialized alveolar cells that secrete surfactant starting from approximately 24 weeks of gestation, with sufficient production by 35 weeks to support normal respiration.

Clinical Insight:

  • A deficiency of surfactant in premature neonates leads to neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), characterized by difficulty in breathing and alveolar collapse. Surfactant replacement therapy is often used to treat this condition.

 

Type I pneumocyte (Option A): Type I pneumocytes are involved in gas exchange and form the thin alveolar lining, but they do not secrete surfactant.

Sertoli cell (Option C): Sertoli cells are found in the seminiferous tubules of the testes and play a role in sperm development (spermatogenesis).

Leydig cell (Option D): Leydig cells are located in the testes and are responsible for producing testosterone.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old female patient who shows a progressive decline in visual clarity in her eye? A post-contrast CT scan of her head indicates the presence of thickening in a specific structure, in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Optic nerve sheath meningioma

Explanation:

The image given shows thickening around the optic nerve making the most likely diagnosis an Optic Nerve Sheath Meningioma.

Optic nerve sheath meningioma (ONSM) is a rare, benign tumor that originates from the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the optic nerve. It typically involves the optic nerve sheath and can lead to vision loss due to compression of the optic nerve.

Radiological Findings:

  1. MRI: The most common imaging modality for diagnosing ONSM. Key findings include:

    • Isointense or mildly hyperintense lesion on T1-weighted images.

    • Hyperintense lesion on T2-weighted images.

    • Contrast enhancement: The tumor usually enhances after gadolinium administration, especially in the meningothelial regions.

    • Enlargement of the optic nerve: The optic nerve may appear thickened and "sharply delineated," with the tumor surrounding it.

  2. CT: Less sensitive than MRI, but may show bone changes (hyperostosis of the optic canal) and optic nerve enlargement. 'Tram-track' appearance caused by thickening and enhancement around the optic nerve.

Optic nerve glioma (Option B): is incorrect because this tumor is more common in children and is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). It presents with fusiform optic nerve enlargement, not optic sheath thickening.

Retinoblastoma (Option C): is incorrect because it occurs in children, typically under 5 years old, and presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) rather than progressive vision loss.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option D): is incorrect because it is a highly malignant soft tissue tumor seen in children, presenting with rapid-onset proptosis and orbital swelling, unlike the slow progression seen in ONSM.

questions.text: Intravenous induction agent of choice for day care anesthesia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Propofol

Explanation:

  • Propofol is the intravenous induction agent of choice for day-care anaesthesia due to its rapid onset, antiemetic effects, short duration of action, and smooth recovery profile. It allows patients to wake up quickly with minimal residual sedation, which is ideal for day-care procedures requiring early discharge.

 

Incorrect Options:

Ketamine (option A): While ketamine provides excellent analgesia and maintains cardiovascular stability, it is associated with slower recovery and potential emergence reactions (e.g., hallucinations). These side effects make it less suitable for day-care anaesthesia.

Etomidate (option C) has a rapid onset and is haemodynamically stable, but it is associated with adrenal suppression and myoclonus, making it less ideal for routine day-care procedures.

Thiopentone (option D) has a rapid onset, but its prolonged recovery time due to accumulation in body fat makes it unsuitable for day-care anaesthesia. It also lacks antiemetic properties, which are beneficial in outpatient settings.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient came with complaints of blurring of vision, photophobia, redness, pain in the left eye, and joint pain. Upon examination keratic precipitates and aqueous cells were observed. Which of the following major histocompatibility complex is be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HLA B27

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of blurring vision, photophobia, redness, pain ,and keratic precipitates are suggestive of anterior uveitis. Patients with acute anterior uveitis with joint pain is suggestive of arthritis associated with uveitis. The disease affects young males who are positive for HLA B27. Among patients with ankylosing spondylitis, 90% of them belong to the HLA-B27 antigenic group.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray): Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

HLA B51 (Option B) It is associated with Behcet's syndrome with anterior uveitis. Behcet's syndrome is characterized by bilateral recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions.

HLA B47 (Option C) Is associated with congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. It is characterized by symptoms like diarrhea, vomiting, arrhythmias, and low blood pressure.

HLA B57 (Option D) Is associated with the detection of abacavir hypersensitivity and slow progression of HIV.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best stimulus for the release of vasopressin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypotension

Explanation:

  • Vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone, ADH) is secreted by the posterior pituitary in response to key physiological changes, including hypotension (low blood pressure) and hyperosmolality of the extracellular fluid. Among the options provided, hypotension is the best stimulus for vasopressin release.
  • Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch detect a drop in blood pressure.
  • Hypotension triggers vasopressin secretion to conserve water, restore blood volume, and stabilize blood pressure.
  • Vasopressin also causes vasoconstriction to elevate blood pressure.

The most potent stimuli for vasopressin release are:

  1. Increased plasma osmolality (hyperosmolarity).
  2. Decreased blood pressure or blood volume (hypotension).

 

Hypotonicity of extracellular fluid (Option A): Hypotonicity (low osmolality) suppresses vasopressin release. The body does not need to conserve water when the plasma is dilute. Instead, water is excreted to restore normal osmolality.

Hypertension (Option B): High blood pressure inhibits vasopressin release as there is no need to conserve water or elevate pressure further.

Hypo-osmolarity of extracellular fluid (Option D): Similar to hypotonicity, hypo-osmolarity inhibits vasopressin release. This allows the kidneys to excrete more water to restore plasma osmolality.

questions.text: During recovery from anesthesia, a patient started experiencing hallucinations and vivid dreams. Which inducing agent is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ketamine

Explanation:

  • Ketamine is the most likely inducing agent responsible for the patient's hallucinations and vivid dreams. It is known to cause emergence reactions, such as hallucinations, delirium, and vivid dreams, particularly during the recovery phase. These reactions are more common in adult patients and can be distressing, but are typically short-lived.

 

Incorrect Options:

Propofol (option B) is known for its smooth induction and recovery profiles. It typically does not cause hallucinations or vivid dreams. In fact, it has anti-emetic properties and is preferred for minimizing post-operative nausea and discomfort.

Thiopentone (option C) is a barbiturate that is commonly used for induction. While it has a rapid onset, it does not typically cause hallucinations or vivid dreams. Its longer duration of action may result in a more prolonged recovery, but not in the same manner as ketamine.

Etomidate (option D) is generally associated with less frequent emergence reactions compared to ketamine. It is favoured in patients at risk for hemodynamic instability, but it does not typically cause hallucinations or vivid dreams.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who exhibits miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Horner syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light is suggestive of horner syndrome. Ptosis is a result of the weakness of Müller muscle and miosis due to the unopposed action of the sphincter pupillae with resultant anisocoria.
  • Pancoast tumor can compress the sympathetic nerves, leading to the classic triad of symptoms seen in Horner syndrome: ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and ipsilateral facial anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

Acquired Neurogenic Ptosis: Acquired ptosis with drooping of the upper eyelid caused by a disruption in the nerve supply to the muscles responsible for elevating the eyelid.

Causes:

  • Third Cranial (Oculomotor) Nerve Palsy: The third nerve can be damaged by trauma, ischemia, infection, tumor, or compression, causing ptosis and diplopia.Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis as it supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle. The ptotic eyelid can be elevated with a frontalis sling or levator aponeurosis advancement.
  • Horner's Syndrome: Involves a lesion in the sympathetic pathway, affecting the Müller’s muscle, leading to mild ptosis accompanied by miosis (pupil constriction) and anhidrosis (loss of sweating).
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine
  • Multiple Sclerosis

Diagnosis:

  • Topical apraclonidine test is now considered the test of choice. Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that also acts as a very weak alpha 1-adrenergic agonist; when topically applied in Horner’s syndrome, it causes dilation of the affected pupil and possibly lid elevation, without change to the normal pupil.

Incorrect Options

Adie’s tonic people (Option A) It is a unilateral condition and is characterized by anisocoria (different size of pupil) and direct light reflex is sluggish or absent.

Marcus gunn pupil (Option C) Aka relative afferent pupillary defect is characterized by paradoxical dilatation of both the pupil when light is flashed on the diseased eye.

Argyll Robertson pupil (Option D) It is a specific sign of late-stage syphilis. The bilaterally small pupils do not constrict when exposed to bright light.

questions.text: What is required for the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calcium

Explanation:

Calcium ions (Ca²⁺) are essential for the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin. Calcium is required for the activation of several coagulation factors, including prothrombin (factor II) in the presence of factor Xa and factor Va, forming the prothrombinase complex.

The conversion of prothrombin to thrombin is a crucial step in the coagulation cascade. It occurs in the common pathway of coagulation. Here’s a brief explanation of the process:

  • Activation of Factor X: In the presence of calcium (Ca²⁺), Factor X is activated to Factor Xa by the prothrombinase complex (which consists of Factor Xa, Factor Va, phospholipids, and calcium).
  • Prothrombinase Complex: Factor Xa, in the presence of Factor Va and calcium, activates prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa).
  • Thrombin Formation: Thrombin (Factor IIa) is the enzyme responsible for converting fibrinogen into fibrin, leading to the formation of a blood clot.

 

Magnesium (Option B): Magnesium is important in various enzymatic reactions but is not involved in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

Potassium (Option C): Potassium does not play a role in the coagulation cascade, including the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

Sodium (Option D): Sodium also does not have a direct role in the coagulation process or the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

questions.text: Which statement below does not accurately describe the clinical condition mentioned?

choices.text: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue
Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen
Destruction of Bowman’s layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctivaoccur.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Destruction of Bowman’s layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea:

Explanation:

  • This statement is not characteristic of pterygium. Bowman's layer is not typically invaded by the pterygium. The pterygium tends to grow over the cornea but does not penetrate Bowman's layer. Instead, it grows between the layers of the cornea, causing distortion and irritation.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue: This statement is correct. Pterygium is associated with abnormal p53 expression, which is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a role in regulating cell growth and preventing the formation of tumors.

Option B - Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen: This statement is correct. Pterygium is associated with an imbalance in the activity of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs), leading to excessive tissue remodeling.

Option D - Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur: This statement is correct. Pterygium is characterized by elastotic degeneration, which refers to the accumulation of abnormal elastic tissue, and hyalinization, which involves the deposition of a substance called hyaline, in the conjunctival tissue.

questions.text: How do local anesthetics work?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Block sodium channels

Explanation:

  • Local anesthetics work by blocking sodium channels in the nerve cells. This action inhibits the influx of sodium ions during depolarization, preventing the generation and propagation of action potentials along nerve fibers. Without the ability to generate action potentials, the sensation of pain (or any other nerve signal) is blocked, leading to a localized numbing effect.

 

Incorrect Options:

Block potassium channels (option B): Potassium channels play a role in repolarizing the membrane after an action potential. While important in the process of nerve conduction, local anesthetics primarily target sodium channels rather than potassium channels to block nerve transmission.

Block calcium channels (option C): Calcium channels are involved in neurotransmitter release at synapses, but they are not the primary target of local anesthetics. While calcium ions are involved in nerve signaling, local anesthetics specifically block sodium channels to prevent the initiation and propagation of action potentials.

Block chloride channels (option D): Chloride channels are involved in maintaining the resting membrane potential and controlling cell volume, but they are not directly blocked by local anesthetics. The primary mechanism of local anesthetics is the blockade of sodium channels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and spasticity in his right leg. He also notices increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign on the same side. His left leg and upper limbs appear unaffected. MRI of the brain reveals a lesion involving the left motor cortex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Right-sided upper motor neuron lesion.

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms—progressive weakness, spasticity, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign on the right leg—indicate signs of upper motor neuron (UMN) involvement. UMN lesions typically cause spasticity, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign on the side of the lesion.
  • The MRI shows a lesion in the left motor cortex, which controls motor function on the opposite (right) side of the body due to the crossing of motor pathways in the brain. This reinforces the diagnosis of a right-sided UMN lesion.

 

Parkinson's disease (Option A): Parkinson's disease primarily affects the basal ganglia and causes symptoms like bradykinesia, resting tremor, and rigidity. It doesn't cause the focal spasticity, hyperreflexia, and Babinski sign observed in this patient.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) (Option B): ALS affects both upper and lower motor neurons. The patient’s presentation of isolated UMN signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia) and no signs of lower motor neuron involvement (such as atrophy or fasciculations) makes ALS less likely.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) (Option C): MS typically causes relapsing-remitting neurological symptoms with demyelinating lesions in the central nervous system, but the patient’s progressive weakness and focal findings on MRI suggest a more localized lesion, not the typical pattern of MS.

questions.text: Which is the anesthesia of choice in a daycare dental surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Infiltration anesthesia

Explanation:

  • Infiltration anesthesiais typically the anesthesia of choice for daycare dental surgeries. This type of local anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic directly into the tissue around the area where the procedure will take place. It numbs only the specific area of the mouth, making it ideal for dental procedures that do not require deep sedation or general anesthesia. The patient remains awake and alert, making it suitable for daycare procedures, allowing for quick recovery.

 

Incorrect Options:

General anesthesia (option A): While general anesthesia can be used in some dental surgeries, it is not typically required for routine daycare procedures, which are often short and localized. General anesthesia carries more risks and requires longer recovery time, making it less ideal for minor dental work.

Spinal anesthesia (option B) is usually reserved for surgeries involving the lower half of the body, such as abdominal or lower limb surgeries. It is not commonly used for dental procedures, which are localized to the mouth.


Epidural anesthesia (option C) is also typically used for surgeries involving the lower body (such as cesarean sections or lower extremity surgeries) and is not necessary for dental procedures. Like spinal anesthesia, it involves more extensive procedures and recovery time.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

  • The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) which helps in lacrimal drainage.

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the definitive surgical procedure designed to create a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, thus resolving the obstruction and restoring proper tear drainage. This approach addresses the underlying blockage and prevents recurrence.

Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  1. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

 

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later.
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage.
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age.

Dacryocystectomy (Option B)This procedure involves the removal of the lacrimal sac and is usually reserved for lacrimal sac fibrosis..

Probing (Option C) It is a common treatment approach for congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants.

Balloon catheter dilation (Option D) This procedure is used in some cases to dilate and open a partially blocked nasolacrimal duct but may not be the primary choice for chronic dacryocystitis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The X ray of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intussusception

Explanation:

  • Intussusception is a medical condition in which one segment of the intestine telescopes into another segment, causing an obstruction.
  • In a barium enema procedure (as shown in the image), intussusception may appear as a characteristic ‘claw sign’ appearance, where the affected segment of the intestine invaginates into the adjacent segment. This is due to the filling defect it creates for the enema.

Intussusception

  • Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into another, often leading to bowel obstruction and ischemia.
  • It is a common cause of acute abdomen in children, while in adults, it is typically associated with a focal lesion acting as a lead point.
  • The classic clinical presentation of intussusception in children may include intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and a palpable "sausage-like" mass in the right upper quadrant, although these symptoms occur in less than 20% of cases.
  • Parents may also report "currant jelly" stools, indicating bowel ischemia, and approximately 15% of patients may present without abdominal pain.
  • Plain Radiograph:
    • Elongated soft tissue mass in the upper right quadrant.
    • Bowel obstruction with air-fluid levels and proximal bowel dilation.
    • Possible absence of gas in the distal collapsed bowel.
  • Fluoroscopy:
    • Gold standard is the contrast enema, showing the intussusception as an occluding mass.
    • Characteristic "coiled spring sign."

Fig. Coiled spring sign

  • Ultrasound:
    • Target sign (doughnut sign)- Concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechoic bands are observed, where the echogenic bands represent the serosa and submucosa, flanking the hypoechoic muscularis propria.
  • Pseudokidney sign- Longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted segment of bowel which mimics a kidney
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.
  • Absence of blood flow in the intussusceptum (contraindication for enema).
  • Features favoring ileocolic intussusception: hyperechoic core, thicker outer hypoechoic wall, larger anteroposterior diameter, and presence of lymph nodes.
  • CT Scan:
    • Characteristic "bowel-within-bowel" configuration.
    • Concentric rings of bowel on axial images, and sausage-shaped mass on longitudinal images.
    • Visualization of the lead point if present, with surrounding mesenteric fat and vessels.

Volvulus (Option B) refers to the twisting or rotation of a portion of the intestine, leading to obstruction of the blood supply and potential bowel strangulation. In a barium enema, volvulus may appear as a characteristic "bird's beak" or "corkscrew" appearance.

Diverticulitis (Option C) is the inflammation or infection of small pouches called diverticula that can develop in the colon. During a barium enema, diverticulitis may present as localized outpouching or sac-like structures filled with barium. Inflammation and thickening of the bowel wall may be visible, and in severe cases, abscesses or fistulas may be observed.

Ulcerative Colitis (Option D) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon and rectum. In a barium enema, ulcerative colitis may show diffuse inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa. The bowel wall may appear thickened, with loss of haustral markings (the characteristic folds of the colon) and a coarse or granular appearance. The extent and severity of the disease can be evaluated using barium enema imaging.

questions.text: In ORS, sodium is given along with glucose to facilitate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Co-transport

Explanation:

  • In Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS), sodium is given along with glucose because sodium-glucose co-transport helps in the absorption of both sodium and glucose across the intestinal epithelium.
  • The presence of glucose enhances the active transport of sodium through the sodium-glucose transporter (SGLT1) in the intestinal cells. This, in turn, increases the absorption of both sodium and water.

Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) absorption:

The absorption of Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) occurs primarily in the small intestine and is facilitated by the co-transport of sodium and glucose. Here's a brief explanation of the process:

  1. Sodium-glucose co-transport:
    • In the small intestine, glucose and sodium are absorbed together through a co-transporter called SGLT1 (Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1).
    • The presence of glucose helps facilitate the active absorption of sodium. The sodium-glucose co-transporter uses the sodium gradient (created by the sodium-potassium pump) to transport both sodium and glucose into the epithelial cells of the intestinal lining.
  2. Water absorption:
    • As sodium and glucose are absorbed into the epithelial cells, they create an osmotic gradient, which leads to water being absorbed into the bloodstream through osmosis.
    • The movement of sodium into the cells triggers water to follow through osmosis, thus replenishing lost fluids.
  3. Effect on dehydration:
    • The combined absorption of sodium, glucose, and water effectively rehydrates the body, replenishing both electrolytes and fluids lost during diarrhea or vomiting.

 

Osmosis (Option B): Osmosis refers to the movement of water across a semipermeable membrane from an area of low solute concentration to an area of high solute concentration, but it doesn't directly explain the role of glucose in ORS.

Facilitated diffusion (Option C): This involves the transport of substances across a membrane through a carrier protein, but glucose and sodium in ORS rely on co-transport, not facilitated diffusion.

Primary active transport (Option D): This type of transport requires energy (ATP) to move substances against their concentration gradient, but sodium-glucose co-transport relies on a secondary active transport mechanism, not primary active transport.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chalazion clamp

Explanation:

  • The above instrument is a chalazion clamp because there is a solid blade (to be kept externally on the skin). There is a ring-shaped blade that needs to be placed on the inner conjunctival surface.
  • The handle has a thumbscrew, which can be tightened and released to achieve the required pressure. There is a forceps-like handle. After aligning the position to enclose the chalazion in the ring, the clamp is tightened and fixed.

Evisceration spatula (Option A) Used for removing only intraocular contents leaving the sclera and muscles of the eye intact.

Enucleation spoon (Option C) Used to remove entire intraocular contents from the eye socket leaving the lining and muscle of the eye intact.

questions.text:
​ What is the cause of the following appearance in IVP?

 ​​ ​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ureterocoele

Explanation:

Ureterocoele is a congenital abnormality where the lower end of the ureter balloons out and forms a cyst-like structure. In an IVP, ureterocoele can be seen as a filling defect or a dilated portion of the ureter. It may cause obstruction to urine flow and can be associated with hydronephrosis.

Ureterocele

USG showing cystic pouching at left and right ureteral orifices

Bilateral “Cobra head” appearance of distal ureters on X-ray Intravenous Urography

Horseshoe Kidney (Option A) is a congenital condition in which the lower poles of both kidneys are fused together, forming a U-shaped structure. In an Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP), horseshoe kidney may be visualized as a single mass or "horseshoe-shaped" structure in the midline of the abdomen.

Bladder Tumor (Option C): Bladder tumors refer to abnormal growths of tissue in the bladder, which may be benign or malignant (cancerous). In an IVP, bladder tumors can appear as filling defects or irregularities within the bladder. These abnormalities may cause partial or complete obstruction of the bladder outlet, and the IVP can help identify the location, size, and extent of the tumor.

Posterior Urethral Valve (Option D) is a congenital abnormality that occurs in male infants where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the urethra, obstructing urine flow. In an IVP, the posterior urethral valve may manifest as dilatation of the urethra and the urinary bladder. The IVP can demonstrate the extent of the obstruction, any associated hydronephrosis, and the impact on the urinary tract.

questions.text: What is the clinical presentation of a patient with a tumor located in the anterior pituitary gland causing compression on the optic chiasma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bitemporal hemianopia:

  • Bitemporal hemianopia is usually caused by tumors in the region of the sella turcica, pressure by a suprasellar aneurysm, or chronic arachnoiditis; these press upon the chiasma, so that the fibers going to the nasal halves of each retina are destroyed.

  • So a tumor in the anterior pituitary pressing on the optic chiasma will present as a case of Bitemporal hemianopia.

Pituitary adenoma:

The most common visual defect associated with Pituitary Adenoma is Bitemporal hemianopia, which results from the compression of Binasal fibres that cross at the Optic Chiasma.

  • It is the most common Suprasellar mass in adults.

  • Classification:

    • Microadenomas: <10 mm; often incidental or present with endocrine symptoms.

    • Macroadenomas: >10 mm; may cause visual field deficits due to mass effect.

  • Common Types:

    • Prolactinomas: 30% of cases present with amenorrhea and galactorrhea.

    • Non-functioning Adenomas: 20%; no hormone secretion.

    • Growth Hormone-Secreting Adenomas: 15%; causes acromegaly.

    • ACTH-Secreting Adenomas: 10% leads to Cushing's disease.

  • Clinical features:

    • Visual Defect: Compression of the optic chiasm often causes bitemporal hemianopia.

    • Endocrine Symptoms: Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and other hormonal imbalances.

  • Imaging and diagnosis involve MRI as the primary modality, along with serum prolactin and thyroid function tests and visual field charting.

  • Treatment:

    • Medical management

      • Prolactinomas: Dopamine agonists (e.g., bromocriptine, cabergoline).

      • Growth Hormone-Secreting Tumors: Somatostatin analogues (e.g., octreotide).

  • Surgical management

    • Transsphenoidal Approach: Preferred for most cases; craniotomy may be needed for large tumours.

    • Sublabial Approach

    • Indications: Acute visual deterioration, GH-secreting tumours, Cushing's disease, or large non-functioning adenomas causing symptoms.

  • Complications:

    • Pituitary Apoplexy: Sudden haemorrhage or infarction in the tumour, presenting with headache, visual loss, and ophthalmoplegia.

    • Postoperative Risks: CSF leaks, pituitary insufficiency, and diabetes insipidus.

Incorrect Options:

Homonymous hemianopia (Option A) is caused by post chiasmal lesions like optic tract, optic radiations, and visual cortex lesions.

Inferior quadrantanopia hemianopia (Option B) It is caused by a lesion of the fibers of the optic radiations in the anterior parietal lobe.

Superior quadrantanopia hemianopia (Option D) It is caused by a lesion of the fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe.

questions.text: Which glycosaminoglycan is responsible for the transparency of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratan sulfate

Explanation:

  • Keratan sulfate and chondroitin sulfate are the major glycosaminoglycan present in the corneal stroma. They exist in the proteoglycan form and are responsible for maintaining the space between the regularly oriented layers of collagen fibrils in the stroma.

Locations of Various Mucopolysaccharides

Mucopolysaccharide

Primary Locations

Functions

Hyaluronic Acid (Option B)

Connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, vitreous humor

Serves as a lubricant in joint cavities and contributes to the structure of connective tissues

Heparin (Option C)

Liver, lungs, spleen, monocytes

Acts as an anticoagulant by activating antithrombin III, which inactivates thrombin and other clotting factors

Chondroitin Sulfate

Cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, skin

Provides structural support to connective tissues and contributes to their resilience and elasticity

Keratan Sulfate (Option A)

Cornea, cartilage

 

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Skin, blood vessels, heart valves

Contributes to the structure of the skin, blood vessels, and heart valves

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has a previous history of wearing contact lenses, and is currently experiencing pain, redness, and the presence of pus coming from his right eye? During examination, a greyish-white ulcer in the shape of a snake was observed on the lower portion of the cornea. Additionally, a hypopyon measuring 4 mm was found in the anterior chamber, along with a moderate flare reaction.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bacterial corneal ulcer

Explanation:

  • Bacterial corneal ulcers present with redness, pain, and discharge. Signs include a greyish-white serpiginous ulcer seen over the lower third of the cornea, indicative of the bacteria

Aetiology of Purulent Corneal Ulcer:

  • Corneal Epithelial Damage:

    • Due to Corneal abrasion, epithelial drying (xerosis, exposure keratitis), necrosis (keratomalacia), desquamation (bullous keratopathy), and trophic changes (neuroparalytic keratitis).

  • Pathogens Invading Intact Epithelium:

    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus aegyptius, Listeria species.

  • Sources of Infection:

    • Exogenous Sources: Conjunctival sac, lacrimal sac (dacryocystitis), infected foreign bodies, vegetative material, waterborne or airborne infections.

  • Common Bacteria Associated with Corneal Ulceration:

    • General: Staphylococci, Pseudomonas, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Enterobacteriaceae, Neisseria.

    • In Contact Lens Wearers: Pseudomonas is the most common cause. Acanthamoeba is another differential in contact lens misuse.

  • All causative organisms:

    • Gram-positive Cocci: Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae.

    • Gram-negative Cocci: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Neisseria meningitidis.

    • Gram-positive Bacilli: Corynebacterium diphtheriae, C. xerosis, Bacillus cereus, Propionibacterium acne, Listeria, Clostridium.

    • Gram-negative Bacilli: Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, Proteus, E. coli, Serratia), Moraxella lacunata, Haemophilus influenzae.

    • Gram-positive Filamentous Bacteria: Actinomyces, Nocardia.

    • Mycobacteria: Non-tuberculous mycobacteria, M. tuberculosis.

Clinical Features of Bacterial Corneal Ulcers:

Symptoms:

  • Pain and foreign body sensation.

  • Watery eye (reflex hyper lacrimation).

  • Photophobia (light intolerance).

  • Blurred vision.

  • Redness of the eye.

Signs:

  • Lid swelling.

  • Blepharospasm (lid twitching).

  • Conjunctival chemosis and hyperemia.

  • Corneal ulcer characteristics:

    • Early stage: Epithelial defect with greyish-white infiltrate.

    • Established: Yellowish-white ulcer, swollen margins, necrotic floor, stromal oedema.

  • Specific bacterial features:

    • Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pneumoniae: Oval, yellowish-white ulcer surrounded by clear cornea.

    • Pseudomonas species: Irregular ulcer with greenish exudate, rapid spread, often with hypopyon.

    • Enterobacteriaceae: Shallow ulcer with greyish-white suppuration, ring-shaped infiltrate.

  • The anterior chamber may contain pus (Hypopyon).

  • Muddy iris colour.

  • Small pupil due to iritis.

  • Possible raised intraocular pressure (inflammatory glaucoma).

Incorrect Options

Viral corneal ulcer (Option A) It is caused due to low immunity. A red, watery, and bloodshot eye is a prominent feature. There is severe eye pain and pus or other eye discharge. This can lead to vision loss and blindness.

Fungal corneal ulcer (Option C) Trauma is one of the causes of Fungal corneal ulcer. There is less pain and Hypopyon if present is thick and immobile.

Parasitic corneal ulcer (Option D) Is characterized by disproportionately severe pain and is caused by either contact lens wear or exposure to contaminated water.

questions.text: A smoker who underwent an interscalene block for an arthroscopic acromioclavicular joint reconstruction 2 days ago presents for a follow-up. A chest X-ray is performed, which shows an abnormality. The patient is asymptomatic and is resting comfortably in bed. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Insert chest drain as soon as possible
Wait and watch and give supplementary oxygen if needed

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Wait and watch and give supplementary oxygen if needed

Explanation:

  • Given that the patient is asymptomatic and resting comfortably, the most appropriate course of action is close observation. This approach ensures that any changes in the patient's condition are promptly identified. If the patient develops any signs of respiratory distress or hypoxia, supplementary oxygen can be administered as necessary.

Key points:

  • The patient’s asymptomatic status suggests that immediate intervention is not required.
  • Close monitoring helps detect any subtle signs of complications such as pneumothorax or diaphragmatic paralysis.
  • Supplementary oxygen can be provided if respiratory symptoms emerge, ensuring optimal management in case the patient becomes symptomatic.

 

Incorrect Options:

Insert chest drain as soon as possible (Option A): Since the patient is asymptomatic and comfortably resting, there is no indication for immediate chest drain insertion.

Do thoracostomy (Option B): Thoracostomy is not necessary in this case as there are no indications of a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Elective intubation and IPPV (Option C): Elective intubation and invasive positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) are not warranted in this scenario as the patient is asymptomatic and comfortably resting.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male comes with complaints of dry cough, fever and shortness of breath for 2 days along with a loss of taste and smell. He is a social worker who has been traveling a lot. What would be the investigation of choice for this patient to confirm the diagnosis of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Real-time RT-PCR

Explanation:

Real-time RT-PCR is the gold standard for confirming COVID-19, as it detects viral RNA in respiratory samples with high sensitivity and specificity, allowing early detection even in asymptomatic cases.

Real-Time RT-PCR for COVID-19 Diagnosis

  • Real-time reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) is the gold standard for diagnosing COVID-19.
  • Turnaround Time: The average time from sample receipt to result generation is approximately 4-5 hours.
  • Capacity: Can process up to 90 samples in a single run, making it efficient for frontline testing.
  • Gene Targets:
    • Screening (Genus Specific):
      • Spike protein (S)
      • Envelope protein (E)
      • Membrane protein (M)
      • Nucleocapsid protein (N)
    • Confirmation (Species Specific for SARS-CoV-2):
      • RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp)
      • Open reading frames (ORF1a/b)
      • N2 nucleocapsid
  • Principle of Testing:
    • Qualitative real-time PCR amplifies target genes in the specimen using a thermocycler.
    • Fluorescence is generated when the amplicon binds to the probe, with the cycle threshold (Ct) indicating positivity.
    • A sample is considered positive if both screening and confirmatory genes are detected with a Ct value ≤ 40 cycles.
  • Detectability: NAAT can be positive as early as day 1 of symptom onset (usually 5 days post-infection) and generally declines by the third week, often becoming undetectable thereafter.

Automated Real-Time RT-PCR

  • Systems include Truenat and CBNAAT (Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test, e.g., GeneXpert).
  • Widely accessible
  • Turnaround Time: Quick results in 30-60 minutes.
  • Automation: Fully automated with minimal handling, reducing biosafety hazards.
  • Gene Targets:
    • CBNAAT: E gene for screening, N2 gene for confirmation.
    • Truenat: E gene for screening, RdRp gene for confirmation.
  • Disadvantages: Limited to 1-4 samples per run, suitable for low sample loads (24-48 samples/day).

Antigen Detection

  • Rapid chromatographic immunoassay (SD Biosensor) for qualitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein.
  • Sample Collection: Nasopharyngeal swab immersed in viral extraction buffer to inactivate the virus and release the antigen.
  • Point-of-Care Testing: Conducted at the bedside within one hour; antigen stability is limited to one hour.
  • Performance: Highly specific (99–100%) but moderate sensitivity (50–84%); symptomatic but negative patients should be referred for RT-PCR testing.

Blood Findings:

  • Increased IL-6 Levels: This suggests a cytokine storm.
  • Elevated D-dimer: Indicates high levels of fibrin degradation products, suggesting an underlying coagulopathy.
  • Raised Serum Ferritin: This is a marker of inflammation.
  • Severe Lymphopenia: Indicates a significant reduction in lymphocyte count.
  • Increased C-reactive Protein (CRP): This serves as a marker of acute inflammation.

Viral Transport Medium:

  • HBSS with Ca, Mg ions
  • Gentamycin, Amphotericin B
  • Fetal Bovine Serum
  • Storage is at 4℃

PCR (Option A) (Polymerase chain reaction) is not specific enough for COVID-19 diagnosis, as it does not necessarily involve reverse transcription for RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2.

ELISA (Option B): ELISA detects antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 but is not useful for early diagnosis since antibodies take time to develop and are more helpful for determining past infection or immune response.

Serology (Option C): Serology measures IgG and IgM antibodies, which indicate past infection rather than an active case, making it unsuitable for acute COVID-19 diagnosis, especially in the first few days of symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proximal tubule

Explanation:

  • The majority of water reabsorption occurs in the proximal tubule.
  • Approximately 65-70% of the filtered water is reabsorbed here, along with sodium, glucose, and other substances.
  • This is mainly through osmosis, driven by the reabsorption of solutes like sodium.

The proximal tubule is the first part of the nephron where most of the reabsorption of water, electrolytes, and nutrients occurs. Here's a brief overview of the process:

  1. Filtration: Blood is filtered in the glomerulus, and the filtrate enters the proximal tubule. This filtrate contains water, sodium, glucose, urea, and other small molecules.
  2. Reabsorption in the proximal tubule:
    • Water reabsorption: Approximately 65-70% of the filtered water is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. This process occurs passively through osmosis, driven by the active reabsorption of solutes like sodium, glucose, and bicarbonate. As these solutes are actively reabsorbed into the bloodstream, water follows to maintain osmotic balance.
    • Sodium, glucose, and bicarbonate: Along with water, sodium, glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate are also reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. This is vital for maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance.
  3. Mechanism: The proximal tubule cells have sodium-potassium ATPase pumps that create a sodium gradient, allowing sodium (and other solutes) to be actively transported into the interstitial space. Water follows passively due to osmosis.

 

Loop of Henle (Option B): The loop of Henle plays an important role in the concentration of urine, with the descending limb being permeable to water (where water is reabsorbed), and the ascending limb being impermeable to water. However, only about 20-25% of water reabsorption occurs here.

Distal convoluted tubule (Option C): The distal convoluted tubule contributes to fine-tuning the reabsorption of sodium and water, but it is not the primary site of water reabsorption.
