A small amount of water is reabsorbed under the influence of hormones like aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH).

Collecting duct (Option D): The collecting duct also contributes to water reabsorption, especially under the influence of ADH, but it is not the site of maximum water reabsorption. The final concentration of urine occurs here, depending on the body's hydration status.

questions.text: Which molecular motor protein results in spread of the rabies virus from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dynein

Explanation:

  • Dynein is the molecular motor protein responsible for the retrograde transport of the rabies virus along microtubules from the site of inoculation (such as at a peripheral nerve) to the central nervous system (CNS). The virus uses dynein to move towards the cell body of the neuron after entering via the peripheral nervous system.

Spread of the rabies virus from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system:

  • The rabies virus spreads from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system (CNS) through retrograde axonal transport.
  • Once the virus enters the peripheral nerves, it binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on the nerve terminals.
  • The virus is then transported along the microtubules of the neuron by the dynein motor protein.
  • Dynein moves the virus towards the cell body of the neuron and eventually to the CNS, where it causes encephalitis.
  • This retrograde transport mechanism is key to the spread of rabies to the brain.

 

Kinesin (Option A): Kinesins are involved in anterograde transport (moving materials away from the cell body towards the axon terminals), which is not the mechanism used by the rabies virus to spread to the CNS.

Actin (Option C): Actin filaments play a role in cell shape and movement but are not involved in the transport of the rabies virus. Actin-based movement is important for some other types of viral spread, such as with certain enteric viruses.

Myosin (Option D): Myosin is primarily involved in muscle contraction and also in some cell movement processes, but it does not play a role in viral transport, particularly for the rabies virus.

questions.text: What is the medical condition of a tennis player who is able to repeatedly and independently reduce a shoulder dislocation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Recurrent shoulder dislocation

Explanation:

  • Recurrent Shoulder Dislocation occurs due to repeated dislocations, often with joint instability or capsular laxity. This patient can reduce the dislocation independently due to muscle memory or prior experience. It is common in athletes, especially those involved in overhead sports like tennis.
  • Recurrent shoulder dislocation is the most common complication following an initial dislocation.
  • It occurs due to repeated trauma, capsular laxity, bone changes, muscle weakness, inadequate rehabilitation, or high-risk activities.
  • Hill-Sachs and Bankart lesions, associated with shoulder dislocations, contribute to joint instability and increase the risk of recurrence.

Complications of Shoulder Dislocation:

Early Complications

Delayed Complications
  • Rotator cuff tear - Common in the elderly due to degenerative changes in the tendons and less common in younger patients.
  • Axillary artery injury - Rare; Occurs with severe trauma
  • Nerve injury - The axillary nerve is most commonly affected; other nerve injuries and complete brachial plexus palsy are rare.
  • Recurrence - Most common, due to instability.
  • Joint stiffness - Results from prolonged immobility.
  • Unreduced dislocation - Due to missed or undiagnosed dislocation.

 

Acute Shoulder Dislocation (Option A) refers to a single episode of dislocation, typically requiring immediate reduction. The patient would not be able to repeatedly reduce it independently, making this option incorrect.

Inferior Shoulder Dislocation (Option C): Rare and occurs when the humeral head is displaced downward. It typically results from significant trauma and would not be easily reduced independently.

Fracture of Upper End Humerus (Option D) involves a fracture of the humeral head or neck, which may mimic dislocation but wouldn't allow the patient to repeatedly reduce the dislocation independently. Fractures require different management and do not typically present with recurrent dislocations.

questions.text:
The egg shown below belongs to?

 ​​ ​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Whipworm

Explanation:

Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura) eggs are barrel-shaped with bipolar plugs (mucoid plugs at both ends) as shown in the image.

Trichuris trichiura / Whip worm

Morphology

Adult worm
  • The male worm is 30-45 mm long.
  • The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger).
  • Appearance:
    • Flesh-colored.
    • Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle).
    • The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally.
    • The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded.
  • Body structure:
    • The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus.
    • The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs.
  • Lifespan: 5-10 years.

Eggs

Characteristics:

  • The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained.
  • They are barrel-shaped.
  • They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum.

Infectivity:

  • Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans.
  • The egg floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day.

Epidemiology
  • Distribution:
    • Worldwide, with higher prevalence in tropical regions.
    • Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia.
    • Widespread in India.
  • Prevalence:
    • An estimated 800 million people are infected globally.
    • While whipworm infections are frequent, whipworm disease is relatively rare.

Pathogenicity:

  • The incubation period is 70 to 90 days.
  • Transmission:
    • The infective stage is the embryonated eggs, which carry the rhabditiform larvae
    • The mode of transmission is by contaminated food or water.
    • The swallowed eggs hatch into larvae in the small intestine.
    • Adult female worms live in the cecum and lay eggs that are excreted in the feces.

The life cycle of Trichuris trichiura:

  • Man is the only natural host for T.trichiura and the egg develops in the soil.
  • There is no intermediate host.

Clinical features:

  • Generally asymptomatic unless the worm load is heavy.
  • Potential issues arise from mechanical effects or allergic reactions.
  • Abdominal pain and anorexia.
  • Trichuris dysentery syndrome: bloody or mucoid.
  • Iron deficiency anemia: due to blood loss.
  • Recurrent rectal prolapse: due to heavy worm load in the rectum.
  • Malnutrition causes growth retardation.
  • Cognitive impairment: due to inflammatory cytokines induced by Trichuris species.

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Stool Examination:
    • Conducted through direct wet mount or stool concentration methods.
    • A single stool specimen is typically sufficient for diagnosing symptomatic cases due to high egg output.
    • Egg characteristics:
      • Measure approximately 50 × 22 µm.
      • Barrel-shaped with mucus plugs at both ends.
      • Bile-stained and capable of floating in a saturated salt solution.
  • Adult worm characteristics:
    • Whip-shaped, measuring 3–5 cm long.
    • The anterior three-fifths is thin and coiled, resembling a rope, while the posterior two-fifths is short and thick.
  • Other findings:
    • Peripheral blood eosinophilia (typically less than 15%).
    • Increased serum IgE levels.
  • Colonoscopy:
    • The adult worms are seen attached to the mucosa, giving a characteristic “coconut cake rectum” appearance.

Management of trichuriasis:

  • Mebendazole:
    • 500 mg as a single dose
    • It is only moderately effective, with cure rates of 70-90%.
  • Albendazole:
    • 400 mg daily for three doses.
    • It is safe and effective.
  • Ivermectin:
    • 200 mg/kg daily for three doses.
    • It is safe but less effective.

Hookworm (Option A): Eggs are oval, thin-shelled, and segmented with a smooth surface.

Pinworm (Option C): Enterobius vermicularis eggs are oval, flattened on one side, and asymmetrical with a thin shell.

Roundworm (Option D): Ascaris lumbricoides eggs have a thick, mammillated (bumpy) shell in their fertilized form.

questions.text: An AIDS-positive patient came with a history of fever, vomiting, and meningismus. Which of the following tests help in the rapid diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis?

choices.text: Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

Explanation:

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen is a rapid, highly sensitive, and specific for cryptococcal antigen detection. It can detect antigen even before symptoms develop in AIDS patients. It is the best for rapid bedside diagnosis in resource-limited settings.

Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system

  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections

 

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen- Best rapid diagnostic test.

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

India Ink Preparation of CSF (Option A):

  • Detects the capsulated yeast Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF.
  • Useful but low sensitivity, especially in cases with low fungal burden.

Blood Culture (Option B):

  • Can grow Cryptococcus in disseminated cases but takes several days.
  • Not a rapid diagnostic method.

CSF Culture (Option C):

  • Gold standard but time-consuming (takes 3-7 days).
  • Requires Sabouraud dextrose agar for fungal growth.

questions.text: Except in which of the following is laryngeal crepitus not present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prevertebral Abscess

Explanation:

  • Laryngeal crepitus refers to the movement of the larynx over the cervical spine during swallowing. It is absent when the larynx is fixed due to an underlying pathology. In a prevertebral abscess, infection spreads in the prevertebral space, restricting the mobility of the larynx, thus abolishing crepitus.

Laryngeal Crepitus and Its Absence

Condition

Laryngeal Crepitus Presence

Reason

Post-cricoid malignancy

Present (unless advanced)

Tumors in this area usually do not fix the larynx early

Hypopharyngeal abscess

Present or reduced

May affect laryngeal movement but not always abolish crepitus

Parapharyngeal abscess

Present or reduced

Can restrict lateral movement but does not fix larynx completely

Prevertebral abscess

Absent

Fixes the larynx to the spine, preventing movement

Incorrect Options:

Post-cricoid malignancy (Option A): is incorrect because early-stage malignancies do not fix the larynx. Crepitus is lost only in advanced cases where the tumor invades deeper tissues.

Hypopharyngeal abscess (Option B): is incorrect because while it can partially restrict laryngeal movement, crepitus is not always completely absent unless the abscess is large.

Parapharyngeal abscess (Option C): is incorrect because this abscess is lateral to the larynx and does not always cause fixation. However, extensive cases may restrict movement.

questions.text: What is the probable cause of bleeding in a patient who experienced a hyphema after being struck in the eye by a tennis ball?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior ciliary artery

Explanation:

  • In the case of a patient who sustains an eye injury from a tennis ball and develops hyphema (bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye), the likely source of bleeding is the anterior ciliary artery.
  • Anterior ciliary arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery that supply blood to the anterior segment of the eye, including the conjunctiva, sclera, and iris. These arteries can be injured in cases of trauma to the eye.

Blood Supply of the Eye:

Structure

Arterial Supply

Cornea

Avascular

Conjunctiva

Anterior ciliary arteries, branches of ophthalmic artery

Sclera

Posterior ciliary arteries (short and long branches) (Option C)

Iris

Major arterial circle of the iris (circulus arteriosus major) (Option A) formed by anterior ciliary and long posterior ciliary arteries

Ciliary Body

Anterior ciliary arteries and long posterior ciliary arteries

Choroid

Short posterior ciliary arteries

Retina

Central retinal artery

Lens

Avascular

Extraocular Muscles

Muscular branches of the ophthalmic artery (including anterior ciliary arteries)

Eyelids

Ophthalmic artery (superior and inferior palpebral branches), facial artery

Lacrimal Gland

Lacrimal artery

Circulus arteriosus minor (Option D) There is no anatomical structure known as the circulus arteriosus minor. It is an incorrect option.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with Bell's palsy, who is experiencing symptoms of dry eye, redness, and irritation, along with the presence of multiple punctate epithelial erosions in the cornea as observed through a slit lamp examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tarsorrhaphy:

Explanation:

  • In the case of an elderly patient with Bell's palsy who presents with dry eye, redness, and irritation, along with multiple punctate epithelial erosions in the cornea, the most appropriate management option is Tarsorrhaphy.

  • It is a surgical procedure in which the eyelids are partially sewn together to reduce the exposure of the cornea.

Paralytic Ectropion:

  • Cause: Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s), Trauma/surgery

  • Clinical Feature: Exposure keratopathy

  • Treatment:

    • Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy.

    • Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation

Incorrect Options:

Contact lens (Option B) As the cornea is already eroded contact lenses should be avoided

Corneal replacement (Option C), such as corneal transplantation or corneal grafting is not recommended because Bell's palsy will result in exposure keratopathy.

LASIK (Option D) (laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis) is a refractive surgery procedure used to correct myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old woman who is experiencing sudden eye pain and redness? An image of her eye is provided for reference.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute angle-closure glaucoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a 50-year-old female presenting with an acute painful red-eye and an image showing redness and congestion which gives a diagnosis of Acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma:

  • Acute angle-closure glaucoma is a sudden and severe form of glaucoma characterized by a rapid increase in intraocular pressure. It occurs when the drainage angle of the eye becomes blocked, leading to a buildup of fluid and pressure within the eye.

Clinical features of Glaucoma are:

  1. Sudden Painful eye.

  2. A ciliary flush around the cornea due to dilated ciliary veins, and in long-standing cases, caput medusae with prominent vessels.

  3. Cornea - initially clear but insensitive, later becoming hazy, with epithelial bullae (bullous keratopathy) or filaments (filamentary keratitis).

  4. Headache and nausea: Some individuals may experience accompanying headache, nausea, and even vomiting.

  5. Anterior chamber - very shallow.

  6. Iris - atrophic.

  7. Pupil - fixed and dilated.

  8. Optic disc - glaucomatous optic atrophy.

  9. IOP is high and the eyeball becomes stony hard.

Management of absolute glaucoma

In absolute glaucoma, the goal of treatment is to relieve pain and reduce IOP, as vision cannot be restored.

  • Retrobulbar alcohol injection - given to relieve pain. First, 1 mL of 2% xylocaine is injected followed after about 5-10 minutes by 1 mL of 80% alcohol. It suppresses the ciliary ganglion.

  • A cyclodestructive procedure, such as cyclocryotherapy or cyclophotocoagulation, is the most appropriate management option in this scenario as it reduces aqueous production by damaging the secretory ciliary processes aiming to reduce IOP.

  • If pain persists despite cyclodestruction, enucleation/evisceration may be considered.

Incorrect Options

Acute retrobulbar neuritis (Option A), also known as optic neuritis, typically presents with vision loss, eye pain, and decreased color vision. It is not characterized by redness and congestion of the eye, so it is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.

Acute anterior uveitis (Option C), also known as iritis, is inflammation of the iris and the anterior chamber of the eye. It commonly presents with symptoms of a red, painful eye with photophobia (sensitivity to light) and decreased vision. The image showing redness and congestion supports this diagnosis. Acute anterior uveitis can be associated with underlying systemic conditions such as ankylosing spondylitis or reactive arthritis. It is the most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario.

Severe keratoconjunctivitis (Option D) refers to inflammation of both the cornea and the conjunctiva. While it can cause redness and irritation of the eye, it is not commonly associated with acute onset and severe pain. It is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with fever and swelling of the left eyelid for the past two days. He has no history of trauma but experienced a mild flu-like illness one week ago. On examination, there is no chemosis or protrusion of the eyeball. Based on these observations, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Preseptal cellulitis

Explanation:

  • Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and surrounding skin anterior to the orbital septum. It is characterized by eyelid swelling, erythema, fever, and tenderness, often following a minor trauma or spreading from a nearby infection, or spreading from a remote infection of middle ear and upper respiratory tract infection. In this case, the absence of significant ocular findings, such as chemosis or proptosis, along with the mild flu-like illness history, is more consistent with preseptal cellulitis

Chandler’s Classification of Orbital Cellulitis

Stage

Description

Key Features

I - Preseptal cellulitis

Infection confined to the eyelid

Eyelid swelling, no ocular involvement

II - Orbital cellulitis (Option B)

Infection spreads to the orbit

Pain with eye movement, restricted mobility, no abscess formation, chemosis or proptosis

III - Subperiosteal abscess

Pus collection beneath periosteum

Localized pus, proptosis, pain on movement, swelling

IV - Orbital abscess

Pus collection within the orbital tissues

Severe proptosis, potential vision loss, risk of optic nerve damage

V - Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Spread of infection to the cavernous sinus

Bilateral eye involvement, headache, cranial nerve palsies

Panophthalmitis (Option A) It is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball, including the tenon’s capsule, characterized by severe pain,fever, malaise complete loss of vision, and purulent discharge.

Lid tumor (Option D) refer to abnormal growths or masses in the eyelid.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 3-year-old boy who has displayed growing clumsiness over the last half a year, has leukocoria, and lacks red reflex in his left eye? After diagnosis, enucleation was performed, and the specimen displayed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes under microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a 3 year old boy having leukocoria, and lacking red reflex in his left eye is consistent with Retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma

  • Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular cancer in children.
  • Symptoms include leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and strabismus (misaligned eyes).
  • Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by indirect ophthalmoscopy, orbital ultrasonography, and MRI to assess tumour extent.
  • Histopathology: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a differentiated type of tumor characterized by columnar cells with a central lumen.
  • Biopsies are not recommended due to the risk of spreading the tumour.
  • Treatment depends on tumour size, location, and whether the disease is unilateral or bilateral. Options include enucleation, chemotherapy, and focal therapies like laser photocoagulation.

Incorrect Options

Congenital glaucoma (Option A) is characterized by epiphora, photophobia, blepharospasm, and buphthalmos.

Toxocariasis (Option C) It is a parasitic infection caused by roundworm Toxocara canis that can be acquired through ingestion of contaminated soil or food animals. It can present with leukocoria, strabismus, floaters, eosinophilia, and hypergammaglobulinemia.

Neurofibroma (Option D) are tumors that arise from nerve sheath cells and are often associated with the genetic disorder neurofibromatosis. In plexiform neurofibroma S-shaped deformity of the lid is observed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Meniere's Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ear Pain

Explanation:

  • Meniere’s disease is an inner ear disorder characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and aural fullness due to endolymphatic hydrops. However, ear pain is not a typical feature of Meniere’s disease unless secondary infections or complications occur.

Meniere’s Disease

Feature

Description

Cause

Excess endolymph accumulation (endolymphatic hydrops)

Triad of Symptoms

1. Vertigo (episodic, lasts minutes to hours)

2. Tinnitus (low-frequency, roaring type)

3. Hearing loss (sensorineural, fluctuating, progressive)

Other Symptoms

Aural fullness (blocked ear sensation)

Not Typically Seen

Ear pain, except in secondary infections

Diagnosis

Clinical + Audiometry (low-frequency SNHL)

Treatment

Dietary modifications (low sodium), diuretics, vestibular suppressants, intratympanic steroids, and surgery in refractory cases

Incorrect Options:

Tinnitus (Option A): is incorrect because tinnitus (low-pitched, roaring) is a hallmark of Meniere’s disease.

Vertigo (Option B): is incorrect because Meniere’s disease presents with episodic vertigo, lasting minutes to hours.

Fullness of ear (Option C): is incorrect because aural fullness or pressure sensation in the affected ear is a classic symptom.

questions.text: What is the most probable reason for the swelling in the tonsils of a 40-year-old woman who has difficulty swallowing food, no past medical history of fever, sore throat, or smoking, but a family history of Marfan's syndrome in her father, and shows unilateral swelling of the tonsils along with pulsation upon oral examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Extracranial Internal Carotid Artery Aneurysm

Explanation:

  • The unilateral tonsillar swelling with pulsation suggests a vascular etiology, and the presence of Marfan’s syndrome in the family history increases the likelihood of an aneurysm due to connective tissue disorder.
  • The extracranial internal carotid artery (ICA) aneurysm is a rare but recognized cause of tonsillar swelling and can mimic a mass lesion.
  • It is located medially to the tonsil and can be identified by pulsation on examination.

Extracranial Internal Carotid Artery Aneurysm

Feature

Description

Cause

Weakening of ICA wall (due to atherosclerosis, Marfan’s syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, infections, or trauma)

Symptoms

1. Unilateral tonsillar swelling

2. Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)

3. Pulsation on oral exam

4. Absence of infection or inflammatory signs

Risk Factors

Connective tissue disorders (Marfan's, Ehlers-Danlos), atherosclerosis, hypertension

Complications

Rupture, thrombosis, stroke, or cranial nerve compression

Diagnosis

CT/MR angiography, Doppler ultrasound

Treatment

Surgical repair or endovascular stenting

Incorrect Options:

Intracranial External Carotid Artery Aneurysm (Option B): is incorrect because the external carotid artery does not run close to the tonsils, and intracranial aneurysms do not present as tonsillar swelling.

Extracranial External Carotid Artery Aneurysm (Option C): is incorrect because the external carotid artery runs laterally in the neck, not medially near the tonsils.

Intracranial Internal Carotid Artery Aneurysm (Option D): is incorrect because an intracranial ICA aneurysm presents with stroke-like symptoms (headache, visual disturbances, or cranial nerve palsies) rather than tonsillar swelling.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms does not cause croup?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rhinovirus

Explanation:

  • Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is a viral infection that causes subglottic airway inflammation, leading to barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness.
  • It is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza viruses (types 1 and 2), followed by RSV and influenza.
  • Rhinovirus, however, is primarily associated with the common cold and does not typically cause croup.

Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis)

Feature

Description

Cause

Parainfluenza virus (Types 1, 2, 3) - most common, RSV, Influenza, Adenovirus

Age Group

6 months - 3 years (most common)

Symptoms

1. Barking cough

2. Inspiratory stridor

3. Hoarseness

4. Respiratory distress

Steeple Sign on X-ray

Subglottic narrowing on AP neck X-ray

Treatment

Mild: Supportive care, humidified air

Moderate-Severe: Dexamethasone + Nebulized Epinephrine

Incorrect Options:

Parainfluenza 1 (Option A): is incorrect because Parainfluenza virus type 1 is the most common cause of croup.

Parainfluenza 2 (Option B): is incorrect because Parainfluenza type 2 also causes croup, though less frequently than type 1.

RSV (Option D): is incorrect because Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) can cause croup, though it is more commonly associated with bronchiolitis.

questions.text: Dohlman’s procedure is for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Zenker’s diverticulum

Explanation:

  • Dohlman’s procedure is a minimally invasive endoscopic technique used to treat Zenker’s diverticulum, a pharyngoesophageal pouch that forms due to cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction.
  • The procedure involves endoscopic diverticulotomy, which divides the cricopharyngeal bar, allowing food to pass freely into the esophagus.

Zenker’s Diverticulum & Dohlman’s Procedure

Feature

Description

Definition

Outpouching of mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence (weak area in the posterior pharynx)

Cause

Cricopharyngeal dysfunction leading to high pressure and diverticulum formation

Symptoms

1. Dysphagia

2. Regurgitation of undigested food

3. Halitosis (bad breath)

4. Aspiration pneumonia

Diagnosis

Barium swallow X-ray (shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch)

Treatment

Dohlman’s procedure (endoscopic diverticulotomy)

Open surgery if large

Incorrect Options:

Meckel’s diverticulum (Option A): is incorrect because Meckel’s diverticulum is a congenital remnant of the vitelline duct in the small intestine and is managed surgically by Meckel’s diverticulectomy, not Dohlman’s procedure.

Bochdalek hernia (Option C): is incorrect because Bochdalek hernia is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia due to failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close and is repaired via surgical closure of the diaphragm defect.

Menetrier’s disease (Option D): is incorrect because Menetrier’s disease is a rare gastric hypertrophic condition with protein loss and increased mucus secretion, treated with medical therapy or gastrectomy in severe cases, not Dohlman’s procedure.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presented with history of dysphagia, halitosis and aspiration pneumonia. A barium swallow was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zenker’s Diverticulum

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with dysphagia, halitosis, and aspiration pneumonia, which are classical symptoms of Zenker’s diverticulum.
  • Barium swallow typically shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch originating from Killian’s dehiscence.

Zenker’s Diverticulum

Feature

Description

Definition

A false diverticulum formed due to herniation of pharyngeal mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence

Cause

Cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction leading to increased pressure and pouch formation

Symptoms

1. Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)

2. Regurgitation of undigested food

3. Halitosis (bad breath)

4. Aspiration pneumonia

Diagnosis

Barium swallow X-ray (shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch)

Treatment

Endoscopic diverticulotomy (Dohlman’s procedure) or open diverticulectomy in large cases

Incorrect Options:

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option A): is incorrect because diffuse esophageal spasm presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia, and barium swallow shows a "corkscrew esophagus", not a diverticulum.

Achalasia cardia (Option B): is incorrect because achalasia presents with progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, with regurgitation. Barium swallow shows a "bird’s beak" appearance, not a pharyngeal pouch.

Esophageal cancer (Option D): is incorrect because esophageal cancer presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and possible hematemesis. Barium swallow shows an irregular stricture with mucosal destruction, not a diverticulum.

questions.text: Please identify the structure shown in this endoscopic image of the nasopharynx.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fossa of Rosenmüller

Explanation:

  • The fossa of Rosenmüller is a common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma and is located posterior to the torus tubarius in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.
  • On endoscopic examination, it appears as a deep recess lateral to the Eustachian tube opening.

Nasopharyngeal Anatomy

Structure

Description

Fossa of Rosenmüller

Deep recess behind the torus tubarius, common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Sinus of Morgagni

Gap between the base of the skull and superior pharyngeal constrictor muscle

Passavant’s Ridge

Muscular ridge formed by the superior pharyngeal constrictor, involved in velopharyngeal closure

Rathke’s Pouch

Embryological remnant from which the anterior pituitary gland develops

Incorrect Options:

Sinus of Morgagni (Option A): is incorrect because it is an anatomical gap at the skull base, not a recess seen in endoscopy.

Passavant’s Ridge (Option B): is incorrect because it is a transient muscular ridge formed during swallowing, not a fixed nasopharyngeal structure.

Rathke’s Pouch (Option D): is incorrect because it is an embryological structure related to pituitary gland development, not visible in nasopharyngeal endoscopy.

questions.text: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by
questions.solution:
​Correct Answer: D) Virus

Explanation:

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus (Molluscum contagiosum virus) and presents as flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules with a characteristic central umbilication.

Poxviruses

Poxviruses are the largest viruses that infect vertebrates.

Morphology

  • Poxviruses measure approximately 400 nm in length and 230 nm in diameter, making them visible under a light microscope.
  • Poxviruses are typically brick-shaped or ellipsoid.
  • They possess an envelope consisting of two lipoprotein membranes (outer and inner), and the outer membrane features ridges.
  • The envelope encases a core, along with two structures of unknown function known as lateral bodies.
  • The core or nucleocapsid is biconcave and shaped like a dumbbell.
  • Poxviruses contain a single linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome.
  • They are unique among DNA viruses for replicating in the cytoplasm.

Human-Important poxviruses
  • Variola is the causative agent of smallpox, the first disease to be eradicated globally.
  • Vaccinia: Used as a vaccine for smallpox.
  • Molluscum contagiosum Virus: Causes warty lesions known as molluscum contagiosum.

Genera classification

  • Orthopoxvirus: Smallpox, monkeypox, vaccinia.
  • Molluscipoxvirus: Molluscum contagiosum.
  • Parapoxvirus: Milker’s nodules, bovine papular stomatitis viruses, etc.
  • Capripoxvirus: Sheeppox, goatpox, lumpy skin disease, etc.
  • Avipoxvirus: Fowlpox, pigeon pox, etc.
  • Leporipoxvirus: Myxoma, hare fibroma, etc.
  • Suipoxvirus: Swinepox virus.
  • Yatapoxvirus: Tanapox, Yabapox viruses.

 

Molluscum contagiosum

Molluscum contagiosum virus is an obligate human poxvirus known for producing characteristic skin lesions.

Clinical manifestations

Lesions:

  • Dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions (2–5 mm in size) with a dimple at the center.
  • Lesions can appear singly or in clusters, located anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles.
  • Lesions are umbilicated.
  • Genital lesions are commonly observed in adults.
  • Lesions typically resolve on their own within 3–4 months.

Transmission

  • Primarily affects children, transmitted through direct and indirect contact (e.g., barbers, shared towels, swimming pools).
  • Rare instances of sexual transmission have been reported in young adults.

Laboratory diagnosis

Molluscum bodies:

  • Characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions were observed in skin scrapings stained with histopathological stains.

Confirmation methods:

  • Electron microscopy
  • PCR

Cultivation:

  • The virus cannot be propagated in tissue culture, embryonated eggs, or animals.

Treatment
  • Surgical removal of the lesions by ablation (by cryotherapy or laser therapy) is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Cidofovir has been shown to have some efficacy.


Options A, B, & C are incorrect. Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a virus (Poxvirus). ​​

questions.text: What is the TNM staging for a patient with carcinoma in the pyriform fossa, presenting with a 5 cm lesion on laryngoscopy, non-mobile right vocal folds, no lymph node involvement, and no distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) T3N0M0

Explanation:

The TNM staging for pyriform fossa carcinoma follows the AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer) classification.

  • T3: Tumor >4 cm or with vocal cord fixation
  • N0: No regional lymph node involvement
  • M0: No distant metastasis

Since the patient has a 5 cm lesion (T3 criterion) and non-mobile vocal cords (vocal cord fixation), the correct stage is T3N0M0.

TNM Staging of Hypopharyngeal Cancer (Including Pyriform Fossa)

Stage

Tumor Size/Extent

Vocal Cord Mobility

Lymph Node Involvement

Metastasis

T1

Tumor confined to one subsite of hypopharynx

Normal

No nodes (N0)

No (M0)

T2

Tumor extends to more than one subsite or adjacent areas

Normal

N0

M0

T3

Tumor >4 cm or vocal cord fixation

Fixed

N0

M0

T4a

Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., thyroid/cricoid cartilage, hyoid, thyroid gland, esophagus)

Fixed

N0/N+

M0

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral fascia, encases carotid artery, or involves mediastinal structures

Fixed

N0/N+

M0

Incorrect Options:

T2N0M0 (Option A): is incorrect because T2 is for tumors extending to multiple subsites but <4 cm and without vocal cord fixation.

T4aN0M0 (Option C): is incorrect because T4a requires invasion into adjacent structures (e.g., cartilage, esophagus), which is not mentioned in this case.

T4bN0M0 (Option D): is incorrect because T4b involves invasion of prevertebral fascia, carotid artery, or mediastinum, none of which are present in this case.

questions.text: Oral hairy leukoplakia is associated with which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Epstein-Barr virus

Explanation:

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the causative agent of oral hairy leukoplakia, which presents as white, corrugated wart like growths of epithelial tissue on the lateral tongue, commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.

Cytomegalovirus (Option A): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause oral ulcers in immunocompromised individuals but does not lead to oral hairy leukoplakia, which is specifically linked to Epstein-Barr virus.

Human Papilloma Virus (Option B): Human papilloma virus (HPV) is associated with oral warts and squamous papillomas rather than the white, corrugated lesions seen in oral hairy leukoplakia.

Herpes Simplex 1 Virus (Option C): Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) typically causes painful oral ulcers or cold sores but does not cause the characteristic painless, non-removable white patches of oral hairy leukoplakia.

questions.text: A 25 year old Volleyball player presents to your OPD with injury to thumb,along with pain, swelling, and tenderness at the base of the thumb. On examination the thumb is in the position of abduction. Which of the following is the diagnosis of the presenting condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Game keepers thumb

Explanation:

  • The injury described in the question, with pain, swelling, tenderness at the base of the thumb, and the thumb in the position of abduction, is consistent with Gamekeeper's Thumb (also known as Skier's Thumb).

Ulnar Collateral Ligament Injury: Known as Gamekeeper’s Thumb or Skier’s Thumb, caused by hyperabduction of the thumb (e.g., falling onto an extended thumb).

Injury Types:

  • Partial Rupture: Only the ligament is torn; instability in flexion but stable in extension.
  • Complete Rupture: Both the ligament and palmar plate are torn; instability in all positions.
  • Stener Lesion: When the ligament pulls away from its attachment and doesn’t heal unless repaired.

Clinical Assessment:

  • Tenderness and swelling over the ulnar side of the thumb.
  • X-ray to rule out fractures.
  • Stress tests to check for laxity.
  • Laxity in flexion and extension suggests complete rupture requiring surgery.

Treatment:

  • Partial Tears: Immobilization in a splint for 2-4 weeks, avoiding pinch for 6-8 weeks.
  • Complete Tears: Surgical repair required, with care to avoid damaging the superficial radial nerve.
  • Post-surgery: Thumb immobilized in a splint for 6 weeks, with early movement in the flexion-extension plane.

 

Bowler's Thumb (Option B): Refers to a condition caused by compression of the ulnar nerve at the hypothenar eminence (not an injury to the thumb ligament).

Kaplan injury (Option C): Refers to an injury to the flexor tendon of the thumb, often seen in deep cuts to the palm or thumb, not related to hyperabduction.

Mallet Finger (Option D): Involves injury to the extensor tendon of the finger, causing an inability to straighten the distal joint, which is not the case here.

questions.text: A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice the inspiratory stridor in the child, and the laryngeal examination is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Laryngomalacia

Explanation:

  • Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital stridor, presenting in infants with inspiratory stridor that worsens when supine or feeding.
  • Laryngeal examination typically shows an omega-shaped epiglottis and redundant arytenoid mucosa, which collapse during inspiration.

Laryngomalacia

Feature

Description

Cause

Congenital floppy laryngeal cartilage, especially affecting the epiglottis and arytenoids

Symptoms

Inspiratory stridor (worse when supine, feeding, or crying)

Onset

At birth or within the first few weeks of life, peaks at 4–8 months, resolves by 12–24 months

Diagnosis

Flexible laryngoscopy → shows omega-shaped epiglottis, redundant arytenoid mucosa

Treatment

Observation in mild cases, surgical intervention (supraglottoplasty) in severe cases

Incorrect Options:

Vocal cord paralysis (Option A): is incorrect because it causes biphasic stridor (both inspiratory and expiratory) and weak cry, unlike the isolated inspiratory stridor seen in laryngomalacia.

Subglottic stenosis (Option B): is incorrect because it causes biphasic stridor and is often associated with prolonged intubation history.

Laryngeal papilloma (Option C): is incorrect because it causes progressive hoarseness and voice changes, whereas laryngomalacia primarily causes stridor without voice involvement.

questions.text: Blount Disease results from the involvement of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proximal tibia

Explanation:

  • Blount Disease is characterized by pathologic tibial varus deformity, often seen in young children, and is linked with abnormal growth of the medial part of the proximal tibial growth plate.

Blount disease:

  • Blount disease, also known as tibia vara, is an acquired genu varus deformity in children caused by disrupted normal cartilage growth at the proximal medial metaphysis of the tibia.
  • This condition develops due to excessive compressive forces on the medial aspect of the proximal tibial physis, leading to altered enchondral bone formation.

Etiopathogenesis:

  • Genetic susceptibility
  • Mechanical overloading of the tibia especially in children who are overweight and started walking earlier.
  • Blount disease results from growth inhibition induced by excessive compressive forces, leading to cartilage damage and a subsequent delay in ossification.
  • Mechanical overload leads to altered enchondral bone formation.

Two forms of Blount disease

Infantile Blount disease

Adolescent Blount disease
  • Diagnosed in children between age 1-3 years.
  • Bilateral condition.
  • Characterised by varus deformity of tibia with identification of lateral thrust.
  • Emerges in children in their late childhood or early adolescent.
  • Unilateral or bilateral conditions.
  • Characterised by pain in the medial aspect of the knee.

Diagnosis:

  • Accurate measurement requires bilateral projection of the radiograph from the hip to the ankle.

Angles for Blount disease detection

Angles

Description

Metaphyseal-Diaphyseal angle(MDA)
  • The intersection occurs between a line drawn from the most distal point on the medial and lateral beaks of the tibial metaphysis to a line perpendicular to the long axis of the tibial diaphysis.
  • An angle >16° is associated with a 95% risk of deformity progression.
  • An angle <10° is likely physiological, with a 95% chance of spontaneous resolution.
  • An angle between 11° and 16° necessitates close observation for the potential tibia vara progression.

Tibiofemoral angle
  • Measures the severity of varus deformity.

Medial Metaphyseal Beak angle(MMBA)
  • Diagnostic screening tool for individual risk of blount disease.
  • MRI effectively assesses cartilage, menisci, ligaments and vascularity of the physis.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Physiological bowing of the legs
  • Ollier disease
  • Metaphyseal Chondrodysplasia
  • Thrombocytopenia absent radius syndrome

Treatment:

Treatment of Blount's disease depends on the child's age and the severity of the deformity.

  • Brace: KAFO are potential treatment options for children diagnosed before age 4.
  • Guided growth or Hemiepiphysiodesis is a surgical technique designed to correct angular limb deformities in skeletally immature patients progressively.
  • Osteotomy: Realignment osteotomy is typically performed before age 4 in pediatric patients with documented and progressive Blount disease

 

Distal tibia (Option B): Blount disease primarily affects the proximal tibia, not the distal tibia.

Proximal femur (Option C): Blount disease is a tibial condition, not related to the femur.

Distal femur (Option D): Blount disease involves the tibia, not the distal femur.

questions.text: Which joints are affected in a condition where the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are involved, while the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrist are spared?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteoarthritis

Explanation:

  • OA typically affects the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, especially in the hands. It often spares the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrists, making it characteristic of OA in the hands.

Osteoarthritis (OA):

  • It is the most common form of arthritis in the world.
  • It mainly affects the hips, knees, spine, hands and feet.

Clinical manifestations

Symptoms:

  • Pain (Nature and severity are variable)
  • Joint stiffness (short-lasting stiffness after a period of inactivity)
  • Fatigue
  • Sleep disturbance
  • Reduced functional ability and activities

Signs:

  • Tenderness of the joint
  • Bony swelling
  • Reduced range of movement with pain at the end of the range
  • Crepitus on movement of the joint
  • Weakness and wasting of muscles around the joint
  • Signs of inflammation (mild)
  • In severe cases - deformity and instability
  • Varus deformity and fixed flexion deformity of the knee

Varus deformity

  • Commonly affected joints in the hand: Distal interphalangeal joints (DIPs) and the thumb base
  • Classical findings in hand:
    • Heberden’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of DIP joints)
  • Bouchard’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of PIP joints)
  • Squaring at the base of the thumb (first CMC joints)

Kashin Beck disease:

  • An extremely rare polyarticular form of OA.
  • Seen in the people of Northern China and Eastern Siberia.
  • Symptoms:
    • Joint pain
    • Polyarticular swelling
    • Deformity from childhood
    • Short stature
  • X-ray:
    • Distorted epiphyses and tubular long bones.

 

Rheumatoid Arthritis (Option B): Affects MCP joints and wrists symmetrically, not typically sparing them.

Psoriasis (Option C): Psoriatic arthritis can affect DIP joints but often involves other joints, including MCP joints.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option D): Causes bone changes but does not specifically affect DIP and PIP joints in the same pattern as OA.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presented with a gradual progressive swelling, and was diagnosed with Adamantinoma. Which of the following bones is typically affected by this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tibia

Explanation:

  • The tibia is the most common site for adamantinoma, particularly the anterior metaphysis or diaphysis. This predilection is due to the close proximity of the tibia's enchondral bone to the skin, which supports the embryological displacement theory.

Adamantinoma

About
  • Rare, low-grade malignant bone tumors of uncertain histogenesis
  • Commonly affects the anterior metaphysis and diaphysis tibia, close to the skin surface.
  • Immunohistochemical studies suggest epithelial origin.
  • Commonly affects individuals aged 20-40 years.

Histopathology
  • Macroscopic: Well-defined, lobulated cortical tumors with yellowish-gray appearance and possible cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic: Biphasic composition (epithelial and osteofibrous components) with basaloid, tubular, spindle-cell, squamous, and osteofibrous dysplasia-like patterns.
  • Immunohistochemistry:
    • Epithelial cells: Positive for keratin, EMA, vimentin, p63, podoplanin.
    • Fibrous component: Positive for vimentin.
    • Expression of EGF, EGFR (epithelial), FGF2, FGFR1 (both components).

Clinical Features
  • Prolonged clinical course with slow-growing swelling, possible pain, bone deformities, or pathological fractures (~23%).
  • Rarely involves neurological deficits when the spine is affected.
  • Metastases commonly involve lungs, lymph nodes, or spine.

Evaluation
  • X-ray: Well-circumscribed, multilobulated, osteolytic cortical tumor with a "soap-bubble" appearance.
  • CT Scan: Assesses soft tissue extension and cortical involvement.
  • MRI: Locoregional staging; visualizes tumor margins, cortical involvement, and soft tissue extension.

Treatment
  • Wide Resection: En bloc removal with wide margins preferred.
  • Metastasectomy: First-line for pulmonary recurrences.

 

Radius (Option A): Although adamantinoma can rarely occur in the radius, it is an atypical site. The tibia remains the most frequently affected bone.

Humerus (Option B): Adamantinoma seldom affects the humerus. It primarily involves long bones of the lower limb, with the tibia being the most common.

Femur (Option C) can be involved in rare cases, but it is far less commonly affected than the tibia.

questions.text: What is the likely pathogen responsible for an 8-year-old boy's continuous diarrhea, starting 20 hours ago, which is rice watery in consistency, causing drowsiness, unresponsiveness, sunken eyes, and poor skin turgor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vibrio cholera

Explanation:

Given the description of the symptoms—continuous rice-water diarrhea, drowsiness, unresponsiveness, sunken eyes, and poor skin turgor—these are classic signs of cholera, which is caused by Vibrio cholera. Cholera often leads to severe dehydration due to the massive loss of fluid in the form of rice-water stools. The signs of dehydration, such as drowsiness, sunken eyes, and poor skin turgor, indicate the severity of fluid loss.

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea.
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Entamoeba coli (Option B): This is a non-pathogenic amoeba that is usually asymptomatic and does not typically cause such severe diarrhea. Entamoeba histolytica can cause dysentery, but it doesn't present with rice-water stools or the severe dehydration seen in cholera.

Escherichia coli (Option C): Certain strains of E. coli, like Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC), can cause watery diarrhea, but it is generally not as severe as the diarrhea caused by cholera, nor does it typically lead to the extreme dehydration described here.

Shigella sonnei (Option D): Shigella causes dysentery, which typically involves bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever, but not rice-water stools or the extreme dehydration seen with cholera

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She was a non-restrained passenger in a car. She has pain in her neck and difficulty in neck movements. She has no associated neurological deficits. A neck collar is applied to protect the spinal cord. An X-ray of the neck is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hangman fracture

Explanation:

  • A Hangman fracture occurs due to hyperextension, often from high-impact trauma like a road traffic accident. It involves fractures of the C2 vertebra (axis), leading to anterior displacement. The injury is unstable, but neurological deficits are rare as the fracture can widen the spinal canal.

C2 Traumatic Spondylolisthesis (Hangman’s Fracture)

  • Cause: Traditionally from judicial hanging; now more commonly due to hyperextension injuries (e.g., force to the forehead, Forsyth mechanism).
  • Injury: Results in anterior translation at C2, leading to pars fractures and possible C2/3 disc disruption.
  • Neurological Injury: Uncommon, as the fractures can expand the spinal canal.
  • Stability Assessment: Depends on C2/3 disc status and facet integrity.

Levine & Edward Classification

Treatment

Type 1: Less than 3 mm subluxation, stable

Rigid cervical collar

Type 2: Greater than 4 mm subluxation, unstable

-Less than 5 mm - Reduction in axial traction and halo fixation for 6 to 12 weeks

-Greater than 5 mm - Require surgery

Type 2a: Unstable with flexion injury and angular deformity

Halo fixation

Type 3: Unstable with facet and anterior longitudinal ligament disruption

Require surgery

 

Jefferson's fracture (Option B): Involves a burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas), typically due to axial loading (e.g., diving accidents), not hyperextension.

Clay Shoveler's fracture (Option C): A fracture of the spinous process of C6, C7, or T1 due to sudden, forceful muscle contraction, not typically caused by hyperextension.

SCIWORA (Option D) (Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality): Refers to a spinal cord injury without visible fractures or dislocations on X-ray, often in young individuals with neck trauma, but it does not involve bone fractures.

questions.text: Albers Schonberg disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Osteopetrosis

Explanation:

  • Osteopetrosis, also known as Albers-Schönberg disease, is a rare genetic condition where bones become abnormally dense due to defective osteoclast function, which impairs bone resorption.

Osteopetrosis

Osteopetrosis, also known as Albers-Schönberg disease, is a rare condition characterized by abnormally dense bones due to defective osteoclast function, which impairs bone resorption.

As a result, bones become thickened but brittle, leading to structural abnormalities and complications. (Option A ruled out)

Types

Infantile Malignant Osteopetrosis

Features

Adult Benign Osteopetrosis

Autosomal recessive

Inheritance

Autosomal dominant

(Option B ruled out)

Early onset with severe symptoms, including growth retardation, genu valgum, abnormal skull development, cranial nerve entrapment, pancytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

(Option C)

Presentation

 

Often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally in adulthood. When symptomatic, it may present with non-specific bone pain, compressive neuropathies, and recurrent fractures.

(Option D ruled out)

Increased risk of hydrocephalus, hearing loss, and osteitis of the mandible.

Complications

Delayed union

Symptom management with vitamin D, γ-interferon, erythropoietin, and corticosteroids.

Treatment

Generally not required unless symptoms are present. Symptomatic management includes pain relief and fracture care.

 

Findings in osteopetrosis

Rugger Jersey Spine (Also seen in renal osteodystrophy)

Sandwich Vertebra

Endplates of the vertebra become densely sclerotic resembling a sandwich.

Densely Sclerotic bones

 

Paget's disease (Option A): A condition characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlarged and weakened bones, but it does not cause the dense, brittle bones seen in osteopetrosis.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option B): A genetic disorder causing brittle bones due to collagen defects, not due to defective osteoclast function like in osteopetrosis.

Osteoporosis (Option C): A condition of reduced bone density and increased fracture risk due to bone resorption outpacing formation, the opposite of osteopetrosis, where bone density is abnormally high.

questions.text: Identify the following fracture:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Monteggia Fracture

Explanation:

  • The presented X-ray findings indicate a fracture of the upper third of the ulna indicating a Monteggia fracture, also called a treacherous fracture. While the ulna fracture is clearly evident on the X-ray, the associated dislocation of the radial head may be overlooked.

Monteggia fracture

Site

Fracture of the proximal third of the ulna is accompanied by a radial head dislocation.

Cause

Fall on an outstretched hand

Mechanism

Complications

  • Nerve injury (Posterior Interosseous Nerve)
  • Malunion
  • Non-union
  • Cubitus valgus.
  • Radio ulnar synostosis (Type 4 Monteggia Fracture)
  • Myositis Ossificans.

 

 

Colles Fracture (Option A) involves a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement, often due to a fall on an outstretched hand. This does not involve the ulna or radial head dislocation, making it different from a Monteggia fracture.

 

Barton's Fracture (Option C) refers to a fracture of the distal radius involving the radiocarpal joint (articular surface), often accompanied by dislocation of the wrist joint. It is distinct from the Monteggia fracture, which involves the ulna and radial head.

 

None of the Above (Option D): This option is incorrect because the fracture shown is clearly a Monteggia fracture, involving the proximal ulna and radial head dislocation.

questions.text: Which of the following is characterized by the presence of both reservoir sign and mastoid tenderness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute mastoiditis

Explanation:

Acute mastoiditis is characterized by:

  • Reservoir sign: It refers to the collection of fluid or pus in the mastoid air cells, which can be visualized during otoscopy or imaging.
  • Mastoid tenderness: This is a key clinical sign of acute mastoiditis, where the patient experiences pain and tenderness over the mastoid process due to inflammation.

Acute Mastoiditis:

  • Acute mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid bone, typically following an untreated or inadequately treated middle ear infection (acute otitis media).
  • It involves the inflammation of the mastoid air cells, which can lead to symptoms like:
    • Pain and tenderness over the mastoid process
    • Swelling behind the ear
    • Fever and irritability in children
  • It can be diagnosed through clinical examination (looking for the reservoir sign and mastoid tenderness) and imaging like CT scans.
  • If left untreated, it can lead to severe complications like hearing loss, intracranial infections, and abscess formation.

Incorrect Options:

Otosclerotic lesion (Option A): is incorrect because otosclerosis is a bone condition affecting the stapes in the middle ear, and it does not cause mastoid tenderness or a reservoir sign.

Intratympanic glomus tumor (Option C): is incorrect because glomus tumors, though they can cause ear symptoms, do not cause mastoid tenderness or reservoir sign. These tumors are typically vascular and are located in the middle ear or jugular bulb.

Chronic suppurative otitis media (Option D): is incorrect because while chronic otitis media may have purulent discharge, it does not typically present with mastoid tenderness or the reservoir sign unless there's a complication such as cholesteatoma or a coexisting acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of burning sensation on eating hot or spicy food, and the following findings are seen. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candidiasis

Explanation:

Chronic use of inhaled steroids is a common risk factor for oral candidiasis (thrush), as steroids can suppress the immune system locally in the mouth, allowing Candida albicans to overgrow. This can lead to symptoms like a burning sensation, particularly when eating hot or spicy food, which can irritate the affected areas. Candidiasis in the mouth typically presents as white patches that can be scraped off, leaving a red, inflamed area underneath.

Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Lead to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.
  • C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

Burning Mouth Syndrome (Option B): This is a condition characterized by a burning or tingling sensation in the mouth, but it doesn't usually have associated lesions or plaques, and it’s not commonly linked to inhaled steroids or the presence of oral candidiasis.

Geographical Tongue (Option C): This condition involves a map-like appearance of the tongue with irregular, red, smooth areas surrounded by white borders. It usually doesn’t cause the same burning sensation with spicy food and isn’t typically associated with inhaled steroid use.


Oral Lichen Planus (Option D): This is an autoimmune condition that affects the mucous membranes of the mouth. It may cause burning or pain, but it typically presents with white, lacy lesions (Wickham’s striae) or erosive areas, which aren't characteristic of candidiasis.

questions.text: A 79 yrs old lady had a fall in the bathroom, the following X-rays were taken in order to make a diagnosis. Which of the following is treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hemiarthroplasty

Explanation:

  • Hemiarthroplasty is the preferred treatment for displaced femoral neck fractures in elderly patients, particularly those who are inactive or have multiple comorbidities. It involves replacing the femoral head while leaving the acetabulum intact.

In a femoral neck fracture, especially in elderly patients, the classic presentation of the limb includes external rotation and shortening.

  • The external rotation occurs due to the pull of the external rotator muscles, such as the gluteus maximus and the short external rotators, on the distal femoral fragment.
  • Shortening of the limb occurs due to muscle contraction and overriding of the bone fragments, particularly in displaced fractures.

Fracture of the Neck of Femur

  • The fracture of the neck of the femur is a significant injury, particularly in the elderly, and is often associated with osteoporosis and trauma.

Etiology

Low-Energy Trauma

Common in elderly with osteoporosis; simple fall from standing height can cause a fracture.

Osteoporosis

Age-related bone loss; post-menopausal women at higher risk; fractures occur with minimal trauma.

Pathological Fractures

Caused by conditions like metastatic bone disease, multiple myeloma, or Paget’s disease; minimal force needed for fracture.

Stress Fractures

Seen in athletes or military personnel due to repetitive stress.

Clinical Presentation

Pain

Groin pain radiating to medial thigh or knee; sharp pain worsened by movement.

Inability to Bear Weight

Unable to stand or walk due to pain, less severe in stress fractures.

Attitude of affected limb

Shortened and externally rotated limb in displaced fractures; limited internal rotation and flexion.

Bruising and Swelling

Minimal swelling due to deep femoral neck location; sometimes bruising around hip or groin.

Diagnosis

Imaging

X-ray (AP and lateral views) is the primary modality; fractures are classified using the Garden classification.

 

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty, total hip replacement)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

 

 

Garden’s classification

Treatment in adults

Treatment in children

Garden’s type 1

(incomplete, impacted, or abducted fracture)
  • Conservative methods
  • Immobilization in a Thomas splint with traction
  • Internal fixation with screws (if displacement is feared)
  • Hip spica (Option B ruled out)
  • Traction is applied through a pin (Moore’s pin) or wire in older adolescents

Garden’s type 2

(complete but undisplaced)

Internal fixation with cannulated screws, dynamic hip screws, proximal femoral locking plates, and cephalomedullary nails.

Garden’s type 3

(complete & partially displaced)

  • Hemiarthroplasty (done in inactive elderly of >60years of age with comorbidities)
  • Total hip arthroplasty (done in active older patients)
  • Internal fixation (done in young adults)

Internal fixation (using Knowle’s screw)

Garden’s type 4

(complete & fully displaced)

 

Total Hip Replacement (Option C) is considered in active older adults with femoral neck fractures, especially when there's a need to address both the femoral head and acetabulum. However, it is usually reserved for patients who are more active and have fewer comorbidities than those typically treated with hemiarthroplasty.

Nailing (Option D) (intramedullary fixation) is generally used for fractures of the femoral shaft or intertrochanteric fractures but is not typically indicated for displaced femoral neck fractures, especially in elderly patients. It is more suitable for younger patients with better bone quality and fewer comorbid conditions.

questions.text: A patient presents with hoarseness of voice. On examination an ulceroproliferative mass is seen on the right vocal cord; the cord was however mobile. There is no lymph node involvement and no metastasis. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Radiotherapy

Explanation:

  • In this case, the patient presents with an ulceroproliferative mass on the right vocal cord with mobile vocal cords, no lymph node involvement, and no metastasis.
  • This suggests an early-stage laryngeal carcinoma (likely T1 or T2), where the tumor is confined to the vocal cord without spread to adjacent tissues or lymph nodes.
  • For early-stage tumors of the larynx, radiotherapy is the treatment of choice.
  • It is effective in treating such localized tumors, helps preserve voice function, and avoids the need for more invasive procedures like surgery.

Laryngeal Cancer Treatment:

  • Laryngeal cancer typically presents with hoarseness, which may be the initial symptom.
  • When a tumor is localized to the vocal cords (as in this case), and there is no evidence of regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, radiotherapy offers an effective non-surgical option. It preserves the vocal cords and the patient's voice function, making it the preferred treatment modality for early-stage cancers.
  • In advanced laryngeal cancers (involving surrounding structures or metastasis), more radical treatments like total laryngectomy or chemotherapy may be necessary, but this is not the case here.

Incorrect Options:

Total laryngectomy (Option A): is incorrect because the tumor appears to be in an early, localized stage, and radiotherapy should be preferred for such cases to preserve the larynx and voice.

Conservative laryngectomy (Option C): is incorrect because while partial laryngectomy may be considered for certain cases, radiotherapy is typically the first-line treatment for early-stage vocal cord cancer with no spread.

Chemotherapy (Option D): is incorrect because chemotherapy is generally reserved for advanced or metastatic cancers, which is not the case in this patient, as there is no evidence of metastasis or lymph node involvement.

questions.text: A child presents to the orthopedic OPD with a limp and limb shortening. His X-ray is given below, What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) DDH

Explanation:

  • Hip joint laxity and a positive Barlow’s test in an infant with no fever is suggestive of Congenital dislocation of hip (CDH) also known as Developmental dysplasia of Hip (DDH).
  • Preferred management in a child <6 months is application of splint - Von rosen splint & Pavlik harness.

Investigations in DDH:

Age

Investigation of choice

Classification used

<6 months

USG (screening investigation)

Graf’s classification

>6 months

MRI (diagnostic investigation)

Kashiwagi’s classification

Management of DDH:

<6 months

Von rosen splint and Pavlik harness

6-18 months

Closed reduction with Hip spica

>18 months

Open reduction with pelvic osteotomies (Salter’s/Chiari osteotomy)

Risk factors for DDH: (5Fs)

  • Female babies
  • First borns
  • Full term (High relaxin levels during term - Relaxin causes joint laxity)
  • Fair (more common in white race)
  • Faulty intrauterine position (Breech, oligohydramnios)

 

Perthes (Option A): Perthes disease involves the avascular necrosis of the femoral head, typically seen in children between 4-8 years old. X-ray findings would show collapse or flattening of the femoral head, not the changes seen in DDH.

SCFE (Option B) (Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis): SCFE involves the slipping of the femoral head on the neck, usually occurring during adolescence. It presents with a limp and restricted hip movement, but X-rays would show a displacement of the femoral head relative to the neck, not typical for DDH.

Fracture neck of femur (Option D): A fracture would typically present with acute pain, inability to move the hip, and a history of trauma. X-rays would show a clear fracture, which is not consistent with DDH.

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic procedure prior to performing functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CT scan

Explanation:

  • The preferred diagnostic procedure prior to performing Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is a CT scan.
  • A CT scan provides detailed imaging of the sinus anatomy and helps to identify any sinus pathology such as sinusitis, nasal polyps, blockages, or anatomical variations that could affect the surgical approach.
  • It is crucial for planning the procedure and avoiding complications during surgery.

Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS):

  • FESS is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis, nasal polyps, and other sinus conditions.
  • Before performing this surgery, it is essential to have a clear understanding of the patient's sinus anatomy and any underlying pathology.
  • CT imaging is the gold standard for evaluating the sinuses, as it provides high-resolution, cross-sectional images that allow for precise assessment of sinus structures, mucosal involvement, and any blockages.

Incorrect Options:

MRI scan (Option A): is incorrect because MRI is typically used for evaluating soft tissue or neurological issues, and it is not as effective as CT for assessing the sinus anatomy and bone structures, which are key for FESS planning.

X-ray (Option B): is incorrect because X-ray imaging is less detailed than CT and cannot provide the necessary clarity to evaluate the sinuses thoroughly, especially for complex sinus conditions.

Antral lavage (Option C): is incorrect because antral lavage is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to irrigate the maxillary sinus in cases of chronic sinusitis. However, it is not used for detailed preoperative planning for FESS. A CT scan is the more accurate and comprehensive diagnostic tool for this purpose.

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound when compressing the swelling. As the X-ray neck was inconclusive a CT neck was taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Laryngocele

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Laryngocele.
  • A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the saccule of the larynx, which can communicate with the laryngeal lumen.
  • The gurgling sound when compressing the swelling suggests the presence of air or fluid within the sac.
  • This condition is often associated with activities that increase intra-abdominal or intrathoracic pressure, such as blowing a trumpet or playing other wind instruments.
  • The CT scan would reveal a characteristic air-filled structure adjacent to the larynx, confirming the diagnosis.

Laryngocele:

  • A laryngocele is a condition where a portion of the laryngeal mucosa becomes dilated, typically due to increased pressure, causing an air-filled sac to form.
  • It can be classified into internal (confined within the larynx) or external (extending outside the larynx into the neck).
  • Laryngoceles are commonly seen in individuals who perform activities that involve frequent increases in intrathoracic or abdominal pressure, such as trumpet players or other wind instrument musicians.
  • The clinical presentation may include a neck mass, hoarseness, or, as in this case, a gurgling sound when the mass is compressed.

Incorrect Options:

Pharyngeal pouch (Option A): is incorrect because a pharyngeal pouch (or Zenker's diverticulum) would present with dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and aspiration, but it is not associated with a gurgling sound on compression. Additionally, it would be located in the posterior aspect of the pharynx, not adjacent to the larynx.

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option C): is incorrect because a tracheoesophageal fistula is a congenital abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, typically diagnosed in infancy. It may present with choking or aspiration but would not present as a swelling with a gurgling sound in the neck of an adult, and a CT scan would show a connection between the trachea and esophagus, not a laryngeal dilation.

Tonsillar (Option D): is incorrect because tonsillar swelling is typically associated with infections or tumors of the tonsils and would not produce a gurgling sound or the findings seen on CT imaging.

questions.text: What is the most frequent location of obstruction caused by a nasal polyp originating from the maxillary sinus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Middle meatus

Explanation:

  • The most common location for an obstruction caused by a nasal polyp originating from the maxillary sinus is the middle meatus.
  • Nasal polyps are benign growths that arise from the mucosa of the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses.
  • When a polyp forms in the maxillary sinus, it typically expands into the middle meatus, which is the drainage pathway of the maxillary sinus.
  • This can lead to obstruction, sinusitis, or blockage of the sinus drainage.

Nasal Polyps:

  • Nasal polyps are non-cancerous growths that develop in the nasal passages or sinuses due to chronic inflammation.
  • They are frequently associated with conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis, asthma, and allergies.
  • The most common location for these polyps is the middle meatus, which is where the maxillary sinuses drain.
  • If the polyps obstruct the drainage system, it can lead to recurrent sinus infections, nasal congestion, and difficulty breathing through the nose.

Incorrect Options:

Inferior meatus (Option A): is incorrect because the inferior meatus primarily drains the nasolacrimal duct and not the maxillary sinus, so polyps from the maxillary sinus would not typically obstruct this area.

Superior meatus (Option B): is incorrect because the superior meatus drains the posterior ethmoidal sinuses, not the maxillary sinus, so it would not be the most common site of obstruction for a maxillary sinus polyp.

Sphenoethmoidal recess (Option D): is incorrect because the sphenoethmoidal recess is the drainage site for the sphenoid sinus, not the maxillary sinus, making it an unlikely location for obstruction due to a maxillary sinus polyp.

questions.text: Which of the following least likely causes nasal septal perforation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Seasonal influenza

Explanation:

  • Seasonal influenza is the least likely cause of nasal septal perforation. While influenza can lead to symptoms like nasal congestion, sore throat, and fever, it typically does not result in nasal septal perforation.
  • This condition is more often associated with chronic inflammation, infection, or trauma to the nasal septum, such as in cases of rhinosporidiosis, syphilis, or tuberculosis.

Causes of Nasal Septal Perforation:

  • Nasal septal perforation is a hole or rupture in the nasal septum, the cartilage and bone that divides the two nostrils. Several conditions can lead to this, including:
    • Rhinosporidiosis: This is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by the fungus Rhinosporidium seeberi, often affecting the nasal mucosa and leading to the development of polyps or perforations in the nasal septum.
    • Syphilis: A sexually transmitted infection caused by Treponema pallidum, syphilis can cause granulomatous inflammation, particularly in the tertiary stage, leading to nasal septal perforation (a manifestation of gumma).
    • Tuberculosis: This chronic bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis can result in chronic granulomatous inflammation, leading to nasal septal perforation as part of the disease process, especially in advanced cases.
    • Seasonal influenza (Option B): is incorrect because while it causes acute viral upper respiratory tract infections, it does not typically result in chronic inflammation or tissue destruction that would lead to septal perforation.

Incorrect Options:

Rhinosporidiosis (Option A): is incorrect because this fungal infection is a well-known cause of nasal septal perforation due to chronic inflammation and polyp formation.

Syphilis (Option C): is incorrect because tertiary syphilis can cause granulomatous lesions, including perforation of the nasal septum.
