Tuberculosis (Option D): is incorrect because tuberculosis, particularly in its chronic form, can cause nasal septal perforation due to granulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: What could be the most probable cause for the progressive vision loss in both eyes of a 25-year-old male who has been undergoing low-dose oral steroid therapy for the past decade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cataract

Explanation:

  • The most likely reason for the progressive loss of vision in a 25-year-old male who has been on low-dose oral steroid therapy for the last 10 years is Cataract.

Toxic cataract:

  • Steroids - Prolonged use in high doses may cause posterior subcapsular cataracts. Children are more susceptible

  • Other causes of posterior subcapsular cataract: Galactosemia, Myotonic dystrophy, BLUNT trauma, complicated cataract, chloroquine, busulfan, NF2,

  • Glaucoma by TOPICAL steroids (Option B) and cataract by SYSTEMIC STEROIDS (mnemonic: GTCS)

  • Miotics - Especially long-acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as echothiophate, demecarium bromide, and diisopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) may cause anterior subcapsular-granular cataracts

  • Other causes of anterior subcapsular cataract - Amiodarone, chlorpromazine, busulfan, gold, and allopurinol

  • AACG ( Mnemonic): Atopic dermatitis- shield cataract, Amiodarone, Chlorpromazine, Gold deposit, AACG(acute angle closure glaucoma)

Incorrect Options

Glaucoma (Option B) is the most common complication of topical steroids.

Cystoid macular edema (Option C) may be associated with steroid use, but it typically presents with symptoms such as blurry vision, central vision loss, and distortion.

Retinal detachment (Option D) causes progressive loss of vision which is not consistent with the above described case.

questions.text: Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Epidermophyton

Explanation:

Epidermophyton is a dermatophyte genus that produces distinctive macroconidia that are typically club-shaped, smooth, and have 2-4 cells. These macroconidia are usually larger than those produced by Trichophyton and Microsporum, which have different shapes and sizes.

Classification of Dermatophytosis

Anatomic Classification

Dermatophytosis can be classified based on the affected anatomical site:

Clinical Type

Description

Tinea barbae

Infection of the bearded areas of the face and neck (barber's itch).

Tinea capitis

Infection of the scalp; variants include favus and kerion.

Tinea corporis

Infection of smooth, non-hairy skin (Tinea glabrosa).

Tinea cruris

Infection of the groin and perineum (jock itch).

Tinea imbricata

Tropical variant of Tinea corporis with concentric scaly patches.

Tinea manuum

Infection of the hand.

Tinea pedis

Infection of the foot (athlete's foot).

Tinea unguium

Infection of the nails.

Classification by Genus

 

Genus

Key Characteristics

Microsporum

Predominantly macroconidia; spindle-shaped, multicellular structures; infects hair and skin. (Option B ruled out)

Trichophyton

More abundant microconidia in clusters; macroconidia are thin, and elongated; include species like T. rubrum which is common in humans. Infects hair, nails and skin. (Option A ruled out)

Epidermophyton

Lacks microconidia; club-shaped, multicellular macroconidia; infects skin and nails but not hair. (Option C) (Option D ruled out)

 

Features

Trichophyton

Microsporum

Epidermophyton

1. Site of infection

Hair, nail, and skin

Hair and skin only

Skin and nail only

2. Colony

Powdery pigmented

Cotton-like pigmented

Powdery greenish yellow

3. Spores

a. Microconidia

Abundant

Relatively scanty

Absent

b. Macroconidia

Pencil or cylindrical-shaped

Spindle-shaped

Club or pear-shaped

Types of Conidia

  • Microconidia: Small, unicellular conidia.
  • Macroconidia: Larger, multicellular, septate conidia

questions.text: A 30 year old apparently healthy man who was carrying laxatives and enema apparatus developed abdominal pain at the airport and an x-ray was done which appears as shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Body packer syndrome

Explanation:

  • Body packer's syndrome, also called the surgical mules syndrome is a planned activity to smuggle drugs.
  • The drug to be smuggled is usually wrapped in polythene or condom, and swallowed/planted inside vagina or rectum.
  • The x-ray shows cylindrical objects which may be containers for the drugs.

Incorrect Options:

Bezoar Syndrome (Option A): It is a syndrome in which there is a tightly packed collection of something inside the stomach.Usually, bezoar occurs for a collection of hair inside the stomach, but it can be any indigestible natural/unnatural object.

Pica due to anemia (Option B): It does not present as shown in the case history.

Constipation due to fecalith (Option D): It mostly shows excessive bloating, not shown in the x ray.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 36-year-old man who has been experiencing bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and pinna for the past 6 months, along with a history of black urine upon standing since childhood?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alkaptonuria

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario described, including darkening of urine upon standing, bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and ear cartilage, and joint pain, is characteristic of Alkaptonuria, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate oxidase.

Garrod's tetrad in alkaptonuria

1. Homogentisic Aciduria

Presence of homogentisic acid in the urine, which turns dark upon standing or when exposed to air.

2. Ochronosis

Deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly noticeable in the ear cartilage, sclera, and other connective tissues, leading to a bluish-black discoloration.The image shows Osler’s sign.

3. Arthropathy

Degenerative joint disease, especially affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic pain and stiffness.

4. Cardiac Involvement

Includes heart valve calcification and atherosclerosis due to the deposition of pigment in cardiac tissues.

 

 

Phenylketonuria (Option A): PKU causes mental retardation, hypopigmentation, and a mousy odor due to phenylalanine accumulation. However, it does not cause bluish-black discoloration of the sclera or black urine upon standing.

Tyrosinemia (Option C): This disorder involves the accumulation of tyrosine or its metabolites, causing liver and kidney damage, but does not lead to bluish-black discoloration of the sclera or pinna or black urine upon standing.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (Option D): This is a metabolic disorder caused by the inability to break down branched-chain amino acids, leading to a sweet, maple syrup odor in the urine. It does not cause black urine or scleral discoloration.

questions.text: A man continues to call females. Achieves sexual gratification by talking obscenity & sharing obscene pictures.The condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Scatologia

Explanation:

Based on the provided information, the patient most likely has scatologia.

  • Scatologia refers to a paraphilic disorder in which a person achieves sexual arousal and gratification by engaging in obscene or sexually explicit talk or behavior.
  • It involves the use of obscene language, sharing obscene píctures, or engaging in explicit conversations with others, often without their consent.

Incorrect Options:

Frotteurism (Option A): This is a paraphilic disorder in which a person derives sexual pleasure from rubbing against or touching non-consenting individuals in crowded places.It typically involves non-consensual physical contact.

Voyeurism (Option B): Voyeurism intense sexual interest in observing others while they are undressing, naked, or engaged in sexual activities, without their knowledge or consent.

Coprophilia (Option D): Coprophilia is a paraphilic disorder in which a person derives sexual pleasure from feces or associated activities.

questions.text: Complex IV is inhibited by --?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cyanide

Explanation:

  • Complex IV, also known as cytochrome c oxidase, is the final enzyme in the electron transport chain, where it catalyzes the transfer of electrons to oxygen, resulting in water formation. Cyanide inhibits Complex IV by binding to the iron in the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase, thereby preventing the transfer of electrons to oxygen.

Inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

Inhibitor

Target Site

Mechanism

Rotenone (Option A)

Amobarbital

Piericidin A

Complex I

(NADH dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex I to ubiquinone​

 

TTFA (Thenoyltrifluoroacetone)

Carboxin (Option C)

Complex II

(Succinate dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex II to ubiquinone​

Malonate

Complex II

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A (Option D)

BAL

Complex III

Cytochrome bc1 complex

 

Blocks electron transfer from Complex III to Cytochrome C.

Cyanide (CN−) (Option B)

Carbon monoxide (CO)

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S)

Complex IV

(Cytochrome c Oxidase)

 

Prevents electron transfer from Complex IV to oxygen​

Oligomycin

ATP Synthase (Complex V)

 

Blocks the proton channel of ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis​

Atractyloside

Adenine Nucleotide Translocase

Blocks ADP/ATP exchange across the mitochondrial membrane​

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty with greenish color skin and a rotten egg odour. The most probable poisoning could be.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hydrogen sulfide

Explanation:

Hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) is a highly toxic gas with a characteristic rotten egg odor.

  • It affects cellular respiration by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase, similar to cyanide poisoning but with distinct features.

Key Features of Hydrogen Sulfide Poisoning:

  • Skin "font-size: 11pt; font-variant:normal; white-space:pre-wrap" > Greenish discoloration (due to sulfhemoglobin formation)
  • Odor: Rotten egg smell (from hydrogen sulfide gas)
  • Respiratory: Severe pulmonary irritation, dyspnea, and respiratory failure
  • CNS: Headache, dizziness, seizures, coma
  • Cardiac: Bradycardia, hypotension, sudden collapse
  • Rapid onset of toxicity due to cellular hypoxia
  • Mechanism: Inhibits cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain → cellular hypoxia → metabolic acidosis.

Incorrect Options:

Carbon monoxide (Option A): Cherry red skin, no odor.

Nitrite (Option B): Chocolate brown blood (methemoglobinemia).

Cyanide (Option C): Bitter almond odor, pink skin, rapid onset of toxicity.

questions.text: Which enzymes show deficiency in Von Gierke's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glucose-6-phosphatase

Explanation:

  • Von Gierke's disease is characterized by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, which impairs the liver’s ability to convert glycogen to glucose. This results in severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and elevated levels of lactate, triglycerides, and uric acid.

Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)

Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and Hyperlipidemia

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)

 

Glycogen Storage Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Type 0

Glycogen synthase deficiency

Type I (von Gierke's Disease)

Glucose-6-phosphatase

Type II (Pompe's Disease)

Acid α-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Type III (Cori's Disease)

Debranching enzyme (amylo-1,6-glucosidase)

(Option C ruled out)

Type IV (Andersen's Disease)

Branching enzyme

Type V (McArdle's Disease)

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase (myophosphorylase)

(Option B ruled out)

Type VI (Hers' Disease)

Liver glycogen phosphorylase

(Option A ruled out)

Type VII (Tarui's Disease)

Phosphofructokinase (muscle type)

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) L-arginine

Explanation:

  • Nitric oxide (NO˙) is a highly reactive free radical with an unpaired electron, making it highly reactive.
  • It is uncharged and has a short half-life (approximately 0.1 second).
  • Synthesis of Nitric Oxide:
    • NO˙ is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
    • NOS contains heme, FAD, FMN, and tetrahydrobiopterine.
    • The process utilizes NADPH and molecular oxygen.
    • Calmodulin is required to modulate NOS activity.
    • The guanidino nitrogen of arginine is incorporated into NO˙, while one oxygen atom from molecular oxygen is incorporated into NO˙ and the other into citrulline. This makes NOS a di-oxygenase enzyme.
  • Isoenzymes of NOS:
  • Mechanism of Action of Nitric Oxide:
    • NO˙ diffuses to adjacent smooth muscle cells and activates guanylate cyclase.
    • This leads to an increase in cyclic GMP levels, which activates protein kinase in smooth muscle.
    • This causes the dephosphorylation of myosin light chains, resulting in relaxation of smooth muscle (vasodilation) in blood vessels, leading to lower blood pressure.

 

L-citrulline (Option B): L-citrulline is a byproduct of nitric oxide synthesis, as it is produced from L-arginine during the enzymatic conversion to NO˙. It is not the direct precursor for nitric oxide.

Glycine (Option C): Glycine is an amino acid, but it is not involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It serves other functions in the body, such as being a neurotransmitter.

Lysine (Option D): L-lysine is another amino acid, but it does not play a direct role in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

questions.text: What is the specific name of the test performed by the doctor during the autopsy where they tied the bronchus and submerged the lung in water to determine if it floats or sinks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hydrostatic test

Explanation:

  • The test described, where the bronchus is tied and the lung is immersed in water to check whether it floats or sinks, is known as the Hydrostatic test.

Hydrostatic test/ Raygat's test/ Breslau's 1 life test/ Lung floatation test

  • If the baby had respired, the alveoli would be expanded/ dilated.
  • Thus, as the lungs are expanded, alveoli are dilated & the specific gravity decreases.
  • Alveoli are dilated d/t presence of residual air.
  • When lungs are expanded, specific gravity becomes <1.
  • Thus, they float when they are placed in the water
  • This test is performed to assess the buoyancy of the lung, as the presence of air within the lung tissue causes it to float in water.
  • It is used as a supportive indication of drowning, as drowning often leads to the aspiration of water into the lungs, resulting in increased lung buoyancy.

Incorrect Options:

Gettler's test (Option A): It is based on the chloride concentration in the blood samples of heart chambers. Normally, chloride concentration in both right side chambers & left side chambers should be equal

Ploucquet's test (Option B): Plouquet's test is a test used to detect ratio between Weight of the lung to the Weight of the baby.

Diatom's test (Option D): Diatom's test is a forensic examination that involves analyzing the presence of diatoms, in various tissues and , fluids to determine if a person was submerged in water.

questions.text: Identify the method of substance abuse as shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bagging

Explanation:

Methods of substance abuse

Explanation

Bagging

(Option B)
  • Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors.
  • The bag is typically held over the nose and mouth, allowing the person to inhale the substance contained within the bag.

Snorting

(Option A)
  • Snorting involves the inhalation of powdered substances, typically drugs, through the nose.
  • The substance is crushed into a fine powder and then snorted through the nostrils using a straw, rolled-up paper, or other devices.

Sniffing

(Option C)
  • Sniffing refers to the act of inhaling or smelling substances, often volatile or aromatic substances.

Huffing

(Option D)
  • Huffing involves the deliberate inhalation of volatile substances or inhalants directly from their container or source.
  • This method is associated with the misuse of chemicals, solvents, or other volatile substances for recreational purposes.

questions.text: While collecting a blood sample for investigations, you accidentally dropped a 5 ml tube of blood and spilled blood. Which among the following is the best solution to clean it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1:100 sodium hypochlorite

Explanation:

Small blood spillage (<10 mL) should be managed by 1:100 dilution of 5.25% Sodium hypochlorite after cleaning the area with an absorbable material.

Halogens:

Examples
  • Tincture Iodine (2% Iodine): bactericidal + sporicidal
  • Povidone Iodine (Betadine): has residual action
  • Sodium hypochlorite (5.25%): Both bactericidal + virucidal

Mechanism of action
  • Oxidisation

Uses

  • Skin antiseptic, wound dressing (Betadine preferred)
  • Town water supply, Swimming pools (Chlorine)
  • Sodium hypochlorite: Blood spills (1:10/1:100 dilution of 5.25% solution used)

 

Blood spills management:

  • Block off the area to be disinfected.
  • Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves.
  • Use brush and tongs to clean up broken glass pieces (never use bare hands) and discard the pieces onto a Sharps container (White).
  • Use an absorbable material (paper/gauze/cloth) to wipe off body fluids/blood.
  • Saturate the area with Sodium hypochlorite:
    • Dose: 5.25% Sodium hypochlorite
    • Strength: Small spills (<10 mL) - 1:100, Large spills (>10 mL) - 1:10 dilution
  • Rinse off the instruments used with running water and place to dry, discard absorbable material into the yellow bin.
  • Remove and discard gloves into the red bin.
  • Wash hands carefully with soap and water and dry using single-use towels.
  • Record the incidence in the register.

Isopropyl alcohol (Option B): While it is a good disinfectant, it’s not as effective against all bloodborne pathogens compared to sodium hypochlorite, especially in the context of cleaning up blood spills.

Hydrogen peroxide (Option C): It can be used for cleaning but is not as effective as sodium hypochlorite for disinfecting blood spills.


1:1000 sodium hypochlorite (Option D): This dilution is too weak to effectively disinfect blood spills. The 1:100 dilution is the standard recommendation.

questions.text: A man was found to be lying dead on the ground. His friend saw a snake passing in the area and took a picture of it and showed it to the doctor (image below). What is the most probable cause of death of this man?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Respiratory failure

Explanation:

  • The most probable cause of death in this scenario is respiratory failure, commonly associated with neurotoxic snake venom.
  • The snake seen was likely an elapid (krait), which are neurotoxic species.
  • Neurotoxic venom affects the nervous system, leading to paralysis of the respiratory muscles (diaphragm).

Mechanism:

  • Neurotoxins block neuromuscular transmission by inhibiting acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Leads to progressive muscle paralysis, including respiratory muscles, causing respiratory failure and death.

Incorrect Options:

Shock (Option A): Typically seen in viper bites (vasculotoxic) due to severe hypotension and tissue damage.

Coagulopathy (Option C): Common in viper bites causing hemotoxic effects like bleeding and DIC.

Renal failure (Option D): Seen in hemotoxic bites causing acute tubular necrosis due to hemoglobinuria or myoglobinuria.

questions.text: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presented with low-grade fever, cough, night sweats, and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. In view of TB investigations, the Mantoux test was negative; chest X-ray showed non-specific findings, and an adequate amount of sputum could not be collected for slide examination. Which of the following is used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Interferon-gamma release assay

Explanation:

The primary use of IGRAs is to identify individuals with latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) and Interferon-gamma Release Assays (IGRAs) are specific for latent tuberculosis infection.

Diagnostic Tests:

  • Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)
  • Interferon-gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)
  • Chest X-ray
  • Sputum Tests
  • Biopsy of suspicious lesions or lymph nodes for histopathological examination.

Interferon-gamma Release Assay (IGRA):

  • Principle: T-lymphocytes release interferon-gamma when exposed to M. tuberculosis antigens. Mycobacterium TB antigen CFP10 is used in the test, and it reacts with the patient's T cells to release γ interferons.
  • IGRAs like QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube offer several advantages for LTBI diagnosis:
    • Higher specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals (negative in BCG-vaccinated individuals)
    • No cross-reactivity with most non-tuberculous mycobacteria
    • Requires only a single patient visit
    • Results are available within 24-48 hours
    • No boosting effect with repeated testing
      • T spot TB Test is also approved in IGRA.

TB lab investigations:

Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

CBNAAT (Option A) (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test): This is primarily used for active TB diagnosis and detecting drug-resistant TB by detecting TB DNA in sputum or other body fluids, but it’s not used to diagnose latent TB.

MGIT system (Option B) (Mycobacteria Growth Indicator Tube): This is a culture-based method used for detecting active TB by growing mycobacteria from sputum or other clinical samples. It’s not used for diagnosing latent TB.

Line probe assay (Option D): This is used to detect drug resistance in active TB by identifying mutations in the TB genome, not for diagnosing latent TB.

questions.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) has defined blindness as a condition where the level of visual acuity is below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option B : 3/60

Explanation:

  • WHO (World Health Organization) defines blindness as visual acuity less than 3/60. It indicates severe impairment of vision, where the person can only see at a distance of 3 meters or less what a person with normal vision can see clearly at 60 meters.

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".
  • The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option D ruled out)

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A ruled out)

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B)

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old healthy man with a history of small streaks of blood in his stools is being sent for a colonoscopy to screen for colon cancer. This type of prevention is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option B: Secondary

Explanation:

Levels of prevention

Definition

Primordial (Option A ruled out)
  • Prevention of establishment of risk factors.
  • It aims to discourage people from adopting harmful habits.

Primary (Option C ruled out)

 
  • Prevention of onset of disease in a high-risk group/individual.
  • It aims to protect the health of those who are at risk.
  • Reduces the incidence of the disease.

Secondary (Option B)
  • Disease progression can be prevented at an early stage (Disease is reversible).
  • It aims to reduce the prevalence of the disease by early identification and prompt treatment of diseases, and it also prevents complications.

Tertiary (Option D ruled out)
  • Prevention or limitation of impairment and disability in a diseased patient who has developed complications due to the disease and the disease has become irreversible.
  • It aims to minimise a patient's suffering and maximise potential years of useful life.

questions.text: When is the population evaluated to calculate the crude death rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A- 1st July

Explanation:

Crude death rate:

CDR = (Total no. or deaths in a community/ MYP (Mid-year population) in the same area) x 100

  • The mid-year population is taken in July (Option A)
  • Limitation: It does not consider the age and sex of the population
  • Interpretation: A higher crude death rate indicates a higher overall mortality burden within a population, while a lower rate indicates a lower mortality burden.
  • Data Sources: Vital registration systems, census data, population surveys, or administrative records may provide the necessary data for calculating the crude death rate.

questions.text: In a train accident, there were 74 dead, 64 were severely injured, 20 moderately injured and 12 mildly injured. Colour coding in triage, from highest to lowest priority is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D- Red-Yellow-Green-Black

Explanation:

Triage:

  • During a disaster, the quantity and severity of injuries overwhelm the operative capacity of the health facilities. Triage involves rapidly organizing the injured individuals based on the severity of their injuries and survival with prompt interventions.
  • During triage, tagging should be done to each individual, including:

    • Name

    • Age

    • Place of origin

    • Triage category

    • Diagnosis and

    • Initial treatment.

 

Color coding in triage:

Types of triage:

  • Reverse triage:

    • Used in surges (bed scarcity) and during wars.

    • Priority: Green → Yellow → Red.

  • Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment (START):

    • Done in remote or inaccessible areas.

    • Laymen can start doing triage before rescue teams reach.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of cholera toxin?

choices.text: Toxin causes increased guanyl cyclase activity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Activates adenylate cyclase

Explanation:

Cholera toxin binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells. Once internalized, the A subunit of the toxin activates adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP disrupts ion transport, causing a significant efflux of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in profuse watery diarrhea.

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea. (Option B)
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Inhibit elongation factor -2 (Option A): This is the mechanism of diphtheria toxin, not cholera toxin. Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by modifying elongation factor-2.

Toxin causes increased guanylate cyclase activity (Option B): This is associated with guanylin or heat-stable enterotoxins (like those produced by some strains of E. coli), but not cholera toxin.

Inhibit 60S subunit (Option D): This mechanism is seen in shiga toxin (produced by Shigella and some strains of E. coli), which inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 60S ribosomal subunit.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, he has extensive cervical swelling and a well-demarcated white-gray exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx and attempts to remove this membrane result in bleeding. The parents report that all his childhood vaccines were skipped due to religious beliefs. A throat swab under Albert's staining is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diphtheria

Explanation:

Diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and it often presents with symptoms like fever, sore throat, and cervical swelling (often referred to as "bull neck"). A key feature is the presence of a well-demarcated, white-gray exudative membrane in the oropharynx, which is adherent and causes bleeding when attempts are made to remove it. This membrane is a hallmark of diphtheria. The fact that the child’s vaccines were skipped increases the risk for this disease, as diphtheria is preventable through vaccination (DPT).

The throat swab showing characteristic Albert's staining would demonstrate the club-shaped, gram-positive bacilli typical of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Diphtheria

Clinical Features

Complications
  • Sore throat
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Low-grade fever
  • Grey Pseudomembrane formation in the throat that bleeds on removal
  • Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin
  • Myocarditis
  • Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy)
  • Renal failure
  • Airway obstruction

 

Culture Media

Colony appearance

Evaluation

Loeffler’s serum slope
  • Small
  • Circular opaque disks
  • Glistening,
  • White with a yellow tinge
  • Advantage: Growth can be detected as early as 6–8 hours.
  • The best medium for metachromatic granule production
  • Disadvantage: Supports the growth of other throat commensals also

Potassium tellurite agar

(McLeod’s and Hoyle’s-modified PTA)
  • Grey or black colour
  • Advantage: Throat commensals are inhibited
  • Disadvantage: Colonies appear only after 48 hours of incubation

Sheep blood agar
  • Small
  • Circular
  • White
  • Sometimes hemolytic(mitis biotype)
  • Differentiate colonies from streptococcal or staphylococcal pharyngitis, which may simulate diphtheria.
  • The serum slope may show growth in 4-8 hours but, if negative, will have to be incubated for 24 hours

Albert Stain

Principle: Albert's stain causes the metachromatic granules of C. diphtheriae to appear bluish-purple upon staining.

  • Corynebacterium diphtheria shows chinese letter/ cuneiform appearance
  • Diphtheroids show regular and palisading appearance with lesser number of granules

 

Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2
  • Iodine
  • Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules.

Procedure:

  1. Stain the smear with Albert I stain, then drain and wash it.
  2. Apply Albert II stain to cover the smear, then drain it.

Application:

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes, characterized by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli.
  • Albert's, Neisser's, and Ponder's stains help stain these distinctive granules in the bacteria.
  • These granules are also Found in Spirillum, Gardnerella, Yersinia pestis, yeast, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB)


Albert stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria shows bacilli with metachromatic granules.

Streptococcal pharyngitis (Option A): This condition, caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, can present with sore throat and fever, but it does not cause the characteristic exudative membrane and bleeding when removed. It is also not associated with cervical swelling like diphtheria.

Tetanus (Option C): Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani and presents with muscle rigidity and spasms (lockjaw), not a sore throat with an exudative membrane. It does not cause the features described in the question.


Pertussis (Option D): Pertussis (whooping cough), caused by Bordetella pertussis, presents with a persistent cough, whooping sounds, and sometimes vomiting, but it does not present with an exudative membrane in the throat or bleeding after membrane removal.

questions.text: What is the average incubation period of plasmodium falciparum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 12

Explanation:

  • For Plasmodium falciparum, the average incubation period is typically around 12 days from the time of infection until the onset of symptoms.
  • The parasite binds to RBCs using the Basigin receptor (CD147), facilitating its entry into the cells.

Properties of different species of Plasmodium:

Properties

P.vivax

P.ovale

P.falciparum

P.malariae

Not seen

Seen

Preference

Reticulocytes

Young erythrocytes

Old erythrocytes

Erythrocytic Cycle

48 hours

48 hours

36–48 hours

72 hours

Prepatent Period

8 days

9 days

5 days

13 days

Incubation Period

12- 17 days

14-17 days

12 days

28-30 days

Stages found in peripheral blood

Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes

As in vivax

Ring form, accole form, gametocytes

Band forms

Infected erythrocyte

Enlarged pale with Schuffner's dots

Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner's dots (Jame's dots)

Normal size, Maurer's cleft

Normal size, Ziemann's stippling

Gametocyte

Yellowish-brown

Prepatent period: The time from the entry of the parasite into the host until it is detectable in peripheral blood.

Incubation period: Time interval from the entry of the parasite until the appearance of the first clinical symptoms.

Receptors on RBC:

  • Plasmodium vivax: Binds to Duffy antigen (also known as Duffy blood group antigen) on the surface of red blood cells (RBCs)
  • Plasmodium falciparum: Binds to Basigin (also known as CD147), a protein expressed on the surface of RBCs

Options B, C, & D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 55 year old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile at 40 degree C, hypotensive, and has tachycardia. The blood smear of this patient is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

Based on the description of the patient's symptoms (fever, hypotension, tachycardia) and the blood smear findings, Plasmodium falciparum is the most likely causative agent. P. falciparum is known to cause severe malaria, which can present with high fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and other complications like cerebral malaria and organ dysfunction. The Microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum.

Aspect

Vivax

Falciparum

Malariae

Ovale

RBC size

Enlarged

Normal

Normal

Enlarged with frayed margins

Pigments

Yellowish brown

Dark brown

Schizont

Large (9-10 μm) Fills the RBC Contains 12-24 merozoite

Not seen in the periphery

Small (6 μm), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites

Gametocytes

Spherical

Crescentic Larger than RBC

Spherical

Ring form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

1.5 μm

Occupies ⅙ of RBC size

It may be

  • Multiple forms
  • Accole (attached to RBC membrane)
  • Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus

Band form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

Plasmodium vivax (Option A): This species can cause milder malaria compared to P. falciparum. The blood smear for P. vivax often shows larger trophozoites with a larger, irregular-shaped ring and sometimes a "schuffner's dots" characteristic, which isn't described in the scenario.

Plasmodium ovale (Option C): This species is similar to P. vivax in causing mild malaria. It tends to have oval-shaped red blood cells in the smear and may also show schuffner's dots. It is less likely to cause the severe symptoms described.


Plasmodium malariae (Option D): This species generally causes milder malaria and may present with quotidian fever (fever occurring every 24 hours). The blood smear shows band forms or Ziemann’s dots, which are not typically associated with the severe symptoms seen in this patient.

questions.text: An unknown disease of suspected infectious origin has come up in your town. As a microbiologist, you collect the relevant samples and detect the etiological cause. Which of the following types of PCR would you do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Real time PCR

Explanation:

  • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR), also known as quantitative PCR (qPCR), is widely used for detecting and quantifying the presence of specific pathogens (whether bacterial, viral, or fungal).
  • It provides real-time monitoring of the amplification process and is sensitive, specific, and fast, making it ideal for diagnosing infectious diseases, particularly in an outbreak situation.
  • It also allows for quantification of the pathogen, which can help in assessing the severity of the infection and monitoring the response to treatment.

Nested PCR (Option B): Nested PCR is useful for amplifying DNA in cases where the target is present in very small amounts, but it requires two sets of primers and multiple amplification steps, which makes it more time-consuming. It is typically used when a specific pathogen is suspected, but real-time PCR is more versatile and quicker for detection and quantification.

Reverse Transcriptase PCR (Option C) (RT-PCR): This is specifically used for RNA viruses, where the RNA is first reverse-transcribed into cDNA before amplification. If you suspect an infectious disease caused by a virus with RNA as the genetic material (like influenza, HIV, or SARS-CoV-2), this could be useful. However, real-time PCR can also be used for RNA detection with added reverse transcription, making it a more comprehensive choice.


Multiplex PCR (Option D): Multiplex PCR allows the simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens in a single reaction, which is useful if you suspect the presence of multiple pathogens. While this is very useful for broad diagnostics, real-time PCR offers the added benefit of quantification and faster results for a more specific pathogen detection.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option A) Chi Square test

Explanation:

  • The Chi-Square test is used to determine whether there is a significant association between two categorical variables. In this case, the variables are "nutritional status" (malnourished or not) and "area of residence" (rural or urban). By comparing the observed frequencies (40 malnourished children in rural areas and 30 malnourished children in urban areas) with the expected frequencies, the Chi-Square test can assess if there is a significant difference in the distribution of malnourished children between rural and urban areas.

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test (Option B ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option D ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

Standard error of the mean (Option C): Quantifies the variability of sample means around the true population mean.

Standard error of the mean = standard deviation / √ sample size

questions.text: What is the most effective method for graphically representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a specific geographical region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A- Line graph

Explanation:

  • A line chart is used for showing trends of events or incidence of cases over time. It has both rise and fall.

Fig. Line chart

Histogram: (Option B ruled out)

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

Ogive: (Option C ruled out)

Aka cumulative frequency curve is useful for understanding how quantities accumulate over time. By plotting cumulative vaccination completion data on an ogive, the clinic can easily visualize the total number of patients vaccinated up to each month and observe trends in the rate of increase in vaccinations.

  • There is no dip or no fall of the curve.
  • Cases are constantly increasing

Fig. Ogive

Tree diagram (Option D): It is a visual tool used to represent hierarchical relationships or branching structures. It is commonly used in decision analysis or to display the possible outcomes of a particular event. It is not typically used to plot changes in disease incidence over time. Therefore, the most appropriate option for plotting the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area is a Line Graph.

questions.text: Identify the given logo below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B- Bureau of Indian standards

Explanation:

  • The Bureau of Indian Standards is the national standards body of India. It operates under the Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution, Government of India.
  • The logo represents the organization's commitment to setting and promoting standards for products, processes, and services in India.

LOGO

DESCRIPTION

(A)
  • Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI)
  • Headquarters: New Delhi
  • Ministry: Health and Family Welfare
  • Provides national food standards for products
  • Adopts standards from CODEX ALIMENTARIUS by WHO and FAO (WHO Headquarters: Geneva; FAO Headquarters: Rome)
  • Recently launched the Eat Right Campaign

(B)
  • Bureau of Indian Standards
  • Ministry: Ministry of Consumer affairs
  • PFA (Prevention of Food Adulteration) provides the Minimum quality of food products.
  • BIS provides quality above the minimum standards of food products.

(C)
  • Fruit Product/Process Order.
  • The Ministry of Food Processing Industries has created an online system for licensing and monitoring all activities related to the enforcement and administration of FPO.
  • Regulates the quality of tinned fruit juices and tinned fruit cans.

(D)
  • This is administered by the Directorate of Marketing and Inspection (DMI) under the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare for agricultural products.
  • AGMARK is a certification mark indicating that agricultural produce meets a grade standard specified by DMI

questions.text: For which type of variables is the following data representation used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C- Continuous

Explanation:

Histogram:

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

 Bar Diagram:

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender. (Options A & B ruled out)
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups
    • These are not represented in decimals so there are gaps

questions.text: A healthy person got in contact with an infected case, and they have to separate him as he is sick now. This is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B- Isolation

Explanation:

  • Isolation separates individuals who are already ill and potentially infectious from others to prevent disease spread, occurring either in healthcare facilities or at home based on illness severity and resource availability.

Isolation

Quarantine

For people who are sick

For well people who may have been exposed to a communicable disease

Separates people who are sick from those who are not sick

Applies to people who may or may not become sick

Restricts movement of people with an infectious disease to stop the spread of the Illness

Restricts the movement of healthy people who may develop a disease after possible exposure to an infectious agent

Allows for appropriate treatment in a hospital type/setting

Requires people to stay in a designated location, e.g. their home. For a specified period of time

Requires appropriate personal protective equipment (ppe) for those coming into contact with the person who is sick

Requires active monitoring including taking temperature twice daily and checking for other symptoms

Requires proper infection control, sterilization and waste management

PPE not required for contact with people who are not ill

Absolute Quarantine (Option A): It separates and restricts the movement of individuals exposed to a contagious disease but not yet symptomatic to monitor for symptoms and prevent potential disease spread upon becoming infectious.

Interruption of transmission (Option C): Tactics to halt disease spread, including tracing, quarantine, and hygiene.

Serial interval (Option D): Time between primary and secondary case symptoms, revealing transmission patterns.

questions.text: A researcher who was studying on plasmodium species decided to visit the malaria-endemic place in Odisha after 2 days to do his clinical study for 5 weeks. Which of the following drugs need to be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C- Doxycycline

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate drug for short-term malaria prophylaxis is Doxycycline 100mg daily.

Chemoprophylaxis of malaria:

 

Short-term prophylaxis

Long-term prophylaxis

Duration of Rx

< 6 weeks

> 6 weeks

DOC

Doxycycline 100 mg daily (Option C)

Mefloquine 250 mg weekly (Option B ruled out)

Prophylaxis period

Before travel

1-2 days

2-3 weeks

After travel

4 weeks

4 weeks

Contraindications of mefloquine:

  • History of convulsions.
  • Neuropsychiatric illness.
  • Cardiac conditions.

Other drugs for short-term prophylaxis:

  • Chloroquine: 100 mg or 150 mg tablets.
    • 300 mg (3 tablets of 100 mg or 2 tablets of 150 mg), once a week, on the same day each week.       (Or)
    • One tablet of 100 mg daily for 6 days per week.
  • Proguanil: 200 mg, 2 tablets once a day.

Artesunate (Option A): It is typically used to treat malaria. This option is incorrect.

Chloramphenicol (Option D): It is an antibiotic that is not typically used for malaria prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painful vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On USG, a well-formed gestation ring with central echoes from the embryo indicates a healthy fetus, and there is observation of fetal cardiac motion. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Threatened abortion

Explanation:

  • The presence of vaginal bleeding in the first trimester along with a healthy fetus observed on USG, indicated by a well-formed gestation ring, central echoes from the embryo, and fetal cardiac motion, is characteristic of a threatened abortion. The cervix is typically closed in such cases, and the pregnancy may still continue successfully with appropriate care.

Clinical Classification of Spontaneous Abortion

Characteristic

Inevitable

(Option A)

(Option C)

Complete

(Option D)

Missed

Vaginal bleeding or membrane rupture in < 20 weeks

No symptoms

Open

Closed

USG Findings

Dilated cervix with sac low in the uterine cavity or cervical canal

Empty gestational sac or retained products of conception

Absence of fetal heartbeat and/or absent growth of gestational sac

Management

Rest, monitor fetal viability

Surgical evacuation or expectant management

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who previously had dilatation and curettage, and now presents with amenorrhea, a negative urine pregnancy test, and a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity on HSG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asherman syndrome

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with amenorrhea following a history of dilatation and curettage (D&C). A honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity on hysterosalpingography (HSG) strongly suggests intrauterine adhesions, which is diagnostic of Asherman syndrome. This condition is characterized by the formation of scar tissue inside the uterine cavity, often due to uterine surgery, infection, or trauma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Kallman syndrome (Option B) is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (loss of smell). Since there is no mention of anosmia in the case history, Kallman syndrome is unlikely.

Sheehan syndrome (Option C) typically follows severe postpartum hemorrhage, leading to ischemic damage to the anterior pituitary. This results in the inability to produce hormones, including those that regulate menstruation. However, there is no history of significant postpartum blood loss in this scenario.

Stein-Leventhal syndrome (Option D), also known as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), is associated with hyperandrogenism, anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. The clinical features do not fit the description of PCOS, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: What is the quickest method for laboratory diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A) CB-NAAT

 

Explanation:

CB-NAAT is a molecular diagnostic test that can detect the genetic material (DNA) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes TB. It is a highly sensitive and specific test that can provide rapid results.

Diagnostic Modality

Description

Usage

Sputum Smear Microscopy (Option B ruled out)

Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings.

Chest X-ray

Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB.

Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis.

TruNAAT/CBNAAT (Option A)

Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance.

Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results.

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid).

Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis.

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)

A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein.

Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis.

Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)

Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens.

Used for detecting latent TB infection

Sputum Culture (Option C ruled out)

 

Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility.

Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results.

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST)

Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs.

Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases.

Radiometric BACTEC method (Option D): It offers faster detection compared to conventional culture methods but still requires several weeks to obtain results. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes for emergency contraception within 8 hours after engaging in sexual intercourse. She expresses a preference for a single pill rather than multiple pills. What would be your recommendation in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg

Explanation:

  • Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the most appropriate option for emergency contraception in this case. It is a progestin-only pill and is highly effective when taken within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse. Since the patient prefers a single-pill regimen, this option is ideal. It does not contain estrogen, avoiding estrogen-related side effects such as nausea or vomiting.

Emergency Contraceptive Methods

Method

Drug(s)

Dosage

Schedule

Time Period for Use

Oral Contraceptive Pills

Levonorgestrel

1.5 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Combination Pills (Yuzpe Regimen)

Levonorgestrel + Ethinyl estradiol

Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg + Ethinyl estradiol 0.1 mg per tablet

2 doses, 12 hours apart

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Levonorgestrel

Levonorgestrel

0.75 mg per tablet (take 2 tablets)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Ulipristal Acetate

Ulipristal acetate

30 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected sex

Copper IUD (Best)

Copper IUD

N/A (inserted by healthcare provider)

Insertion by a healthcare provider

Within 5 days after unprotected sex

Mifepristone (Less Common)

Mifepristone (in combination with misoprostol)

200 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Incorrect Options:

While levonorgestrel 0.75 mg (Option A) is used in some regimens, it requires two doses (one pill initially and another 12 hours later). Since the patient prefers a single pill, this option is not suitable.

Ethinyl estradiol + levonorgestrel (Option B) combination contains both estrogen (ethinyl estradiol) and progestin (levonorgestrel). While effective, the estrogen component increases the risk of side effects, including nausea and vomiting, which the patient is trying to avoid.

Desogestrel 3 mg (Option D) is a progestin-only contraceptive, but it is not typically used for emergency contraception. Furthermore, it is often combined with estrogen, which would introduce unnecessary side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following food items contains the lowest amount of iron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D- Milk

Explanation:

Sources rich in iron:

Two types: haem-iron and non-haem iron.

  • Haem iron
    • Haem iron is better absorbed than non-haem iron.
    • Found in liver (Option A ruled out), meat, poultry, and fish.
    • Promotes absorption of non-haem iron in plant foods eaten concurrently.
  • Non-Haem iron:
    • It is found in plant-based foods such as cereals, green leafy vegetables (Option B ruled out), legumes (Option C ruled out), nuts, oilseeds, jaggery, and dried fruits.
  • Additional Iron Sources: Cooking in iron vessels can significantly contribute to dietary iron in some areas.
  • Iron Content in Milk:
    • Low in all mammalian species. (Option D)
    • Breast milk contains less than 0.2 mg/dL but has good bioavailability.

Bioavailability and Absorption Inhibitors:

  • Non-haem iron absorption is hindered by phytates, oxalates, carbonates, phosphates, and dietary fibre.
  • Foods like milk, eggs, and tea also inhibit iron absorption.
  • Indian vegetarian diets often contain high levels of these inhibitors (e.g., phytates in bran, phosphates in egg yolk, tannin in tea, and oxalates in vegetables).

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a middle-aged woman who complains of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility, and exhibits a retroverted uterus that is fixed, tender, and accompanied by tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endometriosis

Explanation:

  • Endometriosis is the most probable diagnosis in this case. The patient's symptoms, including dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility, are commonly associated with endometriosis. Additionally, the physical examination findings of a fixed, tender retroverted uterus and nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments are classic signs of endometriosis, as the endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus, often involving the ligaments, ovaries, and peritoneum.

Pathology of Endometriosis:

Complications

Fertility-related
  • Infertility
  • Increased risk of ectopic pregnancy

Pain-related
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Dyspareunia
  • Dyschezia

Organ-specific

Gastrointestinal:

  • Bowel obstruction
  • Rectal bleeding

Ovarian:

  • Endometriomas
  • Ovarian torsion
  • Rupture of chocolate cyst

Urinary:

  • Ureteral obstruction
  • Hydronephrosis

Structural
  • Adhesions
  • Frozen pelvis

Incorrect Options:

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) (Option A) is typically associated with a history of infection, fever, and abnormal vaginal discharge. The absence of infection or fever makes PID an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Pelvic tuberculosis (Option C) may present with pelvic pain, but it is usually non-tender on examination. The presence of nodularity and a retroverted uterus, along with the patient's specific symptoms, points more towards endometriosis.

Leiomyomas (fibroids) (Option D) generally present with symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding, not with the characteristic symptoms of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility associated with endometriosis. Fibroids can cause pelvic pain, but the findings of a retroverted uterus with nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments are not typical for fibroids.

questions.text: What is the recommended duration for quarantine for the 30 individuals who had contact with a 28-year-old male who is tested positive for SARS-COV-2, but are currently asymptomatic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B- Maximum incubation period

Explanation:

  • Quarantine should be based on the maximum incubation period, which is the longest time it takes for symptoms to appear after exposure to the virus. This ensures sufficient monitoring for symptom development.

Incubation Period: (Option B)

  • The incubation period refers to the time it takes for an individual to develop symptoms after being infected with a pathogen.
  • It begins with exposure to the pathogen and ends with the appearance of recognisable symptoms.

Window Period:

  • The window period is the time between infection and when the infection can be reliably detected by diagnostic tests.
  • The individual may be infectious during this period, but tests might not yet show positive results.
  • This concept is important in screening and testing strategies for infectious diseases.

Generation Time:

  • Generation time refers to the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host.

Median incubation period (Option D): It is the time for 50% of cases to show symptoms after exposure. This option is incorrect.

Period of communicability (Option C): It is when an infectious agent can be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected person to others, from infected animals to humans, or from infected individuals to animals or arthropods. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of the irregular periods in a 20-year-old female, based on the ultrasound scan findings shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PCOD

Explanation:

  • The most likely cause of irregular periods in this case is Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD). The ultrasound findings described as multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a "necklace pattern" are characteristic of PCOD, which is a common cause of menstrual irregularity in young females.
  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

Components of PCOS:

  • Increased androgens
  • Ovulatory dysfunction
  • Polycystic ovaries

Clinical features:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance

Rotterdam Criteria:

Any 2 of the following 3 should be present to make a provisional diagnosis for PCOS

Increased androgen levels: Hyperandrogenism/Hirsutism: PCOS is associated with elevated androgen levels, which can manifest as clinical signs (like hirsutism and acne) or biochemical findings (elevated testosterone).

Ovulatory dysfunction: Oligomenorrhea/Amenorrhea- Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea) or absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea) are common features of PCOS due to ovulatory dysfunction.

On USG: 1 or both ovaries >12 follicles with 2-9mm in size (<1cm) and/or Ovarian volume >=10 cm3- One of the diagnostic criteria for PCOS is the presence of polycystic ovarian morphology, which is confirmed by ultrasound showing multiple cysts on the ovaries.

USG: Necklace pattern ovarian cyst arranged towards the periphery.

Excessive stromal component in centre-producing androgens

Incorrect Options:

While obesity (Option B) can be associated with PCOD and contribute to menstrual irregularity, it is not the primary cause of the irregular periods in this case. The ultrasound findings strongly point towards PCOD, which is the most likely diagnosis.

Hirsutism (Option C), the excessive growth of hair in a male-pattern distribution due to elevated androgens, is often a feature of PCOD. However, it is not the direct cause of irregular periods, though it can be associated with them. The ultrasound findings are more indicative of PCOD rather than hirsutism itself.

Turner’s syndrome (Option D) is characterized by the presence of streak ovaries, which typically result in primary amenorrhea (absence of menstruation) due to ovarian insufficiency. Since the patient in this case has irregular periods, Turner’s syndrome is unlikely, and the presence of menstruation rules out this diagnosis.

questions.text: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the program whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except:

choices.text: Two rounds of spraying with DDT should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.
Long lasting insecticide nest (LLIN) should be provided in areas with annual parasite Index 25.
Indoor residual sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.
In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option C: Indoor residual sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.

Explanation:

  • This image shows the National Vector-Born Disease Control Program (NVBDCP).
  • Indoor residual spraying (IRS) is considered an effective vector control measure, including in rural areas.
  • IRS involves spraying insecticides on the interior walls of houses to kill mosquitoes and reduce their population. It is an important component of integrated malaria control programs.

National vector-borne disease control program (NVBDCP):

  • Launched: 2002.
  • Includes all vector-borne diseases:

Vector

Disease

Anopheles
  • Malaria

Aedes
  • Dengue & chikungunya

Culex
  • Japanese encephalitis: Culex quinquefasciatus/ Culex fatigans
  • Filariasis: Culex tritaeniorhynchus, Culex vishnui

Sandfly
  • Kala-azar

Indoor residual spray (IRS):

  • Chemicals used:
    • DDT 50% WP: Insecticide of choice
    • Malathion 25%
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Deltamethrin and Cyfluthrin
  • IRS with insecticides when API >2:

2 rounds of DDT (1gm/m2) at a 6-week interval during the transmission season (Option A ruled out)

↓

If refractory:

ADD malathion, 3 rounds of Malathion (2gm/m2) at 6-week intervals. (Option D ruled out)

↓

If still refractory:

ADD 2 rounds of a synthetic pyrethroid (0.25gm/m2) at 6-week intervals.

Note: Long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLIN) covers the population living in areas where API > 5.

Long-Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs) are mosquito nets treated with insecticides that are designed to retain their effectiveness for an extended period, typically up to 3 years, even after repeated washing. They are a critical tool in NVBDCP to fight against mosquito-borne diseases. (Option B ruled out)

Purpose:

  • Dual action provides a physical barrier against mosquito bites while also delivering insecticidal action.

Material and Mesh Size:

  • Made from polyester or polyethene.
  • Mesh size: around 156 holes per square inch.

questions.text: Please determine the study design based on the following information:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option C: Case control study

Explanation:
A case-control study starts by selecting participants based on the outcome (disease or no disease).

  • Cases: individuals who already have the disease/outcome.
  • Controls: individuals without the disease/outcome.

The study then looks backward to determine prior exposure to potential risk factors.

Since the selection is based on outcome status, and exposure is assessed retrospectively, this fits the definition of a case-control study.

Incorrect Options:

Prospective cohort study (Option A): Participants are selected based on exposure status and followed forward in time to see who develops the disease. This is incorrect because the selection here is based on outcome, not exposure.

Retrospective cohort study (Option B): Participants are again selected based on exposure status, but outcomes are assessed from past records. This is incorrect because there is no exposure-based grouping in this study.

Nested case control study (Option D): A case-control study conducted within a pre-existing cohort, where cases and controls are drawn from the same cohort. This is incorrect because there’s no mention of an existing cohort.

questions.text: What is the duration after which the polymorphic rash of Varicella is no longer contagious?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D: After crust formation over lesions

Explanation:

  • The contagious period of varicella extends until the lesions have completely crusted over.
  • Once the crusts have formed and the vesicles are no longer fluid-filled, the risk of transmission decreases significantly. At this stage, the virus is considered less contagious, and the individual is generally considered non-infectious.

Epidemiological factors of chicken pox:

Agent

 
  • Varicella-zoster virus (HHV 3- Human Herpes Virus 3)
  • Double-stranded DNA virus.

Source of infection
 

 
  • Scabs are not infectious, but the vesicular fluid is infectious. (Option D)
  • Airborne- spreads via both droplet infection and droplet nuclei

Period of communicability

 
  • 1-2 days before and 4-5 days after the onset of the rash (crust formation)
  • Secondary attack rate- 85%

Host factors

 
  • Age: <10 years
  • Very common in school-going children
  • One attack gives lifelong immunity
  • Reactivation can occur as Varicella zoster infection in later age

Environmental factors
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

Incubation period
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option C: Population attributable risk

Explanation:

  • Population attributable risk (PAR) measures the proportion of disease in the exposed group due to the exposure. It's expressed as a percentage, indicating the additional risk due to the exposure.
  • It considers baseline disease risk in the population.
  • Helps estimate potential disease reduction if exposure is eliminated or modified.

Measure

Definition

Calculation

Attributable Risk

Proportion of disease incidence attributable to a specific exposure or risk factor

Risk in exposed group - Risk in unexposed group

Relative Risk

Risk of a particular outcome in the exposed group compared to the unexposed group

Risk in exposed group/Risk in unexposed group

Population Attributable Risk

Proportion of disease cases in a population attributable to a specific exposure or risk factor

(Prevalence of exposure) x (Relative risk-1)/(1+ (Prevalence of exposure) x (Relative risk - 1))

Odds Ratio

Strength of association between exposure and outcome in case-control or retrospective studies

(Exposure odds in cases/Non-exposure odds in cases) / (Exposure odds in controls/Non- exposure odds in controls)

questions.text: The USG given below is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hydatidiform mole

Explanation:

  • The USG image showing a "snowstorm appearance" is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole, which is a form of gestational trophoblastic disease. This appearance is due to the presence of multiple cystic spaces within the uterus, representing swollen villi of the placenta. In hydatidiform mole, there is a failure of the embryo to develop, leading to abnormal growth of the placental tissue.
  • Hydatidiform mole is classified as a benign form of GTD and is characterized by abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue in the uterus. This results in swollen, fluid-filled villi and significantly elevated β-hCG levels (often in the range of 100,000 mIU/mL or higher).
  • Initially benign, they can sometimes progress to persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

Molar Pregnancy (Benign)

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (Malignant)
  • Partial Mole
  • Complete Mole
  • Invasive Mole
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT)
  • Epithelial Trophoblastic Tumor (ETT)

Complete Mole and Partial Mole:

Feature

Complete Mole

Partial Mole

Karyotype

46 XX or 46 XY

69 XYY or 69 XXY (triploid)

Diagnosis

Molar pregnancy

Missed abortion

Genetic Origin

All paternal (empty egg + sperm duplication)

2 paternal sets + 1 maternal set

Fetal Tissue

Absent

May be present but abnormal

β-hCG Levels

Extremely high (>1,00,000 mIU/mL)

Elevated, but lower than complete mole

Risk of Persistent GTD

15-20%

5-10%

Risk of Choriocarcinoma

2-3%

2-4%

Theca Lutein Cysts

Common (25-30% of cases)

Less common

Uterus Size

Larger than expected for gestational age

Smaller than expected for gestational age

Vaginal Bleeding

Common (80-90%), dark and intermittent

Less prominent, often associated with missed abortion

Hyperemesis Gravidarum

Common due to high hCG levels

Less common

Hyperthyroidism

Possible due to hCG/TSH similarity

Rare

Products of Conception

Complete molar tissue (grape-like vesicles)

Less advanced hydatidiform changes

Villous Edema

Diffuse, widespread

Focal

Trophoblastic Proliferation

Marked atypical trophoblastic hyperplasia

Focal to mild

Trophoblast Atypia

Prominent

Mild

p57KIP2 Immunostaining

Negative

Positive

In ectopic pregnancy (Option A), the classical USG finding is a "ring of fire" appearance, which is seen due to the vascularization of the ectopic mass. The snowstorm appearance is not typical for ectopic pregnancy.

Ovarian pregnancy (Option B) is a rare type of ectopic pregnancy where the embryo implants in the ovary. It can be difficult to diagnose on ultrasound, but it is typically associated with a mass in the ovary rather than a snowstorm appearance.

Anencephaly (Option C) is characterized by the absence of the brain and skull, and the classic ultrasound finding is the "frog eye sign," where the eyes appear to protrude abnormally due to the absence of the cranial vault. This is not the finding described in the question, which is indicative of hydatidiform mole.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of hepatocellular carcinoma in a factory worker employed in a groundnut factory who does not consume alcohol and has had a prolonged duration of employment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D) Aflatoxins

Explanation:

Aflatoxicosis:

Clinical features
  • Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

Causative agent
  • Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn
  • Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic)

Risk factors
  • Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius
  • Moisture content >16%

Prevention
  • Educating people
  • Moisture content <10% during storage

Incorrect Options

Beta oxalyl amino alanine (Option A): Beta oxalyl amino alanine, also known as BMAA, is a neurotoxic amino acid that has been associated with the development of lathyrism, neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Parkinson's disease. It is not directly linked to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Smoke from factory (Option B): While exposure to certain industrial pollutants and chemicals can contribute to the development of various cancers, including liver cancer, the given scenario specifically mentions the worker being non-alcoholic and working in a groundnut factory. Therefore, smoke from the factory is not the most probable cause in this case.

Sanguinarine (Option C): It is a toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil. It causes epidemic dropsy. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What observation can be made from this hysterosalpingogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

Explanation:

  • In the given hysterosalpingogram, bilateral hydrosalpinx is observed. This condition is characterized by the dilation of the fallopian tubes, specifically the ampulla, and they appear retort-shaped. The tubes are filled with clear fluid, and the contrast dye enters through the open interstitial ends but cannot leave because the fimbrial ends are closed. This blockage results in the typical appearance of hydrosalpinx on HSG.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG):

  • Visualising the uterine cavity & fallopian tubes by retrograde injection of radiocontrast dye to identify filling defects & blocks.

Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
