  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

Extravasation into the venous system (Option B) refers to the leakage of contrast dye into the pelvis and bloodstream, indicating patency of the fallopian tubes, which is not observed in this case. The image in the scenario shows a closed system, indicative of a blockage.

A normal HSG (Option C) would show the dye flowing freely through the fallopian tubes and spilling out into the peritoneal cavity, indicating no blockages. The findings in this case are not consistent with normal HSG.

A bilateral cornual block (Option D) would show the fallopian tubes blocked at the uterine junction, which would prevent the contrast from moving through the tubes entirely. However, in this case, the issue is at the fimbrial ends, not at the cornual ends, and the tubes are dilated, indicating hydrosalpinx, not a cornual block.

questions.text: What type of gestation is observed in the sonographic evaluation of a 26-year-old woman who has reported amenorrhea for 12 weeks, as shown in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dichorionic diamniotic

  • Explanation:
    The sonographic findings, including the presence of the lambda sign (also known as the twin peak sign), indicate a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
  • This is characterized by the presence of two separate chorions and two separate amniotic sacs.
  • The lambda sign is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue seen between the two gestational sacs and occurs when the inner cell mass divides within 3 days of fertilization, leading to dichorionicity.

Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac, forming when the zygote splits early, typically within the first 3 days after fertilization.

Timing of Cleavage

Placenta & Membrane Status

< 72 hours

Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta/chorion and amniotic sac.

Days 4–7

Monochorionic-Diamniotic twins share one placenta (chorion) but have separate amniotic sacs.

Days 8–12

Monochorionic-Monoamniotic twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac.

Day > 13

Conjoined (Siamese) are physically connected and may share organs or tissues, resulting from a very late and incomplete split.

In a monochorionic diamniotic (Option A) pregnancy, a T-sign is typically seen, not the lambda sign. This occurs when the division of the inner cell mass happens after 4-8 days, resulting in a single chorionic membrane shared by the twins and two amniotic sacs.

In a monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) (Option C) pregnancy, both fetuses share the same chorionic sac and the same amniotic sac. This is a rare condition and would not present with the lambda sign.

Conjoined twins (Option D) occur when the zygote fails to completely separate after 13 days of fertilization, leading to physically connected twins. Sonographic findings would show physical fusion, not the typical placental or sac-related signs seen in dichorionic or monochorionic twins.

questions.text: Komal, a 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. Parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

choices.text: The period of infectivity is 3 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis
Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are associated with the disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option B) The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

Explanation:

The child is most probably has measles infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles infection, occurring years after the initial infection. It is characterized by progressive inflammation and degeneration of the brain. While SSPE is a serious condition, it is not the most common cause of death in children with measles.

Measles

Causative agent
  • ssRNA paramyxovirus

Incubation period
  • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash

Source of infection
  • Person with measles
  • Infective material

Period of communicability
  • Roughly 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash (Option A ruled out)

Clinical features

Prodromal stage:

  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Coryza with sneezing
  • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation
  • Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature) (Option D ruled out)

 

Eruptive stage:

  • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs.
  • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days.

 

Post measles stage:

  • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea.

Isolation period
  • 7 days from the onset of rash

Difference between measles and rubella rash
  • Both rashes are maculopapular
  • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent.

Diagnosis
  • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots
  • Gold standard: PCR

Treatment
  • No specific treatment
  • Symptomatic management only

 

Measles Rash

Koplik’s Spots

 

Complications of Measles

Otitis Media

M/c complication in young children. Covered under IMNCI programme.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)

A rare, fatal brain disease that occurs years after measles infection, causing neurological damage and mortality. (Option B)

Pneumonia

Most common fatal complication & cause of death.

Persistent Diarrhea

Long-lasting diarrhea, potentially leading to protein-losing enteropathy.

Prevalent in developing countries, impacting infants significantly.

Keratomalacia

Measles causes acute vitamin A deficiency in children.

Giant Cell Pneumonia, Measles Inclusion-body Encephalitis

Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals.

Other complications: Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup), Encephalitis, Spontaneous abortion, Premature delivery

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are associated with the disease (Option C): This cell is found in hyperplastic lymph nodes early in the course of measles. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the obstetric grip being depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fourth Leopold manoeuvre

Explanation:

  • The image depicts the Fourth Leopold manoeuvre, also known as the pelvic grip. It is used to assess the degree of descent of the fetal presenting part. In this maneuver, the examiner faces the patient's feet and palpates the lower abdomen to determine fetal engagement in the pelvis. This helps in evaluating the fetal position, presenting part, and descent.

Leopold's Maneuvers:

Maneuver

Position

Technique

Purpose

Fundal Grip

(First Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Palpate the fundal area with both hands

To determine which fetal pole is in the fundus:

  • Broad, soft, irregular mass: Breech
  • Smooth, hard, globular mass: Head
  • Transverse lie: Neither pole palpable

Lateral or Umbilical Grip

(Second Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place hands flat on either side of the umbilicus, palpate one side at a time

To identify the position of the fetal back, limbs, and anterior shoulder:

  • Back: Smooth, curved, resistant
  • Limb side: Comparatively empty with small, knob-like parts
  • Anterior shoulder: Prominent in the lower part of the uterus above the head

Pawlik’s Grip

(Third Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place thumb and four fingers over the lower pole of the uterus, ulnar border on the upper symphysis pubis

To grasp the presenting part if not engaged and test its mobility:

Transverse lie: Pawlik’s grip is empty

Pelvic Grip

(Fourth Leopold)

Facing the patient’s feet

Place four fingers of both hands on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus, pressing downward and backward
  • To identify the part in the lower pole, its attitude, and engagement:

Head Characteristics:

  1. Precise presenting area
  2. Attitude (position of sinciput and occiput)
  3. Engagement (noted by the presence/absence of sinciput and occiput, convergence/divergence of finger tips)

 

Incorrect Options:

Hudson’s grip (Option B) is not a recognized obstetric grip. It is an incorrect answer in this context.

Fundal grip (Option C) assesses the uterine fundus to identify the fetal lie (whether the fetus is longitudinal or transverse) and to determine the fetal pole at the fundus. This grip is not the same as the Fourth Leopold manoeuvre.

Umbilical grip (Option D), also known as the lateral grip, involves placing the palms on either side of the maternal abdomen to assess the fetal orientation. It helps identify whether the fetus is in the anterior or posterior position, but it is not the same as the Fourth Leopold manoeuvre.

questions.text: In the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet, the true conjugate is?

choices.text: The distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis
The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis
The distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory
The distance from the posterior margin of the sacral promontory to the symphysis pubis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis

Explanation:

  • The true conjugate is the distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis. It is a critical measurement used to assess the adequacy of the pelvic inlet for vaginal delivery.

True Conjugate (Conjugata Vera)

The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the superior margin of the pubic symphysis.

Determines pelvic inlet adequacy for vaginal delivery; <9.5 cm suggests possible cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD).

Diagonal Conjugate

(Option C)

The distance between the sacral promontory and the lower margin of the pubic symphysis, measured via the vaginal exam.

Estimates true conjugate; <12 cm may indicate a narrow pelvic inlet.

Obstetric Conjugate

(Option B)

The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis.

Assesses pelvic cavity adequacy for fetal head passage; inadequate may lead to obstructed labor.

Distance from the posterior margin of the sacral promontory to the symphysis pubis (Option D): This is another description of the true conjugate but is less precise than option A. The correct anatomical definition refers to the midpoint of the sacral promontory, not the posterior margin.

questions.text: Within what time frame should Cholera, a disease that requires notification, be reported to the World Health Organization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option B: 24 hours

Explanation:

  • Cholera, being a notifiable disease, should be reported to the World Health Organization (WHO) within 24 hours. This allows for early detection, investigation, and response to cholera outbreaks, which is essential for minimizing the impact on public health.

Notifiable diseases:

  • Notifiable diseases in India include diseases that are contagious, severe, or frequent, and require health providers to report them to public health officials.

List of Notifiable diseases in India

Note: the list is not comprehensive

  1. AIDS
  2. Dengue fever
  3. Hepatitis B
  4. Malaria
  5. Whooping cough (Pertussis)
  6. Rabies
  7. Tetanus
  8. Viral encephalitis
  9. Anemia
  10. Chickenpox
  11. Diphtheria
  12. Influenza
  13. Measles
  14. Plague
  15. Smallpox
  16. Tuberculosis
  17. Malnutrition
  18. Iodine deficiency
  19. Cholera
  20. Hepatitis A
  21. Leprosy
  22. Cerebro spinal fever
  23. Polio
  24. Scarlet fever
  25. Typhoid fever
  26. Vitamin A deficiency

questions.text: A primigravida presents with labor pain, and on per vaginal examination, her cervix is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced. What stage of labor is she in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acceleration phase

Explanation:

  • The acceleration phase refers to the period of active cervical dilation, typically occurring from about 4 cm to full dilation (10 cm). During this phase, contractions become more intense, frequent, and regular, leading to progressive cervical dilation. Since the cervix is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced, the patient is in the active phase of labor, which is the acceleration phase.

Stages of Labor

Stage

Definition

Features

Contractions

First Stage

Onset of labor to full cervical dilatation (10 cm).

  • Latent Phase: Early cervical changes with slower progress.
  • Active Phase: Faster cervical dilatation (≥5 cm) with regular contractions.
  • Cervical dilatation and effacement occur.
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions.
  • "Show" (blood-stained mucus) is common.
  • Active labor starts at cervical dilatation ≥5 cm with regular contractions.

Latent Phase: Irregular and mild.

Active Phase: Regular; 3–5 min apart, lasting ~45 seconds.

Second Stage

From complete cervical dilatation (10 cm) to fetal delivery.
  • Begins after complete cervical dilation.
  • Ends with the delivery of the baby.

Strong and frequent; 2–3 minutes apart.

Third Stage

From fetal delivery to placental expulsion.
  • Placental separation and expulsion occur.
  • Average duration: 5–15 minutes.

Mild uterine contractions to aid placental expulsion.

Fourth Stage

Observation for at least 1 hour after placental expulsion.
  • Monitoring for postpartum hemorrhage and uterine contraction.

Uterine contractions continue, aiding hemostasis.

Incorrect Options:

The latent phase (Option B) is the early phase of labor, during which the cervix dilates from 0 to 6 cm. It is characterized by milder, less frequent contractions. Since the cervix is already 7 cm dilated, the patient is beyond the latent phase.

The term deceleration phase (Option C) is not a standard term used to describe the stages of labor. Deceleration generally refers to a decrease in the fetal heart rate, which may occur during labor and is typically monitored as a potential sign of distress, not a stage of labor.

The “phase of maximum slope” (Option D) is not a recognized term in the context of the stages of labor.

questions.text: Please identify the genetic disorder mentioned in the text.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Turner’s syndrome

Explanation:

Turner’s syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality characterized by partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome. The patient in the scenario exhibits typical features of Turner’s syndrome, including:

  • Webbed neck
  • Short stature
  • Streak ovaries
  • Low hairline at the back of the neck
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics
  • Widely spaced nipples

These features are highly suggestive of Turner’s syndrome, which occurs when a female has only one functioning X chromosome or has abnormalities in the second X chromosome.

Incorrect Options:

Testicular feminizing syndrome (Option A), also known as androgen insensitivity syndrome, this condition involves the partial or complete inability of cells to respond to androgens, leading to a female phenotype despite a male genotype (XY). It is not associated with the features described in the scenario.

Kallmann syndrome (Option B) is characterized by anosmia (loss of sense of smell) and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, leading to delayed or absent puberty. The absence of anosmia in the patient makes Kallmann syndrome unlikely in this case.

Klinefelter syndrome (Option D), typically described by the chromosomal pattern 47, XXY, involves males with an extra X chromosome. Common features include infertility and small, poorly functioning testicles, but this syndrome does not present with the characteristic features observed in this patient, such as webbed neck or streak ovaries.

questions.text: What is the most reliant part of a female body among the following choices?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rectouterine pouch

Explanation:

  • The rectouterine pouch, also known as the pouch of Douglas, is considered the most dependent part of the female peritoneal cavity.
  • It is located between the posterior surface of the uterus and the anterior surface of the rectum. In a standing position, this area is the lowest point of the peritoneal cavity, making it the most reliant part in terms of fluid accumulation and drainage.

Incorrect Options:

The ovarian fossa (Option B) is a shallow depression on the peritoneal surface located on the lateral pelvic wall. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and houses the ovary in nulliparous women. While important anatomically, it is not the most reliant part of the body.

The posterior fornix (Option C) is the recess behind the cervix, where the vagina meets the cervix. It is an important anatomical feature but is not the most dependent part of the female reproductive system.

The vesicouterine pouch (Option D) is formed by the anterior reflection of the peritoneum over the fundus and body of the uterus, covering the posterior surface of the bladder. While it plays a role in the anatomy of the female pelvis, it is not the most reliant or dependent part compared to the rectouterine pouch.

questions.text: In the case of a patient scheduled for dilatation and curettage, if a Sim's sound is inserted into the uterus but no resistance is felt, what is the next step in management according to the available options?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Immediate laparoscopy

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the absence of resistance during the insertion of the Sim's sound indicates the possibility of uterine perforation. This is a serious complication where the uterus is punctured, potentially leading to injury of surrounding organs. The next best course of action is immediate laparoscopy to directly visualize the abdominal cavity and assess for any injuries, thereby preventing further complications.

Incorrect Options:

Continue the procedure (Option A): Continuing with the procedure after the absence of resistance could lead to further damage and potential injury to surrounding organs. It is not recommended.

Do planned evacuation (Option B): A planned evacuation is not appropriate in this situation, as immediate action is needed to assess the extent of the perforation, which would require surgical intervention (laparoscopy) rather than continuing the procedure.

Mifepristone and Misoprostol (Option D): Mifepristone and misoprostol are used for medical abortion or for facilitating labor in specific situations, not for the management of uterine perforation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient visits the outpatient department (OPD) with a case of primary absence of menstrual periods and recurring pain. During the examination of the perineal area, a visible protrusion is observed from the vagina. Please identify the underlying cause for this particular presentation.

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Imperforate hymen

Explanation:

  • Based on the given scenario, the patient presents with primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain, along with a vaginal bulge, suggesting cryptomenorrhea. Cryptomenorrhea occurs when menstrual blood accumulates in the uterus due to an obstruction in the vaginal outflow tract, preventing its release.
  • The most common cause of cryptomenorrhea is imperforate hymen, where the hymen is completely sealed, obstructing menstrual flow.
  • The treatment typically involves making cruciate incisions to create an opening for the menstrual flow.

Cryptomenorrhea

Causes

  • Congenital Causes:
    • Imperforate hymen
    • Transverse vaginal septum
    • Atresia of upper-third of vagina and cervix
  • Acquired Causes:
    • Stenosis of the cervix following amputation, deep cauterization and conization
    • Secondary vaginal atresia following neglected and difficult vaginal delivery.

Clinical Features

  • Patients are usually around 13-15 years old (congenital cases).
  • Symptoms: Periodic lower abdominal pain and, in cases of hematocolpos, urine retention occurs
  • Physical Examination:
    • An abdominal exam reveals a uniform globular mass in the hypogastrium.
    • Vulvar inspection shows a bulging hymen.
    • Rectal examination confirms a full vagina and uterine mass.

Management

  • Imperforate Hymen: Perform a cruciate incision and drain the accumulated blood.
  • Cervical Stenosis: Dilate the cervix to relieve the obstruction.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy weighing 30 kg has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he's NPO?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- 1700 mL

Explanation:

  • Based on the Holliday-Segar method, the daily maintenance fluid requirement for a 7-year-old boy who weighs 30 kg can be estimated as follows:

Calculation of maintenance fluid:

Body weight

Maintenance fluid (mL/kg/day)

<10 kg

100 mL/kg

10-20 kg

1000 + 50 for each kg in excess of 10kg

>20 kg

1500 + 20 for each kg in excess of 20kg

In case of 7 year old boy of 30 kg weight:

  • For the first 10 kg of body weight: 100 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 100 mL/kg/day = 1000 mL/day
  • For the next 10 kg (from 11 to 20 kg): an additional 50 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 50 mL/kg/day = 500 mL/day
  • For the remaining 10 kg (from 21 to 30 kg): an additional 20 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 20 mL/kg/day = 200 mL/day
  • Adding the results from the above calculations: 1000 mL/day + 500 mL/day + 200 mL/day = 1700 mL/day

questions.text: A child with an IQ of 55 comes under:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Mild intellectual disability

Explanation:

Mild intellectual disability:

  • Intellectual disability: IQ < 70
  • IQ = (Mental age / Chronological age) x 100
  • Mild intellectual disability: IQ 51-70

IQ level

IQ range

Mild intellectual disability

51-70

Moderate intellectual disability

36-50

Severe intellectual disability

21-35

Profound intellectual disability

0-20

questions.text: A child presents with continuing seizures for the past 30 minutes. The relatives say that there had been no seizure-free intervals in the past 30 minutes. After stabilizing the vitals, what is the first drug that should be administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Diazepam

Explanation:

  • The patient is experiencing Status epilepticus, which occurs when seizures continue for >30 minutes.
  • The American Epilepsy Society SE Guidelines recommend using either intravenous lorazepam, rectal diazepam, or intravenous/intramuscular midazolam as a first-line agent.

Management of Status Epilepticus:

Status epilepticus is a medical emergency characterized by continuous seizure activity or recurrent seizures without recovery of consciousness between episodes. The definition has evolved to recognize the importance of early intervention:

  • Traditional definition: seizures lasting >30 minutes

  • Current definition: continuous seizures lasting ≥5 minutes, or two or more seizures without full recovery between them

Early intervention is critical as neuronal damage can begin to occur after 5-30 minutes of continuous seizure activity.

Initial Assessment and Stabilization (0-5 minutes)

  1. Stabilize airway, breathing, and circulation

    • Position patient appropriately to maintain open airway

    • Assess oxygenation and provide oxygen via nasal cannula/mask

    • Monitor vital signs continuously

    • Consider intubation if respiratory assistance is needed

  2. Initial assessment

    • Perform quick neurological exam if possible

    • Check blood glucose levels (treat if <60 mg/dl)

    • Secure IV access

  3. Laboratory tests to obtain

    • Electrolytes, hematology, toxicology screen

    • Anticonvulsant drug levels (if on medication)

First-Line Treatment (5-20 minutes)

 

A benzodiazepine is the initial therapy of choice:

  • Intravenous lorazepam: 0.1 mg/kg up to maximum of 4 mg, may repeat in 5-10 min

  • Intravenous midazolam: 0.2 mg/kg up to 10 mg total dose, may repeat in 5-10 min

  • Intramuscular midazolam: 0.2 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

  • Rectal diazepam: 0.5 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

  • Buccal midazolam: 0.5 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

Second-Line Treatment (20-40 minutes)

 

If seizures continue after benzodiazepine administration, proceed to one of these options:

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin: 20 mg PE/kg loading dose (maximum 1500 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous valproate: 40 mg/kg loading dose (maximum 3000 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous levetiracetam: 30-60 mg/kg loading dose (maximum 4500 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous phenobarbital: 15-20 mg/kg loading dose (if not given initially)

Third-Line Treatment (40-60 minutes)

 

If seizures still continue (refractory status epilepticus):

  • Consider repeating second-line therapy

  • Consider anesthetic doses of:

    • Thiopental

    • Midazolam

    • Pentobarbital

    • Propofol (with caution in children due to propofol infusion syndrome risk)

Continuous EEG monitoring is recommended at this stage.

Incorrect Options:

Phenytoin (Option B): Phenytoin (or its prodrug fosphenytoin) is considered as a second-line therapy to be used if seizures continue after benzodiazepine administration (20-40 minute during the second therapy phase

Phenobarbital (Option C): While phenobarbital can be used in status epilepticus, it's typically considered a second-line agent according to the standard protocl. It is to be used only in cases if first line pharmacological agents have failed.

Thiopentone sodium (Option D): Thiopental (thiopentone) is a third-line agent for refractory status epilepticus (40-60 minute during the third therapy phase. It is used only when first and second-line treatments have failed.

questions.text: In a 1-year-old male child who arrives at the hospital with fever and neck stiffness, the suspected diagnosis is meningitis. Among the options provided, which pathogen is the leading cause of meningitis in this particular age group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Streptococcus pneumoniae

Explanation:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae, also known as pneumococcus, is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in children.
  • Haemophilus influenzae is the second most common cause of bacterial meningitis in children.’

Bacterial meningitis- Etiological agents

 

In India

Overall

Neonates

Gram negative organisms

(E.Coli > Acinetobacter > Klebsiella)

Group B streptococci

 

Infants and older children

Streptococcus pneumoniae >

Neisseria meningitidis > Haemophilus Influenzae.

Streptococcus pneumoniae

Children with T-cell defect

Listeria monocytogenes

Children with CSF shunts

Staphylococci

Children with Complement System Defects

Meningococcal infections

Children with Splenic Dysfunction or Asplenia
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae,
  • Neisseria Meningitidis Haemophilus Influenzae. (Encapsulated organisms)

Incorrect Options:

Klebsiella (Option A): While Klebsiella can cause meningitis, particularly in neonates and immunocompromised patients, it is not the leading cause of meningitis in children.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): Although S. aureus can cause meningitis, especially following neurosurgical procedures or in cases of head trauma, it is not the primary causative organism in meningitis in children.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option D): While tuberculous meningitis is an important consideration, it is not the most common cause of meningitis in children.

questions.text:
Which of the following congenital heart disease presents with split-second heart sounds?


	Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)
	Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
	Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
	Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Only 1,2,3 is correct

Explanation:

Congenital heart diseases that can present with split-second heart sounds include:

  • Atrial Septal Defect (ASD): An ASD is a hole in the wall (septum) that separates the two upper chambers of the heart (atria). It can lead to increased blood flow from the left atrium to the right atrium, resulting in more evident splitting of the second heart sound (S2) during auscultation.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): A VSD is a hole in the septum between the two lower chambers of the heart (ventricles). Like ASD, it can cause increased blood flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, leading to accentuated splitting of S2.
  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): PDA is a condition where a blood vessel called the ductus arteriosus, which connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta during fetal development, remains open after birth. This can result in abnormal blood flow and increased flow across the pulmonary valve, leading to a more pronounced splitting of S2.

The congenital heart disease that does not typically present with split-second heart sounds is: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Pulmonary Stenosis:
    • Narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):
    • A large hole between the right and left ventricles, usually misaligned, allowing abnormal blood flow.
  • Overriding Aorta:
    • The aorta is positioned over the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy:
    • Thickening of the right ventricle wall due to the extra effort required to pump blood.

Examination findings in TOF

Cardiac Auscultation
  • Heart Sounds: Typically normal first heart sound with a single second heart sound (pulmonic component usually inaudible)
  • Murmur: Harsh systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo in quality
    • Best heard at the left mid to upper sternal border
    • Radiates posteriorly
    • The severity of the murmur correlates with the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
    • May occasionally have a regurgitant quality
  • Early systolic click: Sometimes heard along the left sternal border (attributed to flow through a dilated ascending aorta)
  • Continuous murmur: Present over the back and axillary regions in patients with pulmonary atresia and aortopulmonary collaterals

Palpation
  • Prominent ventricular impulse
  • Systolic thrill may be palpable along the left sternal border

questions.text: What is the most common cause of jaundice in this newborn presenting with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, intrahepatic cholestasis, high alkaline phosphatase, and the presence of eosinophilic, PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules in liver biopsy specimens, suggestive of Alpha 1 AT deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Neonatal hepatitis

Explanation:

Neonatal hepatitis:

Neonatal hepatitis is inflammation of the liver that occurs in newborn infants. It can be caused by various factors, including viral infections (such as hepatitis viruses), metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and drug-induced liver injury.

In the given scenario, the presentation indicative of neonatal hepatitis includes:

  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
  • Intrahepatic cholestasis
  • High alkaline phosphatase,
  • Presence of eosinophilic PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules on liver biopsy

Hypoplasia of biliary tract (Option A): Hypoplasia of the biliary tract refers to underdevelopment or incomplete formation of the bile ducts. It presents with pale stools and bile duct proliferation on biopsy, and can lead to impaired bile flow and subsequent cholestasis. However, it is not the most common cause of jaundice in the neonates.

Choledochal cyst (Option C) : A choledochal cyst is a congenital anomaly characterized by dilatation of the bile ducts. It can cause bile flow obstruction and subsequently leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, jaundice and an abdominal mass due to bile duct dilation. Unlike A1AT deficiency, it shows extrahepatic obstruction on imaging and lacks PAS-positive inclusions.

Physiological (Option D): Physiological jaundice, is a normal and temporary condition that occurs in many newborns due to the immature liver's ability to process bilirubin efficiently. It presents with unconjugated bilirubinemia, not conjugated.

questions.text: Which of the options listed below does not represent an absolute contraindication for the use of the device depicted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) HIV-infected women

Explanation:

  • The device depicted is the CuT 380A intrauterine contraceptive device (IUD).
  • The use of IUDs is not contraindicated in women with HIV infection.
  • In fact, IUDs, including the CuT 380A, are considered safe and effective for most women, including those who are HIV-positive, as long as there are no other contraindications.
  • The device works by preventing fertilization, offering long-term contraception.

Contraindications of IUCD:

Absolute Contraindications

Relative Contraindications
  • Pregnancy (Option B)
  • Current Pelvic Infection (Option D)
  • Unexplained Vaginal Bleeding (Option A)
  • Active Cervical or Uterine Cancer
  • Distorted Uterine Cavity
  • History of Ectopic Pregnancy
  • Immunocompromised States
  • History of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • Severe Menstrual Pain or Heavy Periods
  • Postpartum Women
  • Trophoblastic disease
  • Previous Intrauterine Device (IUD) Expulsion

questions.text: The earliest indication of sexual maturation in females:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Thelarche

Explanation:

Thelarche, the development of breast buds, occurs as a result of hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis activation, leading to estrogen release and subsequent breast tissue growth. This process typically begins between ages 8 and 13, marking the earliest visible sign of puberty in girls.

Pubertal Changes

Girls

Boys

Onset of Puberty

  • Age: Around 10 years (range 8-12 years)
  • Duration: 3-5 years

Onset of Puberty

  • Age: Around 11.5 years (range 9-14 years)

Sequence of Pubertal Changes

Sequence of Pubertal Changes

Breast Development(Thelarche)

↓

Pubic Hair Growth (Pubarche)

↓

Growth Spurt

↓

Onset of Menstrual Cycles(Menarche)

2 years after Thelarche

↓

Final Breast Development(Adult Breast Maturation)

Testicular Enlargement

↓

Penile Enlargement

↓

Pubic Hair Growth (Pubarche)

↓

Growth Spurt

↓

Spermarche

 

Incorrect Options:

Maturation (Option A): This term is quite broad and does not specifically refer to any particular aspect of sexual maturation. It does not provide a clear indication of the onset of sexual development in females.

Pubarche (Option C): Pubarche refers to the development of pubic hair, specifically in the pubic region. It is another sign of sexual maturation in females and typically occurs after thelarche. Pubarche is influenced by androgen hormones, such as adrenal androgens. The onset of pubarche varies, but it often occurs around the same time as thelarche or shortly after.

Menarche (Option D): Menarche refers to the onset of the first menstrual period in females. It is a significant milestone in sexual maturation and signifies the ability to conceive. Menarche usually occurs after the development of breast buds (thelarche) and the growth of pubic hair (pubarche). The average age of menarche is around 12 to 14 years, but it can vary widely.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 came to the physician at 32 weeks of gestation. She underwent OGTT (75 g of glucose) and her values were fasting 110 mg/dl and 2 hours glucose at 180 mg/dl. Which of the following is the next step regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Induce labor due to risk of fetal macrosomia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Admit and start insulin

Explanation:

  • The patient in this scenario is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) based on the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) values, where the fasting glucose is ≥ 92 mg/dl, which is diagnostic.
  • Insulin is the drug of choice for managing gestational diabetes, as it does not cross the placenta, effectively controlling blood glucose levels in the mother and reducing risks for the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Oral hypoglycemics (Option A), such as metformin or glyburide, are not typically used as first-line treatment for GDM, particularly because they can cross the placenta and may carry risks for the fetus, including potential hypoglycemia.

Reassurance (Option B) alone is insufficient in the management of gestational diabetes. It requires active monitoring and treatment to maintain appropriate glycemic control to prevent complications such as fetal macrosomia and neonatal hypoglycemia.

Induction of labor (Option D) at 32 weeks is premature and not advisable. The fetal lungs may not be adequately developed, and induction should be considered only after 37 weeks if necessary. The immediate concern should be blood sugar control, not early delivery.

questions.text: In an asymptomatic woman aged 35 years, an ultrasound scan reveals a single-chamber cyst measuring 6 cm in the ovary. Serology results are negative. The recommended approach for this condition includes treatment measures such as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Follow-up after 1-2 cycles of OCPs

Explanation:

  • The correct approach for a functional ovarian cyst that is asymptomatic, unilocular, less than 7 cm, and with negative serology, is conservative management. Follow-up after 1-2 cycles of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) helps suppress ovarian function and promotes cyst resolution. Most functional cysts resolve spontaneously without the need for surgical intervention.

Incorrect Options:

Laparotomy (Option A) is not indicated for a simple 6 cm functional cyst. It is reserved for larger cysts (>7 cm), persistent cysts, or those with suspicious features.

Ovariotomy (Option C) involves the removal of the ovary and is not necessary for functional cysts. It is reserved for cases of ovarian torsion, malignancy, or complicated cysts.

CA-125 testing (Option D) is used to monitor ovarian cancer or evaluate complex adnexal masses. It is not applicable for a benign, functional ovarian cyst in an asymptomatic patient.

questions.text: How is the contraceptive shown in the below image inserted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hysteroscopic

Explanation:

  • The contraceptive device depicted in the image is the Essure coil, a permanent sterilization method. It is inserted hysteroscopically, which involves the use of a hysteroscope through the vagina into the uterus. The device is then placed into each fallopian tube to create a physical barrier, causing fibrosis and occlusion of the tubes over time.

Essure

  • It is a permanent, non-surgical form of sterilization that involves placing small coils into the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy.

Procedure: The procedure involves the insertion of small, flexible coils (made of stainless steel and polyester fibers) into the fallopian tubes through the cervix and uterus. This is done under local anesthesia.

Mechanism: Over a few months, the body forms scar tissue around the coils, which blocks the fallopian tubes, preventing sperm from reaching the eggs.

Indications:

  • Permanent contraception for women who are sure they do not want future pregnancies.
  • Suitable for women who are not planning to undergo traditional tubal ligation or who have contraindications for surgery.

Advantages:

  • Non-surgical
  • Quick recovery: Most women can resume normal activities within a day or two.
  • Performed under local anesthesia.
  • Permanent

Effectiveness: After about three months, a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is performed to confirm tube blockage.

Complications:

  • Side effects: Mild cramping, bleeding, or infection after the procedure.
  • Rare complications: Expulsion or migration of the coils, perforation of the uterus or fallopian tubes.

questions.text: What is the most suitable course of action for managing a one and a half year old child who was brought to the hospital presenting symptoms of breathlessness, fever, cough, and cold, and upon examination has a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute, chest retractions, but no danger signs were present?

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate pneumonia based on WHO IMCI guidelines. The child presents with fast breathing (>40/min for ages 1-5 years) and chest retractions without any general danger signs.
  • According to standard guidelines, this classification of pneumonia requires oral antibiotic therapy (5-day course of oral amoxicillin) with careful monitoring at home, rather than hospitalization or intravenous antibiotics.

Pneumonia Classification: WHO IMNCI Guidelines

Signs

Classify as

Treatment

Presence of any general danger sign

Severe pneumonia or very severe disease

Give 1 dose of inj ampicillin & gentamycin & refer urgently to hospital

Presence of either chest indrawing &/or fast breathing but no general danger sign

Pneumonia
  • Start oral Amoxicillin x 5 days.
  • The child is sent home and assessed after 48 hours.
  • If the child has improved, continue the same treatment.
  • If the child has worsened, refer to a higher center.

No fast breathing, no chest indrawing, no general danger signs

No pneumonia: cough or cold only

Home-based supportive care

Fast Breathing Criteria:

  • < 2 months: > 60/min
  • 2-12 months: > 50/min
  • 1-5 years: > 40/min

General Danger signs:

  1. Convulsions
  2. Lethargy
  3. Inability to drink or breastfeed
  4. Persistent vomiting
  5. Unconsciousness
  6. Stridor in a calm child

Incorrect Options:

Give IV antibiotics and observe (Option A): IV antibiotics are reserved for severe pneumonia or cases with danger signs. This level of intervention is not warranted for a case without danger signs and represents overtreatment.

Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre (Option B): Referral to a higher center is indicated only for severe cases with danger signs such as lethargy, inability to drink, or persistent vomiting. The child's current presentation does not warrant this level of care.

No need of treatment only home remedies (Option D): This approach would be appropriate for cases with no fast breathing and no chest retractions. Given the presence of tachypnea and retractions, antibiotics are necessary, making home remedies alone insufficient.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 45-year-old female patient who experiences bleeding after sexual intercourse, and upon per vaginal examination, a lesion is observed that bleeds when touched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cervical polyp

Explanation:

  • In this case, the patient presents with post-coital bleeding, and a per vaginal examination reveals a vascular lesion that bleeds easily when touched, which is characteristic of a cervical polyp. These are benign growths that arise from the mucous membrane of the cervical canal and are commonly associated with post-coital or irregular bleeding.

Cervical Polyp

  • A benign growth in the cervical canal, often found in women aged 30-50, though they can occur at any stage.

 

  • Origin: Typically from the endocervical canal, occasionally the ectocervix.
  • Size and Shape: Small (few millimeters to 2 cm), finger-like or stalked.
  • Color: Red/purplish (vascular) or pale (fibrous).

Symptoms:

  • Postcoital bleeding
  • Intermenstrual bleeding
  • Vaginal discharge

Diagnosis:

  • Colposcopy
  • Pap smear/Biopsy: To rule out malignancy.

Management:

  • Polypectomy:
  • Histopathology: To confirm benign nature.

Incorrect Options:

Hemorrhagic cysts (Option A) typically occur within or on the surface of the ovary. They are not associated with post-coital bleeding or lesions on the cervix.

Cervical cancer (Option C) can cause irregular bleeding, including post-coital bleeding, but the lesion typically does not bleed on light touch and may require significant friction or manipulation to exhibit bleeding.

Cervical fibroids (Option D) are rare and more likely to present with post-coital pain or symptoms related to their size, such as interference with urination, rather than easy bleeding upon touch.

questions.text: A 5 year old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted after a few seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child?

choices.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some danger signs develop
Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate severe dehydration. The patient presents with characteristic features including irritability, hasty drinking, sunken eyes, and delayed skin pinch test, which are classic signs of severe dehydration requiring immediate intervention.
  • In cases of severe dehydration, the most appropriate treatment would be to start intravenous (IV) fluids, administer IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre.

Assessment and Management of Dehydration:

Degree of Dehydration

Clinical Features

Management

Mild
  • Slightly increased thirst
  • Normal urine output
  • Normal skin turgor
  • Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose
  • Encourage the child to drink small, frequent amounts of the ORT solution
  • Continue regular feeding if the child is not vomiting or unable to tolerate oral intake

Moderate
  • Increased thirst
  • Decreased urine output
  • Decreased tears
  • Dry mucous membranes
  • Delayed capillary refill (>2 seconds)
  • Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose
  • Administer ORT in larger amounts and more frequently
  • Monitor vital signs (heart rate, blood pressure), urine output, and mental status
  • Consider antiemetic medication if vomiting is present
  • If unable to tolerate oral intake or deteriorating clinical status, consider intravenous fluids

Severe
  • Markedly increased thirst
  • Minimal or no urine output
  • Sunken eyes, lethargy, irritability
  • Cool extremities, mottled or pale skin
  • Altered mental status, decreased consciousness
  • Initiate intravenous fluids with a bolus of isotonic saline or lactated Ringer's solution
  • Administer maintenance intravenous fluids and correct electrolyte imbalances as necessary
  • Monitor vital signs closely, including heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen saturation
  • Address underlying causes, such as infections or other medical conditions
  • Consider transfer to a higher level of care if there are signs of severe or life-threatening dehydration

Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher centre (Option A): While antibiotic therapy may be indicated in some cases of diarrhea, the priority in this scenario is to address the dehydration and provide appropriate fluid replacement. Referral to a higher center is necessary for the management of severe dehydration.

Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day (Option B): Given the signs of dehydration mentioned, providing oral fluids alone may not be adequate to correct the dehydration rapidly. Prompt intervention with IV fluids is required in severe dehydration cases.

Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask the mother to come back if some danger signs develop (Option C): Zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution are essential components of managing diarrheal illnesses, but in cases of severe dehydration, intravenous fluid therapy is necessary.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presented with hematemesis and was found to have splenomegaly, on examination. There was a past history of exchange transfusion in this child for neonatal jaundice. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Portal vein thrombosis

Explanation:

  • The presentation of hematemesis and splenomegaly, along with the significant history of exchange transfusion in the neonatal period, strongly suggests portal vein thrombosis.
  • This condition is a common cause of portal hypertension in children and can result from umbilical vein catheterization during exchange transfusion.

Incorrect Options

Splenic vein thrombosis (Option A) is also a possibility in a case of splenomegaly, but the history of exchange transfusion suggests a more generalized thrombotic event involving the portal vein.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (Option C) is a condition characterized by the obstruction of hepatic veins, leading to liver congestion. It is less likely in this case, as the presentation of hematemesis and splenomegaly is more suggestive of portal vein involvement.

Liver cirrhosis (Option D): Although it can cause portal hypertension, cirrhosis is uncommon in a 5-year-old without a history of chronic liver disease.

questions.text: The Pearl index is used to calculate which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Accidental pregnancies

Explanation:

  • The Pearl Index is an indicator of Couple protection practices in the community. Defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 women years of exposure. It is the percentage of eligible couples protected against childbirth by family planning.

It is a standard method to evaluate the effectiveness of contraceptive methods in preventing unintended pregnancies.

Contraceptive Method

Indication

Pearl Index (Failure Rate per 100 Woman-Years)

Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

Women with irregular menstrual cycles or acne seeking contraception

0.3 - 9

Intrauterine Device (IUD)

Long-term contraception; contraindications to estrogen

0.1 - 0.8 (Copper)

0.1 - 0.2 (Hormonal)

Condoms (Male)

Prevention of STIs and contraception

2 - 18

Condoms (Female)

Non-hormonal, barrier method

5 - 21

Contraceptive Implant
  • Long-term contraception; high efficacy, minimal user intervention
  • Considered in women with seizures or sickle cell disorder

0.05 - 0.3

Contraceptive Injection (e.g., Depo-Provera)

Long-term, non-daily hormonal contraception; those who cannot use estrogen

0.2 - 6

Vaginal Ring (e.g., NuvaRing)

Monthly regimen with local hormone delivery

0.3 - 9

Sterilization (Female Tubal Ligation)

Permanent contraception

0.5 - 0.1

Sterilization (Vasectomy)

Permanent contraception; more effective than female sterilization

0.1 - 0.15

Natural Family Planning

Natural method, often for religious or personal reasons

2 - 25

Emergency Contraception Pills

Post-coital contraception

1 - 2

Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM)

Breastfeeding women, within first 6 months postpartum with exclusive breastfeeding and amenorrhea

0.5 - 2

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT represent a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thick white discharge

Explanation:

  • Thick white discharge is not a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis (BV). The discharge associated with BV is typically thin, grayish-white, and homogenous, rather than thick.

Pathophysiology of BV:

BV occurs due to a reduction in lactobacilli (normal vaginal flora) and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria such as Gardnerella vaginalis, Prevotella, Mobiluncus, and Bacteroides.

Symptoms: Thin, foul-smelling vaginal discharge.

Diagnosis: Based on Amsel criteria (at least 3 of 4 present)

Amsel's Criteria for Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)

Thin, gray-white discharge

Homogeneous vaginal discharge, often malodorous.

pH > 4.5

Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 is indicative.

Positive Whiff Test

Fishy odor when 10% KOH is added to the discharge.

Clue cells on microscopy

Vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, giving a stippled appearance.

 

Feature

BV

Normal

Colposcopic findings (A, B)

Homogeneous, milk-like secretions observed.

Homogeneous, clear secretions seen.

Microscopic findings (C, D)

Gardnerella-like microbes and presence of clue cells on microscopy.

Lactobacillus-like microbes observed with no clue cells.

Microbial composition

Overgrowth of anaerobes (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis).

Dominance of Lactobacillus species, maintaining vaginal acidity.

Clinical significance

Associated with fishy odor and elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), characteristic of BV.

Represents a healthy vaginal microbiome with stable pH (≤4.5) and protective lactobacilli.

 

Feature

Bacterial Vaginosis

Candidiasis

Trichomoniasis

Causative agent

Overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and others

Candida albicans or other Candida species

Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan)

Discharge appearance

Thin, gray-white, homogeneous

Thick, white, "cottage cheese-like"

Yellow-green, frothy

Odor

Fishy (especially post-coital or with KOH)

None or mild

Foul-smelling

Vaginal pH

> 4.5

≤ 4.5

> 4.5

Whiff Test

Positive (fishy odor with KOH)

Negative

May be positive

Microscopy

Clue cells, few lactobacilli

Hyphae or pseudohyphae, spores

Motile trichomonads, many WBCs

Associated symptoms

Often asymptomatic, may have itching or irritation

Intense itching, burning, dyspareunia

Itching, burning, erythema

Treatment

Metronidazole or clindamycin

Fluconazole or topical antifungals

Metronidazole or tinidazole

questions.text: A male infant was brought to the emergency pediatric unit with abdominal distention. There was a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. On examination, he was found to have urinary retention. Imaging showed bilateral hydronephrosis. What could be the probable diagnosis of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Posterior urethral valves

Explanation:

  • The presentation of abdominal distention, recurrent urinary tract infections, and urinary retention is consistent with the diagnosis of Posterior urethral valves (PUV). Also the bilateral hydronephrosis, which is the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to urinary obstruction, further supports this diagnosis.
  • Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are a congenital abnormality that occurs only in males. It is characterized by the presence of abnormal leaflets or flaps of tissue in the posterior urethra, leading to partial or complete obstruction of urine flow.

Posterior urethral valves:

Feature

Description

Definition

Abnormal flaps of tissue in the posterior urethra that obstruct the flow of urine in male infants

Etiology

Developmental anomaly during fetal development

Clinical Presentation
  • Urinary tract obstruction symptoms, such as poor urinary stream, dribbling, or difficulty urinating
  • Urinary tract infections (UTIs) with fever, irritability, and poor feeding
  • Enlarged bladder (palpable abdominal mass)
  • Hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidneys due to urine backup)
  • Poor weight gain and growth

Diagnostic Evaluation
  • Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG): Radiographic imaging to visualize the urinary tract and identify the valves
  • Ultrasound of the kidneys and bladder to assess for hydronephrosis
  • Blood tests: Renal function tests and electrolyte levels

Management
  • Endoscopic valve ablation or fulguration to remove or destroy the obstructing valves
  • Surgical intervention: Valve resection or reconstruction in severe cases
  • Management of urinary tract infections and associated complications

Prognosis
  • The prognosis varies depending on the severity of the obstruction and associated renal damage
  • Early diagnosis and intervention can lead to better outcomes and improved renal function
  • Long-term monitoring and follow-up are necessary to monitor renal function and manage any potential complications

Incorrect Options:

Vesicoureteric reflux (Option A): VUR is urine flow from the bladder to the ureters/kidneys due to an incompetent valve at the ureter-bladder junction. While this condition can cause recurrent UTIs, the primary feature is retrograde flow of urine & it typically doesn't present with significant urinary retention or abdominal distention.

Horseshoe kidney (Option C): A horseshoe kidney is a congenital fusion anomaly of the kidneys, where the kidneys are fused at the lower poles. While it may be associated with hydronephrosis, it does not typically cause urinary retention or recurrent UTIs as described in the scenario.

Pelviureteric junction obstruction (Option D): Although this condition can cause hydronephrosis, it typically presents unilaterally rather than bilaterally. Additionally, its presentation includes asymptomatic flank mass, upper abdominal pain & urinary tract infection (UTI).

questions.text: In a woman presenting with amenorrhea, headache, blurred vision, and galactorrhea, the appropriate investigation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prolactin level

Explanation:

  • The symptoms described, amenorrhea, headache, blurred vision, and galactorrhea—are classic signs of hyperprolactinemia, often caused by a prolactinoma (pituitary adenoma). Measuring serum prolactin levels is the most appropriate initial investigation to confirm the diagnosis. Elevated prolactin levels help pinpoint the cause and guide further management.

Incorrect Options:

Although LH (Option B) can be affected in conditions of pituitary dysfunction, it is not the first-line investigation for a patient presenting with hyperprolactinemia symptoms.

FSH (Option C) evaluation is more relevant in cases of primary ovarian insufficiency or menopause, not hyperprolactinemia.

hCG (Option D) is used to confirm pregnancy, which does not align with the clinical symptoms described in this case.

questions.text: During infancy, what is the most prevalent causative agent of acute bronchiolitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Respiratory syncytial virus

Explanation:

  • The most common etiological agent responsible for acute bronchiolitis in infants is Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV).

Bronchiolitis

Age Group

Infants between 1 and 6 months, but can affect children up to 2 years old.

Seasonality

Occurs primarily in winter and spring.

Causative Agent
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (Most common)
  • Others include:
    • Parainfluenza virus (Option B)
    • Adenovirus
    • Influenza virus (Option A)
    • Rarely Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Risk factors
  • M/c in male infants.
  • Infants exposed to tobacco smoke, not breastfed, or living in crowded conditions.
  • Maternal smoking
  • Older family members/siblings (common source of infection)

Protection
  • IgG3 antibodies (short half-life, limited placental transfer)
  • Breastfeeding provides IgA antibodies.

Pathophysiology
  • Bronchiolar obstruction with edema, mucus and cellular debris.
  • Increased airway resistance during both inspiration and exhalation.
  • Leads to expiratory wheezing, air trapping, lung hyperinflation and possible atelectasis.
  • Hypoxemia due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
  • With severe obstructive disease hypercapnia develops.

Clinical Manifestations
  • First develop upper respiratory symptoms: Sneezing and clear rhinorrhea.
  • Fever (±)
  • Diminished appetite
  • Persistent Cough
  • Dyspnea
  • Irritability
  • Respiratory distress
  • Cyanosis.

Physical Examination
  • Prolonged expiratory time
  • Wheezing
  • Increased work of breathing with nasal flaring and retractions
  • Accessory muscles of respiration are working
  • Auscultation: Fine crepitations and rhonchi
  • Faint or inaudible breath sounds in severe disease

questions.text: The FIGO stage of endometrial carcinoma with metastasis to the vagina is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stage III b

Explanation:

  • Stage III b refers to endometrial carcinoma with vaginal involvement, without involvement of the serosa, adnexa (e.g., fallopian tubes, ovaries), or positive peritoneal cytology. Vaginal metastasis is characteristic of this stage and does not indicate further extension to distant sites.

FIGO STAGING OF ENDOMETRIAL CANCER (2023)

STAGE

DESCRIPTION

I

Confined to the uterine corpus and ovary
 

IA

Confined to endometrium; invasion of <50% of myometrium

IB

Confined to endometrium; invasion of >50% of myometrium

IC

Aggressive histological types are limited to a polyp or Confined to endometrium

II

Cervical stromal invasion
 

IIA

Non-aggressive histological types

IIB

Substantial LVSI (lymphovascular space involvement) of non-aggressive histological types

IIC

Aggressive histological types with any myometrial involvement

III

Local and/or regional spread of the tumor

 

IIIA

Invasion of uterine serosa &/or adnexa (Option A)

IIIB

Vagina &/or the parametria or pelvic peritoneum involved

IIIC

Pelvic &/or para-aortic lymph node involvement (Option C)

IV

Spread to the bladder mucosa &/or intestinal mucosa &/or distance metastasis.
 

IVA

Invasion of the bladder mucosa and/or the intestinal/bowel mucosa (Option D)

IVB

Abdominal peritoneal metastasis

IVC

Distant metastasis, including metastasis to any extra- or intra-abdominal lymph nodes above the renal vessels, lungs, liver, brain, or bone

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT associated with fibroids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amenorrhoea

Explanation:

  • Amenorrhoea (absence of menstrual periods) is not a common feature of fibroids. While fibroids often cause abnormal uterine bleeding, including heavy or prolonged periods, they typically do not lead to a complete absence of menstruation.

Fibroid (Uterine Leiomyoma)

  • Benign smooth muscle tumor of the uterus.
  • Estrogen-dependent growth; typically regresses after menopause.
  • Commonly occurs in reproductive-age women.

Types (Based on Location):

  • These fibroids are classified as Type 0 under the FIGO classification of fibroids.

FIGO Classification of Fibroids
 

Type

Name

Submucosal

0

Pedunculated, Intracavity

1

<50% Intramural and rest in cavity

2

≥ 50% Intramural and a part in cavity

3

100% intramural but contacts endometrium

Intramural

4

Intramural

Subserosal

5

≥ 50% Intramural and partly in serosa

6

<50% Intramural and rest in serosa

7

Subserosal Pedunculated

Others

8

Other - Cervical, Parasitic

2-5

Hybrid - Present both in the cavity (type 2) and in the serosa (type 5)

Symptoms:

  • Menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding).
  • Dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation).
  • Pelvic pain or pressure.
  • Dyspareunia (painful intercourse).
  • Urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, or retention).
  • Infertility or recurrent miscarriages.

Signs:

  • Enlarged, irregular, firm uterus on bimanual examination.
  • Mobility of the uterus may be reduced if fibroids are large.

Complications:

  • Severe anemia due to chronic menorrhagia.
  • Infertility and subfertility.
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Red degeneration (painful necrosis, often during pregnancy).
  • Torsion of pedunculated fibroids.
  • Malignant transformation (rare; <1% cases to leiomyosarcoma).

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: Primary imaging modality; identifies size, number, and location.
  • Hysteroscopy: For evaluation of submucosal fibroids.
  • MRI: Detailed imaging in complex or unclear cases.
  • Sonohysterography: Detects submucosal fibroids and cavity distortion.

Treatment Options:

  • Medical:
    • Hormonal therapy (GnRH agonists, progestins).
    • Non-hormonal options (NSAIDs, tranexamic acid).
  • Surgical:
    • Myomectomy: For preserving fertility.
    • Hysterectomy: Definitive treatment for symptomatic fibroids in women who have completed childbearing.
    • Uterine artery embolization (UAE): Minimally invasive, for reducing fibroid size and symptoms.
  • Other Interventions:
    • MRI-guided focused ultrasound (non-invasive ablation).
    • Laparoscopic or hysteroscopic resection.

Prognosis: Recurrence possible after myomectomy, especially in younger women.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Atrial septal defect

Explanation:

Atrial septal defect is not the component of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

Tetralogy of Fallot

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Pulmonary Stenosis: (Option D Ruled Out)
    • Narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): (Option A Ruled Out)
    • A large hole between the right and left ventricles, usually misaligned, allowing abnormal blood flow.
  • Overriding Aorta:
    • The aorta is positioned over the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy: (Option B Ruled Out)
    • Thickening of the right ventricle wall due to the extra effort required to pump blood.

Clinical features:

  • Cyanosis (central) due to hypoxia; SpO2 <75-85%
  • Clubbing
  • Polycythemia
  • Cyanotic spells

Auscultatory findings:

  • Ejection systolic murmur in the pulmonary area
  • Single S2 (P2 is soft and inaudible)

Chest X-ray:

  • Boot-Shaped Heart or 'Cor en Sabot' appearance = Pulmonary oligemia

questions.text: What does the ferning pattern of drying cervical mucus indicate in terms of its mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Estrogen

Explanation:

  • The ferning pattern of drying cervical mucus is caused by the influence of estrogen.
  • During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, rising estrogen levels cause cervical mucus to become thin, clear, and elastic, facilitating sperm movement.
  • When dried, this mucus exhibits a characteristic fern-like pattern under the microscope due to the crystallization of sodium chloride in the mucus, which is influenced by estrogen.

Organ/System

Estrogen

Progesterone

Uterus

Proliferates endometrium.

Has a secretory effect on the endometrium.

Upregulates progesterone receptors on endometrium.

Downregulates estrogen receptors.

Leads to the growth of the non-pregnant uterus.

Promotes the growth of the pregnant uterus (in estrogen-primed endometrium).

Cervix

Cervical mucus is thin, watery, copious, and elastic.

Cervical mucus is thick, scanty, viscous, and non-elastic.

Permeable to sperm.

Impermeable to sperm.

Fern-like appearance on microscopy (day 8 of cycle).

Ferning disappears by day 18 of the cycle.

Vagina

Superficial cells (eosinophilic, pyknotic nucleus) predominate in the first half of the cycle.

Intermediate cells (basophilic, small nucleus) predominate in the second half of the cycle.

Breast

Promotes ductal growth.

Promotes glandular growth.

Salt & Water Regulation

Causes retention of salt and water.

Promotes excretion of salt and water.

Fallopian Tube

Increases motility and decreases secretions.

Decreases motility and increases secretions.

Lipid Profile

Increases HDL, LDL, and triglycerides.

Increases HDL but lowers LDL and triglycerides (3rd/4th gen progesterones are cardioprotective).

Incorrect Options:

Progesterone (Option B) leads to thick and sticky cervical mucus, which does not show a ferning pattern. It is predominant in the luteal phase of the cycle.

Prolactin (Option C) is mainly associated with lactation and does not affect the properties of cervical mucus.

17-ketosteroids (Option D) are adrenal hormone metabolites and do not play a role in the changes seen in cervical mucus.

questions.text: A patient undergoing treatment for eclampsia at present. When should the subsequent administration of MgSO4 be skipped?

choices.text: Urine output of more than 45 mL/hr

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Absence of knee jerk reflex

Explanation:

  • In eclampsia management, the absence of deep tendon reflexes (such as knee jerks) can be a sign of magnesium toxicity.
  • Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is administered to prevent seizures, but an excessive dosage can lead to magnesium toxicity, which depresses the central nervous system, causing loss of deep tendon reflexes.

Magnesium Sulfate Toxicity

  • Monitor magnesium sulfate toxicity by observing deep tendon reflexes, respiratory status, and urine output (primarily excreted by kidneys)
  • Impaired kidney function can lead to toxicity.
  • Loss of patellar/ knee reflexes at ~12 mg/dL is an early warning sign.

MgSO₄ Monitoring (Before Each Maintenance Dose):

Avoid the next dose if:

  • Patellar reflex is absent.
  • Urine output <30 mL/hour in the last 4 hours.
  • Respiratory rate <16 breaths/min.

Serum Magnesium Testing:

  • Routine testing is not recommended.
  • Test 4-6 hours after starting infusion to adjust rate (target: 4-7 mEq/L or 4.8-8.4 mg/dL).
  • Elevated serum creatinine (≥1.0 mg/dL) to assess kidney function.
  • Check for toxicity signs (diminished reflexes, breathing issues) to confirm diagnosis and guide treatment. Administer fluids cautiously to avoid overload and pulmonary edema.

Adverse Effects of Magnesium Sulfate

Mechanism:

  • Acts as a smooth muscle relaxant.

Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5–9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of knee jerk reflex

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest

Management of Magnesium Toxicity:

Immediate Actions:

  • Administer 10 mL 10% calcium gluconate IV over 3 minutes to reverse mild to moderate respiratory depression.
  • Discontinue magnesium sulfate.

Further Steps:

  • Administer furosemide to increase urinary excretion.
  • Severe respiratory depression requires intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • The effects of IV calcium may be short-lived if steady-state toxicity is present.

Urine output more than 45 mL/hr (Option B) suggests adequate renal perfusion and function. This is a positive sign, indicating that the kidneys are adequately eliminating magnesium and other waste products.

Respiratory rate more than 14/min (Option C): While an elevated respiratory rate can indicate potential issues, it is not a specific parameter for withholding MgSO4. Respiratory distress could be caused by various factors, and further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, as shown in the image, presents with fever and painful sores in the mouth, along with a rash on his hand. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Coxsackie virus

Explanation:

The characteristic presentation of fever accompanied by painful oral sores and hand rash is the classic triad of Hand Foot Mouth Disease.

Coxsackie virus, particularly type A16, is the causative agent of this condition.

Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Causative organism

Coxsackie A16 virus, Enterovirus 71

Age group

<5 years

Clinical features
  • Low grade fever, feeling of being unwell, sore throat are commonly observed.
  • Characterized by papulovesicular skin rash commonly on buttocks, knees, elbows and genital area.
  • Ulcers/blisters are also seen in the oral cavity, mostly on the posterior aspect.

Management

  • Resolves on its own in 5-7 days, till then symptomatic and conservative treatment is given.
  • Isolation of affected children at home and promotion of hand hygiene to prevent disease spread is important. 

Incorrect Options:

Pox virus (Option A): While pox viruses can cause skin lesions, they typically present with pustular lesions rather than the papulovesicular rash characteristic of HFMD.

HHV 7 virus (Option C): Human Herpesvirus 7 causes roseola infantum (6th disease), characterized by fever and maculopapular rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities. It does not cause oral sores or the characteristic hand lesions seen in this case.

HIV virus (Option D): While HIV can cause various skin manifestations, it does not present with oral sores along with the typical hand rash as seen in the patient, which is more consistent with HFMD.

questions.text: What could be a potential cause for a child with short stature who is brought to the pediatrician and has high growth hormone levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Laron dwarfism

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate Laron dwarfism, also known as growth hormone insensitivity syndrome.

  • This rare genetic disorder is characterized by the paradoxical combination of elevated growth hormone levels with low IGF-1 levels, resulting from mutations in the growth hormone receptor gene or post-receptor signaling pathway.
  • Despite high circulating levels of growth hormone, the body's inability to respond to it leads to inadequate IGF-1 production, which is essential for normal growth and development.

Incorrect Options:

Turner syndrome (Option A): Growth hormone treatment is often used to help girls with Turner Syndrome achieve greater height. The underlying cause of short stature in Turner Syndrome is related to the SHOX gene, not growth hormone deficiency. Also, this condition is associated with other characteristic features, such as webbed neck and ovarian dysgenesis, which are not mentioned in this case.

Pituitary dwarfism (Option B): This condition, also known as growth hormone deficiency, is characterized by low growth hormone levels and subsequent low IGF-1 levels. The presentation of high growth hormone levels, in this case, makes pituitary dwarfism an unlikely diagnosis.

Maternal deprivation dwarfism (Option D): This psychosocial condition occurs in infants due to severe emotional deprivation or neglect. While it can cause growth failure and stunting, it does not present with the specific hormonal pattern of high growth hormone and low IGF-1 levels.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 10-year-old boy who was brought for psychiatric evaluation due to intellectual disability and exhibits an IQ of 45? The boy also presents with physical characteristics such as a long face, large ears, and large testes, along with a cardiac murmur. Additionally, there is a history of poor intellectual function in the paternal family.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Fragile X syndrome

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with the classic triad of physical features, including a long face, large ears, and macroorchidism (large testes), along with intellectual disability (IQ 45) and a cardiac murmur suggestive of mitral valve prolapse, which indicates Fragile X syndrome.
  • The X-linked inheritance pattern is supported by the paternal family history of poor intellectual function.
  • This condition is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome, making it the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability.

Fragile X Syndrome:

Genetic Basis

CGG repeats on FMR-1 (Familial mental retardation) gene on X chromosome

CGG Repeat Numbers
  • Normal population: 5-55 repeats
  • Carriers (premutation): 55-200 repeats
  • Fragile X Syndrome: >200 repeats

Gender Prevalence
  • More common in males (X-Linked Dominant Inheritance)
  • Females mostly carriers

Clinical Features
  • Long face & large ears
  • Large mandible/Prominent jaw
  • High arched palate
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Macroorchidism/large testes (seen in adolescent age group)
  • Intellectual disability

Clinical features of female carriers

  • May be associated with premature ovarian failure
  • 10% may have an intellectual disability/low IQ

Incorrect options:

Cushing's syndrome (Option A): While this condition can affect growth and development, it typically presents with central obesity, moon face, and buffalo hump. The characteristic features of large ears and macroorchidism are not associated with Cushing's syndrome.

Rett syndrome (Option B): This condition primarily affects females and is characterized by progressive loss of motor functions such as inability to speak, use hands, walk or perform other activities. It does not present with distinctive facial features or macroorchidism.

William syndrome (Option D): While this condition can cause intellectual disability and cardiac abnormalities, it typically presents with elfin facies and a distinctive "cocktail party" personality.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhoea and mucocutaneous lesions, as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with diarrhea and mucocutaneous lesions, which started since weaning is suggestive of a zinc deficiency disorder called as acrodermatitis enteropathica.
  • This rare autosomal recessive condition occurs due to impaired zinc absorption from a defective ZIP4 protein, typically becoming apparent when breast milk (naturally rich in bioavailable zinc) is replaced with solid foods.
  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica:

 

  • Autosomal recessive disorder.
  • Severe zinc deficiency due to impaired intestinal absorption (ZIP4 protein defect).
  • Early infancy onset: Vesiculobullous, dry, scaly skin lesions (periorificial, buttocks, acral areas).
  • Associated with alopecia, eye changes, chronic diarrhea, growth retardation, and stomatitis.
  • Treatment: 2-3 mg/kg/day oral zinc therapy.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (Option A): This primary immunodeficiency presents with the classic triad of recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia. The timing of onset with weaning and the absence of bleeding manifestations make this diagnosis unlikely.

Pediatric epidermolysis bullosa (Option C): While this condition causes skin fragility and blistering, it is present from birth and is not associated with weaning or diarrhea. The lesions in epidermolysis bullosa occur primarily at sites of mechanical trauma.

Atopic dermatitis (Option D): Although this can present in infancy, it is not associated with weaning or diarrhea.

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother presented with her 2-week-old newborn who had a large tongue and an umbilical hernia. Which of the following investigations has to be done in view of congenital hypothyroidism?

choices.text: A fresh blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A fresh blood sample and screen first for T4 levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate congenital hypothyroidism, as evidenced by the large tongue and umbilical hernia.

The screening method for congenital hypothyroidism involves using dried blood spot samples and testing for TSH levels.

  • TSH is a more sensitive and specific marker for detecting hypothyroidism in newborns
  • Elevated TSH levels indicate hypothyroidism, while low or normal TSH levels suggest normal thyroid function
