  • Measuring T4 levels alone is not sufficient (Option B and C Ruled Out) for the initial screening of congenital hypothyroidism because T4 levels can be affected by various factors, including stress, illness, and medications
  • Dried blood spot testing is a simple, minimally invasive method to collect a blood sample, allowing for large-scale newborn screening programs where a small amount of blood from a heel prick is readily accessible for analysis. (Option A Ruled Out)

Congenital Hypothyroidism

Definition
  • Most common preventable cause of intellectual disability
  • Prevalence of 1 in 2,000 newborns
  • Results from defects in hypothalamic-pituitary axis or thyroid gland
  • Can be congenital or acquired

Etiology
  • Thyroid dysgenesis (75% of cases)
  • Spectrum ranging from agenesis to ectopic thyroid
  • Biosynthetic defects affecting iodine transport, peroxidation, thyroglobulin synthesis
  • Pendred syndrome (associated with decreased intracellular transport of iodine and deafness)
  • Genetic defects associated with TSHR, PAX8, and TSHB genes

Clinical Features

Congenital Signs:

  • Open posterior fontanel
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Delayed neurodevelopment
  • Large tongue

Common Features:

  • Growth retardation
  • Sallow edematous facies
  • Delayed skeletal maturation
  • Delayed dental eruption
  • Delayed puberty
  • Constipation
  • Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy
  • Hypothermia

Screening
  • Dried blood spot (DBS) sample at age 2-4 days
  • Screen first for TSH levels
  • TSH thresholds for treatment:
    • >20 mU/L in first week
    • >10 mU/L between 7-21 days
    • >6 mU/L beyond 21 days

Investigations

Initial Tests:

  • Serum TSH and FT4 levels
  • TSH > 20 mU/L in first week needs evaluation

Further Evaluation:

  • Radionuclide scan
  • Ultrasound of thyroid
  • Children with undetectable thyroid may need testing for:
  • Defects in iodine transport
  • TSH receptor abnormalities
  • TSH blocking antibody

Management
  • Immediate thyroxine replacement after diagnosis
  • Dosage: 10-15 μg/kg/day
  • In central hypothyroidism, cortisol replacement should precede thyroid replacement
  • Monitor FT4 and TSH levels every 2 months in first year
  • Long-term follow-up required
  • Most children require lifelong therapy

questions.text: The artery that is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Posterior tibial artery

Explanation:

  • The posterior tibial artery runs posterior to the medial malleolus, between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon.
  • It is commonly palpated at this location to assess peripheral circulation, especially in conditions like peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

Arrangement of Structures Under the Flexor Retinaculum (Medial to Lateral)

Mnemonic: Tom Dick ANd Harry

  • T: Tibialis posterior
  • D: Flexor Digitorum longus
  • A: Posterior tibial Artery
  • N: Tibial Nerve
  • H: Flexor Hallucis longus

Incorrect Options:

Anterior tibial artery (Option A): The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg, and it travels through the anterior compartment. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus (inner ankle) and the calcaneal tendon (Achilles tendon).

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option C): The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the dorsal (top) aspect of the foot, specifically between the first and second metatarsal bones. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.

Popliteal artery (Option D): The popliteal artery is located behind the knee joint in the popliteal fossa. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.

questions.text: A patient has lost sensation over the dorsum of the foot and medial four toes. There is the associated difficulty of eversion of the foot. Which nerve injury is likely to be the reason for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Superficial peroneal nerve

Explanation:

  • The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot and medial four toes, except for the web space between the first and second toes (which is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve).
  • It also supplies the lateral compartment muscles (fibularis longus and brevis), which are responsible for foot eversion.
  • Therefore, an injury to this nerve results in loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot and difficulty with eversion.

Fracture of the neck of fibula → Common peroneal nerve injury

Features of Common Peroneal Nerve Injury:

  • Loss of dorsiflexion → Foot drop
  • Complete loss of eversion
  • No loss of complete inversion (Tibialis posterior intact via tibial nerve)
  • Loss of extension of great toe and lateral four toes
  • Complete sensory loss on dorsum of foot (except lateral part)

Injury of Tibial Nerve

Injury of Superficial Peroneal Nerve

Injury of Deep Peroneal Nerve

Loss of plantar flexion

Eversion completely affected

Loss of dorsiflexion – foot drop
  • No loss of complete inversion (because of tibialis anterior supplied by deep peroneal nerve is intact)
  • Loss of flexion of great toe
  • Loss of flexion of lateral four toes
  • Paralysis of all muscles of sole
  • Loss of sensory supply over sole

Sensory loss on major part of dorsum except medial side of foot and lateral side of foot and lateral side of little finger
  • Inversion not completely affected because tibialis posterior functional
  • Loss of extension of great toe
  • Loss of extension of lateral four toes
  • Sensory loss on the area between great and second toe

Incorrect Options:

Deep peroneal nerve (Option A):

  • Supplies the anterior compartment of the leg
  • Provides sensation only to the first web space between the first and second toes.
  • Injury would cause foot drop, not loss of eversion.

Common peroneal nerve (Option C):

  • The common peroneal nerve branches into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves.
  • Injury would cause a wider deficit, including foot drop (due to deep peroneal involvement) and loss of eversion and sensation over the dorsum of the foot.
  • The given symptoms are specific to superficial peroneal nerve injury only.

Posterior tibial nerve (Option D):

  • Supplies the posterior compartment of the leg.
  • Provides sensation to the sole of the foot, not the dorsum.
  • Injury affects plantar flexion and sensation of the sole, not eversion.

questions.text: What type of joint is seen in the labeled structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Secondary cartilaginous joint

Explanation:

The pubic symphysis is a joint sandwiched between your left pelvic bone and right pelvic bone. It is a secondary cartilaginous joint. The secondary cartilaginous joints are permanent joints, which are slightly movable and their movements depend upon the sufficient amount of white-fibro cartilage tissues.

Primary Cartilaginous Joint (Option B)

Secondary Cartilaginous Joint

Sutures

Syndesmoses

(Option A)

Gomphosis
  • Joint between epiphysis and diaphysis
  • Between basiocciput and basisphenoid
  • Symphysis menti
  • Symphysis pubis
  • Manubrio sternal
  • Joint between vertebral bodies, xiphisternal joint, midline intervertebral joint
  • Serrate: Sagittal
  • Denticulate: Lambdoid
  • Squamous:Temporoparietal
  • Plane: Between palatine process of maxillae
  • Schindylesis: Between rostrum of sphenoid and upper margin of vomer

Inferior tibiofibular joint

Tooth fit in the socket

Fibrous joints are classified into: (Option C)

  • Sutures,
  • Syndesmoses
  • Gomphosis

questions.text: The below image is of a femur bone. Which muscles are attached to "A"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Iliopsoas

Explanation:

  • The A point marked on the image of the femur is the lesser trochanter of the femur.
  • The Iliopsoas muscle arises from the Iliac fossa and lumbar spine and attaches to the lesser trochanter of the femur.
  • Iliopsoas is a large compound muscle of the inner hip composed of the iliacus and psoas major muscles. It is situated on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • The iliopsoas muscle is the primary flexor of the hip joint. It is also responsible for external hip rotation at the hip joint.
  • It causes flexion of the trunk at the hip, lateral flexion of the trunk (psoas major only)

Incorrect Options:

Gluteus maximus (Option A):

  • is the largest and heaviest muscle in the body.
  • It takes its origin from the dorsum of the hip bone as well as from the dorsum of the sacrum and also has ligaments.
  • Insertion is on the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior aspect of the upper femur bone.

Quadriceps femoris (Option C):

  • are the group of muscles in front of the thigh. Quadriceps perform a variety of movements, including running, jumping, kicking, and walking.
  • There are 4 Quadriceps:
    • Rectus femoris.
    • Vastus lateralis
    • Vastus medialis
    • Vastus intermedius.
  • When Quadriceps muscles contract, they extend the knee joint, straightening the leg.
  • The quadriceps femoris attaches to the patella via the quadriceps tendon and does not attach to the lesser trochanter, so this is incorrect.

Adductor Magnus (Option D):

  • is a prime mover of the femur into adduction. One portion of the adductor muscle flexes the thigh and works as a medial rotator; the other extends the thigh and is a lateral rotator.
  • The adductor magnus attaches to the adductor tubercle on the femur, not the lesser trochanter, so this is also incorrect.

questions.text: The image showed a normal elbow. What is the structure marked in the image called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Capitulum

Explanation:

The capitulum is a rounded knob-like structure located on the distal end of the humerus bone. It articulates with the radius bone to form the radiocapitular joint, which allows for flexion and extension movements of the forearm at the elbow joint.

Incorrect Options:

Trochlea (Option B):

  • The trochlea is a spool-shaped structure located on the distal end of the humerus bone, just medial to the capitulum.
  • It forms the trochlear notch of the ulna bone, creating the ulnohumeral joint.
  • The trochlea is responsible for the hinge-like movements of the elbow Joint, allowing flexion and extension of the forearm.

Olecranon (Option C):

  • The olecranon is a bony prominence located at the proximal end of the ulna bone, forming the bony tip of the elbow.
  • It serves as an attachment point for muscles and ligaments, including the triceps brachii muscle and the triceps tendon.
  • The olecranon helps stabilize the elbow joint and provides leverage for extension movements of the forearm.

Head of radius (Option D):

  • The head of the radius is the rounded, disc-shaped structure located at the proximal end of the radius bone.
  • It articulates with the capitulum of the humerus, forming the radiocapitular joint.
  • The head of the radius allows for rotation movements of the forearm, such as pronation and supination.

questions.text: Identify the labelled tarsal bone in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Navicular

Explanation:

  • There are 7 tarsal bones in the foot.
  • The Navicular is located medially in the midfoot between the talus posteriorly and the 3 cuneiform bones anteriorly.

Bone Group

Bones

Description & Function

Tarsals

 

Provide mechanical support and structure to the foot.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Proximal Group

 

Talus

Transmits body weight to the foot.

 

Articulates at three joints:

 

Superiorly: Ankle joint (tibia/fibula)

 

Inferiorly: Subtalar joint (calcaneus)

 

Anteriorly: Talonavicular joint (navicular)

Calcaneus

Largest tarsal bone, forms the heel.

 

Articulates at two joints:

 

Superiorly: Subtalar joint (talus)

 

Anteriorly: Calcaneocuboid joint (cuboid)

Intermediate Group

 

Navicular

Boat-shaped; articulates with talus, cuneiforms, and cuboid.

 

Has a tuberosity for tibialis posterior tendon attachment.

Distal Group

 

Cuboid

Lateral; articulates with calcaneus and fourth/fifth metatarsals.

 

Features a groove for fibularis longus tendon.

Cuneiforms (3)

Medial, intermediate, lateral; wedge-shaped.

 

Help form the transverse arch; attach to various muscles.

Metatarsals

 

I-V (1-5)

Connect tarsals to phalanges; numbered medial to lateral.

 

Have a head, neck, shaft, and base; facilitate movement and support.

Phalanges

 

Great Toe: 2 (proximal, distal)

Toes 2-5: 3 each (proximal, intermediate, distal).

 

Each phalanx has a base, shaft, and head; provide structure to toes.

Incorrect Options:

Calcaneus (Option A): is the largest of the tarsal bones in the foot's heel. It bears the weight of the body as the heel touches the ground.

Cuboid (Option B): is the lateral bone of the foot lying in front of the calcaneus and behind the fourth and fifth metatarsal bones.

Talus (Option D): is the second largest tarsal bone, which lies above the calcaneus in the hindfoot.

questions.text: In the labeled structure, what kind of joint is present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Secondary cartilaginous joint

Explanation:

The pubic symphysis is a joint sandwiched between your left pelvic bone and right pelvic bone. It is a secondary cartilaginous joint. The secondary cartilaginous joints are permanent joints, which are slightly movable and their movements depend upon the sufficient amount of white-fibro cartilage tissues.

Primary Cartilaginous Joint (Option B)

Secondary Cartilaginous Joint

Sutures (Option A)

Syndesmoses

Gomphosis
  • Joint between epiphysis and diaphysis
  • Between basiocciput and basisphenoid
  • Symphysis menti
  • Symphysis pubis
  • Manubrio sternal
  • Joint between vertebral bodies, xiphisternal joint, midline intervertebral joint
  • Serrate: Sagittal
  • Denticulate: Lambdoid
  • Squamous:Temporoparietal
  • Plane: Between palatine process of maxillae
  • Schindylesis: Between rostrum of sphenoid and upper margin of vomer
  • Inferior tibiofibular joint
  • Tooth fit in the socket

Fibrous joints are classified into: (Option C)

  • Sutures,
  • Syndesmoses
  • Gomphosis

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient visits you with symptoms of finger swelling, heartburn, and occasional joint pain. During the examination, her hands appeared shiny, tight, and thickened with non-pitting oedema. Additionally, she has interstitial lung disease and tests positive for ANA antibodies, topoisomerase I antibodies, and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

Explanation:

Diffuse Scleroderma

  • Skin thickening over large body areas (fingers, hands, arms, anterior trunk, legs, and face).
  • Significant risk of organ damage (GI tract, kidneys, lungs, heart).
  • Associated with skin dryness, itching, and musculoskeletal pain.
  • Life-threatening when lungs or heart are severely involved.
  • Acute, severe high blood pressure can lead to kidney damage.

Dermal Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc)

  • Bilateral Symmetrical Skin Thickening: Begins distally in the fingers and progresses proximally.
  • Skin Pigmentation Changes:
    • Early diffuse tanning without sun exposure.
    • Hypopigmentation with a "salt-and-pepper" appearance on the scalp, upper back, and chest is common in dark-skinned individuals.
  • Sclerosis of Skin and Loss of Appendages:
    • Leads to hair loss, reduced sweating, xerosis, and itching.
    • Disappearance of transverse finger creases and fixed flexion contractures causing muscle atrophy.
  • Fixed Contractures: Affects wrists, elbows, and knees due to skin and tendon fibrosis.
  • Neck Skin Ridges: Firm adherence to platysma muscle limits neck extension.
  • Facial Changes ("Mauskopf"):
    • Taut, shiny skin with loss of wrinkles and reduced mobility.
    • Thinned lips, prominent perioral radial furrows, and microstomia.
    • Pinched, beak-like nose.
  • Telangiectasia: Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity.
  • Skin Ulcerations:
    • Chronic ulcers on fingertips, PIP joints, and bony prominences heal slowly and may become infected.
    • Fingertip ischemia leaves fixed digital "pits."
  • Acro-Osteolysis: Resorption of terminal phalanges due to ischemia.
  • Calcinosis Cutis:
    • Dystrophic calcifications in the skin and soft tissues, commonly in patients with anti-centromere antibody–positive lcSSc.
    • Calcific deposits vary in size and may ulcerate, causing pain, infections, or nerve compression.

Incorrect Options:

Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (Option A) is positive for anti-centromere antibody or ACA.

Raynaud’s phenomenon (Option C) is one of the characteristic presentations of diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Some body parts, like the fingers and nose, feel numb and cool in response to cold temperatures or stress.

Peutz-jeghers syndrome (Option D) is an inherited condition that increases the risk of hamartomatous polyps in the GIT and cancers in the GIT and that of the breast, testicles, and ovaries. Since there are no polyps, PJS is unlikely to be the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with chest pain, exertional dyspnea and syncope. He was diagnosed with a case of aortic stenosis and his chest x-ray was taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Post stenotic dilatation of aorta

Explanation:

  • Based on the given clinical presentation of chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and syncope, along with the diagnosis of aortic stenosis and chest x-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis in this case is post-stenotic dilatation of the aorta.

Aortic Stenosis

  • Symptom onset:
    • AS is clinically significant when the aortic valve orifice narrows to ~1 cm².
    • Severe AS can remain asymptomatic for years due to LV compensation.
  • Symptom progression: Often develops in the sixth to eighth decades; patients with bicuspid aortic valves may experience symptoms 10-20 years earlier.
  • Clinical Manifestations of Aortic Stenosis:
    • Triad: Exertional dyspnea, Angina pectoris, Syncope on exertion
    • Early symptoms: Fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance.
    • Advanced stages:
      • Orthopnea
      • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
      • Pulmonary edema.
    • Late Findings:
      • RV failure
      • Systemic venous hypertension
      • Hepatomegaly
      • Atrial fibrillation
      • Tricuspid regurgitation

Post-Stenotic Aortic Dilatation (PSAD)

Definition:

  • Post-stenotic aortic dilatation refers to the enlargement of the aortic vessel wall distal to a stenotic or malformed aortic valve. It typically involves the ascending aorta, with a diameter greater than 4.0 cm, and is characterized by a progressive increase in size of more than 0.3 cm per year.

Risk:

  • It is considered a precursor to serious conditions like aortic dissection and rupture, which can be fatal.

Aetiology:

  • PSAD can occur in patients with aortic stenosis (AS) or aortic regurgitation (AR), and even in those with a normal aortic valve (e.g., in the case of a bicuspid aortic valve, BAV), or after aortic valve replacement (AVR).
  • PSAD is not solely related to the severity of AS but may have a genetic basis, alongside mechanical stresses placed on the aortic wall.
  • The bicuspid aortic valve is an independent risk factor for both AS and progressive aortic dilatation.

Imaging findings:

  • Dilatation of the aorta immediately distal to the stenosis.
  • Normal or narrowed aortic segment proximal to stenosis.
  • Additional findings depend on aetiology.


Incorrect Options:

Aortic root dilatation (Option A) is typically asymptomatic and discovered incidentally, but in rare cases, it can lead to severe complications like aortic dissection, rupture, or congestive heart failure due to aortic insufficiency. This is not the given scenario.

Widening of the aortic knob (Option B) is seen in congenital heart diseases, aortic dissection, systemic hypertension, post-stenotic dilatation, etc. However, the location of the given lesion is not of the aortic knob.

Widening of the vascular pedicle (Option C): The vascular pedicle is measured between parallel lines drawn from the point at which the superior vena cava intersects the right main bronchus and a line drawn at the takeoff of the left subclavian artery from the aorta. This is not the given radiograph.

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is a defect in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fascia transversalis

Explanation:

  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This defect allows the passage of the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

Inguinal canal:

Structure

Description

Parietal peritoneum

Most posterior structure.

Transversalis fascia

Has a defect called the deep inguinal ring, through which the testes and spermatic cord pass. Site for indirect inguinal hernias. Anterior to parietal peritoneum. Forms the posterior in the whole extent.

Lateral umbilical fold

Formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

Median umbilical ligament

Remnant of the urachus (from the allantois).

Medial umbilical ligament

Remnant of the obliterated umbilical artery.

Pyramidalis muscle

Small muscle attaching to the pubic bone. Rectus abdominis lies above it. Covered by the rectus sheath and supplied by the subcostal nerve (T12).

Rectus abdominis muscle

Receives segmental innervation from T6–T12.

Transversus abdominis muscle

Does not form the anterior wall of the inguinal canal. Contributes to the roof and posterior wall. Combines with internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon.

Internal oblique muscle (Option B)

Forms parts of the anterior, roof, and posterior walls of the inguinal canal. Contributes to cremasteric muscle and fascia.

External oblique muscle (Option A)

Aponeurosis forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal and the superficial inguinal ring. Forms external spermatic fascia.

Internal spermatic fascia

Derived from the transversalis fascia.

Rectus sheath (Option D): The rectus sheath encloses the rectus abdominis muscle and is not involved in the formation of the deep inguinal ring. This is incorrect.

questions.text: Based on the clinical image below, what is the most probable nerve to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Long thoracic nerve

Explanation:

  • Injury to the long thoracic nerve results in weakness of the serratus anterior and winging of the scapula, as seen in the image.
  • The long thoracic nerve, from the upper part of the brachial plexus's superior trunk, usually receives contributions from cervical nerves C5, C6, and C7.
  • It innervates the serratus anterior muscle, weakness of which often causes scapular winging due to inadequate protraction countered by rhomboid and trapezius actions, leading to medial scapular winging.

Long thoracic nerve

Origin

C5 - C7

Insertion

Serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for scapular protraction and upward rotation.

Nerve actions

(Motor function)
  • Protracts the scapula (pulls it forward around the thorax).
  • Assists in arm anteversion (moving the arm forward).
  • Lifts the ribs, aiding in respiration.
  • Responsible for the anterolateral motion of the scapula, which is necessary for arm elevation.

Incorrect Options:

Thoracodorsal nerve (Option A): mainly from C7 with contributions from C6 to C8, innervates the Latissimus dorsi muscle. It's often utilized as a nerve graft in surgeries.

Axillary nerve (Option B): arising from the brachial plexus's posterior cord, controls the teres minor, deltoid muscles, shoulder skin, and glenohumeral joint, often injured in orthopedic surgeries, shoulder dislocations, and rotator cuff tears.

Intercostal nerve (Option C): from T1 to T11 spinal nerves, provides sensory innervation to the chest wall and abdomen skin and motor innervation to intercostal and abdominalmuscles.

questions.text: The device seen in the following image is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cardiac pacemaker

Explanation:

  • The device shown in the x-ray is a cardiac pacemaker.

Cardiac Conduction Devices (CCDs)

  • Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (ICD):
    • Function: Delivers electrical shocks to treat dysrhythmias and restore normal sinus rhythm.
    • Types:
      • Transvenous ICDs (T-ICD): Leads placed at the junction of the brachiocephalic vein/superior vena cava and right ventricle (RV). Can be combined with biventricular pacemakers for Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT).
      • Subcutaneous ICDs (S-ICD): No transvenous lead insertion. The pulse generator is placed subcutaneously, and the shock is delivered via a left parasternal subcutaneous lead.
  • Components of CCDs:
    • Pulse Generator: Provides the electrical signals.
    • Electrode: Sends electrical impulses to the heart.
    • Lead Wires: Connect the electrode to the pulse generator, with different tips for attachment to the heart.
      • Active Fixation: Leads with helical tips screw into the myocardium.
      • Passive Fixation: Leads anchor onto heart trabeculae through fibrosis.
  • Chest Radiography for CCD Evaluation:
    • Preferred imaging modality for assessing CCD location, lead integrity, and complications.
    • Two Views Required:
      • Posterior-Anterior (PA) View: Provides a 2D view for lead integrity.
      • Lateral (LAT) View: Essential for evaluating lead tip location and distinguishing between leads in the right or left ventricle.
  • Purpose of Imaging:
    • To ensure correct positioning of leads, diagnose complications, and confirm device functionality for maximal therapeutic benefit.

Chemoport device (Option B) Implantable ports, commonly referred to as chemoports, totally implantable central venous access ports, or Port-A-Caths, are a type of central venous catheter designed for patients needing extended venous access. These devices provide a long-term solution for central venous access, offering a distinct advantage over peripherally inserted central catheters (PICC).
 



Options C and D are incorrect.

Correct Answer A- Falciform ligament

Explanation:
