Falciform ligament (Option A): The falciform ligament arises from the ventral mesogastrium during embryonic development.

Lesser omentum (Option C): The lesser omentum does not develop from the dorsal mesogastrium but rather from the ventral mesogastrium.

Liver (Option D): The liver does not develop directly from the dorsal mesogastrium. It forms in association with the ventral mesogastrium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to the hospital complaining of palpitations. During the examination, a diastolic murmur is detected in the left third intercostal space, along with the presence of a pistol shot sound over the femoral arteries. What is the diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aortic regurgitation

Explanation:

  • The diastolic murmur and the pistol shot sound over the femoral artery along with palpitations signify the diagnosis of aortic regurgitation.

Signs of Aortic Regurgitation

Muller Sign

It is a visible systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach sign

Systolic pulsations of the Liver

Gerhardt's sign

Systolic pulsations of the Spleen

Quincke's sign

Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations)

Landolphi sign

Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils

Traube Sign

It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery.

Water-Hammer pulse

Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.

Duroziez Sign

It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery.

De-Musset sign

The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat

 

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

  

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

Murmurs
  • A decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.

Incorrect Options:

Aortic stenosis (Option B) presents with a midsystolic ejection murmur at the upper sternal border.

Tricuspid regurgitation (Option C) presents with a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border.

Mitral regurgitation (Option D) presents with a systolic murmur at the apex of the heart with radiation to the left axilla.

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has a slight limitation in physical activity and doing ordinary activity causes symptoms but he is asymptomatic at rest. To which class does he belong, based on the New York Heart Association functional classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Class II

Explanation:

  • The given scenario belongs to Class II in the New York Heart Association classification for heart failure.

New York Heart Association (NYHA) Classification

Class

Symptoms

I (Option A)
  • No limitation of physical activity.
  • No symptoms with ordinary exertion (e.g. shortness of breath when walking, climbing stairs etc).

II
  • Slight limitation of physical activity.
  • Ordinary activity causes symptoms.

III (Option C)
  • Marked limitation of physical activity.
  • Less than ordinary activity causes symptoms.
  • Asymptomatic at rest.

IV (Option D)
  • Inability to carry out any physical activity without discomfort.
  • Symptoms at rest.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here?

choices.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • Chronic vomiting leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

Development of metabolic Alkalosis due to vomiting

  • Occurs due to a net gain of bicarbonate (HCO3−) or loss of nonvolatile acid (usually HCl) from the extracellular fluid, commonly caused by vomiting.

Generation Stage:

  • Vomiting leads to the loss of HCl from the stomach, preventing HCO3− secretion in the small intestine.
  • As a result, HCO3− gets retained in the extracellular fluid, leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis.

Maintenance Stage:

  • After vomiting ceases, the kidneys fail to appropriately excrete the excess HCO3−, maintaining the alkalosis.
  • This failure is influenced by factors such as volume deficiency, chloride deficiency, and potassium deficiency, combined with a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Saline-Responsive Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • In cases of volume, chloride, and potassium deficiency, the alkalosis can be corrected by restoring extracellular fluid volume through intravenous administration of NaCl and KCl.

Saline-Unresponsive Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • In cases of hypokalemia due to hyperaldosteronism, the alkalosis may require pharmacologic or surgical treatment, rather than saline correction.

Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an increase in arterial pH, elevated serum bicarbonate [HCO3−], and increased PaCO2​ due to compensatory hypoventilation.
  • Often presents with hypochloremia and hypokalemia.
  • Occurs as a mixed disorder with respiratory or metabolic acidosis or alkalosis.

Clinical Features

  • Neurological: Mental confusion, obtundation, potential seizures
  • Peripheral Nervous System: Paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (similar to hypocalcemia effects)
  • Cardiovascular: Aggravation of arrhythmias, particularly in COPD patients

Electrolyte Imbalances

  • Potassium (K⁺): Hypokalemia, especially in cases involving secondary hyperaldosteronism or diuretic use.
  • Chloride (Cl⁻): Hypochloremia, frequently accompanying alkalosis, especially in cases of vomiting or diuretic use.
  • Calcium (Ca²⁺): Symptoms may mimic hypocalcemia despite normal levels.


Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain, easy fatigability and a history of multiple urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. His ESR is elevated, and an x-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following investigations is useful for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serum electrophoresis

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of chronic back pain, easy fatigability, and the x-ray skull features depict multiple myeloma

Investigations of Multiple myeloma

  • Hematological Analysis:
    • It may reveal anaemia; ESR is usually elevated.
    • Rare cases of plasma cell leukaemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/μL.
    • Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated.
    • Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal.
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • A/G ratio: Decreased
    • Increased level of β2 microglobulin.
    • Decreased albumin
  • Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
    • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
    • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease
  • Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike
    • M spikes are monoclonal immunoglobulins
      • The presence of the M spike is a hallmark of monoclonal gammopathies.
      • Serum Protein Electrophoresis (SPEP): (Option D)
        • Preliminary test for multiple myeloma detection
        • Used for detection and quantification of monoclonal gammopathy.
        • Separates serum proteins into five main bands: Albumin, α1 globulins, α2 globulins, β globulins and γ globulins.
        • The gamma region, rich in immunoglobulins, is key in SPEP interpretation for detecting monoclonal gammopathies, which produce a sharp, church-spire-like peak.
      • MRI (Option A): To evaluate the extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
      • PET/CT (Option B & C): Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease

 

  • Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased
  • Serum light chain assay: Increased
  • Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain
  • 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion
  • Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits
  • Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells)
  • FISH:
    • Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10%

Clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma is based on the following:

  • Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow
  • Presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anaemia and bone lesions)

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman who had a heart attack 2 years ago is currently experiencing a cough and difficulty breathing while walking short distances. Physical examination revealed dullness upon percussion and reduced breath sounds on the right side. A chest x-ray indicated the presence of moderate pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis, guided by ultrasound, was performed and the laboratory results are provided below.

Pleural fluid findings:


	Appearance: turbid
	pH: 7.1
	Protein: 3.2 g/dL
	Lactate dehydrogenase: 80 U/L (normal serum LDH- 50-150 U/L)
	Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio: 0.34
	Pleural fluid LDH /serum LDH: 0.3
	Glucose: 54 mg/dL
	WBC count: 4000 cells/µL with >50% lymphocytes
	Adenosine deaminase: 30 U/L
	AFB smear microscopy: Negative
	Gram staining and microscopy: No organisms, no pus cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Congestive heart failure

Explanation:

  • The above case with the given clinical findings is suggestive of the diagnosis of congestive heart failure. The effusion is transudative in nature here according to Light’s criteria.

Congestive Heart Failure: Clinical features

  • Cardiac output decreased
  • Stroke volume decreased
  • Heart rate increased
  • Increased sympathetic drive leading to palpitations and diaphoresis
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Dyspnea
  • Exertional dyspnea).
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop
  • Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal oedema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

 

 

Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Parapneumonic pleural effusion (Option A) has increased in WBCs, especially neutrophils and the appearance is cloudy.

Malignant pleural effusion (Option B) and tubercular pleural effusion (Option D) are exudative in nature

questions.text: Which is the best confirmatory method to ensure the central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chest X-ray

Explanation:

Importance of Chest X-ray in Central Line Placement

  • Initial Assessment:
    • A chest X-ray should be performed immediately after internal jugular and subclavian line placement to confirm correct catheter placement and rule out iatrogenic pneumothorax.
       
  • Post-Procedure Verification:
    • It is crucial to verify catheter placement and ensure no complications, like pneumothorax, following the procedure.
       
  • Ipsilateral Side Approach:
    • If the internal jugular central venous line (CVL) insertion fails, move to the ipsilateral subclavian vein.
    • A chest X-ray or ultrasound should be performed before attempting the opposite side to prevent bilateral pneumothoraces.


Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 45-year-old man who experiences chest pain and difficulty breathing that worsens when lying down but improves when sitting upright, and has muffled heart sounds during examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pericardial effusion

Explanation:

  • The above presentation of breathlessness on lying down and it being relieved on sitting, and the X-ray given which shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette is suggestive of a probable diagnosis of pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion:

  • Pericardial effusion can lead to cardiac tamponade if rapid.
  • Faint heart sounds and a large cardiac silhouette on X-ray.

Chest X-ray showing waterbottle configuration in Pericardial effusion

  • Electrical alternans is a classic ECG finding in pericardial effusion, particularly when it leads to cardiac tamponade.
  • It manifests as beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, reflecting the heart's movement within the fluid-filled pericardial space.
  • This finding is indicative of significant fluid accumulation and increased intrapericardial pressure, which impedes the heart's ability to fill properly during diastole.

ECG showing Electrical alternans

White arrows showing variations in the amplitude of QRS complexes

Incorrect Options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B) shows a boot-shaped heart on an x-ray.

Transposition of great arteries (Option C) shows an egg-on-string appearance on x-ray.

Pulmonary hypertension (Option D) shows a pruned tree appearance of the pulmonary vasculature.

questions.text: Identify the tachycardia depicted in the given ECG.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrial flutter

Explanation:

  • The above ECG is that of atrial flutter since it shows narrow QRS complexes and sawtooth-shaped waves.
     

Atrial Flutter

Features
  • Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute.
  • It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute.

ECG Features
  • The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves, often referred to as "F-waves."
  • With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify.

Diagnosis
  • Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute.
  • Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block.

Management

1. Rhythm Control:

  • Acute Management:
    • Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion.
    • Stable Patients:
      • Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus).
      • Pharmacological cardioversion:
        • Antiarrhythmic drugs:
          • Amiodarone
          • Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide
          • Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone
        • Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem
        • Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol
  • Long-Term Management:
    • Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus.

2. Rate Control:

  • First-Line Agents:
    • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem)
    • Beta-blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol)
    • Digoxin (use cautiously due to toxicity).
  • Goal: Heart rate < 110 beats per minute.

3. Anticoagulation:

  • Assess stroke risk using the CHADS2-VASC score:
  • Anticoagulation Recommendations:
    • 2 or more points: Strong recommendation for anticoagulation.
    • 1 point: Consider either aspirin or full anticoagulation.


Incorrect Options:

In atrial fibrillation (Option A), the QRS complexes are irregularly irregular, is RR intervals vary.

Ventricular tachycardia (Option C) has broad QRS complexes

Ventricular Fibrillation (Option D) has no identifiable P wave or QRS complexes.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an adult patient with a pulsatile swelling in the neck below the jaw angle that causes an outward expansile impulse, based on the findings of an MRI angiography?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carotid body tumour

Explanation:

  • In the above scenario, there is a pulsatile swelling, and on MRI angiography, it shows Lyre's sign which is the splaying of internal and external arteries, which is diagnostic of carotid body tumour.

 

Carotid Body Tumor (CBT)

  • CBT, also known as paraganglioma or chemodectoma, is a rare benign neck tumour originating from the neural crest at the adventitia of the common carotid artery bifurcation.
  • CBTs grow slowly, have a low cancer rate, and are not significantly associated with age or gender, though some suggest a slightly higher incidence in women.
  • The pathogenesis is unclear but is linked to chronic hypoxia and mutations in mitochondrial oxygen-sensitive genes.

Diagnosis:

  • B-mode Ultrasonography:
    • It shows solid, hypoechoic tumours near blood vessels.
       
  • Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA):
    • DSA visualized tumour blood supply and the displacement of arteries, with a diagnostic coincidence rate of 100%.
       
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):
    • MRI showed tumours at the bifurcation of the carotid artery with compression and displacement of arteries.
    • Tumours appeared as round or round-like masses, showing heterogeneous or high signals on T2-WI.
       
  • The Lyre sign refers to the splaying of the internal and external carotid by a carotid body tumour.
  • It is classically described in angiography it is also visible in CT angiography.

Treatment:

  • Surgical Resection: The most effective treatment for CBTs.
  • Other Modalities: Radiotherapy, embolization, and combination therapy can also be considered.

Incorrect Options:

Grave’s disease (Option A) is a hyperthyroid condition with bulging eyes, and the neck swelling is not pulsatile.

Branchial cysts (Option B) are small fluid-filled sacs that look like lumps under the skin on the side of the neck and are more common in children than adults.

A thymic cyst (Option C) is a benign mediastinal disease and presents with dyspnea, chest pain, cough, hoarseness and dysphagia.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ventricular tachycardia

Explanation:

  • The given ECG shows ventricular tachycardia with wide, regular QRS complexes and a rate typically over 100 bpm.

 

Ventricular tachycardia

Pathology:

  • VT is defined as three or more consecutive premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) with a heart rate of over 100 bpm. It can be either monomorphic (all QRS complexes appear similar) or polymorphic (QRS complexes vary in shape).
  • Monomorphic VT is often related to a reentry circuit around a myocardial scar, typically after myocardial infarction, while polymorphic VT, especially Torsades de Pointes, is related to prolonged QT intervals, ischemia, or electrolyte imbalances.

ECG Findings:

  • Monomorphic VT: Wide QRS complexes (>120 ms), regular rhythm, and consistent morphology across leads. The QRS axis may vary depending on the site of origin (e.g., LBBB or RBBB-like morphology).
  • Polymorphic VT: Continuously changing QRS morphology, often associated with prolonged QT intervals (in Torsades de Pointes).

Treatment:

  • Stable Monomorphic VT: Intravenous procainamide or amiodarone can be used.
  • Unstable Monomorphic VT: Immediate synchronized cardioversion is required.
  • Polymorphic VT (Torsades de Pointes): IV magnesium sulfate and correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia) are crucial, along with discontinuation of QT-prolonging drugs.

Incorrect Options:

The above is not a normal ECG (Option A) as it has tachycardia, absent P wave, and vast QRS complexes.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option B) usually has no identifiable QRS complex hence the given ECG does not show ventricular fibrillation.

Misplaced leads (Option D) do not produce the given ECG.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the following X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hydropneumothorax

Explanation:

  • The chest x-ray shows air-fluid levels with clear demarcation signifying hydropneumothorax.

Hydropneumothorax

  • Hydropneumothorax is characterized by the presence of both air and fluid within the pleural space, usually due to trauma, rupture of a lung abscess, or after thoracic interventions.
  • Hydropneumothorax shows an air-fluid level on upright imaging, with a clear demarcation between air and fluid in the pleural cavity.

Pleural effusion (Option B) has the following features in the x-ray as given below:

Pericardial effusion (Option C) shows a large cardiac silhouette in the chest X-ray.

Pneumothorax (Option D) has a readily apparent visceral pleural line seen without distal lung markings. The following image shows a right sided pneumothorax.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed delayed symptom of radiation therapy for the head and neck?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Xerostomia

Explanation:

  • The most common late symptom of radiation therapy for head and neck cancers is xerostomia (dry mouth).

Late symptoms of radiation therapy for head and neck tumours

Side effects

Symptoms

Management

Permanent dry mouth (xerostomia)

Dry mouth, difficulty in eating, swallowing, and speaking

Maintain adequate oral hygiene, salivary substitutes’ saliva stimulation, low-level laser treatment of the salivary gland, chlorhexidine, antifungal therapy, adequate hydration, acupuncture

Burning mouth syndrome

Burning or scalded of mouth; dryness, increased thirst; loss of taste

Oral rinses, lidocaine, saliva substitutes, capsaicin, clonazepam or Klonopin, antidepressants, pain medications, low-level laser therapy, cognitive behavioural therapy

Dental caries

Dental caries

Oral hygiene, management of xerostomia, topical fluorides and/or remineralizing agents

Osteoradionecrosis

Pain, bad breath, dysgeusia, numbness, trismus, mastication and speech difficulties

Debridement, antibiotic treatment and prophylaxis, hyperbaric oxygen

Fibrosis

Woody texture and limited neck enhance lymphedema

Physiotherapy, myofascial release, external laser

Physiotherapy, myofascial release, external laser

Mastication muscles fibrosis

Oral appliances, diet modification, pharyngeal strengthening, swallow retraining

The dropped head syndrome

Severe kyphotic deformity of the cervicothoracic spine

Supportive care, external orthotic devices

Pharyngoesophageal stenosis

Dysphagia (Option A)

Dilation, surgery and stents

Skin changes and skin cancer

Acute inflammatory reaction in an area previously exposed to radiation after a chemotherapeutic agent or other medication

Removal of skin cancer, maintaining proper skin hygiene, hydrophilic or lipophilic barrier creams with or without hydrogel or hydrocolloid dressings

Lymphedema

Neck and facial swelling, heaviness, achiness

Manual lymph drainage, compression bandages and garments, lymphatic pump

Hypothyroidism

Slowing of metabolic processes symptoms

Thyroxine replacement

Hyperparathyroidism

Excessive urination, abdominal pain, tiring weakness, depression. bone and joint pain, nausea, vomiting and loss of appetite

Calcimimetics, hormone replacement therapy, bisphosphonates

Surgical removal of the parathyroid adenoma(s) is curative in most patients

Brachial plexopathy

Paresthesia, dysesthesia, decreased sensitivity, movement loss, muscular atrophy, shoulder joint dislocation

Physical and occupational therapies

Eye damage

Cataract, retinopathy

Monoclonal antibody, triamcinolone, laser, photodynamic therapy, hyperbaric oxygen, pentoxifylline


Myelopathy (Option C) refers to a condition affecting the spinal cord and is not a common delayed symptom of head and neck radiation therapy.

Dysgeusia (Option D) refers to a distorted or altered sense of taste. While taste changes can occur after head and neck radiation therapy, xerostomia is more commonly observed as a delayed symptom.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause of the leg lesion shown in the image below, as presented by a young man? The lesions exhibit pain, well-defined raised edges, and the patient also reports blisters on his body. Furthermore, the patient is in good health with no co-existing medical conditions.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Group A streptococcus

Explanation:

From the presentation—a painful, sharply demarcated, raised-edged leg lesion (likely erysipelas) with blister formation in an otherwise healthy young individual—the most common causative organism is Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes).

Erysipelas:

  • Erysipelas is a skin infection that usually affects the upper half of the dermis but may also extend to the superficial cutaneous lymphatics.
  • It occurs due to the entry of bacteria through a breach in the skin barrier.
  • Erysipelas is most commonly caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci.
     

Clinical features: It manifests as an area of erythema that is well-demarcated and raised around the edges. Acute onset constitutional symptoms like fever, chills and malaise are also present

Milian's ear sign:

  • Involvement of ear is characteristic of erysipelas as the ear does not have a deeper dermis layer
  • Milian's ear sign is a distinguishing feature of erysipelas.

Treatment:

  • First line: Flucloxacillin/ Clarithromycin
  • Second line: Roxithromycin
  • Prophylaxis for recurrent infections: Long-term penicillin/ erythromycin

Group B streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) (Option A):

  • More commonly causes neonatal sepsis, maternal infections, and certain infections in the elderly or immunocompromised.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C):

  • Often causes more localized abscesses, folliculitis, or cellulitis with less well-demarcated borders.

Haemophilus influenza type b (Option D):

  • Typically does not present this way; it is more associated with respiratory tract infections, meningitis (especially in unvaccinated populations), or epiglottitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female comes with complaints of pain in her fingernail. On examination, nail folds were seen to be red and with erythema as shown in the picture. The most likely diagnosis is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paronychia

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis for the described symptoms of a 40-year-old female with pain in her fingernail, along with redness and erythema of the nail folds, is paronychia.

Paronychia:

  • is an infection or inflammation of the skin around the nail, specifically the nail folds.
  • It can occur acutely or chronically.
    • Acute paronychia is typically caused by bacterial infection, often by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
    • Chronic paronychia is often associated with fungal infections, particularly Candida species.
  • Symptoms:
    • redness, swelling, tenderness, and pain around the nail.
    • The affected area may also appear warm and may develop pus-filled abscesses.
  • Commonly seen in:
    • Individuals who frequently immerse their hands in water
    • Who engage in activities that cause minor trauma to the skin around the nails, such as nail biting, picking, or manicuring.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination of the affected area and evaluate the patient's symptoms.
    • a sample of the pus or discharge may be sent for laboratory analysis to determine the causative organism.
  • Treatment:
    • Warm water soaks, topical antibiotic ointments or creams, and, if necessary, oral antibiotics.
    • In cases of chronic paronychia associated with fungal infection, antifungal medications.
    • In some instances, incision and drainage of abscesses may be required.

Incorrect Options:

Yellow-nail syndrome (Option B): is a condition characterized by yellowish discoloration, thickening, and slow growth of the nails. It is usually associated with underlying respiratory or lymphatic disorders and is not consistent with the described symptoms.

Psoriasis (Option C): is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that can affect the nails, causing pitting, discoloration, separation of the nail from the nail bed (onycholysis), and thickening of the nails.

Alopecia areata (Option D): is an autoimmune condition characterized by hair loss, typically in patches. It does not involve the nails and is not related to the described symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with the given rash after he had taken NSAIDs for his knee pain. He reported that he developed the same rash in the same location 6 months ago when he took the same drugs for back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fixed drug eruption

Explanation:

  • The recurrent nature of the rash in the same location after taking NSAIDs strongly supports Fixed Drug Eruption (FDE).

Fixed drug eruption:

  • Fixed drug eruption is a distinctive cutaneous allergic reaction that characteristically recurs at the same sites with the same morphology on re-exposure to the medication or other chemical agent.
  • Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction (Option B ruled out)
  • Causative drugs: Co-trimoxazole, NSAIDs, tetracyclines, sulfonamides.
  • Mediated by memory T-cells.
  • Acutely, erythematous and bullous phases of fixed eruptions, followed by well-circumscribed areas of slate-brown pigmentation
  • Site of lesions: Mucous membrane (Lips, tongues, Glans penis), face and acral areas although can occur anywhere on the skin surface.
  • Leaves residual hyperpigmentation on healing (Option A ruled out).
  • Upon reexposure, lesions develop within 30 minutes to 8 hours (Option C ruled out).
  • Treatment:
    • Stop the causative drug.
    • Topical steroids and antibiotics combinations

Incorrect Options

Drug hypersensitivity (Option A): While this is a broad term for adverse drug reactions, it doesn't specify the unique characteristic of recurrence at the same site.

Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) (Option B): PIH is a result of inflammation or injury to the skin, but it wouldn't consistently reappear in the same location with each exposure to the same drug.

Drug-induced hypermelanosis (Option D): This is a general term for increased melanin production due to drugs, but it doesn't fit the specific pattern of a solitary lesion recurring at the same site with each drug exposure.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the distinctive finding shown in the image below, which is pathognomonic for Psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subungual oil drop sign

Explanation:

  • This sign refers to small, yellowish-orange discolourations seen beneath the nail plate, resembling drops of oil, and is highly specific for nail psoriasis.
  • It is the most specific sign of psoriasis with a specificity of ~98%
  • It occurs due to nail bed parakeratosis and psoriasiform hyperplasia
  • It occurs just before onycholysis

Important findings in nail psoriasis are (Mnemonic: POLISH)

  • Pits
  • Onycholysis
  • Leukonychia
  • Salmon patch (Subungual oil drop sign)
  • Subungual Hyperkeratosis

Incorrect Options:

Nail Pitting (Option A):

  • Although nail pitting is common in psoriasis, it is not pathognomonic, as it can also be seen in alopecia areata and eczema.

Thinning of Nails (Option C):

  • Nail thinning is more commonly associated with lichen planus or trauma-related nail dystrophy, rather than psoriasis.

Pterygium (Option D):

  • Pterygium (dorsal or ventral) occurs due to scarring of the nail matrix, commonly seen in lichen planus, not psoriasis.

questions.text: What is the name of the clinical sign shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dermographism

Explanation:

  • Dermographism (also called dermatographia or skin writing) is a condition where firm stroking of the skin induces an urticarial wheal within minutes.

Type of Physical Urticaria

Eliciting Factors

Urticaria factitial / Dermographism

  • Most common type, red, itchy, linear wheal appearing immediately after light stroking of the skin.

Mechanical shearing forces (wheals arising within 1-5 mins)

Cold contact urticaria

Cold objects, air, fluids, wind

Heat contact urticaria

Localized heat

Solar urticaria

UV and/or visible light

Delayed pressure urticaria (poor prognosis)

Vertical pressure (wheals arise with 3-12 hours latency)

Aquagenic urticaria

Water

Cholinergic urticaria

Increase in core body temperature by exercise or spicy food

Nikolsky Sign (Option B):

  • Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS).
  • It refers to the sloughing of epidermis upon slight rubbing of the skin.

Koebner’s Phenomenon (Option C):

  • This describes the development of new skin lesions at sites of trauma in diseases like psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.
  • Unlike dermographism, it is not immediate and takes days to develop.

Option D: Auspitz Sign (Option D):

  • Seen in psoriasis, where removal of scales leads to pinpoint bleeding due to exposure of dermal papillary capillaries.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with palpitation and weight loss. On examination of her legs the following lesion was found which on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. ECG shows sinus rhythm. What is the probable cause of the oedema?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myxedema

Explanation:

  • The patient has palpitations and weight loss, suggestive of hypermetabolic or hyperthyroid state.

  • The leg lesion described is a form of edema where indenting the swollen area does not leave a persistent indentation on release—this is non-pitting edema.

  • ECG shows sinus rhythm (normal heart rhythm), so no arrhythmia implying heart failure currently.

  • Myxedema causes non-pitting edema due to mucopolysaccharide (glycosaminoglycan) deposition in the skin and tissues, commonly seen in severe hypothyroidism. The edema does not pit on pressure.

Nephrotic syndrome (Option B): Causes pitting edema due to low albumin and fluid retention.

Chronic lymphangitis (Option C): Usually causes non-pitting edema along with skin changes but is an inflammatory condition often with signs of infection.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option D): Usually causes pitting edema due to heart failure and fluid overload.

questions.text: HV interval in the below given His bundle electrogram is for conduction:

choices.text: From AV node to bundle of His
From a bundle of His and bundle branches to ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) From the bundle of His and bundle branches to ventricles

Explanation:

  • The HV interval represents the time it takes for electrical conduction to occur from the His bundle and bundle branches to the ventricles of the heart.

A typical His bundle electrogram includes the following components:

  • A: Atrial deflection
  • H: His deflection
  • QRS: Ventricular depolarization

The intervals measured are as follows:

  • P-H: The interval from the start of the P wave (either from a standard lead ECG or high atrial lead) to the initial rapid deflection of the His bundle spike. (Option B)
  • A-H: The interval from the onset of the atrial deflection on the His bundle electrogram (low RA) to the His bundle deflection. (Option A)
  • H-V: The interval from the first rapid deflection of the His bundle to the onset of ventricular depolarization, measured either from the His bundle electrogram or standard leads.

Option C is incorrect.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of chest pain which is seen only on exertion or exercise and lasts 2-5 minutes. He was assessed and was diagnosed with a case of stable angina however his BP was consistently elevated. What is the most appropriate antihypertensive for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Amlodipine

Explanation:

The most appropriate antihypertensive for a patient with stable angina and consistently elevated blood pressure would be Amlodipine.

  • It is particularly beneficial in patients with stable angina, as it can improve coronary blood flow by reducing vasospasm and decreasing myocardial oxygen demand.
  • Additionally, amlodipine has a favourable effect on blood pressure control, which makes it suitable for patients with both stable angina and hypertension.

Medical management of stable angina

Medication Class

Function/Mechanism

Indications

Nitrates

Sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 or 0.6 mg)

Long-acting forms (oral, transdermal)
  • Systemic venodilation
  • Reduces LV end-diastolic volume and pressure
  • Releases nitric oxide (NO) to relax vascular smooth muscle
  • Angina relief
  • Preemptive use before activities
  • Improves exercise tolerance

Beta-Blocker (Option A)
  • Reduces heart rate, arterial pressure, and myocardial contractility
  • Improves survival post-MI
  • Angina relief
  • Reduces mortality and reinfarction rates

Calcium Channel Blockers
  • Coronary vasodilators
  • Reduces myocardial oxygen demand and arterial pressure
  • Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) and non-dihydropyridines (e.g., verapamil)
  • Angina treatment when beta-blockers are ineffective
  • Variant angina

Antiplatelet Drugs
  • Aspirin: inhibits platelet activation
  • Clopidogrel 75mg: blocks platelet aggregation
  • Reduces coronary events in high-risk populations
  • Stent placement


Thiazide (Option B) diuretics are a class of medications used to treat hypertension. They help reduce blood pressure by promoting diuresis and decreasing fluid volume. However, they may not be the most appropriate choice in this case since the patient already has stable angina, and thiazides are not specifically indicated for the treatment of angina.

Enalapril (Option C) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that is commonly used in the management of hypertension and are effective antihypertensive agent, they may not be the initial choice in this case, considering the patient's primary symptom of stable angina

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the OPD with fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain, and productive cough with red currant jelly sputum for the last two days. On examination, there was bronchial breathing on the right side, increased vocal fremitus, increased vocal resonance, and a dull note on percussion. The patient’s plain radiograph is shown below. Which is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Klebsiella pneumoniae

Explanation:

The given scenario of alcoholism along with the clinical symptoms suggests pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

  • In individuals with alcohol use disorder, the most frequently identified organisms responsible for lung abscesses are Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Actinomyces.

Specific aetiology of pneumonia:

  • Alcoholic patient with Pneumonia: Pneumococcus pneumonia.
  • Alcoholic with Red currant jelly sputum: Klebsiella pneumonia/Friedlander pneumonia.
  • COPD & smokers end up with Hemophilus influenzae. (Option D)
  • Structural lung disease Eg. Cystic fibrosis where mucus plugs thickened present - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C) /Burkholderia cepacia
  • Contact with Birds: Chlamydia psittaci
  • Contact with Bats: Histoplasmosis
  • Contact with Rabbits: Francisella tularensis (Tularemia)
  • Contact with Goat/sheep: Coxiella burnetii can cause Q fever.
  • Hotel/cruise: Legionella pneumophila

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A) is a common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia, but it typically presents with a more acute onset and is associated with rust-coloured sputum. It is less commonly associated with the clinical findings described in this case.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman complains of dryness in her mouth and eyes and has positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The image below shows a positive test result with a score of less than 5 mm in 5 minutes without anaesthesia.



What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sjogren Syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of dry eyes and mouth with a Schirmer’s test ≤5 mm/5 min and positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies suggest the diagnosis of Sjogren syndrome.

Sjogren syndrome

Pathogenesis:

  • Sjogren Syndrome is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting the exocrine glands.
  • The pathogenesis involves lymphocytic infiltration (mainly T and B cells) into exocrine glands, especially the salivary and lacrimal glands.
  • A complex interaction of genetic predisposition, environmental factors, and abnormal immune response triggers this infiltration.
  • B-cell hyperactivity: Characterized by hypergammaglobulinemia and autoantibody production (e.g., anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB).
  • Epithelial cell role: Exocrine gland epithelial cells may express autoantigens (Ro, La), produce pro-inflammatory cytokines, and express Toll-like receptors, facilitating immune activation​.
  • Genetic predisposition: Certain HLA alleles (e.g., HLA-DQA1*0501) and immune-regulatory genes (IRF5, STAT4) increase susceptibility.

Clinical Features:


The hallmark symptoms are xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). Other symptoms include:

  • Oral symptoms: Dry mouth, difficulty swallowing, increased dental caries, and parotid gland enlargement.
  • Ocular symptoms: Gritty sensation, burning, decreased tear production.
  • Systemic involvement: Fatigue, joint pain, Raynaud’s phenomenon, and increased risk of lymphoma, particularly marginal zone B-cell lymphoma​.

Diagnosis of Sjogren Syndrome: Diagnosis involves clinical features supported by specific tests.

Tests:

Any of the following is present:

  • Unstimulated whole saliva flow rate ≤0.1 mL/min
  • Schirmer’s test ≤5 mm/5 min on at least one eye
  • Ocular staining score ≥5 (or van Bijsterveld’s score ≥4) on at least one eye

And, any of the following:

  • Serum antibodies - Anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB
  • Minor salivary gland biopsy (A labial biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration with a focus score ≥1).

Treatment:
Treatment is largely symptomatic and involves:

  • Ocular symptoms: Artificial tears and, if needed, topical cyclosporine for inflammation.
  • Xerostomia: Regular sips of water and pilocarpine or cevimeline to stimulate saliva.
  • Systemic disease: Hydroxychloroquine for mild symptoms and in severe cases, immunosuppressants like rituximab​.

Scleroderma (Option A) antibodies are anti-Scl-70 and anti-centromere. Hence this is not the diagnosis here.

Dehydration & Lacrimal duct stones (Option B & C): Dehydration & Lacrimal duct stones are unlikely since this patient tested positive for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies which are characteristic of Sjogren syndrome.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with no comorbidities presented with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers of both hands along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no other illnesses and she says these episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold climates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primary Raynaud’s phenomenon

Explanation:

This patient has Primary Raynaud's phenomenon because:

  • Young female (age 20-40 years, female: male ratio 5:1)
  • No underlying condition
  • Symmetric involvement
  • Cold trigger

Raynaud's Phenomenon

Primary Raynaud's:

  • Young female (age 20-40 years, female: male ratio 5:1)
  • No underlying disease
  • Normal nail fold capillaries showing regular hairpin loops
  • Accounts for >50% of cases
  • Better prognosis
  • Improves in 15%, progresses in 30%
  • Classic triphasic colour changes

Secondary Raynaud's: (Option B)

Common causes include:

  • Connective tissue diseases (especially scleroderma: 80-90%) (Option D)
  • Arterial occlusive diseases
  • Blood dyscrasias
  • Drugs (ergot, beta-blockers, bleomycin)
  • Occupational (vibrating tools)

Clinical Features:

  • Sequential colour changes: White (Ischemia) → Blue (Deoxygenation) → Red (Reperfusion)
  • Triggered by cold exposure or emotional stress
  • It may affect fingers, toes, nose, ears
  • It can be associated with pain, numbness, or paresthesias

Treatment:

  • Conservative: Warm clothing, avoid cold temperatures, smoking cessation
  • Medications for severe cases:
    • Dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blockers
    • Alpha-1 Blockers- Prazosin
    • Phosphodiesterase-5 Inhibitors
    • Topical Nitroglycerin
    • Digital sympathectomy in refractory cases


Cold sores (Option C) are caused by the virus Herpes and present as small, fluid-filled blisters that appear on the lips, mouth, nose, or cheeks. Given the absence of any comorbidities or underlying diseases, the association of symptoms with cold temperatures or stress, and the characteristic colour changes during episodes, the most likely diagnosis, in this case, is primarily Raynaud's phenomenon.

questions.text: The flow-volume curve of a patient after spirometry is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) COPD

Explanation:

  • The vignette depicts the characteristic flow volume loop seen in patients with COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease).

Test

Details

Spirometry/PFTs
  • Best initial test
  • IOC
  • Obstructive pattern
    • Reversible with short-acting β2-agonists (SABAs)
  • Findings:
    • FEV1/FVC < 70%
    • ↓ FEV1
    • Normal or ↓ FVC
    • ↑ Residual Volume (RV)
    • ↑ Total Lung Capacity (TLC)
    • Normal or ↑ Diffusing Capacity of Lung for Carbon Monoxide (DLCO)
  • Reversibility:
    • Increase in FEV1 ≥ 12% and >200 mL with SABA (albuterol)
  • PFTs between exacerbations: Often normal

Methacholine Challenge
  • Tests for bronchial hyperresponsiveness
  • Positive if ≥20% decrease in FEV1
  • Sensitive but not specific

Arterial blood gas

  • Early
    • Respiratory alkalosis (↓ PaCO2, ↑ pH) due to hyperventilation
  • Late
    • Respiratory acidosis due to muscle fatigue (normalizing PaCO2, normalizing pH, ↓ PaO2)

Chest X-ray

  • Normal appearance to hyperinflation with flattening of the diaphragm


Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A postoperative cardiac surgery patient developed sudden hypotension, raised central venous pressure, and pulsus paradoxus at the 4th postoperative hour. The most probable diagnosis is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cardiac tamponade

Explanation:

  • Based on the symptoms described in the postoperative cardiac surgical patient, the most probable diagnosis is cardiac tamponade which is a medical emergency characterized by the accumulation of fluid or blood in the pericardial sac, which leads to compression of the heart and impaired cardiac function.

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2 L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

Low-Pressure Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

This occurs when lower pericardial pressure leads to tamponade, often in cases of intravascular fluid depletion (e.g., hypovolemia).

Features

Jugular Venous Distension: Often absent

Pulsus Paradoxus: Rare

Requires a high degree of suspicion due to the absence of typical signs like jugular venous distension and pulsus paradoxus.

 

Incorrect Options:

While ventricular dysfunction (Option A) can cause hypotension and cardiac symptoms, it does not typically present with raised central venous pressure or pulsus paradoxus. Additionally, the sudden onset of symptoms in this case suggests a more acute problem like cardiac tamponade rather than chronic ventricular dysfunction.

CHF (Option C) can cause fluid retention, leading to increased venous pressure and symptoms such as dyspnea and oedema. However, it does not typically present with sudden hypotension, raised central venous pressure, or pulsus paradoxus.

Excessive mediastinal effusion (Option D) can potentially cause compression of the heart and lead to symptoms similar to cardiac tamponade. However, the specific mention of raised central venous pressure and pulsus paradoxus points more towards cardiac tamponade as the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A hepatitis B-positive person came to your OPD on routine urine massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day). Further renal biopsy was performed as below. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Membranous glomerulonephritis

Explanation:

Investigations of Membranous Nephropathy/ glomerulonephritis:

  • Kidney function tests reveal increased creatinine
  • Urine Protein: >2gm protein/gram of urinary creatinine
  • Renal biopsy:
    • Light Microscopy: Reveals uniform basement membrane thickening along peripheral capillary loops.
  • Immunofluorescence: Diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3
  • Electron Microscopy: Dense subepithelial deposits
    • Spike & dome appearance (arrows & asterisk)
  • Autoantibody Testing:
    • Autoantibodies against M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) are present in 70% of cases.
    • Thrombospondin type-1 domain containing 7A (THSD7A) (3-10%)
    • Secondary MGN often lacks these autoantibodies.

Management of Membranous Nephropathy:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Manage oedema (Thiazide diuretics), dyslipidemia, and hypertension (ACE inhibitors/ARBs)
  • Immunosuppressive Therapy: For primary MGN with persistent proteinuria (>3g/24 h)
    • Corticosteroids
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Chlorambucil
    • Mycophenolate mofetil
    • Cyclosporine
    • Rituximab (anti-CD20 antibody)
  • Prophylactic Anticoagulation may be recommended for patients with hypoalbuminemia due to the risk of thrombotic complications.

Complications:

  • Increased risk of Renal vein thrombosis.
  • Others: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism due to hypercoagulability associated with nephrotic syndrome.

Prognosis:

  • One-third of patients progress to more severe disease.
  • One-third experience spontaneous remission.
  • One-third maintain stable disease.
  • Factors associated with a poorer prognosis include male gender, older age, hypertension, and persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Incorrect Options:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option A) is characterized by scarring and sclerosis of certain glomeruli in a focal and segmental pattern.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) (Option C) is characterized by both thickening and proliferation of the glomerular basement membrane.

Minimal change disease (Option D) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children but is less common in adults.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency room with a history of RTA. GCS progressively declines over hours and axial T2 MRI shows multiple small hypointense lesions at the corticomedullary junction and basal ganglia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation:

  • Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a form of traumatic brain injury caused by a blunt force injury to the brain, often from high-speed motor vehicle accidents.

Aetiology:

  • Cause: High-speed accidents, where accelerating and decelerating forces cause shearing of axons in the white matter of the brain.
  • Affected Areas: Primarily the corpus callosum, brainstem, and white matter tracts, especially at the junction of grey and white matter.

Pathophysiology:

  • Shearing forces disrupt neuronal connections, leading to brain dysfunction.
  • Common Deficits: Affect frontal and temporal white matter, corpus callosum, and brainstem.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis, typically with a GCS of less than 8 lasting over six hours.
  • Symptoms:
    • Mild: Headache, dizziness, nausea, and fatigue.
    • Severe: Loss of consciousness, persistent vegetative state, potential long-term recovery for a few.
    • Dysautonomia: Tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia, abnormal muscle tone, and posturing.

Evaluation:

  • CT: Small punctate haemorrhages to white matter tracts.
  • MRI: Investigation of choice
    • Small areas of cerebral microbleeds at the grey-white matter junction, corpus callosum, or the brainstem.

Treatment/Management:

  • Goals: Prevent secondary injuries (e.g., hypoxia, hypotension, intracranial hypertension) and support recovery.
  • Initial Treatment: Focus on stabilization, including resuscitation and prevention of complications like cerebral oedema and elevated ICP.
  • ICP Monitoring: Recommended for GCS below 8 and for patients unable to be regularly evaluated neurologically.
  • Anticonvulsants: Short-term use (7 days) to prevent early seizures.
  • Emerging Therapies: Progesterone treatment shows promise but cannot be routinely recommended.

Incorrect Options:

Extensive subarachnoid haemorrhage (Option B) is a life-threatening condition due to the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid and pia mater.

Hypoxic cerebral injury (Option C) refers to injury of the brain due to a lack of oxygen delivery enough to support metabolic needs. This is caused due to conditions like cardiac arrest, strangulation, severe anaemia, systemic hypotension, etc.

Multiple hemorrhagic contusions (Option D) are traumatic brain injuries which are the most disabling type of traumatic phenomenon. These can be caused by falls, road traffic accidents, aggression, sports injuries, cyclists, etc. These appear as several localized areas of bleeding.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man collapsed in his house and was rushed to the hospital. On arrival, his ECG tracing was as shown below. Which of the following is the best intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Injection of Adrenaline 1mg IV

Explanation:

  • The ECG here is starting to show asystole and the best treatment modality is CPR and injection of Adrenaline 1mg IV.

Resuscitation Steps for Asystole


Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Occipital lobe

Explanation:

  • A lesion in the occipital lobe, specifically in the Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) territory affecting the calcarine cortex, typically causes congruous homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.
  • This characteristic defect arises because the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is the major artery supplying the primary visual cortex, while the macula is protected by its blood supply from the middle cerebral artery (MCA).

Lesions in Visual Cortex:

  • Typically present as congruous homonymous hemianopia (visual field loss is consistent in both eyes).

The frontal visual field (Option A) is incorrect since a lesion in this area affects functions like attention, visual scanning, and decision-making. The image in the given scenario is not associated with this area.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a copper-containing enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mitochondrial superoxide dismutase

Explanation:

Mitochondrial superoxide dismutase (MnSOD or SOD2) is not a copper-containing enzyme. Instead, it contains manganese (Mn) as its cofactor, not copper. It is one of the three isoforms of superoxide dismutase (SOD) that help protect cells from oxidative stress by converting superoxide radicals (O2•−) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and molecular oxygen (O2).

The copper-containing enzymes rely on copper to carry out various essential functions in the body.

  • Ceruloplasmin
  • Cytochrome oxidase
  • Cytochrome c
  • Tyrosinase (Option C ruled out)
  • Lysyl oxidase (Option D ruled out)
  • ALA synthase
  • Monoamine oxidase
  • Cytosolic Superoxide dismutase (Option B ruled out)
  • Phenol oxidase

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 45-year-old male patient with a history of chronic alcoholism, who is currently experiencing symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and diplopia?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

Explanation:

  • This patient is presenting with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy, commonly seen in patients with chronic alcoholism. The treatment for Wernicke's encephalopathy is to administer thiamine (vitamin B1) before or simultaneously with glucose to prevent exacerbating the condition.

WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation. (Option B)

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

Treatment

Acute Phase (Wernicke Encephalopathy):

  • Intravenous thiamine (100 mg) for 3-7 days is standard; however, higher doses (500 mg TID) may be required if symptoms persist.
  • Glucose should be administered after thiamine to prevent exacerbating symptoms.

Chronic Phase (Korsakoff’s Psychosis):

  • Continue oral thiamine indefinitely, especially in alcohol-dependent patients.
  • Address co-occurring deficiencies, provide nutritional support, and consider rehabilitation or residential care if needed.

Glucose infusion followed by thiamine injection (Option B): Giving glucose before thiamine can exacerbate Wernicke’s encephalopathy, as it can increase the metabolic demand for thiamine, worsening the deficiency.

Glucose infusion alone (Option C): Glucose infusion without thiamine can precipitate or worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy in patients with thiamine deficiency (such as in chronic alcoholics).

Thiamine infusion alone (Option D): While thiamine is essential, glucose infusion is also necessary if the patient is hypoglycemic. Thiamine alone is insufficient for immediate management if glucose is needed for the patient’s energy requirements.

questions.text: A child with mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness was investigated and was found to be deficient for Hexosaminidase-A enzyme. She is most likely suffering from ..
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tay-sachs disease

Explanation:

The child in the clinical scenario is showing signs of mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness, which strongly suggest a lysosomal storage disorder. Upon investigation, the child was found to be deficient in hexosaminidase A enzyme. The disease most likely causing these symptoms is Tay-Sachs disease.It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the failure of degradation of gangliosides, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

Lipid Storage Diseases (Sphingolipidoses):

  • They are a group of lysosomal storage diseases.

Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

(Option C)

Hexosaminidase A
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in the macula

Fabry disease

(Option B ruled out)

α-Galactosidase
  • Skin rash
  • Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males
  • X-linked recessive)

Krabbe disease

(Option A ruled out)

β-Galactosidase
  • Mental retardation
  • Near absence of myelin
  • Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness.

Gaucher disease

(Option D ruled out)

β-Glucosidase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Erosion of long bones
  • Mental retardation in infants
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Niemann-Pick disease

Sphingomyelinase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life
  • Cherry red spot in macula

Farber disease

Ceramidase
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

questions.text: In a 14-year-old male, a medical condition has been identified as a result of a defect in a gene responsible for DNA repair. The individual is experiencing increased pigmentation on the skin and is at a heightened risk of developing skin cancers, according to the physician. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely to be impaired in this particular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nucleotide excision repair defect

Explanation:

In this 14-year-old male, the condition described involves increased pigmentation on the skin and a heightened risk of skin cancers. These symptoms are consistent with Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP), a disorder caused by an inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage. UV radiation can cause the formation of pyrimidine dimers (thymine dimers) in the skin cells, which, if not repaired, lead to mutations and an increased risk of cancer. The key defective mechanism in XP is Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER).

Nucleotide excision repair: Nucleotide excision repair is required when chemical damage to a segment occurs. UV mediated Pyr Pyr dimerization is observed in a segment. 30 bases are removed and then the correct bases are added

Recognition and Excision:

  • In bacteria, UvrABC proteins (uvrABC excinuclease) recognize these dimers and cleave the damaged strand on both the 5′ and 3′ sides of the lesion.
  • A short oligonucleotide containing the dimer is excised, leaving a gap in the DNA strand.
  • The gap is subsequently filled in by DNA polymerase I and sealed by DNA ligase.

Nucleotide Excision Repair in Humans:

  • A related nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway exists in humans, addressing UV-induced damage encountered during DNA synthesis.
  • Transcription-coupled repair, a type of NER, specifically targets lesions that obstruct RNA synthesis.

Clinical application:

  • Pyrimidine dimers can form in human skin cells exposed to unfiltered sunlight.
  • In xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a genetic disorder, the inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage leads to the accumulation of mutations and a heightened risk of developing early and multiple skin cancers.
  • XP results from defects in genes coding for proteins necessary for NER of UV damage

questions.text: What diagnostic tool is used to determine the cause of chest pain at rest for 6 hours and an electrocardiogram indicating myocardial ischemia in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) LDH 1

Explanation:

LDH-1 is the isoenzyme predominantly found in the heart muscle, making it the most relevant for diagnosing conditions related to the heart, particularly myocardial infarction (heart attack). During a myocardial infarction (MI), heart muscle cells are damaged or destroyed, causing the release of LDH-1 into the bloodstream.

LDH-1 increases significantly in the case of heart injury, and its levels can be 5-10 times higher than in normal conditions during a heart attack.

LDH in Myocardial Infarction:

  • Total LDH activity is increased during a heart attack (myocardial infarction).
  • H4 isoenzyme increases 5-10 times more than other forms during myocardial infarction.
  • The size of the myocardial infarct correlates with the peak value and area under the LDH curve.
  • Increased total LDH levels are observed in:
    • Hemolytic anemias
    • Hepatocellular damage
    • Muscular dystrophy
    • Carcinomas
    • Leukemias
    • Any condition causing necrosis of body cells.
  • LDH Isoenzymes:
    • LDH enzyme is a tetramer with 4 subunits: either H (heart) or M (muscle) polypeptide chains.
    • There are 5 possible isoenzymes based on combinations of H and M chains:
      • H4
      • H3M1
      • H2M2
      • M3H1
      • M4
    • Isoenzymes are separated using cellulose acetate electrophoresis at pH 8.6.
    • The reaction is identified with NAD+ and nitroblue tetrazolium.
  • Isoenzyme Locations and Patterns:
    • M4 form is predominantly found in skeletal muscles.
    • H4 form is predominantly found in the heart.
    • In normal conditions, LDH-2 (H3M1) concentration is higher than LDH-1 (H4), but in myocardial infarction, the pattern reverses (known as the "flipped pattern").

Isoenzyme

Activity at 60°C for 30 minutes

Electrophoretic Mobility at pH 8.6

Tissue of Origin

Percentage in Human Serum (Mean)

LDH-1

Not destroyed

Fastest

Heart muscle

30%

LDH-2

Not destroyed

Faster

RBC (Option A)

35%

LDH-3

Partially destroyed

Fast

Brain (Option B)

20%

LDH-4

Destroyed

Slow

Liver (Option D)

10%

LDH-5

Destroyed

Slowest

questions.text: A patient has come in with bleeding gums and the examination results are as follows. This particular condition can be observed in the case of a deficiency in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vitamin C

Explanation:

Vitamin C is essential for collagen production. Its deficiency causes scurvy, leading to symptoms like bleeding gums, swollen gums, and delayed wound healing.

Vitamin C

  • Dietary Sources: Amla, guava, lime, lemon, and green leafy vegetables.
  • Requirements: The daily recommended intake is 75 mg/day, increased to 100 mg/day during pregnancy, lactation, for the elderly, smokers, and those on oral contraceptives.
  • Scurvy:
    • Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which can be severe in infants between 6–12 months (infantile scurvy or Barlow’s disease).
    • Hemorrhagic Tendency: Collagen is abnormal in vitamin C deficiency, causing fragile capillaries that lead to bleeding under pressure, seen as petechiae or ecchymoses.
    • Internal Hemorrhage: Severe deficiency may cause hemorrhages in the conjunctiva, retina, nose (epistaxis), urine (hematuria), and stools (melena).
    • Oral Cavity: Severe scurvy causes swollen, painful gums, and tooth loss due to separation of pulp from dentine. Wound healing is delayed.
  • Bones: Vitamin C deficiency weakens bones, leading to fractures, joint hemorrhage, and pain due to failure of osteoblasts to form osteoid.
  • Anemia: Vitamin C deficiency causes microcytic, hypochromic anemia, with poikilocytosis and anisocytosis. Causes include blood loss, decreased iron absorption, and decreased tetrahydrofolic acid.

Vitamin A (Option A): Deficiency in vitamin A is associated with night blindness, dry skin, and impaired immune function, not bleeding gums.

Vitamin B12 (Option B): Deficiency in vitamin B12 leads to megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and glossitis, but not specifically bleeding gums.

Vitamin D (Option D): Deficiency in vitamin D can lead to bone issues like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, but it does not directly cause bleeding gums.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a gradual onset of swallowing difficulties for both solid and liquid foods, persisting for 8 months. The barium swallow test results are presented below. The patient undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and manometry. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux
<75% relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter
It is a primary motility disorder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux

Explanation:

  • The given condition, along with the barium swallow finding, is suggestive of Achalasia cardia, which is characterised by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax.
  • Achalasia is associated with increased pressure rather than a loss of pressure of the LES.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is a primary motility disorder (Option B ruled out) characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

(Option A & D ruled out)

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

 

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris. It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

questions.text: According to GCS, a verbal score of 1 indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) No Verbal response

Explanation:

  • A verbal score of 1 on the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) means no verbal response from the patient, indicating the most severe level of impairment in verbal communication.
  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a tool used to assess a patient’s level of consciousness based on three parameters: eye-opening, verbal response, and motor response. Each parameter is scored, and the total GCS score ranges from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).

Simplified Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

4

5 (Option D ruled out)

3 (Option B ruled out)

Incomprehensible sounds

2 (Option C ruled out)

None

Obeys commands

6

Localizes to pain
