questions.text: What would be the subsequent course of action for managing a 35-year-old woman who has been experiencing swelling in her right groin for the past six months, as determined during her arrival at the emergency department? Upon examination, a reducible hernia is observed in the right groin without any signs of strangulation.

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and later observe
Reduce the swelling and do elective surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reduce the swelling and do elective surgery

Explanation:

  • For a reducible hernia with no signs of strangulation, the correct course of action is to reduce the swelling and proceed with elective surgery.
  • A groin hernia occurs when abdominal contents, typically a portion of the intestine or fatty tissue, protrude through the femoral canal in the lower abdominal wall.
  • They are at a higher risk of incarceration and strangulation compared to inguinal hernias.
  • Hence, elective surgery is advised to repair the hernia and prevent complications.

 

Exploratory laparotomy (Option A) is an invasive procedure that is usually performed when there is concern about internal injury, peritonitis, or significant abdominal pathology. In this case, since the hernia is reducible and there are no signs of strangulation, a laparotomy is not needed.

Reduce the swelling and later observe (Option B) is not ideal as a surgical intervention should still be planned in the near future to prevent any complications like recurrent or incarcerated hernias.

A CT abdomen (Option D) is not necessary here because the diagnosis of a reducible hernia is already done, and there are no signs of strangulation. It may be required if there is uncertainty about the diagnosis or if other abdominal pathologies are suspected.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate course of action for managing a 25-year-old male patient who was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident (RTA)? The patient has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45 mmHg. During examination, hyper-resonance is detected over the left side of the chest. The provided chest x-ray is shown below.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the right 5th ICS
Wide bore needle insertion in the left 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wide bore needle insertion in the left 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a traumatic injury after a road traffic accident; his clinical findings, along with the given chest X-ray suggest tension pneumothorax.
  • A wide bore needle is inserted into the 5th intercostal space at the mid-axillary line to decompress the pleural space and allow the trapped air to escape, which is the first emergency intervention in suspected tension pneumothorax.
  • After the initial needle decompression, the next step is to insert a chest tube (intercostal drain) in the same location to allow for continuous drainage of air or fluid from the pleural space. (Options A & D ruled out)
  • This will help the lung re-expand and prevent the pneumothorax from recurring.

Aspiration of the pleural fluid (Option C) is done for pleural effusion, where fluid accumulates in the pleural space. In this case, the clinical findings suggest pneumothorax, where air is trapped, not fluid. Therefore, aspiration is not the correct approach here.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of increasing urinary frequency without burning and nocturia four times each day. He has limited his fluid consumption and caffeine intake in the evening without much benefit. On prostate examination, the swelling was palpated with a smooth surface, and a firm, non-tender rubber-like consistency was found. The physician thinks of benign prostate hypertrophy. All are characteristic features of benign prostate hypertrophy except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increased trabeculations in the bladder

Explanation:

  • Increased trabeculations in the bladder are not characteristic features of BPH.
  • Trabeculations refer to irregular muscular bands or folds in the bladder wall, commonly seen in conditions of chronic bladder outlet obstruction, where the bladder muscle hypertrophies due to long-term pressure, but increased trabeculations in the bladder is not commonly seen.

Benign Prostate Hyperplasia (BPH)

Explanation
  • Age affected: Men over 50 years
  • After 60 years, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH.
  • Common cause of significant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men: BPH
  • Common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men more than 70 years of age: BPH

Etiopathogenesis
  • Role of hormones in BPH:
    • DHT (Dihydrotestosterone)
      • DHT, derived from testosterone via 5-alpha reductase, binds to androgen receptors in the prostate, promoting cellular proliferation and contributing to prostatic enlargement.
    • Estrogen
      • Estrogen levels increase relative to testosterone in ageing men, influencing prostate growth through the activation of estrogen receptors, particularly ER-α, in the prostatic tissue.
  • Affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees.

Common site of origin

Submucosal glands of the periurethral transitional zone

Secondary changes in the bladder

It is due to increased force of contraction of detrusor muscles):

  • Collagen deposition
  • Detrusor muscle hyperplasia
  • Detrusor muscle hypertrophy.

Clinical features
  • Obstructive symptoms:
    • Poor flow/stream
    • Hesitancy
    • Intermittency
    • Incomplete voiding-High post-void residual urine
    • Dribbling of urine
  • Irritative symptoms:
    • Frequency
    • Urgency
    • Nocturia

Complications
  • Retention
  • Haematuria
  • Urinary infection
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis

 

J-shaped/ fish hook proximal ureter (Option B) is a common finding in cases of bladder outlet obstruction, where the increased pressure causes changes in the course of the ureter.

J-shaped/ fish hook distal ureters (Option C) is another manifestation of the pressure changes from bladder outlet obstruction, leading to tortuosity or a hook-like appearance in the distal ureters in BPH.

Bilateral hydronephrosis (Option D) ​​refers to the dilatation or swelling of the kidneys caused by the blockage of urine flow from the bladder. BPH can result in bladder outlet obstruction, which leads to urine backing up into the kidneys, ultimately causing hydronephrosis.

questions.text: In a patient experiencing excessive bleeding, with limbs displaying low temperature and reduced central venous pressure (CVP), what type of shock is observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypovolemic shock

Explanation:

  • The type of shock seen in a patient with profuse bleeding, cold extremities, and decreased central venous pressure (CVP) is "Hypovolemic shock."
  • It occurs due to a significant loss of blood or fluid volume, leading to insufficient circulation and oxygen delivery to tissues.

Pathophysiology of Hypovolemic shock
  • The decreased cardiac output leads to
    • Inadequate tissue perfusion, lactic acidosis, metabolic acidosis along with
    • Compensatory mechanism activation & increased sympathetic tone cause an increase in PR & TPR.

 

Cardiogenic shock (Option A) is due to the primary failure of the heart to pump blood. It may be due to myocardial infarction, cardiomyopathy, or blunt myocardial injury.

Obstructive shock (Option C) is characterised by a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling of the left and/or right side of the heart, which in turn leads to a fall in cardiac output.

Hypoadrenal shock (Option D) stems from inadequate cortisol release during stress, illness, or trauma, often due to chronic glucocorticoid use or adrenal insufficiency related to metastatic disease, amyloidosis, bilateral adrenal haemorrhage, etomidate, TB, or idiopathic atrophy.

SU752

questions.text: Most common site of peripheral aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Popliteal artery

Explanation:

  • The popliteal artery is the most common site for a peripheral aneurysm. Aneurysms in this location are more frequent due to the anatomical structure of the popliteal artery and its exposure to mechanical stress in the knee area.
  • Popliteal artery aneurysms are often associated with degenerative changes in the arterial wall, such as atherosclerosis.
  • These aneurysms can lead to the development of a pulsatile mass behind the knee and may increase the risk of complications such as thrombosis or embolism.

 

Brachial artery (Option A) is located in the upper arm and is responsible for supplying blood to the arm. However, aneurysms in the brachial artery are not as common compared to other popliteal artery aneurysms.

Radial artery (Option C) is located in the forearm and is a major artery responsible for supplying blood to the hand. While aneurysms can occur in the radial artery, they are rare compared to other sites.

Femoral artery (Option D) aneurysms are uncommon compared to those in the popliteal artery but can still occur.

questions.text: Which one of the following is absent in cases of massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypercalcemia

Explanation:

  • Hypercalcemia is not commonly seen in massive blood transfusions. In fact, the risk is usually the opposite (hypocalcemia) due to citrate-binding calcium.
  • Massive blood transfusion refers to the transfusion of a large volume of blood products over a relatively short period. While blood transfusions can be life-saving, they can also be associated with certain adverse effects.

Complications of massive blood transfusion

Complication

Cause

Effect

Hypothermia

Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C).

Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy), and worsening bleeding.

Coagulopathy

 

 

Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage.

Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, thrombocytopenia, and increased risk of continued bleeding.

(Option D ruled out)

DIC

(Option A ruled out)

Due to the release of procoagulant substances

Leads to haemorrhage due to depleted hemostatic components, tissue hypoxia, and infarction due to microthrombi, or both.

Citrate Toxicity

Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium.

Hypocalcemia leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Hypocalcemia

 
  • Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and other blood products are preserved with citrate, an anticoagulant.
  • Citrate binds to ionised calcium (Ca²⁺) in the recipient's blood, reducing the free calcium level - hypocalcemia

Presents as muscle spasms, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased myocardial contractility

Hyperkalemia

 

Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage.

Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest.

Hypokalemia

 

Potassium may shift intracellularly once transfused red blood cells are metabolically revived.

Hypokalemia causes muscle weakness, paralysis, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Metabolic Alkalosis

Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate.

Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin.

Metabolic Acidosis

Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation.

Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function.

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs.

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion.

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

Volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload.

Pulmonary oedema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure.

Iron Overload

Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron.

Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time.

Hemolytic Reactions

ABO or Rh incompatibility.

Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causes fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock.

Allergic Reactions

Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products.

Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock).

Bacterial Contamination

Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage.

Sepsis, characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.

Febrile transfusion reaction

(Option B ruled out)

It is a non-hemolytic condition that is not completely understood but is believed to be caused by residual white blood cells in the blood unit or cytokines that accumulate during storage.

Fever, rigour, chills

questions.text: In a hypotensive patient with a head injury, which of the subsequent fluids should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 5% Dextrose

Explanation:

  • In a hypotensive patient with a head injury, 5% dextrose should be avoided because it is a hypotonic solution, and its administration can lead to cerebral oedema and ICP by reducing serum sodium.
  • The aim of fluid resuscitation in such cases is to improve circulation without worsening intracranial pressure or causing cerebral oedema.
  • Isotonic crystalloids like 0.9% NS are preferred for fluid resuscitation in head injuries (Option A ruled out)

 

Ringer Lactate (Option C) is an isotonic solution mainly used in aggressive volume resuscitation from blood loss or burn injuries. Its osmolarity of 273 mOsm/L is slightly lower than plasma but still within an isotonic range; it could increase intracellular space volume, leading to an increase in intracranial pressure in brain-injured trauma patients.

3% saline (Option D) is a hypertonic solution that is a preferred treatment for head injuries that involve increased intracranial pressure (ICP). It helps reduce brain oedema by drawing fluid out of the brain cells into the bloodstream. They also support circulatory stability by increasing blood pressure and cardiac output.

questions.text: The likely diagnosis for a newborn infant presenting with signs of intestinal obstruction, as indicated by the x-ray image and CT abdomen showing an annular pancreas, is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Duodenal atresia

Explanation:

  • The given x-ray shows a classic finding of Duodenal atresia, which is the "double bubble" sign, where there are two air-filled spaces visible: one in the stomach and one in the duodenum, indicating obstruction at the level of the duodenum.

Duodenal Atresia

Pathophysiology
  • Failed recanalisation of intestinal lumen during gestation

Associated Conditions
  • Prematurity (50%)
  • Congenital anomalies (heart disease, malrotation, annular pancreas, etc.)
  • Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 21)

Clinical Presentation
  • Bilious vomiting without abdominal distention.
  • Symptoms typically present within the first few days of life.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed by the double bubble sign on the abdominal X-ray and prenatal ultrasonography.

Treatment
  • Initial: Nasogastric decompression and IV fluids
  • Definitive: Surgical repair (Duodenoduodenostomy)
  • Postoperative care: Gastrostomy tube, nutritional support

Jejunoileal atresia (Option A) is characterised by multiple dilated loops of the small bowel and a "triple bubble sign" on X-ray, not the double bubble sign. It can cause bilious vomiting, and polyhydramnios association is less common compared to duodenal atresia.

Esophageal atresia (Option B) involves a discontinuity or abnormality of the esophagus, often presenting with excessive drooling, coughing, difficulty feeding, and respiratory distress. Imaging shows a gas-filled or gasless abdomen and a coiled tube in the upper oesophagus.

Colonic atresia (Option D) refers to a blockage or absence of a portion of the colon, which is less common than other forms of atresia. It would not present with the classic "double bubble" sign in duodenal atresia or annular pancreas.

questions.text: A factory worker working in a plastic pipe factory presented to the OPD with weight loss and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for 6 months duration. He had hepatomegaly. Further investigation revealed that most of the liver was replaced by a hemorrhagic tumour with extensive necrosis. What can be the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Angiosarcoma of the liver

Explanation:

  • The patient's occupation, history of weight loss, abdominal pain, and hepatomegaly, coupled with the imaging findings of extensive haemorrhage and necrosis, strongly point to Angiosarcoma of the liver as the likely diagnosis.

Hepatic Angiosarcoma

Definition
  • It is a high-grade vascular malignancy that arises from the endothelial cells lining blood vessels or lymphatic channels.
  • It is the most common sarcoma arising in the liver, especially in those with significant exposure to Vinyl chloride.

Common in

Men and elderly

Risk Factors
  • Arsenic,
  • Radiation,
  • Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast)

Metastasis
  • It can spread through lymphatic and hematogenous routes, but due to the tumour's vascular nature, hematogenous spread (via blood vessels) is more common.
  • The liver and lungs are common sites of metastasis, reflecting the tumour's aggressive nature

Clinical presentation

It presents as a red-brown, indurated, and ulcerated skin lesion.

 

 

Cavernous hemangioma (Option A) is the most common benign liver tumour. It appears as a discrete red-blue, soft nodule less than 2 cm in diameter, commonly located in a subcapsular location. It does not explain the severe symptoms or the findings of tumour necrosis and haemorrhage in this case.

Metastatic carcinoma of the liver (Option B) refers to the spread of cancer from other sites to the liver. While it can cause hepatomegaly and liver involvement, the description of extensive necrosis and hemorrhage is more suggestive of a primary malignant tumour.

Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (Option D) is the most common primary malignancy of the liver. It typically presents with symptoms like hepatomegaly, weight loss, and abdominal pain. However, the extensive necrosis and hemorrhage described in this case are more characteristic of angiosarcoma rather than HCC.

questions.text: A patient who underwent Nissen’s fundoplication was seen in the ward during evening rounds. He is asymptomatic at present and has stable vitals. What is the next line of management for this patient?

choices.text: Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome
Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Monitor vitals

Explanation:

  • Given that the patient is asymptomatic and has stable vitals, the primary management at this stage is to continue monitoring their vitals closely.
  • Nissen fundoplication is a surgical procedure used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD); it involves wrapping the upper part of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to increase the pressure at the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES), reducing reflux.

Management of GERD

Lifestyle Changes
  • Elevate the head of the bed
  • Avoid lying down after meals
  • Quit smoking

Medical management
  • Antacids: Neutralize stomach acid
  • H2-receptor antagonists: Ranitidine, Famotidine
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): Omeprazole, Esomeprazole

Surgical management

Antireflux operation: 3 components

  • Restoration of the intra-abdominal segment of the esophagus
  • Crural repair
  • Reinforcement of the LES by the upper stomach or prosthesis.

Fundoplication: A surgical procedure to wrap the top of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to strengthen the sphincter.

  • Complete fundoplication (Nissen)
  • Partial fundoplication: Posteriorly (Toupet) or Anteriorly(Dor, Watson) has few short-term side effects but has a higher long-term failure rate.
  • Transoral Incisionless Fundoplication (TIF): An endoscopic procedure performed through the mouth but may be less effective for severe GERD and not suitable for all patients.
  • Magnetic Sphincter Augmentation (LINX Device): Involves implanting a ring of magnetic beads around the lower oesophagal sphincter to enhance its function and prevent reflux.

 

 

Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome (Option A): While gas bloat syndrome can be a complication post-surgery, it would not necessitate routine nasogastric tube insertion unless symptoms of bloating or distension arise.

Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax (Option B): There is no indication of a pneumothorax, and the patient is asymptomatic with stable vitals, making a chest tube unnecessary.

Imaging to rule out perforation (Option D) is not recommended as the patient is asymptomatic and stable, without signs of perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following do not require instruments to examine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute anal fissure

Explanation:

  • An acute anal fissure is a fresh, superficial tear in the anal canal lining typically caused by trauma, such as passing a large stool. It can be diagnosed through a visual inspection and digital rectal examination without the need for any specialised instruments like anoscopes or proctoscopes.

 

Carcinoma rectum (Option B) requires a sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy to visualise and assess the tumour's extent. Imaging studies are also needed to evaluate staging.

Haemorrhoids (Option C): While external haemorrhoids can be diagnosed through visual inspection, internal haemorrhoids typically require the use of an anoscope or proctoscope for proper assessment.

Rectal polyps (Option D) are usually diagnosed and removed using colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy, making instruments necessary for both diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Identify the incision marked as B
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lanz incision

Explanation:

  • B in the given image depicts Lanz incision which is a type of incision used commonly in appendectomy surgery. It is a low transverse incision made in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Types of Incisions used for appendicectomy

Name of the incision

Incision area

Type of incision

McBurney's incision

(A in the image)
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision (Option A ruled out)

Lanz incision

(B in the image)

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision (Option D ruled out) / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision

(C in the image)

(Option C ruled out)

 
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis.
  • Upward & laterally by cutting the conjoint tendon.
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carcinoid tumours in the appendix is false?

choices.text: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behaviour and metastatic potential
Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Leiberkuhn
Most common location is the base of the appendix
Most common tumor of the appendix

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Most common location is the base of the appendix

Explanation:

  • The most common location of carcinoid tumours in the appendix is actually the tip of the appendix, not the base.

Carcinoid tumor of the appendix (aka Argentaffinoma)

Definition

(Options A & D ruled out)
  • They are neuroendocrine tumours that originate from the enterochromaffin cells (also known as Kulchitsky cells) of the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
  • They are considered the most common tumours of the appendix.

MC Location

Tip of the appendix

Clinical Presentation

Mostly discovered incidentally during surgery

Larger tumours may cause abdominal pain, flushing, and diarrhoea due to hormone secretion

Hormone Secretion

Secretes serotonin and other vasoactive substances.

Risk of Metastasis

(Option A ruled out)
  • Low for tumours <2 cm
  • Higher for tumours>2 cm

Diagnosis

Confirmed by histopathological examination

Treatment
  • <2 cm: Appendectomy
  • >2 cm: Right hemicolectomy

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. Upon examination, there was tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes, and abdominal ultrasound, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described, along with the ultrasound provided her,e suggests Hydatid disease.
  • The given ultrasound shows a characteristic waterlily sign, indicating a cyst with a detached membrane floating within the cyst cavity, which is a hallmark of stage CE 3.

Hydatid cyst

Causative agent

Echinococcus granulosus

Commonly Affected Organs
  • Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases)
  • Lungs (second most common site)
  • Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum

Clinical Features

Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst growth.

Symptomatic Phase:

  • Liver Involvement: Mostly right lobe; Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, obstructive jaundice, portal hypertension.
  • Lung Involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pneumothorax.

Investigations

Imaging Studies:

  • USG is the first-line imaging modality, particularly for liver involvement.
    • Features: Echinococcal cyst wall shows double echogenic lines separated by a hypoechoic layer (double contour)
  • CT Scan
  • MRI

Serological Tests:

  • ELISA
  • Immunoblotting

Other tests:

  • Casoni Intradermal Test
  • ARC5 Immunoelectrophoresis

 

Amoebic liver abscess (Option A) can cause pain and liver enlargement, they are more common in individuals who have a history of travel to endemic areas and typically present with an abscess in the liver, not a cyst.

Pyogenic liver abscess (Option C) are mostly caused by bacterial infections and are more likely to present with fever, chills, and more localized pain. They would not typically cause the marked eosinophilia seen in this case.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option D) can cause liver enlargement; it is a malignant tumour and generally doesn't present with the eosinophilia or characteristic ultrasound findings seen in parasitic infections.

questions.text: A car driver was brought into the A & E following a RTA with complaints of breathlessness. On examination, his vitals are PR-112/min, BP-100/70, SpO2-90 %, and there is extensive bruising on his chest. What is the management of this patient?

choices.text: Internal operative fixation of the fracture’s segments

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IPPV

Explanation:

  • The given condition, along with the X-ray showing multiple rib fractures, is suggestive of a Flail chest, and the most appropriate intervention in this case is IPPV.
  • Positive pressure ventilation is the appropriate initial management in such cases, as it helps to stabilise the flail segment by providing consistent internal pressure, reducing paradoxical movement, and improving oxygenation.

Flail chest

Definition
  • It occurs when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in at least two places, creating a flail segment that moves independently.
  • It exhibits paradoxical chest movement (inwards during inhalation & outwards during exhalation)

Clinical features
  • Hypoventilation: Reduced lung ventilation leads to low oxygen and high CO₂ levels.
  • Mediastinal Flutter: Abnormal mediastinal movement risks sudden cardiac arrest.
  • Pendular Air Movement: Inefficient air exchange between lungs.

Complications
  • Hemothorax: Blood in the chest cavity.
  • Pneumothorax: Air in the chest cavity.

Management
  • Ventilation Support:
    • Oxygen supplementation and Analgesics- Initial management
    • IPPV is the preferred TOC.
    • Tracheostomy if support exceeds 10 days.
  • Injury Management:
    • Intercostal Tube Drainage: Removes air/fluids from the pleural space.
    • Rib Fixation: Stabilises the chest wall.
  • Supportive Care:
    • Blood Transfusions: For blood loss.
    • IV Fluids: For hydration.
    • Antibiotics: To prevent infection.
    • Medications: Bronchodilators and steroids.
  • Thoracotomy:
    • Considered in severe cases

 

Chest tube drainage (Option C) is used for pneumothorax or hemothorax, which may accompany the flail chest. However, without these complications, immediate airway management and stabilisation are more crucial, given the severity of the respiratory distress.

24% oxygen (Option B) is not sufficient for a patient in respiratory distress with a SpO2 of 90%. The primary management here should be focused on supporting ventilation and ensuring adequate oxygenation, which IPPV would achieve more effectively.

Internal operative fixation of the fracture’s segments (Option D): Operative fixation of the rib fractures is typically reserved for cases of severe flail chest associated with instability and massive respiratory compromise. In this case, the priority is to stabilise the patient’s airway and ventilation with IPPV before considering surgical stabilisation.

questions.text: Which of the following tests would a surgeon advise first in a patient with a large thyroid swelling?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ultrasound of the neck

Explanation:

  • When a patient presents with a large thyroid swelling, the first step in evaluating the swelling is typically to perform an ultrasound of the neck.
  • USG provides high resolution of the thyroid gland by well-characterizing parenchymal and nodular abnormalities.
  • It provides valuable information about the size, characteristics, and composition of the swelling, and it also helps differentiate cystic and solid thyroid nodules.
  • Ultrasound can guide further management, such as whether fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is necessary.


FNAC (Option B) is a minimally invasive diagnostic procedure to evaluate abnormalities in various tissues, including thyroid nodules, but it is usually performed after imaging to assess the cytological details of the swelling.


Biopsy (Option C) is generally not the first step in managing thyroid swelling. FNAC is typically preferred over a surgical biopsy for diagnostic purposes. A biopsy would be considered only if malignancy is strongly suspected and other tests (like FNAC) are inconclusive.


Radioiodine uptake (Option D) is used to assess the functional status of the thyroid, but it is not the first step in evaluating a swelling. It is primarily used in cases where there are concerns about thyrotoxicosis or hyperthyroidism or in the context of thyroid nodules with known thyroid dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumour marker of pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CA 19-9

Explanation:

  • CA 19-9 is a tumour marker that is commonly associated with pancreatic cancer.
  • Pancreatic cancer tumor marker: Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9 (CA19-9)
    • Usage: Establish a baseline level for monitoring.
    • Characteristics:
      • Not highly specific or sensitive.
      • Useful for detecting recurrence if initial levels are raised

Tumor markers

Tumor marker

Associated conditions

Alpha-fetoprotein

(AFP)

(Option B ruled out)

 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour)
  • Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis
  • ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects
  • ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13

β-HCG

 
  • Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma)
  • Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease)

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers)
  • Gastric cancer

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)

Prostate cancer
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Prostatitis

Calcitonin

Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2)

Alkaline phosphatase

Metastases to bone or liver

Paget disease of the bone

Placental alkaline phosphatase

Seminoma

Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma)
  • Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma)
  • Lymphomas
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Neuron specific enolase (NSE)

(Option A ruled out)
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Neuroblastoma

CA 19–9 (Option D)
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Cholangiocarcinoma

CA 15–3 and CA 27–29 (Option C ruled out)

Breast cancer

CA 125

  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Other gynecologic malignancies

S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B)

Malignant melanoma

SMRP

Mesothelioma

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to OPD with a low backache. His PSA level is 100 ng/ml. Which of the following drugs is indicated for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Goserelin

Explanation:

  • The given condition with low back pain and an elevated PSA level of 100 ng/ml is suggestive of prostate cancer, and Goserelin is the correct drug for this patient.
  • Goserelin is a hormonal therapy medication that is a GnRH agonist that works by reducing the levels of testosterone in the body and can help in slowing down the growth of prostate cancer cells.
  • Prostate cancer is testosterone-dependent, and reducing testosterone levels is a critical part of managing advanced or metastatic prostate cancer.

CA Prostate Management

Strategy

Key Points

Active Surveillance

For low-risk cases; regular monitoring

Radical Prostatectomy

Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative

Radiation Therapy

High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy

Hormone Therapy

Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases

Chemotherapy

Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

 

Somatostatin (Option A) analogues such as octreotide and lanreotide are used in treating conditions like acromegaly, carcinoid tumours, and neuroendocrine tumours, but they are not effective for treating prostate cancer.

Terlipressin (Option B) is a synthetic analogue of vasopressin and is primarily used for the management of variceal bleeding (e.g., in cirrhosis with portal hypertension) but is not used in prostate cancer treatment.

Testosterone (Option D) is the hormone that is often implicated in the growth of prostate cancer. Administering testosterone would exacerbate prostate cancer nand ot help in treating it.

questions.text: Most common primary source of metastasis to the brain is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lung

Explanation:

  • The most common primary source of metastasis to the brain is lung cancer with approximately 47% of patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) showing brain involvement.
  • This high prevalence is due to the vascular nature of the brain and the tendency of lung cancer cells to spread hematogenous
  • Ca lung is the most common primary for metastasis to: (Pneumonic- KEPABS)
    • K– Kidney
    • E– Esophagus
    • P– Pancreas
    • A– Adrenal
    • B– Brain
    • S– Skin

Thyroid (Option A) can metastasise to the brain, but it is not as common compared to lung cancer. Thyroid cancer more commonly spreads to the bones and lungs.

Liver (Option C) cancer, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma, does not commonly metastasise to the brain. It usually spreads to the lungs and other abdominal organs.

Breast (Option D) cancer is also a common cause of brain metastases, but it is not as common as lung cancer. However, it remains a significant cause, particularly in cases of advanced-stage breast cancer.

questions.text: What kind of thyroid cancer is frequently linked to prior radiation exposure, elevated RET/PTC rearrangements, and BRAF mutations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Papillary carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is frequently linked to prior radiation exposure.
  • It is also associated with RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations, both of which are genetic alterations commonly found in this type of cancer.

 

Papillary

(Option B)

Follicular

(Option A ruled out)

Medullary

(Option D ruled out)

Anaplastic

(Option C ruled out)

Origin

Follicular cells

Follicular cells

Para follicular cells

Follicular cells

Risk factors
  • Radiation
  • Thyroglossal cyst
  • Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Multinodular goitre

-

-

Genetics

BRAF, RET-PTC

PAX-8,/PPAR-1, PTEN, P-53, RAS

RET, MEN II

P53

Clinical Manifestations
  • Seen in the 3rd to 4th decade.
  • Midline swelling in the anterior part of the neck
  • Occasionally, lateral aberrant thyroid is seen.
  • Seen in the 5th to 6th decade.
  • A sudden increase in the size of the swelling
  • Minimal or no pain
  • Raised calcitonin.
  • History of diarrhoea
  • Family history of pheochromocytoma or hyperparathyroidism

 

Metastasis

Lymphatic

Hematogenous

Both

Both and Direct invasion.

Histopathology
  • Optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei)
  • Dystrophic calcification (Psammoma bodies)

Follicles (multiple foci are seen)

 

 

 

 

Amyloid deposition

 

 

 

 

 

Highly pleomorphic cells, spindle cells, giant cells, often areas of necrosis and mitotic figures.

questions.text: A patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. A picture of the resected gall bladder is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gall bladder carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The given image shows a resected gall bladder with features suggestive of carcinoma, it is typically nodular and infiltrative, causing thickening of the gall bladder wall, which may extend to the entire gall bladder.
  • It is often difficult to differentiate from chronic cholecystitis.

Gall bladder carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Gallstones, (The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population)
  • Porcelain gallbladder,
  • PSC,
  • Abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction

Presentation
  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage)

Lab investigation
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging & Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

Mixed stone in gall bladder (Option B) refers to gallstones composed of a mixture of cholesterol, bilirubin, and calcium salts. They are normally identified through imaging methods such as ultrasound and may not appear visibly as a carcinoma.

Cholecystitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of the gall bladder, often due to gallstones or infection. It can present with acute symptoms like pain, fever, and nausea. Imaging shows gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm), pericholecystic fluid, & ultrasonographic Murphy's sign.

Choledocholithiasis (Option D) refers to the presence of stones in the common bile duct, and its diagnosis typically requires imaging to show stones in the bile duct.

questions.text: A 25-year-old morbidly obese male patient presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals, and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL)

Explanation:

  • Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the most suitable option for a 2.5 cm cystine stone (given in the image), especially in a morbidly obese patient where ESWL and ureteroscopy may be less effective.
  • The given image shows hexagonal-shaped crystals that suggest cystine stones, typical of cystinuria.
  • PCNL involves the creation of a small percutaneous tract through the skin, directly accessing the renal collecting system and is indicated for the treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter or stones resistant to ESWL.
  • Typically, this procedure is done in the prone position. Fluoroscopy or ultrasound is used for localisation. The posterolateral calyx is commonly chosen for entry.

Management of renal stones

Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis). (Option A ruled out)
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm. (Option B)
  • Ureteroscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).

Open surgery (Option C) is rarely necessary these days and is typically reserved for complex cases or when other treatments have failed. Given the effectiveness of PCNL for large stones, open surgery would not be the first option.

Ureteroscopy-assisted removal (Option D) involves inserting a thin tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to access stones in the ureter or kidney. While it is effective for smaller stones, a 2.5 cm stone in the kidney may be challenging to remove entirely using ureteroscopy alone.

questions.text: The most common type of gastric sarcoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GIST

Explanation:

  • GISTs are the most common type of gastric sarcoma and arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, which are involved in the regulation of gastric motility.
  • These tumours are often located in the stomach and can be malignant.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)

Mutations
  • Most common- c-KIT/CD117
  • Others:
    • PDGFR- beta
    • Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)- Small baby( Pediatric GIST)

Mechanism

KIT (c-kit) is a proto-oncogene encoding a receptor tyrosine kinase. Mutations result in constant activation of KIT signalling, driving tumour growth and survival.

Common Locations
  • Stomach: 60-70% of cases.
  • Small Intestine: 20-30%.
  • Other Areas: Colon, rectum, and oesophagus (less common).

Treatment
  • Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors - Imatinib
  • Surgical management

 

Liposarcoma (Option B) is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that originates from adipose (fat) tissue. While liposarcomas can occur in the stomach, they are less common compared to GIST.

Leiomyosarcoma (Option C) is a malignant smooth muscle tumour. Although they can occur in the gastrointestinal tract, they are less common than GISTs in the stomach.

Epithelioid sarcoma (Option D) is a rare and aggressive sarcoma that affects the soft tissues (primarily arise in the deep tissues) of the limbs or other peripheral areas; they can also happen anywhere in the body.

questions.text: According to Weigert Meyer’s rule of duplication of the ureter, the lower pole ureter in the urinary bladder is:

choices.text: Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Lateral and caudal to the upper pole ureter
Medial and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Medial and caudal to the upper pole ureter

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter

Explanation:

  • Weigert Meyer's rule states that in incomplete duplication of the ureter, the upper pole ureter is caudal and medial compared to the lower pole ureter.
  • Hence, the statement “lower pole ureter is positioned laterally and cephalad in relation to the upper pole ureter” corresponds with the expected anatomical configuration as per Weigert Meyer's rule.
  • Weigert Meyer's rule explanation:
    • The upper and lower renal moieties each have separate ureters, each with its own orifice in the bladder.
    • The upper renal moiety ureter typically inserts ectopically, medially and inferior to the lower renal moiety ureter, often leading to a ureterocele.
    • The lower renal moiety ureter inserts orthotopically, laterally, and superiorly to the upper moiety's ureter, which has a risk of vesicoureteral reflux.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man suffered a blow on a distended bladder ,following which he developed sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium associated with syncope. Later on, as the pain subsided, the abdomen began to distend. However, he had no desire to micturate. Which among the following is true regarding his condition?

choices.text: This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture
MRI is the ideal investigation to diagnose bladder rupture
Repair is done by suturing edges with single-layer 2/0 absorbable suture
Laparoscopic method is avoided as it can be done only on laparotomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture

Explanation:

  • The patient experienced a blow to the distended bladder, resulting in sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium associated with syncope and subsequently, the abdomen began to distend, indicating leakage of urine into the extraperitoneal space.
  • These findings are consistent with extraperitoneal bladder rupture, which occurs when the bladder wall is disrupted but the peritoneal lining remains intact.

Extra peritoneal bladder rupture

Definition

It occurs when the bladder wall is disrupted, but the peritoneal lining remains intact, often due to trauma.

Investigations

(Option B ruled out)
  • CT cystography reveals characteristic features like a flame-shaped appearance, pear sign & teardrop appearance.
  • Retrograde cystography is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing bladder ruptures, including extraperitoneal injuries.
  • Extravasation of contrast limited to the perivesical space is a key finding that helps differentiate extraperitoneal from intraperitoneal ruptures, where contrast would outline bowel loops.

Management
  • Initial management:
    • Urethral catheterisation with free bladder drainage for 10-14 days.
    • Followed by a cystogram to confirm healing before catheter removal.
  • If the injury is iatrogenic:
    • Repair during the same procedure (open or laparoscopic).
    • Repair done in two layers using 2/0 vicryl absorbable sutures (Option C ruled out)
  • Bladder injury with pelvic fracture:
    • The bladder should be repaired at the same time during the surgery for pelvic fracture.
    • Immediate surgical repair is indeed indicated in cases where there are complicating factors like intravesical bone spicules, bladder neck injuries, or associated vaginal or rectal lacerations.
    • Laparoscopy can be used in the management of bladder rupture, particularly in cases where less invasive approaches are preferred (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy had a recent urinary tract infection that was resolved with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination revealed an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. However, a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. The USG revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal, as shown in the image below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Surgical exploration

Explanation:

  • The condition described in the question is most likely cryptorchidism, where the testicle fails to descend into the scrotum, and as the testis is located in a suboptimal location like the inguinal canal (as seen in the ultrasound), surgical exploration is typically the next step in management.

Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition

It is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration. (Option D)
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy. (Option B ruled out)
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilised to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option C ruled out)

 

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

Observation (Option A) is not the best option since the child is approaching the age when early intervention is critical for testicular health.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on her face that was growing rapidly in size and associated with itching. The lesion is shown below. Which of the following is likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Malignant melanoma

Explanation:

  • Given the rapid growth, pigmentation, and associated itching, the most likely diagnosis is Malignant melanoma.

Malignant melanoma

Definition

Melanoma is a malignant tumour arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it is a rare skin cancer, it has a high mortality rate. It presents as a pigmented lesion that enlarges, ulcerates, or bleeds.

Risk factors
  • Positive family history.
  • Fair skin.
  • Genetics: CDKN2A (chromosome 9p21), MC1R, and TYR genes.
  • Nevus:
    • Congenital melanocytic nevi.
    • Junctional nevi.
    • Atypical nevi.
    • Dysplastic nevi.

Diagnostic criteria

(Pneumonic: ABCDE)

  • Asymmetry: Irregular shapes.
  • Border: Irregular.
  • Colour: Various colours present or uneven distribution.
  • Diameter: > 6 mm.
  • Evolution: Changes in lesion over time (size, shape, itching, or bleeding)

Investigations
  • Clinical examination.
  • Dermoscopy.
  • Biopsy.
  • Immunohistochemistry: The markers are S-100, HMB-45 (the most specific), Melan-A (MART-1), and MITF.
  • CT scan.

Management
  • Wide local excision (with margins measured before excision and determined by Breslow depth, sentinel lymph node biopsy indicated for tumours with a depth of >1.0 mm).
  • If the tumour is aggressive:
    • Immunotherapy.
    • Chemotherapy.
    • Targeted therapy.
  • Interferon-𝛼 is the only adjuvant treatment that has documented beneficial effects on overall survival.


Dysplastic nevus (Option A), also called as atypical moles, are abnormal moles that have irregular borders, varied pigmentation, and larger size and are at higher risk of developing into melanoma. However, they typically grow slowly and don’t cause rapid enlargement or significant itching.

Congenital melanocytic nevus (Option B) are present at birth and are usually large, pigmented moles. They generally grow slowly over time. They don't usually grow rapidly in adulthood or cause itching, unlike the lesion described in this case. They also have a higher risk of developing melanoma.

Acquired melanocytic nevus (Option C), also commonly called moles, is a benign, small, symmetrical, and well-defined lesions that develop during childhood or adolescence. They grow slowly and do not typically cause rapid changes or itching. This is in contrast to the features described in the patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a lesion over his left ear. It slowly grew in size over the past 3 months, and he is a chronic smoker with 20 pack years. Vitals are within normal limits, and his physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. The histopathologic evaluation shows keratin pearls. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Squamous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis for the lesion over the left ear in the 40-year-old chronic smoker with histopathologic evaluation showing keratin pearls is Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

Squamous cell carcinoma

Definition

It is a type of skin cancer that arises from the squamous cells, which are the flat cells found in the epidermis, mucous membranes & tissues lining your organs. It is the second most common type of skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma.

Risk factors
  • High sunlight exposure
  • Arsenic exposure.
  • Immunosuppression (organ transplant, HIV)
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Human papilloma virus.

Presentation

It commonly presents as papules, nodules, or plaques with induration and signs of photodamage like crusting and scaling.

Diagnosis

It involves physical examination and biopsy

Histopathology

Reveals characteristic keratin pearls.

Treatment
  • Primary treatment involves wide surgical excision with margins.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) aids in intraoperative histopathological examination.
  • Advanced cases may require radiation or chemotherapy.

Nodular melanoma (Option A) is a type of melanoma that is a malignant skin cancer originating from melanocytes. It typically appears as a darkly pigmented, elevated nodule with irregular borders. It often has a different histopathological appearance, with atypical melanocytes rather than keratinisation.

Basal cell carcinoma (Option B) is the most common type of skin cancer, which commonly presents with non-healing ulcers, pearly or translucent papules or nodules with rolled borders, often associated with telangiectasias. Histologically, BCC arises from basal cells of the epidermis.

 Malignant melanoma (Option D) is a malignant tumour arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. It presents as a pigmented lesion that enlarges, ulcerates, or bleeds. They generally have abnormal melanocytes and lack keratinisation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ranula is FALSE?

choices.text: Bluish, translucent cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth
Marsupialization or excision is the treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arises from submandibular salivary gland

Explanation:

  • A ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst, which most commonly arises from the sublingual salivary gland, not the submandibular salivary gland.

Ranula

Definition

(Options A & C ruled out)
  • Ranulas are a type of extravasation mucocele, caused by the rupture of the main duct or obstructed acini of the sublingual gland.
  • They appear as bluish, translucent, cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth and resemble the belly of a frog.

Location
  • Commonly found in the anterior floor of the mouth.
  • When it extends through the mylohyoid muscle, it presents as a submental swelling known as a "plunging ranula."

Symptoms

Typically soft, fluctuant, and painless unless infected.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed through Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
  • Ultrasound
  • Aspiration of thick, sticky saliva differentiates it from a lymphangioma.

Treatment

(Option D ruled out)
  • Excision of the sublingual gland is preferred.
  • Incision, drainage, and marsupialisation have low success rates. Although marsupialisation is often adequate, it has a higher recurrence rate compared to sublingual gland excision.
  • OK-432 injection
  • Botulinum toxin injections

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who is taking steroids for psoriasis and is experiencing a low-grade fever only at night, weight loss, and an ulcer on her neck with undermined edges, as depicted in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tubercular lymphadenitis

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms of night sweats, weight loss, and the ulcer with undermined edges indicate Tubercular lymphadenitis.
  • It is a common manifestation of tuberculosis, especially in immunosuppressed patients, such as those taking steroids.
  • Steroids can weaken the immune system, increasing susceptibility to infections like tuberculosis.

Lymph Node TB (Tuberculous Lymphadenitis)

Most common extrapulmonary TB presentation.

Risk Groups

HIV-positive individuals, Immunosuppressive individuals, children, and non-Caucasian women.

Causative Organism

Previously M. bovis; now mainly M. tuberculosis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless swelling in lymph nodes, usually posterior cervical or supraclavicular (historically called scrofula).
  • Early disease: Discrete nodes
  • Advanced disease: Matted, nontender mass, possible fistula draining caseous material.
  • Pulmonary disease in <50% of cases.
  • Systemic symptoms are uncommon except in HIV-positive patients.
  • Non-specific reaction → Matting → Cold Abscess → Collar stud abscess → Sinus formation

Diagnosis
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (80% yield) or surgical excision biopsy.
  • Granulomatous lesions may or may not contain AFBs.
  • Cultures are positive in 70–80% of cases.
  • HIV-positive patients: Poorly organised or absent granulomas; higher bacterial loads increase diagnostic yield.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Infectious diseases
  • Lymphomas
  • Metastatic carcinomas
  • Rare disorders: Kikuchi’s disease, Kimura’s disease, Castleman’s disease.

Psoriasis flare-up (Option A) presents red, scaly patches on the skin and is unlikely to cause the ulcer and systemic symptoms described.

Lymphosarcoma (Option C) can present with lymphadenopathy, but it doesn’t typically cause the characteristic ulcer with undermined edges seen in tubercular lymphadenitis.

Syphilis (Option D) can cause ulcers (chancre), but it doesn't typically present with the described systemic symptoms like night fever and weight loss in this context.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for the unconscious patient brought to the casualty department following a road accident, as depicted in the provided CT scan image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subdural hematoma (SDH)

Explanation:

  • A crescent-shaped or concave collection of blood on a CT scan is characteristic of a subdural hematoma, which often results from trauma, such as a road accident.
  • This type of hematoma occurs between the dura mater and the brain, commonly due to the tearing of bridging veins.
  • Symptoms include
    • Rapid deterioration
    • Loss of consciousness
    • Focal deficits
    • High mortality
  • It can be managed conservatively or it might need surgery based on the type and size of the SDH.

Types of brain haemorrhage

Type

CT Findings

Mechanism

Epidural or Extradural Hematoma

(Option A ruled out)
  • Biconvex/lentiform shape
  • Does not cross suture lines
  • Cross-dural venous sinuses
  • Hyperdense
  • Usually unilateral

 
  • Typically, meningeal artery injury (especially middle meningeal)
  • High-velocity trauma
  • Young patient
  • Always traumatic

Subdural Hematoma
  • Crescent-shaped
  • Crosses suture lines
  • Can be bilateral
  • Don't cross dural venous sinuses
  • Follows brain surface
  • Bridging vein tears
  • Can be Traumatic or non-traumatic
  • Elderly patients
  • Extent of brain injury more in SDH than in EDH

Intraparenchymal Hematoma

(Option C ruled out)
  • Irregular shape within brain tissue
  • May have surrounding oedema

Direct tissue damage or coagulopathy

Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

(Option D ruled out)
  • Blood in sulci/cisterns
  • Follows CSF spaces

Trauma or aneurysm rupture

questions.text: A patient with inflammatory bowel disease presents with the following lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pyoderma gangrenosum

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Pyoderma gangrenosum which is more common in Ulcerative colitis a type of inflammatory bowel disease.

  • Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare, inflammatory skin condition characterized by the development of painful, ulcerative lesions.
  • It can occur in patients with inflammatory bowel disease, and the lower limbs are a common site of involvement.
  • The ulcers typically have undermined borders and may have a necrotic or purulent appearance.

Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD:

  • Erythema nodosum (A skin condition characterized by painful red nodules typically found on the shins). (Option A)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis (Arthritis of the spine)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Uveitis (Inflammation of the uvea)
  • Osteoporosis and Osteonecrosis are overall the most common extra-intestinal manifestations of IBD.
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum is common in Ulcerative colitis.
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis is common in Ulcerative colitis.
  • Renal calculi is common in Crohn’s disease.

Diabetic ulcer (Option C) is not associated with inflammatory bowel disease. It is a complication of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.

Venous ulcer (Option D) is usually caused by conditions like long-standing varicose veins. It is usually situated around the ankles.

questions.text: A patient who is a tour guide of Mount Everest presented with blisters on her hand as shown in the figure below. She has severe pain and on examination is erythematous and tender. Which of the following is used in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Apply heat to the area and cast it as soon as possible

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) NSAID’s

Explanation:

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be used to relieve pain and reduce inflammation associated with blisters.

  • The recommended approach includes protecting the blister, keeping it clean, and using pain-relieving measures such as NSAIDs, if necessary.
  • Avoid Sun Exposure: Keep the affected area out of the sun to prevent further damage.
  • Skin Care: Apply cool compresses, aloe vera gel, or lotion to soothe the skin. Avoid local anaesthetic creams.
  • Blister Care: Wash ruptured blisters with soap and water and cover with moist gauze.

Options A and B are incorrect.

Pentoxyphylline (Option C) is a medication that can improve blood flow and is sometimes used in the treatment of vascular disorders. This is not indicated here.

questions.text:
For which type/s of cancer/s is prophylactic cranial radiation administered?


	Lung cancer
	Liver cancer
	Prostate cancer
	Breast cancer
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1 and 4

Explanation:

Lung and breast cancers have a high risk of metastasizing into the brain. Hence, prophylactic cranial radiation is administered in these cases.

  • Lung cancer:
    • Prophylactic cranial radiation is commonly used in patients with small cell lung cancer (SCLC) who are at high risk of developing brain metastases.
    • SCLC has a strong tendency to spread to the brain, and PCR is given to reduce the risk of metastatic disease in the brain.
  • Breast cancer:
    • Prophylactic cranial radiation may be considered in certain cases of breast cancer.
    • It is typically recommended for patients with breast cancer who have a high risk of developing brain metastases, such as those with aggressive subtypes like HER2-positive or triple-negative breast cancer.

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which is the false statement among the following for the condition given in the picture?

choices.text: Retention cyst of major salivary glands
Most common site is lower lip

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Retention cyst of major salivary glands

Explanation:

Based on the image, the lesion is most likely a mucocele, which commonly presents as a bluish, fluctuant swelling on the lower lip due to mucus accumulation from minor salivary glands.

  • Mucoceles are typically retention or extravasation cysts of the minor salivary glands, not major ones.

  • Hence the statement "Retention cyst of major salivary glands" is false

  • A retention cyst of the major salivary glands typically forms in the ductal system due to the blockage of the duct or ductal dilation.
  • The most common sites for retention cysts of the major salivary glands are the parotid gland and the submandibular gland, not the lower lip, which is a common site for minor salivary gland cysts.

Retention Cyst of Salivary Glands

Feature

Description

Cause

Blockage or damage to the duct system of the salivary gland leads to cyst formation.

Location

Major salivary glands (parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands) for major retention cysts.

Minor Salivary Glands

Most often found on the lower lip, buccal mucosa, or palate for minor salivary glands.

Treatment

Surgical excision is the standard treatment to remove the cyst and prevent recurrence.

Diagnosis

Clinical examination and ultrasound or sialography for confirmation.

Most common site is lower lip (Option B): This is true. The lower lip is the most frequent site for mucoceles

Is a benign condition: (Option C): This is true. Mucoceles are benign lesions.

Treatment is surgical excision (Option D): This is true. The standard treatment for mucoceles is surgical excision.

questions.text: Which laser is most commonly used for performing a laser iridotomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Nd:YAG laser

Explanation:

  • Laser Peripheral Iridotomy (LPI), used for treating angle-closure glaucoma, uses an argon or Nd: YAG laser.
  • It operates via a photodisruptive mechanism, which vaporizes the iris tissue to create a precise and clean opening without causing significant thermal damage to surrounding structures.
  • This procedure involves creating a small hole in the peripheral iris to re-establish communication between the anterior and posterior chambers, bypassing the pupillary block and relieving angle crowding in glaucoma.

Argon laser (Option A): The Argon laser is used for laser iridotomy but is typically employed to pre-treat the iris by thinning the tissue before creating an opening. It uses a photocoagulative mechanism, which involves thermal energy. However, it is less effective than the Nd:YAG laser for standalone iridotomy due to higher chances of tissue damage and incomplete penetration.

Excimer laser (Option C): Excimer lasers are not used for iridotomy. These lasers emit ultraviolet light and are designed for corneal refractive procedures like LASIK and PRK. They ablate corneal tissue rather than creating openings in the iris.

CO₂ laser (Option D): CO₂ lasers are suitable in ophthalmology to vaporize lymphangiomas and capillary hemangiomas and to provide hemostasis in patients with bleeding disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pterygium?

choices.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

Explanation:

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

 

 

 

 

 

 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process

 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons

 

 

 

 

 

Pathology

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

 

 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane

 

 

 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 

Management of pterygium:

 

 

 

Management

  • Best left alone

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia

 

 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique:
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or
    • An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

 

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.text: In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the point of opening of the lacrimal sac is into which nasal meatus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Middle meatus

Explanation:

  • During DCR, the lacrimal sac is opened into the middle meatus by creating an osteotomy in the lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla. This provides a direct pathway for tear drainage, bypassing the nasolacrimal duct.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the definitive surgical procedure designed to create a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, thus resolving the obstruction and restoring proper tear drainage. This approach addresses the underlying blockage and prevents recurrence.

Types of DCR

  • External Dacryocystorhinostomy (External DCR) procedure is performed through an incision near the inner corner of the eye, providing direct access to the lacrimal sac and nasal mucosa. It is widely regarded as the gold standard due to its high success rate, which exceeds 90%. However, it leaves a visible scar and may result in greater blood loss compared to other methods.

External DCR

Endonasal Dacryocystorhinostomy (Endonasal DCR) involves using an endoscope inserted through the nasal cavity to create a drainage opening, thus avoiding any external incision. While it has the advantage of being scarless and typically involves less bleeding, its success rate is slightly lower, ranging between 70-90%.

Endocanalicular Laser Dacryocystorhinostomy (Laser DCR): This method utilizes a laser passed through the tear duct to create a drainage opening. It is minimally invasive and can be performed quickly under local anaesthesia. However, its success rate is lower than external or endonasal DCR, around 70%, and patients often require additional surgery if the initial procedure fails.

Conjunctivodacryocystorhinostomy (CDCR): CDCR is specifically used when both the canaliculi and the nasolacrimal duct are blocked. It is a more specialized procedure compared to standard DCR and is not typically the first choice for isolated nasolacrimal duct obstruction.

  • CDCR involves creating a passage directly from the conjunctival sac to the nasal cavity, often using a Jones tube and is reserved for more complex cases where the canaliculi are also involved.

Inferior meatus (Option A): The inferior meatus is the natural site where the nasolacrimal duct drains under normal conditions. However, in DCR surgery, a direct connection is created between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus, bypassing the nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: What is the average degree of hypermetropia in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - +2.5 D

Explanation:

  • Newborns are physiologically hypermetropic, with an average refractive error of approximately +2.5 to 3 diopters.
  • This occurs because the axial length of the eye is shorter at birth, and the eye grows over time, reducing hypermetropia.
  • Hypermetropia, or long-sightedness, is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light from distant objects focus behind the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed.

Type of Hypermetropia

Cause

Axial Hypermetropia

Shortening of the eyeball's axial length. Commonest form.

Curvatural Hypermetropia

Flatter curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Index Hypermetropia

Decreased refractive index of the lens, usually due to cortical sclerosis in old age or in treated diabetics.

Positional Hypermetropia

Posterior displacement of the crystalline lens.

Aphakia

Absence of the crystalline lens, either congenital or acquired (e.g., after surgery), leads to high hypermetropia.

Consecutive Hypermetropia

Overcorrected myopia after refractive surgery (e.g., LASIK, ICL) or underpowered intraocular lens (IOL) after cataract surgery.

Features:

  • Small eyeball in high hypermetropia
  • Smaller cornea
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Fundus Examination:
    • Optic disc - Small , ill-defined margins, possibly simulating papillitis (pseudopapillitis).
    • Retina - Shot silk appearance (shining retina).

+1 D (Option D): +1 D is below the average hypermetropia seen in newborns. This degree of refractive error is more commonly observed in older children or adults after emmetropization has occurred.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the corneal endothelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Neural crest cells

Explanation:

  • The corneal endothelium originates from neural crest cells, which migrate during embryogenesis to form the inner layer of the cornea.
  • Neural crest cells also contribute to other anterior segment structures, including the stroma and trabecular meshwork.

Corneal Development and Cellular Origins

  • Corneal development involves ectodermal-derived tissues.
  • Neural ectoderm-derived optic vesicles interact with cranial ectoderm → form presumptive corneal epithelium and ocular surface epithelia. (Option A ruled out)
  • Neural tube-ectoderm interactions generate neural crest cells, which are migratory and multipotent.
  • Neural crest cells migrate between the lens and corneal epithelium → form corneal endothelium and stromal keratocytes.
  • Trigeminal ganglion (from neural crest and ectodermal placodes) supplies sensory innervation to the corneal stroma and epithelium.

Mesoderm (Option C): The mesoderm is responsible for forming structures like muscles, blood vessels, and connective tissue in the body. It does not contribute to the corneal endothelium.

Surface ectoderm (Option D): The surface ectoderm forms the corneal epithelium, the outermost layer of the cornea, but not the corneal endothelium.
